Description: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT ECOLOGICALLY SOUND, SCIENCE-BASED FISHERIES CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CREATION AND SUPPORT A CT AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) POSITION AT THE UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT THROUGH A SUBAWARD AND TO CONTINUE FUNDING ONGOING AQUATIC PLANT SURVEY WORK AND HERBICIDE APPLICATIONS (WHOLE-LAKE FLURIDONE TREATMENTS) IN COLLABORATION WITH THE TOWN OF COVENTRY WITH THE GOAL OF ERADICATING HYDRILLA FROM COVENTRY LAKE. EXPECTED OUTCOME INCLUDES PREVENTING THE SPREAD OF AIS, WHICH SUPPORTS THE BUREAU OF NATURAL RESOURCES  MISSION OF CONSERVATION. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE THESE NATURAL RESOURCES IN COLLABORATION WITH THE TOWN OF COVENTRY TO CONTINUE EFFORTS TO ERADICATE HYDRILLA FROM COVENTRY LAKE.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO IMPLEMENT A COORDINATED APPROACH TO MINIMIZING THE ECONOMIC, ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIAL IMPACTS OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) ON THE MARINE AND FRESHWATER ECOSYSTEMS AND RESOURCES OF RHODE ISLAND. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE: PUBLIC OUTREACH AND EDUCATION, MONITORING, REMOVING AND SURVEYING FOR AIS IN MARINE AND FRESHWATER SYSTEMS, AND RECOMMENDING ACTIONS TO RESTORE CONDITIONS AND CONTROL FUTURE AIS GROWTH. EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE TO REDUCE THE RISK OF SPREADING AIS, HAVE AN INFORMED PUBLIC, AND CREATE A HEALTHIER ECOSYSTEM. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE ALL USERS OF INLAND AND MARINE WATERS IN RHODE ISLAND, AS WELL AS THE STATE S NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

ACROSS THE GREAT LAKES, MUSKELLUNGE WERE EXTIRPATED FROM MANY AREAS, INCLUDING GREEN BAY, DUE TO ENVIRONMENTAL DEGRADATION (E.G., SILTATION, WETLAND LOSS, POLLUTION) THAT REDUCED OR ELIMINATED SUCCESSFUL NATURAL REPRODUCTION. SPECIFICALLY, FISHERIES RESTORATION EFFORTS FOCUSED ON LOWER GREEN BAY INCLUDE THE RE-ESTABLISHMENT OF A SELF-SUSTAINING MUSKELLUNGE POPULATION AS A GOAL.  HABITAT RESTORATION IN THE SOUTHERN GREEN BAY HAS SPECIFICALLY TARGETED MUSKELLUNGE IN LOCATIONS SUCH AS THE CAT ISLAND CHAIN AND THE DUCK CREEK ESTUARY. STOCKING EFFORTS HAVE ESTABLISHED A WORLD-RENOWNED FISHERY FOR MUSKELLUNGE WITHIN GREEN BAY, BUT THERE HAS BEEN LITTLE EVIDENCE OF SUCCESSFUL NATURAL REPRODUCTION AND THE POPULATION REMAINS RELIANT ON STOCKING TO SUSTAIN THE FISHERY. SPAWNING IN SOUTHERN GREEN BAY THAT OCCURS OUTSIDE OF TRIBUTARIES COULD REPRESENT A POTENTIAL SOURCE OF SUCCESSFUL NATURAL REPRODUCTION THAT HAS NOT BEEN THOROUGHLY ASSESSED. FURTHERMORE, LIMITED EVIDENCE SUGGESTS THAT AT LEAST SOME MUSKELLUNGE SPAWN IN THE STURGEON BAY AREA (E.G., LITTLE STURGEON BAY, SAWYER HARBOR) BUT IT IS UNKNOWN IF THESE FISH CONTRIBUTE TO THE POPULATION OF MUSKELLUNGE IN SOUTHERN GREEN BAY. DETERMINING IF SUCCESSFUL NATURAL REPRODUCTION OF MUSKELLUNGE IS OCCURRING OUTSIDE OF GREEN BAYS TRIBUTARIES HAS IMPORTANT IMPLICATIONS FOR MEETING ECOSYSTEM RECOVERY GOALS THROUGH STOCKING AND HABITAT RESTORATION. LIMITED EVIDENCE SUGGESTS STOCKED MUSKELLUNGE RETURN TO STOCKING LOCATIONS TO SPAWN. HENCE, STOCKING FISH IN LOCATIONS WHERE SUCCESSFUL HATCHING OCCURS MAY ENHANCE NATURAL RECRUITMENT AND HELP INFORM HABITAT RESTORATION, BUT THESE LOCATIONS MUST FIRST BE IDENTIFIED.OUR RESEARCH GOALS ARE TO DETERMINE IF SUCCESSFUL NATURAL REPRODUCTION IS OCCURRING AT POTENTIAL SPAWNING LOCATIONS IN SOUTHERN GREEN BAY IDENTIFIED VIA REMOTE TRACKING (TELEMETRY) OF ADULTS, AND SAMPLING SITES THAT WERE IDENTIFIED AS POTENTIAL SPAWNING SITES IN PREVIOUS RESEARCH. ADDITIONALLY, WE SEEK TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE POTENTIAL CONTRIBUTION OF ADULT MUSKELLUNGE SPAWNING IN THE STURGEON BAY AREA TO THE POPULATION OF FISH IN SOUTHERN GREEN BAY AND TO DETERMINE IF SUCCESSFUL NATURAL REPRODUCTION IS OCCURRING WITHIN THE STURGEON BAY AREA.  SPAWNING HABITAT IDENTIFIED BY PREVIOUS RESEARCH IN LOWER GREEN BAY WILL BE SAMPLED TO DETERMINE IF EGG DEPOSITION AND LARVAL MUSKELLUNGE ARE PRESENT. IN STURGEON BAY, ADULT MUSKELLUNGE WILL BE IMPLANTED WITH ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY TAGS TO TRACK THEIR MOVEMENTS THROUGHOUT THE COURSE OF THE STUDY UTILIZING THE TELEMETRY GRID IN GREEN BAY. SPAWNING HABITAT AND LARVAL FISH SURVEYS WILL ALSO BE CONDUCTED IN STURGEON BAY. TOBJECTIVES: TO DETERMINE IF: 1) SUCCESSFUL HATCHING IS OCCURRING AT OPEN-WATER LOCATIONS IN GREEN BAY, INCLUDING LOCATIONS IN THE STURGEON BAY AREA  2) PRESENCE OF EGGS OR LARVAL MUSKELLUNGE AT A LOCATION IS RELATED TO A SUITE OF HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS INCLUDING DISTANCE TO SHORE, BOTTOM SLOPE, DEPTH, DISSOLVED OXYGEN, SUBSTRATE TYPE, AND AQUATIC VEGETATION, AND 3) MUSKELLUNGE SPAWNING IN THE STURGEON BAY AREA CONTRIBUTE TO THE OVERALL POPULATION IN SOUTHERN GREEN BAY.DELIVERABLES: 1) SUPPORT ONE GRADUATE STUDENT AND PRODUCE AT LEAST ONE SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATION IN A PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL  2) PRESENTATIONS AT THE WISCONSIN STATE CHAPTER MEETING OF THE AMERICAN FISHERIES SOCIETY HIGHLIGHTING THE BEGINNING OF THE PROPOSAL   3) PRESENTATIONS AT LOCAL CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS SUCH AS MUSKIES, INC. TO RAISE AWARENESS WITH THE GENERAL PUBLIC ABOUT THE PROJECT  AND 4) THE GRADUATE STUDENT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR COMPLETING THE PROPOSAL AND COMPLETING THEIR GRADUATE THESIS AND THESIS DEFENSE, INCLUDING A PUBLIC SEMINAR.

THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (MDNR) AND SAGINAW COUNTY HAVE A UNIQUE RESTORATION OPPORTUNITY IN SAGINAW COUNTY AT THE CONFLUENCE OF THE TITTABAWASSEE AND SHIAWASSEE RIVERS, WHERE OVER 600 MILES OF STREAMS AND RIVERS FROM ACROSS MICHIGAN JOIN TO FORM THE SAGINAW RIVER, 22 MILES FROM LAKE HURONS SAGINAW BAY. THIS CRITICAL PIECE OF THE WATERSHED FEATURES 334 ACRES, WITH OVER 100 ACRES OF WETLANDS, AND WAS PREVIOUSLY IMPACTED BY NEARLY 200 YEARS OF INDUSTRIALIZATION, MOST RECENTLY HOUSING THE SAGINAW MALLEABLE IRON FACTORY UNTIL ITS DECOMMISSIONING IN 2007. SUBSTANTIAL REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES HAVE TAKEN PLACE IN THE LAST TEN YEARS TO BRING THE PROPERTY INTO SITE-SPECIFIC PASSIVE RECREATIONAL CRITERIA ESTABLISHED BY THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT, GREAT LAKES, AND ENERGY. THE SITE SITS IN THE HEART OF THE SAGINAW BASIN WHICH IS A MAJOR STOP-OVER SITE FOR MIGRATING BIRDS, A REFUGE FOR MANY SPECIES OF WILDLIFE, AND PART OF A PREMIER WATERSHED FOR FISH, INCLUDING A WORLD CLASS WALLEYE FISHERY. FURTHER, THE SITE IS IDEALLY JUXTAPOSED TO LONG-UNDERSERVED URBAN COMMUNITIES THAT WOULD IMMENSELY BENEFIT FROM EASILY ACCESSIBLE GREEN AND BLUE SPACE, INCLUDING RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES SUCH AS FISHING, BIKING, AND WILDLIFE VIEWING.DUE TO A LONG HISTORY OF SHIFTING ANTHROPOGENIC USE, THE NATURAL TERRAIN HAS BEEN ALTERED, AND THE VAST MAJORITY OF NATIVE HABITAT HAS BEEN DEGRADED OR LOST, INCLUDING HIGHLY REDUCED CAPACITY FOR FLOOD CONTROL. FROM A FAUNAL PERSPECTIVE, THE GOAL IS TO RESTORE ESSENTIAL HABITAT REFUGIA AND CONNECTIVITY FOR A WIDE BREADTH OF ARBOREAL, TERRESTRIAL, AND AQUATIC TAXA, INCLUDING STATE AND OR FEDERAL THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES. THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON CONTINUING SIGNIFICANT AND INTENTIONAL HABITAT RESTORATION OF THE SITE, INCLUDING INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL (E.G., PHRAGMITES AND BUCKTHORN) AND ESTABLISHING NATIVE HABITAT TO BENEFIT FISH AND WILDLIFE, INCLUDING MONARCH BUTTERFLIES, HUNDREDS OF SPECIES OF MIGRATORY BIRDS, AND REPTILES AND AMPHIBIANS. ADDITIONAL AND CONTINUING MANAGEMENT AND FUNDING SUPPORT FROM SAGINAW COUNTY ADDS A SIGNIFICANT LEVEL OF SUSTAINABILITY TO THE PROJECT THROUGH CONTINUED MONITORING AND MAINTENANCE OF THE GREAT LAKES FISH AND WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACT (GLFWRA) FUNDED PROJECT. ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A RANGE OF DIRECT AND INDIRECT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THAT MUTUALLY BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT, ANIMALS, AND PUBLIC  FITTING WITHIN MDNRS ACCELERATED EFFORTS TOWARDS CLIMATE RESILIENCE AND A NATIONAL EFFORT TOWARDS ONE HEALTH FOR WILDLIFE CONSERVATION.OBJECTIVE: INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL AND HABITAT RESTORATION OF 40 ACRES OF UPLAND HABITAT AND AN ADDITIONAL 100 ACRES OF WETLAND HABITAT, BUILDING ON INITIAL RESTORATION AND RECLAMATION INVESTMENTS THAT WERE FUNDED THROUGH NATURAL RESOURCE DAMAGE ASSESSMENT FUNDS.DELIVERABLES: APPROXIMATELY 40 ACRES OF DEGRADED UPLAND HABITAT RESTORATION AND 100 ACRES OF WETLAND INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL WITH AN EMERGENT WETLAND RESTORATION FOCUS ARE EXPECTED TO BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH THIS PROJECT. PERFORMANCE PROGRESS REPORTS WILL BE COMPLETED FOLLOWING THE SCHEDULE SPECIFIED BY GREAT LAKES FISH AND WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACT. REPORTS WILL INCLUDE PHOTOGRAPHS OF PROJECT AREAS TO ILLUSTRATE PROGRESS AND RESULTS, ALONG WITH NOTES FROM THE FIELD TECHNICIANS PERFORMING THE WORK.

WE WILL MODEL PREDICTED IMPACTS TO UNITED STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) FOCAL AND OTHER SPECIES OF CONSERVATION NEED, AND HIGH-QUALITY NATURAL COMMUNITIES, DUE TO CHANGES IN GREAT LAKES WATER LEVELS UNDER A RANGE OF PREDICTED CLIMATE SCENARIOS. GREAT LAKES WATER LEVELS REACHED HISTORIC HIGHS TOWARD THE END OF THE LAST DECADE, FOLLOWING HISTORIC LOWS IN THE PREVIOUS DECADE. THESE FLUCTUATIONS LEAD TO CHANGES TO COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS AND LIKELY RESULT IN DEGRADATION OF NEAR-SHORE HABITATS FOR SOME SPECIES. MANY RARE PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES, INCLUDING 12 USFWS FOCAL SPECIES, DEPEND ON THESE HABITATS. THERE IS CONSIDERABLE UNCERTAINTY REGARDING HOW CLIMATE CHANGE WILL IMPACT GREAT LAKES WATER LEVELS LONG TERM, AND AS A RESULT, WHICH SPECIES MAY LOSE OR GAIN HABITAT. A PROACTIVE APPROACH IS NEEDED TO GUIDE CONSERVATION OF THIS SUITE OF SPECIES IN THE CONTEXT OF CLIMATE CHANGE. THIS PROJECT WILL ACHIEVE TWO COMPATIBLE OUTCOMES: 1) QUANTIFY THE ESTIMATED RISK AND CHANGES TO POTENTIAL HABITAT UNDER POTENTIAL CLIMATE SCENARIOS FOR A LARGE NUMBER OF NATURAL COMMUNITIES AND RARE SPECIES, AND 2) PROVIDE A BASIS FOR TARGETING SPECIES FOR CONSERVATION AND MONITORING THAT MAY BE MOST AT-RISK UNDER CLIMATE CHANGE. ACHIEVING THESE OUTCOMES WILL INFORM EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION DECISIONS, INCLUDING WHERE TO FOCUS EFFORTS ON LAND ACQUISITION, CREATING CORRIDORS FOR INLAND DISPERSAL, AND IDENTIFYING CRITICAL AREAS FOR HABITAT RESTORATION.OBJECTIVES: 1) MODEL THE IMPACT OF CHANGING GREAT LAKES WATER LEVELS ON HABITAT AVAILABILITY FOR AT-RISK PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES, ACROSS THE RANGE OF FLUCTUATIONS PREDICTED BASED ON CLIMATE MODELING  2) ASSESS HOW AT-RISK PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES MAY RESPOND TO CHANGES IN HABITAT AVAILABILITY DUE TO MODELED LAKE LEVEL CHANGE (I.E., DECLINE, INCREASE, OR DISPERSE)  AND 3) DEVELOP A LIST OF PRIORITY SPECIES, COMMUNITIES, AND SPECIFIC LOCATIONS ON THE LANDSCAPE SUPPORTING THEM, THAT ARE IN MOST NEED OF MONITORING, RESTORATION, AND CONSERVATION.DELIVERABLES: WE WILL PROVIDE A YEAR-ONE PROGRESS REPORT AND A FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT SUMMARIZING OUR RESULTS ANDRECOMMENDATIONS FOR CONSERVATION MEASURES AND ONGOING MONITORING. WE WILL DISSEMINATE THE INFORMATION BY SUBMITTING A MANUSCRIPT TO A PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL, PRESENTING AT SCIENTIFIC MEETINGS, AND PROVIDING THE FINAL REPORT TO USFWS. FINAL PRODUCTS WILL ALSO BE DISTRIBUTED TO MEMBERS OF THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI GREAT LAKES JOINT VENTURE SCIENCE TEAM AND STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCY PARTNERS INVOLVED WITH THE CONSERVATION OF AT-RISK SPECIES (E.G., MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES ENDANGERED SPECIES COORDINATOR, WILDLIFE ACTON PLAN COORDINATOR, USFWS BIOLOGISTS). WE WILL PROVIDE THE SPATIAL DATA, SHADED RELIEF HILLSHADE RASTERS, INUNDATION MODELS AND UNCERTAINTY DATA) AS VALUE-ADDED PRODUCTS USEFUL FOR PRELIMINARY PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT OR FUTURE WORK. WE WILL UTILIZE THE ESRI PLATFORM TO DEVELOP A STORYMAP THAT WILL BE SHARED WIDELY WITH THE PUBLIC AND CONSERVATION PARTNERS. WE VIEW THIS AS AN EASY-TO-USE INTERACTIVE FRAMEWORK TO EXAMINE AND INTERPRET MODEL OUTPUTS, MAKING THE INFORMATION READILY AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC TO RAISE AWARENESS TO THE EFFECTS OF COASTAL WATER LEVELS ON NATURAL COMMUNITIES AND AT-RISK SPECIES. BY MAKING INFORMATION AVAILABLE TO THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY, LAND MANAGERS, AND PUBLIC, WE ENVISION OUR OUTPUT PACKAGE TO HAVE AN IMMEDIATE IMPACT ON CONSERVATION LAND MANAGEMENT AND GENERATE INCREASED PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE OF GREAT LAKES ECOSYSTEMS, WHILE PROVIDING A BASELINE FOR FUTURE GREAT LAKES SHORELINE RESTORATION.

THE PROJECT AIMS TO SUPPORT ECOLOGICALLY SOUND, SCIENCE-BASED CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS REGARDING INVASIVE AQUATIC SPECIES. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE RESEARCH, FIELD SURVEYS, MAPPING, MONITORING, AND CONTROLLING PHRAGMITES, ALLIGATORWEED, AND TWO-HORNED TRAPA IN VIRGINIA. OTHER ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ORGANIZING AND FACILITATING THE INVASIVE SPECIES WORKING GROUP MEETINGS, OFFERING INVASIVE SPECIES WORKSHOPS FOR RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS AND COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS, AND CREATING AND MAINTAINING GIS TOOLS AND DATA. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE STAKEHOLDERS WHO ARE BETTER INFORMED AND EQUIPPED TO ADDRESS INVASIVE SPECIES AND STRENGTHEN NATURAL COMMUNITIES WITHIN BIOLOGICAL AND CULTURAL LIMITS, WHICH SUPPORTS THE DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION AND RECREATIONS MISSION. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE VIRGINIA RIVERS, STREAMS, AND WETLANDS. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE GREAT LAKES RESTORATION INITIATIVE AND MINNESOTAS LESSARD-SAMS OUTDOOR HERITAGE FUND HAVE MADE UNPRECEDENTED INVESTMENTS INTO RESTORATION OF HABITAT FOR GREAT LAKES FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS IN THE ST. LOUIS RIVER ESTUARY (SLRE) OVER THE PAST 12 YEARS. THE INITIAL REMEDIAL ACTION PLAN (RAP) FOR THE SLRE WAS BASED ON THE DISTRIBUTION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE FOLLOWING OVER A CENTURY OF SEVERELY IMPAIRED CONDITIONS. EVIDENCE INDICATES THAT THE ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES HAS CHANGED FOLLOWING GAINS IN WATER QUALITY, REMEDIATION OF CONTAMINATED SEDIMENT, AND HABITAT RESTORATION HOWEVER, STATE AND TRIBAL RESOURCE AGENCIES HAVE IDENTIFIED ADDITIONAL STRATEGIES AND PROJECTS NECESSARY FOR THE CONTINUED RECOVERY OF THE ESTUARYS FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS. BIRDS ARE OFTEN USED AS INDICATORS OF ECOLOGICAL CONDITION BECAUSE THEY PLAY IMPORTANT ROLES IN ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION AND SHOW PREDICTABLE AND QUANTIFIABLE RESPONSES TO ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE. THEREFORE, WE WILL USE HISTORICAL BIRD MONITORING DATA AND COLLECT CONTEMPORARY DATA AT WETLANDS WITHIN THE SLRE TO DIFFERENTIATE ESTUARY-WIDE SHIFTS IN BIRD COMMUNITY COMPOSITION RELATIVE TO SHIFTS ASSOCIATED WITH RESTORATION ACTIVITIES. THE GOAL OF OUR PROJECT IS TO DETERMINE HOW EFFORTS TO REMEDIATE AND RESTORE HEAVILY DEGRADED SITES IN THE SLRE HAVE IMPROVED CONDITIONS (I.E. BREEDING HABITAT) FOR WETLAND-DEPENDENT BIRDS AT BOTH THE SITE-LEVEL AND ESTUARY-WIDE. OBJECTIVES: 1) HAVE BIRD COMMUNITIES CHANGED SIGNIFICANTLY DURING THE LAST 50 YEARS IN THE SLRE AND 2) HAVE RECENT REMEDIATION AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES CREATED HIGHER QUALITY HABITAT RELATIVE TO PRE-RESTORATION CONDITIONS AS EVIDENCED BY CHANGES IN BIRD COMMUNITY COMPOSITION  IN ADDITION TO ASSESSING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE SLRE RAP FOR BIRD POPULATIONS, THIS STUDY WILL ALSO CONTRIBUTE KEY INFORMATION FOR UPCOMING RESTORATION SITE PRIORITIZATION AND PROJECT DESIGN. RESULTS WILL BE USED TO MAXIMIZE BENEFITS OF RESTORATION FOR BREEDING BIRDS AND AID IN CONSERVATION EFFORTS FOR FOCAL SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN.DELIVERABLES: RESULTS OF OUR RESEARCH WILL BE PRESENTED AT RELEVANT LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL CONFERENCES AND MEETINGS. WE WILL ALSO PUBLISH THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY IN AN APPROPRIATE PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL. AS REQUIRED, WE WILL PROVIDE ANNUAL REPORTS TO THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE DOCUMENTING OUR PROGRESS AS WELL AS A COMPREHENSIVE FINAL REPORT.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO IMPLEMENT A COORDINATED APPROACH TO MINIMIZE THE ECOLOGICAL AND SOCIO-ECONOMIC IMPACTS OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES IN THE MARINE AND FRESHWATER ENVIRONMENTS OF MASSACHUSETTS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE: PURCHASING SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT  ATTENDING SYMPOSIA, CONFERENCES AND LAKE MEETINGS  PROVIDING FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO GROUPS TO PREVENT, CONTROL AND ERADICATE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES  AND PRODUCE AND DISTRIBUTE PUBLIC INFORMATION OUTREACH DOCUMENTS AND SUPPLIES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE TO REDUCE THE RISK OF SPREADING AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES, PREVENT AND CONTROL AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES, HAVE AN INFORMED PUBLIC, AND CREATE A HEALTHIER ECOSYSTEM. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE ALL USERS OF INLAND AND MARINE WATERS IN MASSACHUSETTS, AS WELL AS THE STATE S NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES. SUB-RECIPIENTS INCLUDE VARIOUS PUBLIC GROUPS WHO WILL TO PREVENT, CONTROL AND ERADICATE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO CONDUCT NEW WORK THAT ACHIEVES ACTIONS WITHINMARYLANDS AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES PLAN. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE: 1) PURCHASING AND UTILIZE AN ELECTROFISHING BOAT TO HARVEST INVASIVE BLUE CATFISH  2) IDENTIFING LOCATIONS ON MARSHYHOPE CREEK (NANTICOKERIVER) WHERE BLUE CATFISH IS ABUNDANT USING A COMBINATION OF EDNA MONITORING ANDELECTROFISHING  3) HARVESTING LARGE (  700 MM) BLUE CATFISH FROM THOSE AREAS MONTHLY TODETERMINE IF HARVEST SHIFTS LENGTH-FREQUENCY DISTRIBUTIONS  AND 4) RESEARCHING LITERATURE ANDPERFORMING WORK TO ESTABLISH FOOD WEB RELATIONSHIPS ASSOCIATED WITH BLUE CATFISH AND DETERMINETHROUGH FOOD WEB ANALYSIS THE IMPACTS OF INVASIVE BLUE CATFISH ON IMPORTANT RECREATIONAL ANDCOMMERCIAL FISHERIES OF MARSHYHOPE CREEK (NANTICOKE RIVER). THE EXPECTED OUTCOME FROM THISPROJECT IS DOCUMENTING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF BOAT ELECTROFISHING FOR INFLUENCING BLUE CATFISH SIZESTRUCTURE AND DENSITY  AND 2) DOCUMENTING FOOD WEB RELATIONSHIPS AND MODELING POSSIBLE IMPACTSTO NATURAL RESOURCES AS RELATED TO POTENTIAL INCREASES OR DECREASES IN BIOMASS OF BLUE CATFISH.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE GENERAL PUBLIC AND THE STATE THAT SEEKS TO PREVENT ESTABLISHMENT OFAQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES IN NEW WATERS. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) HIRING A GRADUATESTUDENT TO LEAD THE PROJECT  2) ASSISTING WITH FIELD COLLECTIONS OF BLUE CATFISH  3) CONDUCTING WORKTO ELUCIDATE FOOD WEB RELATIONSHIPS  4) MODELING AND OR EXAMINING HOW CHANGES IN BIOMASS OFBLUE CATFISH COULD AFFECT THE FOOD WEB  AND 5) GENERATING A REPORT (I.E., MASTERS OF SCIENCETHESIS) THAT DOCUMENTS ACTIVITIES (3) AND (4).

SUCCESSFUL MANAGEMENT OF THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES LIKE KIRTLANDS WARBLERS REQUIRES UNDERSTANDING THEIR POPULATION DYNAMICS AND DETERMINING THE FACTORS THAT LIMIT POPULATION GROWTH. MANAGEMENT OF MIGRATORY SPECIES IS SIGNIFICANTLY HINDERED BY THEIR COMPLICATED ANNUAL CYCLES, WHICH INVOLVE TWICE-ANNUAL MIGRATIONS BETWEEN WINTERING AND BREEDING AREAS. DESPITE THEIR RECENT RECOVERY, KIRTLANDS WARBLERS FACE SIGNIFICANT THREATS TO THEIR POPULATION FROM ONGOING HABITAT-CREATION SHORTFALLS, CLIMATE CHANGE ON THE WINTERING AND BREEDING GROUNDS, AND LIMITED FUNDING FOR MANAGEMENT POST-DELISTING. FULL-ANNUAL-CYCLE INTEGRATED POPULATION MODELS ARE A RECENTLY DEVELOPED TOOL THAT CAN ASSIST RESEARCHERS IN UNDERSTANDING AND PREDICTING POPULATION DYNAMICS FOR MIGRATORY SPECIES THROUGHOUT THE ANNUAL CYCLE. ALTHOUGH A WEALTH OF DEMOGRAPHIC INFORMATION NECESSARY TO INFORM SUCH MODELS IS AVAILABLE FOR KIRTLANDS WARBLERS, SEVERAL KEY PIECES OF INFORMATION ARE CURRENTLY UNAVAILABLE, INCLUDING PAIRING RATE, RATE OF POLYGYNY, AND SEX RATIO. ADDITIONALLY, MANAGERS CANNOT ESTIMATE THE NUMBER OF BREEDING PAIRS IN THE POPULATION WITHOUT MAKING THE UNTENABLE ASSUMPTION THAT ALL SINGING MALES PAIR AND BREED. FILLING THESE INFORMATION GAPS AND DETERMINING WHERE AND WHEN IN THE ANNUAL CYCLE KIRTLANDS WARBLER POPULATIONS ARE MOST LIMITED IS A CRITICAL NEXT STEP TOWARDS ENSURING THEIR LONG-TERM VIABILITY.  WE PROPOSE TO FILL IN THESE KNOWLEDGE GAPS BY: 1) DOCUMENTING VARIATION IN BREEDING STATUS IN RELATION TO STAND-LEVEL HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS, 2) DETERMINING SEX RATIO AT BIRTH, AND 3) COMPARING THE DETECTABILITY OF MATED AND UNMATED MALES DURING THE CENSUS. WE WILL THEN INTEGRATE OUR ESTIMATES OF HABITAT-SPECIFIC BREEDING STATUS WITH NEW DATA ON MALE DETECTABILITY AND SINGING MALE CENSUS DATA TO ESTIMATE THE NUMBER OF BREEDING PAIRS. THIS WILL ALLOW MANAGERS TO PRODUCE MORE ACCURATE ESTIMATES OF THE SIZE OF THE BREEDING POPULATION, WHICH WILL HELP THEM INFORM FUTURE LISTING AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. WE WILL THEN UPDATE OUR FULL-ANNUAL-CYCLE INTEGRATED POPULATION MODEL WITH THIS NEW INFORMATION ABOUT HABITAT-SPECIFIC BREEDING STATUS, SEX RATIO, AND BREEDING POPULATION SIZE. USING THIS MODEL, WE WILL BE ABLE TO ESTIMATE HOW SENSITIVE KIRTLANDS WARBLER POPULATION DYNAMICS AND EXTINCTION RISK ARE TO VARIATION IN SURVIVAL IN DIFFERENT PERIODS OF THE ANNUAL CYCLE AND REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS. SUCH INFORMATION WILL ALLOW MANAGERS TO DETERMINE IF INTERVENTIONS BEYOND PLANNED HABITAT CREATION ARE NEEDED TO KEEP THE POPULATION ABOVE THE LISTING THRESHOLD OF 1000 BREEDING PAIRS. MOREOVER, IT WILL ALLOW MANAGERS TO EVALUATE HOW AND WHERE MANAGEMENT FUNDS COULD BE MOST EFFICIENTLY AND EFFECTIVELY DIRECTED TO SUSTAIN THE SPECIES FOR GENERATIONS TO COME.OBJECTIVES: I: INFER WHETHER MATED AND UNMATED MALES ARE EQUALLY LIKELY TO BE DETECTED BY THE CENSUS BASED ON THEIR SINGING RATE AND HOME RANGE SIZE  II: INCREASE THE ACCURACY OF KIRTLANDS WARBLER BREEDING POPULATION ESTIMATION BY INTEGRATING SPATIALLY-EXPLICIT ESTIMATES OF BREEDING STATUS INTO THE CENSUS, AND THEN MODELING BREEDING AND NON-BREEDING POPULATION SIZE. BY PROVIDING CRITICAL DATA ON HABITAT-SPECIFIC PAIRING AND POLYGYNY RATE, INCREASING THE ACCURACY OF ESTIMATES OF THE NUMBER OF BREEDING PAIRS, AND DETERMINING SEX RATIO AT BIRTH, MEETING OBJECTIVES I AND II AND TESTING HYPOTHESIS IV WILL ALLOW US TO ACHIEVE THE FINAL OBJECTIVE  AND III: UPDATE AND IMPLEMENT A FULL-ANNUAL-CYCLE INTEGRATED POPULATION MODEL TO DETERMINE THE SENSITIVITY OF KIRTLANDS WARBLER POPULATION DYNAMICS AND EXTINCTION RATE TO VARIATION IN SEASONAL (I.E., BREEDING, POST-BREEDING, MIGRATION, WINTERING) SURVIVAL RATES, REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS, AND PAIRING RATE.DELIVERABLES: WRITE SEVERAL PEER-REVIEWED PAPERS, DEVELOP POPULATION MODELS, AND RESULTS WILL BE SHARED WITH MANAGEMENT AGENCIES, THE KIRTLANDS WARBLER CONSERVATION TEAM, AT SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES, AND THE PUBLIC.

OVERFISHING, HABITAT DEGRADATION, AND OTHER FACTORS HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THE LISTING OF MULTIPLE NORTH AMERICAN STURGEON SPECIES AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED. LIKEWISE, LAKE STURGEON (LST), THE ONLY GREAT LAKES (GL) INDIGENOUS STURGEON SPECIES, IS CURRENTLY BEING CONSIDERED FOR LISTING UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. DESPITE SUBSTANTIAL RESOURCES BEING DEVOTED TOWARD THE RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION OF THIS ICONIC SPECIES, LITTLE WAS KNOWN ABOUT THEIR INFECTIOUS DISEASES AND WHAT ROLE THEY MAY BE PLAYING IN POPULATION DECLINES. HOWEVER, BETWEEN A RECENTLY COMPLETED GREAT LAKES FISH AND WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACT FUNDED STUDY AND OTHER EFFORTS, WE CHARACTERIZED TWO NEVER-BEFORE DESCRIBED LAKE STURGEON HERPESVIRUSES (LSHV) IN WILD ADULT LST INHABITING MULTIPLE GREAT LAKES WATERSHEDS AND MARKING THE FIRST TIME A VIRUS HAS BEEN ISOLATED FROM GL-LST. BOTH VIRUSES WERE LINKED TO SKIN DAMAGE IN INFECTED ADULTS ( 15  PREVALENCE AT SOME SAMPLING SITES). CONCERNINGLY, LAB EXPERIMENTS REVEALED JUVENILE LST IMMERSED IN WATER CONTAINING THE LSHV-2 BECAME DISEASED AND SUFFERED CUMULATIVE MORTALITY EXCEEDING 33  (COMPARED TO 0  IN MOCK-EXPOSED AND IDENTICALLY HANDLED FISH  JOHNSTON ET AL. 2022). FURTHER, THE VIRUS WAS RE-ISOLATED FROM THE DISEASED LST, PROVING THAT LSHV-2 IS CAPABLE OF INDUCING DISEASE AND DEATH IN EXPERIMENTALLY EXPOSED JUVENILE LST. IN LIGHT OF THESE VERY RECENTLY PUBLISHED AND COMMUNICATED FINDINGS, FEDERAL, STATE AND TRIBAL FISHERIES MANAGEMENT AGENCIES (E.G., UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, MICHIGAN AND WISCONSIN DEPARTMENTS OF NATURAL RESOURCES, LITTLE TRAVERSE BAY BAND OF ODAWA INDIANS, FOND DU LAC BAND OF LAKE SUPERIOR CHIPPEWA) HAVE COMMUNICATED SUBSTANTIAL CONCERNS ABOUT THE RISKS THESE NEWLY DISCOVERED HERPESVIRUSES POSE TO PREVIOUS AND ONGOING GL-LST DECLINES AND RESTORATION EFFORTS. GIVEN THE IMMUNOSUPPRESSIVE AND OFTEN LIFELONG INFECTIONS THAT HERPESVIRUSES CAUSE IN OTHER ANIMAL SPECIES, AS WELL AS THE RISK FOR TRANSMISSION FROM INFECTED PARENTS TO OFFSPRING, HOW CAN FISHERIES MANAGERS MOST EFFECTIVELY PREVENT LSHV TRANSMISSION DURING ARTIFICIAL SPAWNING AND HATCHERY-REARING  HOW CAN FISH HEALTH PROFESSIONALS MORE RAPIDLY AND ACCURATELY DETECT AND DIAGNOSE LSHV INFECTIONS TO GUIDE MANAGEMENT INTERVENTIONS MORE EFFECTIVELY  AND HOW WIDESPREAD AND PREVALENT ARE LSHV INFECTIONS IN WILD AND HATCHERY-REARED GL-LST, ESPECIALLY GIVEN THAT STREAMSIDE REARING FACILITIES (SRFS) RAISING GL-LST ARE OFTEN POPULATED WITH GAMETES COLLECTED FROM WILD ADULTS  OBJECTIVES: 1) TO DEVELOP RAPID AND ACCURATE LABORATORY- AND FIELD-BASED DIAGNOSTIC ASSAYS TO DETECT LSHV INFECTIONS  2) TO ELUCIDATE THE PATHOGENESIS AND HOST TISSUE TARGETS OF LSHVS IN GL-LST  3) TO DETERMINE THE PREVALENCE AND RANGE OF LSHV INFECTIONS IN WILD   HATCHERY-REARED GL-LST  AND 4) TO DETERMINE IN VITRO ULTRAVIOLET (UV) ZAP DOSES THAT EFFICACIOUSLY INACTIVATE LSHVS. COMPLETION OF THE PROPOSED OBJECTIVES WILL ENHANCE GL-LST RESTORATION EFFORTS IN THE SHORT AND MEDIUM, AND, LONGER TERM, WILL PROVIDE A PLATFORM FROM WHICH FUTURE LSHV PREVENTION STRATEGIES (E.G., VACCINE DEVELOPMENT) CAN BE LAUNCHED. DELIVERABLES: 1) GREAT LAKES FISHERY MANAGERS AND FISH HEALTH PROFESSIONALS CLINICIANS WILL BE EQUIPPED WITH NEWLY DEVELOPED, SENSITIVE, RAPID, AND ACCURATE LAB AND FIELD (I.E., STREAMSIDE) -BASED DIAGNOSTIC ASSAYS FOR THE DETECTION AND DIAGNOSIS OF LSHVS  2)UV TREATMENT EFFICACY DATA THAT ARE CRITICAL FOR REDUCINGLSHV TRANSMISSION RISK IN THE HATCHERY ENVIRONMENT, WHICH IS OF DIRECT AND IMMEDIATE RELEVANCE TO LAKE STURGEONSTREAMSIDE REARING EFFORTS IN THE GREAT LAKES AND THAT IS COMPLETELY UNKNOWN FOR LSHVS  3) RESEARCH FINDINGS WILL BE PUBLISHED IN PEER-REVIEWED PROFESSIONAL JOURNALS SUCH AS THE JOURNAL OF AQUATIC ANIMAL HEALTH, NORTH AMERICAN JOURNAL OF FISHERY MANAGEMENT, AND TRANSACTIONS OF THE AMERICAN FISHERY SOCIETY, AND 4) PRESENT FINDINGS AT REGIONAL AND NATIONAL MEETINGS, AND TO PARTNERS IN THE GREAT LAKES BASIN.

THE CITY OF MANITOWOC IS TAKING A HOLISTIC APPROACH TO STABILIZE ERODING STREAM BANKS AND IMPROVE IN-STREAM AND RIPARIAN HABITAT WITHIN SILVER CREEK PARK, WHICH PROTECTS 3,700 LINEAR FEET OF UNDEVELOPED RIPARIAN SHORELINE ALONG SILVER CREEK AND 2,000 LINEAR FEET OF LAKE MICHIGAN SHORELINE. THE PARKS COMBINATION OF STREAM, ESTUARY, SHORELINES, WETLANDS, GRASSLANDS, AND FOREST HABITATS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS ONE OF THE MOST SIGNIFICANT REMAINING MIGRATORY STOPOVER HABITATS ON THE WISCONSINS CENTRAL LAKE MICHIGAN COAST. ANGLERS FROM ACROSS THE MIDWEST TRAVEL TO SILVER CREEK PARK FOR THE ANNUAL STEELHEAD RUN, AND THE 36-HOLE DISC GOLF COURSE IS CONSIDERED ONE OF THE BEST IN WISCONSIN. THIS UNIQUE MIX OF RECREATIONAL ACCESS AMENITIES AND DIVERSE HABITATS PROVIDES AN EXCELLENT OPPORTUNITY TO BALANCE MULTIPLE USES AND EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ON THE NEED FOR RESTORATION, TO SUSTAIN IMPORTANT COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS. SILVER CREEK AND ITS ESTUARY HAVE BEEN SIGNIFICANTLY DEGRADED BY BANK EROSION, WHICH CONTRIBUTES SEDIMENT LOADS TO THE STREAM AND LAKE MICHIGAN, AND HAS RESULTED IN A WIDE, SHALLOW CHANNEL, ACCUMULATION OF FINE SEDIMENTS, AND LOSS OF IN-STREAM HABITAT STRUCTURE.  THIS PROPOSAL WILL STABILIZE AND INSTALL NATIVE VEGETATION ALONG 3,333 LINEAR FEET OF ERODING BANKS, INSTALL IN-STREAM HABITAT STRUCTURES, AND ENHANCE THE DEGRADED RIPARIAN ZONE WITH NATIVE POLLINATOR-FRIENDLY PLANTINGS. ONCE IMPLEMENTED, THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE NATIVE SPECIES DIVERSITY, ENHANCE STRUCTURAL COMPLEXITY OF RIPARIAN AND COASTAL HABITAT, ABSORB AND ATTENUATE SURFACE WATER RUNOFF, REDUCE EROSION AND SEDIMENT REACHING SILVER CREEK AND LAKE MICHIGAN, IMPROVE WATER QUALITY, AND IMPROVE FISH HABITAT. THE SINGLE PRIMARY TARGET SPECIES TO BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT IS STEELHEAD (RAINBOW TROUT), WHICH IS AN IMPORTANT ECONOMIC DRIVER FOR THE REGION. HOWEVER, THE FISH COMMUNITY AS A WHOLE, WHICH INCLUDES IMPORTANT RECREATIONAL FISHERY SPECIES SUCH AS BROOK TROUT, RAINBOW TROUT, BROWN TROUT, WHITE SUCKER, STEELHEAD, NORTHERN PIKE, CHINOOK SALMON, AND COHO SALMON, AS WELL AS ECOLOGICALLY IMPORTANT FORAGE FISH, WILL BENEFIT FROM IMPROVED HABITAT STRUCTURE, WATER QUALITY, AND REDUCED EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION.  SIGNIFICANT SECONDARY BENEFITS TO MIGRATORY BIRDS, INCLUDING NEOTROPICAL MIGRANT SONGBIRDS AND DIVING DUCKS, ARE EXPECTED AS A RESULT OF ENHANCED AQUATIC MACRO-INVERTEBRATE AND FORAGE FISH POPULATIONS. THE ENHANCEMENT OF POLLINATOR HABITAT WITHIN THE RIPARIAN AREA WILL INCLUDE DIVERSE NECTAR SOURCES FOR THE FEDERALLY-ENDANGERED RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (RPBB), WHICH WAS DOCUMENTED LESS THAN A MILE AWAY IN 2022. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE THE NECESSARY STEPS FOR FINAL DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE STREAMBANK RESTORATION, BUILDING ON PREVIOUS SITE ANALYSIS AND PRELIMINARY DESIGN, IN ORDER TO ACHIEVE THE OBJECTIVES OF IMPROVING WATER QUALITY AND AQUATIC HABITAT CONDITIONS FOR MACROI-NVERTEBRATES, FORAGE FISH, TO SUSTAIN A PRODUCTIVE SPORT FISHERY, SUPPORT MIGRATORY BIRD USE AT A CRITICAL STOPOVER HABITAT, AND SUPPORT POLLINATOR HABITAT FOR IMPERILED SPECIES.  THIS SHOVEL-READY PROPOSAL WILL INCLUDE FINAL DESIGN, PERMITTING, CONSTRUCTION, OVERSIGHT AND NATIVE RE-VEGETATION WITHIN THE STABILIZATION AREAS, PLUS THE LARGER RIPARIAN CORRIDOR.  THIS PROPOSAL ADDRESSES BROAD NEEDS FOR CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION OF KEY FUNCTIONS FOR VULNERABLE GREAT LAKES FISH AND WILDLIFE, IN THE FACE OF CLIMATE CHANGE, INVASIVE SPECIES, DEVELOPMENT PRESSURE, AND WATER QUALITY DEGRADATION. THIS PROPOSAL WILL TARGET URGENT AND EMERGING NEEDS TO RESTORE FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITATS THAT HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS HIGH PRIORITY IN STATE, REGIONAL, AND LOCAL PLANS.  IN PARTICULAR, THE IMPORTANCE OF SILVER CREEK, ITS ESTUARY, AND CONTIGUOUS PROTECTED RIPARIAN AND UPLAND HABITATS, HAS BEEN RECOGNIZED AS GREAT IMPORTANCE LOCALLY TO SUPPORTING A SUSTAINABLE FISHERY, AND REGIONALLY NATIONALLY, TO SUPPORTING THRIVING POPULATIONS OF MIGRATORY BIRDS, MONARCHS, AND THE FEDERALLY-LISTED RPBB.

A WATERSHED COMMUNITY OF SCIENTISTS WILL CONDUCT SPAWNING ABUNDANCE ESTIMATES FOR A REMNANT POPULATION OF LAKE STURGEON IN THE GRAND RIVER, MI. TWO METHODOLOGICAL APPROACHES WILL BE USED AND INCLUDE THE PILOTING OF HYDROACOUSTIC IMAGING OF SPAWNING STURGEON AND GENETIC ANALYSIS OF AGE-0 STURGEON. THE TWO METHODS WILL PROVIDE ANNUAL SPAWNING ABUNDANCE AND EFFECTIVE SPAWNING SIZE ESTIMATES THAT WILL ESTABLISH A BASELINE TO BE USED FOR EVALUATING AND REFINING DETAILED MANAGEMENT PRESCRIPTIONS.THE GRAND RIVER LAKE STURGEON POPULATION IS ONE OF THE LAST IN THE LAKE MICHIGAN BASIN WHERE BASIC POPULATION DATA IS ABSENT. THE VOID COMES FROM DIFFICULTY IN SAMPLING A LARGE RIVER SYSTEM AND INVESTMENT TO UNDERSTAND FEASIBLE SURVEY METHODS. THIS HAS INHIBITED KNOWLEDGE OF A POPULATION TRAJECTORY, A PRIMARY METRIC WHICH MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (MIDNR) BASES MANAGEMENT PRESCRIPTIONS. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO EVALUATE HYDROACOUSTIC METHODOLOGIES IN A LARGE RIVER SYSTEM THAT COULD PROVIDE AN EFFICIENT OPTION FOR OBTAINING POPULATION-LEVEL DATA ON A LARGE RIVER SYSTEM. A MULTI-ORGANIZATIONAL COLLABORATIVE HAS BEGUN TO ADDRESS LAKE STURGEON KNOWLEDGE GAPS IN THE GRAND RIVER AND HAS COLLECTED LAKE STURGEON RECRUITMENT DATA THROUGH VISUAL NIGHTTIME SURVEYS CONDUCTED OVER SIX YEARS. INDEX SITES HAVE BEEN ESTABLISHED AND RECRUITMENT DOCUMENTED.IN 2022, PROJECT PARTNERS MEASURED LAKE STURGEON HABITAT IN THE GRAND RIVER AND EVALUATED LOCATIONS FOR DEPLOYING FIXED-LOCATION, HYDROACOUSTIC TECHNOLOGY TO QUANTIFY THE ANNUAL NUMBER OF STURGEON MIGRATING TO SPAWN. THIS STUDY WILL EXPAND UPON THE CURRENT EFFORT AND PROVIDE ESTIMATES ON ANNUAL SPAWNER ABUNDANCE, EFFECTIVE SPAWNER SIZE(PARENTS CONTRIBUTING TO SPAWNING), GENETIC DIVERSITY, AND RECRUITMENT. THE FIXED-LOCATION, SPLIT-BEAM HYDROACOUSTIC TECHNOLOGY WILL BE PILOTED DURING THE FIRST SEASON OF THE PROJECT AND THEN THE REFINED METHODOLOGICAL PROCESS WILL BE REDEPLOYED TO ASSESS ANNUAL NUMBERS OF LAKE STURGEON IN THE SPAWNING RUN. NIGHTTIME VISUAL SURVEYS WILL BE USED TO COLLECT GENETIC SAMPLES FROM AGE-0 STURGEON TO CALCULATE EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZE, PARENTAL CONTRIBUTION, AND GENETIC DIVERSITY (SCRIBNER ET AL. 2022). THE USE OF ACOUSTICS TECHNIQUES HOLDS GREAT PROMISE FOR RAPID-ASSESSMENT OF LAKE STURGEON POPULATIONS AND HAVE BEEN USED FOR ASSESSING FISHERIES IN THE NORTHWEST ALTHOUGH ONLY A SINGLE LAKE STURGEON SPAWNING ASSESSMENT HAS BEEN CONDUCTED IN THE GREAT LAKES. THIS STUDY WILL PILOT ACOUSTIC METHODS WHICH MAY BE THE MOST FEASIBLE TECHNIQUE FOR ASSESSING LAKE STURGEON SPAWNING POPULATIONS IN LARGE RIVERS WITH TURBID WATERS. THE INFORMATION COLLECTED FROM BOTH METHODS WILL PROVIDE THE BASELINE INFORMATION THAT WILL BE NEEDED TO MAKE INFORMED MANAGEMENT DECISIONS FOR THE GRAND RIVER LAKE STURGEON POPULATION.

THIS GRANT PROVIDES TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FOR RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES RELATED TO REDUCING OR ELIMINATING INVASIVE CARP POPULATIONS IN INDIANA WATERS.WORK PERFORMED UNDER THIS PROJECT INCLUDES  FACILITATING CONTRACTED AND COMMERCIAL FISHING EFFORTS, TRACKING ANDMONITORING DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE, EVALUATING MANAGEMENT AND SUPPRESSION ACTIONS AND ASSESSING HABITAT USE AND SUITABILITY. TRACKING AND MONITORING INVASIVE CARP POPULATIONS AND ASSOCIATED HABITAT USE ALLOWS FOR THEAPPLICATION OF STRATEGIC SUPPRESSION ACTIONS INCLUDING COMMERCIAL FISHING AND AGENCY REMOVAL EVENTS. WORK UNDERTHIS PROJECT INCLUDES THE EXPANSION OF INVASIVE CARP HARVEST IN INDIANA WATERS BY UTILIZING CONTRACTED FISHERS AND ESTABLISHING A NEW INVASIVE CARP HARVEST PERMIT.REDUCING OR ELIMINATING INVASIVE CARP POPULATIONS RESULTS IN SAFER AND HEALTHIER WATERS FOR CITIZEN BENEFIT. CITIZENS UTILIZING PUBLIC WATERS FOR RECREATIONAL BOATING AND FISHING WILL SEE DIRECT BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT INCLUDING INCREASED QUALITY OF LIFE, INCREASED BOATING SAFETY AND INCREASED APPRECIATION FOR INDIANA S WATER RESOURCES.

FUNDS SUPPORT COORDINATION, PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION, AND OUTREACH EFFORTS BY THE COORDINATING GROUP ON ALIEN PEST SPECIES (CGAPS) PROGRAM MANAGER. WITH RESPECT TO INVASIVE SPECIES ISSUES IN THE STATE OF HAWAII, THIS INTER-AGENCY NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATION PARTNERSHIP, LED BY THE CGAPS PROGRAM MANAGER, PROMOTES COMMUNICATION AND COLLABORATION ON PROJECTS THAT FOCUS ON PREVENTION, EARLY DETECTION AND RAPID RESPONSE, AND CONTROL OF INVASIVE SPECIES ON PRIVATE AND PUBLIC LANDS AND WATERS. SPECIFICALLY, USFWS FUNDING WOULD PROVIDE CONTINUED SUPPORT FOR: 1). PROGRAM MANAGER TIME TO WORK WITH CGAPS STAFF AND RELEVANT AGENCIES TO PROMOTE STRONGER AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES (ANS) PREVENTION AND RESPONSE PROCEDURES, PROGRAMS, AND LAWS. 2). PROGRAM MANAGER TIME TO PLAN AND FUNDING TO PRODUCE AND DISTRIBUTE COMMUNICATIONS PIECES AND OUTREACH MATERIALS RELATED TO ANS , INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO STONY CORAL TISSUE LOSS (SCTLD), UNOMIA STOLONIFERA, AND OTHER PRIORITY ANS ISSUES, AND TOP ANS PATHWAYS. 3). PROGRAM MANAGER TIME TO PLAN, AND FUNDING TO CONDUCT STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT RELATED TO COLLABORATIVELY ADDRESSING THE TOP ANS PATHWAYS. 4). PROGRAM MANAGER TIME TO PARTICIPATE AND COORDINATE, WITH THE STATE DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES (DLNR-DAR), IN ENGAGING WITH REGIONAL AND NATIONAL PARTNERS TO ASSESS AND COMMENT ON FEDERAL RULES FOR BALLAST WATER AND BIOFOULING, AND TO RAISE CAPACITY FOR STATE CO-ENFORCEMENT.

THE MID KLAMATH WATERSHED COUNCIL (MKWC) KLAMATH RIVER COHO SPAWNER SURVEY PROJECT WILL CONDUCT SURVEYS OF ADULT COHO SPAWNING POPULATIONS IN THE MID-KLAMATH REGION AND DOCUMENT ALL OBSERVED COHO LIVE ADULTS, REDDS, AND CARCASSES. MKWC HAS SUCCESSFULLY IMPLEMENTED COHO SPAWNER SURVEYS ON SELECT TRIBUTARIES OF THE KLAMATH RIVER BETWEEN PORTUGUESE CREEK AND IRON GATE DAM SINCE 2015.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO GATHER INFORMATION ON INVASIVE CARP DISTRIBUTIONS, BEHAVIOR, AND POPULATION CHARACTERISTICS IN THE OHIO RIVER BASIN. AS PARTNERS IN A MULTI-STATE PROJECT, PENNSYLVANIA FISH AND BOAT COMMISSION BIOLOGISTS WILL CONDUCT SAMPLING SURVEYS IN THE MONONGAHELA, OHIO, AND ALLEGHENY RIVERS TO COLLECT DATA, WITH A FOCUS ON INVASIVE CARP EARLY DETECTION AND REMOVAL. THIS DATA WILL BE USED TO ASSESS MANAGEMENT ACTIONS RELATED TO THE REMOVAL, SUPPRESSION, AND CONTAINMENT OF INVASIVE CARP AND TO AID IN DETERMINING THE IMPACTS OF THESE SPECIES ON NATIVE FISH POPULATIONS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME OF THIS WORK IS TO PROVIDE AN ACCURATE POPULATION TREND ASSESSMENT OF INVASIVE CARP CONTROL AND RESPONSE EFFORTS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE CITIZENS, NATIVE FISH AND AQUATIC SPECIES, AND WATERWAYS OF PENNSYLVANIA. NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES ARE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT.

THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF INVASIVE CARP (SILVER, BIGHEAD, BLACK AND GRASS CARP) HAVE BEEN INCREASING IN MOST OF ARKANSAS S RIVER SYSTEMS. THESE NON-NATIVE FISH SPECIES POSE SIGNIFICANT ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC THREATS IN ARKANSAS AND THROUGHOUT THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN. WHILE COMPLETE ELIMINATION ON INVASIVE CARP IS NOT FEASIBLE, MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL OF THESE SPECIES IS NECESSARY TO REDUCE THEIR IMPACT ON NATIVE SPECIES, THE ECOSYSTEM, AND THE ECONOMY.FOR FEDERAL FISCAL YEAR 2023, FIVE SUB-BASIN PROJECTS HAVE BEEN FUNDED TO SUPPORT INVASIVE CARP CONTROL WITHIN THE LOWER MISSISSIPPI (LMR) AND ARKANSAS-RED-WHITE (AWR) SUB-BASINS IN ARKANSAS. THESE INCLUDE THE CONTINUED REMOVAL OF INVASIVE CARP BY THE ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSION S (AGFC) INVASIVE CARP REMOVAL PROGRAM IN BOTH THE LMR AND AWR SUB-BASINS  A TWO YEAR RESEARCH PROJECT TO DETERMINE IF SILVER CARP ARE SUCCESSFUL RECRUITING AND WHAT HABITATS ARE UTILIZED FOR RECRUITMENT IN THE LOWER WHITE AND ARKANSAS RIVERS OF THE LMR SUB-BASINS, WHICH INCENTIVIZES COMMERCIAL HARVEST AND ENCOURAGES MARKET UTILIZATION OF INVASIVE CARP TO INCREASE BIOMASS REMOVAL.THE AGFC INVASIVE CARP REMOVAL PROGRAM WAS FIRST IMPLEMENTED IN 2021, AND IS SUPPORTED BY FEDERAL INVASIVE CARP GRANT FUNDS. CONTINUED FUNDING OF THE PROGRAM SUPPORTS ONE FULL TIME AND FIVE PART-TIME STAFF AND PROVIDES SUPPLIES, SUCH AS GILL NETS, USED BY THE PROGRAM TO CATCH AND REMOVE INVASIVE CARP FROM THE ARKANSAS AND WHITE RIVER SYSTEMS.THE SILVER CARP RECRUITMENT STUDY SEEKS TO IDENTIFY IF AND WHERE SILVER CARP ARE SUCCESSFULLY RECRUITING IN ARKANSAS S WATERS. RESULTING FROM RECENT MICROCHEMISTRY ANALYSIS OF SILVER CARP OTOLITHS HAVE SHOWN NATAL ORIGINS FROM THE WHITE AND ARKANSAS RIVERS. HOWEVER, IT IS UNKNOWN IF THE FISH RECRUITED IN THOSE RIVER SYSTEMS OR THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER. KNOWING THE ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, HABITATS, AND LOCATIONS WHERE SILVER CARP ARE RECRUITING IN THE LOWER ARKANSAS AND WHITE RIVERS WOULD HELP MANAGERS TARGET THOSE LOCATIONS FOR REMOVAL. IF RECRUITMENT IS NOT OBSERVED, THEN IT IS MOST LIKELY ALL SILVER CARP IN THE ARKANSAS AND WHITE RIVER SYSTEMS ARE RECRUITING FROM THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER, WHICH SUPPORTS FURTHER INVESTIGATION INTO THE FEASIBILITY OF IMPLEMENTING BARRIERS.COMMERCIAL HARVEST HAS PROVEN TO BE THE MOST EFFECTIVE MEANS OF INVASIVE CARP BIOMASS REMOVAL IN THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN. CURRENTLY, COMMERCIAL HARVEST AND MARKET USE OF INVASIVE CARP IN ARKANSAS IS LIMITED DUE TO MARKET VALUE AND LACK OF AVAILABLE MARKETS FOR THE FISH. FUNDING FOR THE ARKANSAS INVASIVE CARP MARKET STIMULATION PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE REMOVAL OF OVER 1.9 MILLION POUNDS OF INVASIVE CARP FROM THE LMR AND ARW SUB-BASINS IN ARKANSAS, BY INCENTIVIZING COMMERCIAL HARVEST AND ENCOURAGING MARKET DEVELOPMENT. THE AGFC WILL ADMINISTER SUBSIDY PAYMENTS OF 18 CENTS PER POUND TO LICENSED COMMERCIAL FISHERS, WHO PROVIDE RECEIPTS FOR INVASIVE CARP CAUGHT IN ARKANSAS WATERS AND SOLD TO ANY BUYER. IN ADDITION, AGFC WILL PROVIDE START-UP FISHING SUPPLIES SUCH AS GILL NETS, ROPE, AND ANCHORS, AS WELL AS ACCESS TO EQUIPMENT SUCH AS ICE MACHINES TO COMMERCIAL FISHERS WHO REGISTER FOR THE PROGRAM. THE ARKANSAS ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION WILL AID WITH MARKET DEVELOPMENT BY PROVIDING ASSISTANCE TO BUSINESSES OR ENTITIES INTERESTED IN INCREASING PROCESSING CAPACITY AND OR DEVELOPING PRODUCTS FROM INVASIVE IN ARKANSAS. IF MORE MARKETS FOR INVASIVE CARP BECOME AVAILABLE, FUTURE FUNDING REQUEST WILL BE DIRECTED TO SUPPORT INCREASED BIOMASS REMOVAL THROUGH COMMERCIAL HARVEST, AND MONITORING EFFECTS OF COMMERCIAL HARVEST ON INVASIVE CARP POPULATIONS IN ARKANSAS.

THE UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES (UDWR) INTENDS TO CONTINUE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE UTAH AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN (PLAN) WITH THE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE OF THIS FEDERAL GRANT.  AS IDENTIFIED IN THE PLAN, THE GOAL IS TO  IMPROVE THE ABILITY OF NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ENTITIES WITHIN UTAH TO PREVENT INVASION OF AIS INTO THE STATE, AND TO CONTAIN AIS THROUGH ACCEPTED MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO AREAS THAT ARE EITHER ALREADY INFESTED OR BECOME INFESTED. PRIORITY 1:  STATEWIDE, INTERDICT BOATS AND EQUIPMENT POTENTIALLY CONTAMINATED WITH AIS AT LAUNCH RAMPS, ADMINISTRATIVE CHECK POINTS, MANDATORY HIGHWAY INSPECTION STATIONS, AND UTAH S PORT OF ENTRY - YEARLONG.ACTIVITY IB1A- PROVIDE ADDITIONAL DECONTAMINATIONS AT THE DANIELD PORT OF ENTRY AND EXPANDED RAMP COVERAGE AT UTAH LAKE TO INCLUDE ADDITIONAL LAUNCH RAMPS, NOT PREVIOUSLY COVERED. WITH THESE FUNDS, IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT OVER 9,200 BOATS AT UTAH LAKE AND OVER 7,000 BOATS AT THE DANIELS PORT OF ENTRY, WILL BE INVOLVED.ACTIVITY IB2A- INCREASE THIS PROGRAM S CAPACITY TO INCLUDE ADDITIONAL INTERDICTION HOURS THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO ALLOWING UDWR PERSONNEL THE OPPORTUNITY TO CONDUCT FULL INSPECTIONS OF ALL BOATS DEEMED TO BE IN HIGH RISK OF TRANSPORTING AIS. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT UDWR WILL PERFORM OVER 4,300 DECONTAMINATIONS, WITH THE MAJORITY OF THOSE EXITING WATERCRAFT AT LAKE POWELL, AS WELL AS OVER 600 DECONTAMINATIONS (COLLECTIVELY) AT UTAH LAKE AND THE DANIELS PORT OF ENTRY S MANDATORY INSPECTION STATIONS.

THE PROJECT FOCUS IS IMPLEMENTATION OF A WATERCRAFT INSPECTION AND DECONTAMINATION PROGRAM IN 2023 FOR THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA. THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO INCREASE THE RATE AT WHICH BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ARE ADOPTED BY THE BOATING PUBLIC STATEWIDE TO SLOW THE SPREAD OF ANS. THE SOUTH DAKOTA ANS MANAGEMENT PLAN PRIORITIES ADDRESSED BY THE PROJECT INCLUDE: PREVENT NEW INTRODUCTIONS OF ANS TO SOUTH DAKOTA, EDUCATING ALL AQUATIC USERS ON ANS RISKS AND BEST PRACTICES TO REDUCE THE TRANSPORT OF ANS TO NEW WATER BODIES, AND LIMIT DISPERSAL OF ESTABLISHED POPULATIONS OF ANS INTO UNINFESTED WATERS OF SOUTH DAKOTA THROUGH OUTREACH AND EDUCATION.

SOME OF KANSAS  AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS HAVE ALREADY BEEN INVADED AND NEGATIVELY IMPACTED BY AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES (ANS), SUCH AS ZEBRA MUSSELS, SILVER AND BIGHEAD CARP, WHITE PERCH, EURASIAN WATERMILFOIL, HYDRILLA, SALT CEDAR, AND RUSTY CRAYFISH.  THESE AND OTHER ANS POSE A SERIOUS THREAT TO MANY OTHER KANSAS WATERBODIES AND THOSE OF SURROUNDING STATES.  IN MAY 2005, THE USFWS ANS TASK FORCE AND STATE GOVERNOR APPROVED THE KANSAS ANS MANAGEMENT PLAN. THE GOALS OF THE KANSAS ANS MANAGEMENT PLAN ARE:1. TO PREVENT NEW INTRODUCTIONS OF ANS TO KANSAS.2. TO PREVENT DISPERSAL OF ESTABLISHED POPULATIONS OF ANS INTO UNINFESTED WATERS.3. TO ERADICATE OR CONTROL TO MINIMIZE THE ADVERSE ECOLOGICAL, ECONOMIC, SOCIAL, AND PUBLIC HEALTH EFFECTS OF ANS IN AN ENVIRONMENTALLY SOUND MANNER.4. TO EDUCATE ALL AQUATIC USERS OF ANS RISKS AND HOW TO REDUCE THE HARMFUL IMPACTS.5. TO SUPPORT RESEARCH ON ANS IN KANSAS AND DEVELOP SYSTEMS TO DISSEMINATE INFORMATION.FUNDING PROVIDED BY THIS OPPORTUNITY WILL BE USED TO MEET THESE GOALS. KANSAS IS COMMITTED TO ADDRESSING THE INVASIVE SPECIES PROBLEM. WITH THE SUPPORT OF THIS GRANT, WE MOVE CLOSER TO ACHIEVING THE GOALS OUTLINED IN THE KANSAS ANS MANAGEMENT PLAN.

COLORADO HAS SHOWN EFFECTIVE AT IMPLEMENTING A ROBUST, EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PROGRAM AND THIS COST SHARE FUNDING WILL SERVE TO MEET THE GOALS OF COLORADO AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN. THE PLAN WAS APPROVED IN DECEMBER OF 2020 AND WE LOOK FORWARD TO FURTHERING OUR ANS MANAGEMENT EFFORTS WITH YOUR FUNDING SUPPORT.OBJECTIVE 2, STRATEGY 2A. PROVIDE SUFFICIENT WATERCRAFT INSPECTION AND DECONTAMINATION STATIONS TO EFFECTIVELY PROTECT THE WATERS OF THE STATE FROM ANS INTRODUCTIONS.OBJECTIVE 2, STRATEGY 2F. INCREASE OPPORTUNITIES FOR ANGLERS TO CLEAN THEIR WADERS, BOOTS, AND GEAR TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF NEW ZEALAND MUDSNAILS AND OTHER ANS.OBJECTIVE 4, STRATEGY 4C. PROVIDE FOR STANDARDIZED LABORATORY TESTING PROTOCOLS BETWEEN CPW AND THEIR PARTNERS TO ENSURE RELIABLE TEST RESULTS AND CONSISTENT INTERPRETATION OF THOSE RESULTS AND CORRESPONDING MANAGEMENT ACTIONS.OBJECTIVE 5, STRATEGY 5B. EXPAND CURRENT INVASIVE SPECIES INFORMATION AND EDUCATIONAL EFFORTS.THE TOTAL AMOUNT REQUESTED IS  90,000 AND THE TOTAL STATE MATCH IS  30,000.00. THE ATTACHED PRIORITIZED TABLE LISTS OUR PLANNED ACTIVITIES FOR WHICH WE ARE REQUESTING FUNDING. THE REQUIRED 25  STATE MATCH IS INCLUDED ON THE ATTACHED TABLE  WE ALSO UNDERSTAND THERE IS A 5  LIMITATION ON THE ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS.

THE PACIFIC STATES MARINE FISHERIES COMMISSION OPERATES THE REGIONAL MARK PROCESSING CENTER. THE RMPC PROVIDES ESSENTIAL SERVICES TO INTERNATIONAL, STATE, FEDERAL, AND TRIBAL FISHERIES ORGANIZATIONS INVOLVED IN TAGGING AND MARKING ANADROMOUS SALMONIDS THROUGHOUT THE PACIFIC REGION. THESE SERVICES INCLUDE REGIONAL COORDINATION OF TAGGING AND FIN MARKING PROGRAMS, ENGAGEMENT WITH DATA PROVIDERS AND CONSUMERS TO REFINE DATA AND TOOLS FOR THEIR NEEDS, MAINTENANCE OF DATABASES FOR CODED WIRE TAG RELEASES, RECOVERIES, LOCATIONS, AND CATCH SAMPLE DATA, WEB-BASED DATA ACCESS AND QUERY TOOLS, AS WELL AS THE DISSEMINATION OF REPORTS OF THESE DATA IN ELECTRONIC OR PRINTED FORM WHEN REQUESTED. THESE DATABASES ARE KNOWN COLLECTIVELY AS THE REGIONAL MARK INFORMATION SYSTEM (RMIS).

PURPOSE AND ACTIVITIES: ANNUALLY SURVEY SPAWNING POPULATIONS OF COHO AND FALL CHINOOK SALMON IN THE CHEHALIS BASIN AS PART OF A LONG-TERM HABITAT-MONITORING PROJECT WITH USFWS AND WA DEPT. OF FISH   WILDLIFE. INFORMATION COLLECTED BY THE TRIBE AND WDFW WILL BE USED TO ESTIMATE THE ANNUAL SALMON SPAWNING ESCAPEMENT OF BOTH SPECIES.DELIVERABLES: PROJECT IS ANTICIPATED TO RUN FROM 10 1 23-6 30 24. THE TIME OF ONE STAFF BIOLOGIST WILL BE PARTIALLY ALLOCATED TO SUPERVISE TWO FULL TIME TECHNICIANS. AN ANNUAL REPORT WITH DATA ON SALMON ESCAPEMENT ESTIMATES WILL BE PRODUCED. THE QUINAULT INDIAN NATION COORDINATES WITH THE STATE FISHERIES MANAGERS TO SET ESCAPEMENT GOALS FOR SALMON SPECIES IN THE CHEHALIS RIVER WATERSHED. OUTCOMES AND BENEFICIARIES: DATA COLLECTED WILL PROVIDE RELIABLE INFORMATION TO HELP THE QUINAULT INDIAN NATION CO-MANAGE RESOURCES TO MAINTAIN PRODUCTIVITY OF SALMON STOCKS IN THE CHEHALIS RIVER BASIN. QUINAULT INDIAN NATION MEMBERS, COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FISHERIES USERS WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS WORK.

THE CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF THE CHEHALIS RESERVATION (CTCR) WILL BE COMPLETING A RIPARIAN PLANTING PROJECT IN FY 2023. THIS PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF MAINTAINING OLDER PLANTINGS, ORDERING TREES AND SHRUBS, AND HIRING A CONTRACTOR TO PLANT ABOUT 1,100 NEW PLANTS IN A NEW SECTION OF THE RIPARIAN CORRIDOR EQUALING APPROXIMATELY 6 ACRES. OVER TIME, THE ADDITIONAL ACREAGE OF RIPARIAN CORRIDOR WILL IMPROVE HABITAT CONDITIONS ON THE MAIN STEM OF THE CHEHALIS RIVER BY PROVIDING ADDITIONAL SHADE AND WOODY DEBRIS RECRUITMENT TO THE RIVER. THAT WILL IMPROVE HABITAT COMPLEXITY AND WATER QUALITY CONDITIONS FOR MANY AQUATIC SPECIES INCLUDING SALMONIDS, WHICH ARE OF VITAL IMPORTANCE CULTURALLY AND ECONOMICALLY TO CHEHALIS TRIBAL MEMBERS, AS WELL AS SPORT FISHERMEN IN THE CHEHALIS BASIN.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO FULLY IMPLEMENT THE NEBRASKA ANS MANAGEMENT PLAN AND PREVENT THE SPREAD OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES IN THE STATE AND TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE THE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PRESENT WITHIN ITS BORDERS. THIS INCLUDES: 1) WATERCRAFT INSPECTIONS THAT WILL BE PLACED STRATEGICALLY THROUGHOUT THE STATE, PROVIDING THE GREATEST AMOUNT OF GEOGRAPHIC COVERAGE  2) SURVEYING WATERBODIES FOR EARLY DETECTION OF INVASIVE AQUATIC PLANTS FROM MAY THROUGH AUGUST  AND 3) OBTAINING WATER SAMPLES ON PRIORITY WATERBODIES FOR DETECTION OF ZEBRA MUSSEL VELIGERS FROM MAY TO SEPTEMBER - WITH SAMPLES BEING SENT TO MONTANA S AIS LABRORATORY FOR SECONDARY CONFIRMATION. TO ADEQUATELY MANAGE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES IN NEBRASKA, IT IS EXPECTED THAT MORE THAN 5,000 WATERCRAFTS WILL BE INSPECTED DURING NEBRASKA S BOATING SEASON AND AT LEAST 25 WATERBODIES WILL BE SURVEYED FOR THE DETECTION OF INVASIVE AQUATIC PLANT SPECIES, AS WELL AS GREATER THAN 40 LAKES WILL BE SURVEYED FOR ZEBRA MUSSEL VELIGERS. THROUGH EDUCATION AND OUTREACH TO SPREAD AWARENESS AND AGGRESSIVE, BUT CRITICAL ANS PREVENTION ACTIVITIES, NEBRASKA IS WELL ON A PATH TO A NATIONALLY-RECOGNIZED ANS PROGRAM.

CONTINUE REMOVAL PROGRAM USING CONTRACT FISHING, ENHANCED CONTRACT FISHING, AND CONTRACTED FACILITATION AT INTENSIVE MANAGEMENT ZONES TO REDUCE INVASIVE CARP NUMBERS ACROSS THE OHIO RIVER BASIN. QUANTIFY BIGHEADED CARP IN THE WABASH RIVER BASIN, INCLUDING ASSESSING MOVEMENT BETWEEN THE WABASH AND OHIO RIVERS AND BETWEEN THE WHITE AND WABASH RIVERS. INFORM HARVEST EFFORTS IN THE WABASH AND WHITE RIVERS BY DETERMINING BIGHEADED CARP DENSITIES, SPATIAL DISTRIBUTIONS, AND DENSITY RESPONSES TO HARVEST. USE LARVAE AND EGG MONITORING IN THE WABASH RIVER AND TRIBUTARIES TO DELINEATE THE REPRODUCTIVE RANGE OF INVASIVE CARPS WITHIN THIS SYSTEM. ADDITIONALLY PROVIDE CONSULTATION IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A BASIN-WIDE STANDARDIZED ICHTHYOPLANKTON SAMPLING PROTOCOL. IDENTIFY THE EXTENT OF INVASIVE CARP SPAWNING AND RECRUITMENT IN THE OHIO RIVER AND INFORM POTENTIAL AND ONGOING MANAGEMENT ACTIONS SUCH AS TARGETED REMOVAL, BARRIER DETERRENT PLACEMENT, AND SPAWNING DISRUPTION.

THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO ACT TO REDUCE INVASIVE CARP POPULATION DENSITIES, MONITOR THEIR RECRUITMENT, CONTROL THEIR EXPANSION, AND EVALUATE THE ABILITY OF ASIAN CARP, PADDLEFISH, BIGMOUTH BUFFALO, LAKE STURGEON, AND FLATHEAD CATFISH TO PASS THESE MAJOR PINCH POINTS IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER.

THE QUARTZ VALLEY INDIAN RESERVATION (QVIR) WILL PARTICIPATE IN THE FOLLOWING TASKS AS DIRECTED BY THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW).TASKS:TASK 1KLAMATH NATIONAL FOREST AND THE CDFW WILL COMPLETE LANDOWNER CONTACTS FOR PERMISSION TO ACCESS STREAMS THROUGH PRIVATE LANDS.TASK 2PROVIDE SURVEY CREWS TO COORDINATE WITH THE CDFW AND CONDUCT SURVEYS AS DIRECTED BY CDFW. ALL SURVEYS TO BE CONDUCTED FOLLOWING PROTOCOLS AND PROCEDURES IN CONDUCTING SPAWNING SURVEYS IN THE SALMON, SCOTT, AND MIDDLE KLAMATH BASIN TRIBUTARIES.TASK 3ATTEND TRAINING FOR SURVEY CREWS COORDINATED BY THE KLAMATH NATIONAL FOREST AND THE CDFW.TASK 4PROVIDE ALL MATERIALS, EQUIPMENT, TOOLS, PERMITS, LICENSES, AND TRANSPORTATION.TASK 5GATHER DATA ON SPAWNER ABUNDANCE BY SPECIES, ENUMERATE SALMONID REDDS AND DOCUMENT DISTRIBUTION, AND SAMPLE SALMONID CARCASSES.TASK 6MARK ALL SAMPLED CARCASSES FOR POTENTIAL SUBSEQUENT RECAPTURE.TASK 7COLLECT SCALE SAMPLES FROM SALMONID CARCASSES LOCATED DURING SURVEYS FOR SUBSEQUENT AGE ANALYSIS.TASK 8COLLECT AND FREEZE HEADS OF ADIPOSE FIN CLIPPED FISH LOCATED DURING SURVEYS FOR LATER ANALYSIS.TASK 9SUBMIT SURVEY DATA SHEETS AND SCALE SAMPLES TO THE CDFW ONCE PER WEEK. SUBMIT REDD DATA SHEETS AND MAPS TO THE U. S. FOREST SERVICE (USFS) ON A DAILY OR WEEKLY BASIS AS DIRECTED BY THE TWO ORGANIZATIONS.B. METHODSTHE SURVEYS OCCUR FROM EARLY OCTOBER THROUGH DECEMBER THROUGHOUT THE SCOTT, SALMON AND SELECTED TRIBUTARIES IN THE MID-KLAMATH RIVERS. THE COOPERATORS WILL PARTICIPATE IN SURVEYS IN EACH OF THESE WATERSHEDS AS DIRECTED BY CDFW. SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED USING CDFW S AND USFSS ESTABLISHED PROTOCOL AND REGULATIONS FOR THESE ONGOING INVENTORIES. SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED UTILIZING BANKSIDE AND OR SNORKEL TECHNIQUES AS CDFW DEEMS APPROPRIATE FOR THE SURVEY REACH. SURVEY CREWS WILL ENUMERATE ALL OBSERVED ADULT SALMONIDS. ALL LOCATED REDDS WILL BE ENUMERATED AND LOCATED ON A SURVEY MAP. ALL COLLECTED CARCASSES WILL BE IDENTIFIED TO SPECIES, CHECKED FOR ADIPOSE CLIP AND RECAPTURE TAGS, MEASURED, AND SEXED. IN ADDITION, IN TRIBUTARIES WHERE CARCASS MARK-SAMPLING OCCURS, ALL CARCASSES WILL BE MARKED WITH A NUMBERED TAG AND OR CHOPPED WITH A MACHETE TO ALLOW RECAPTURE IDENTIFICATION AND ENUMERATION ON SUBSEQUENT SURVEYS. IN ADDITION TO ENUMERATING SALMON REDDS AND OR MARKING AND SAMPLING CARCASSES, SURVEY CREWS WILL COLLECT SCALE SAMPLES FROM RECOVERED CARCASSES AND RETRIEVE SNOUTS FROM ADIPOSE-CLIPPED CHINOOK FOR LATER CODED WIRE TAG (CWT) EXTRACTION. ALL COLLECTED DATA WILL BE RECORDED ON ESTABLISHED CDFW AND USFS SURVEY DATA SHEETS AND MAPS.

MINNESOTA DNR AND PARTNERS CONTINUE TO ADAPTIVELY DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A COMPREHENSIVE MONITORING AND RESPONSE PROGRAM FOR BIGHEAD, SILVER, BLACK, AND GRASS CARPS IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN. MONITORING ACTIVITIES HELP DETERMINE THE CURRENT STATUS AND EXTENT OF INVASIVE CARP IN MINNESOTA WATERS, IMPORTANT KNOWLEDGE FOR MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. ADDITIONALLY, THIS EFFORT HELPS EVALUATE THE EFFECTS OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS SUCH AS COMMERCIAL HARVEST. SAMPLING USES A DIVERSE ARRAY OF TRADITIONAL AND NOVEL GEARS TO SAMPLE ALL POTENTIAL LIFE STAGES IN TARGETED AREAS. TAGGING AND TRACKING ADULT INVASIVE CARP REVEALS PATTERNS IN MOVEMENT AND SEASONALITY THAT HAVE AIDED IN THE CAPTURE OF MULTIPLE INVASIVE CARP. RESPONDING TO INVASIVE CARP SIGHTINGS AND CAPTURES IS ALSO PART OF THE PROGRAM AND HAS TAKEN ON AN INCREASED SIGNIFICANCE SINCE CAPTURES BEGAN TO INCREASE IN 2020. NOW, MINNESOTA DNR IS PARTNERING WITH WISCONSIN DNR, USGS, USFWS, NPS, AND WILD RIVERS CONSERVANCY TO IMPLEMENT LARGE COORDINATED REMOVAL EVENTS, EXPAND TAGGING AND TRACKING, AND TO TEST NOVEL METHODS TO ENHANCE OUR ABILITY TO CAPTURE INVASIVE CARP. COMMERCIAL FISHERS WILL BE CONTRACTED TO REMOVE INVASIVE CARP FROM THE SYSTEM AND ATTEMPT TO PREVENT SPAWNING IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER. FINAL SAMPLING REPORTS AND DATA FROM REMOVED OR TAGGED INVASIVE CARP WILL BE AVAILABLE AT THE CONCLUSION OF THIS PROJECT.

A SUCCESSFUL AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PROGRAM IS COMPOSED OF THREE KEY INITIATIVES: PREVENTION OF AIS ARRIVAL, MONITORING OF KNOWN SPECIES AND FOR NEW SPECIES, AND CONTROL OR RAPID RESPONSE EFFORTS. TWO SUPPORTING ELEMENTS ACCOMPANY THESE KEY INITIATIVES: SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH OR DATA COLLECTION AND OUTREACH   EDUCATION. THOUGH THE MOST COST-EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGY IN THE STATE OF HAWAII IS PREVENTION OF NEW SPECIES ARRIVAL COUPLED WITH EARLY DETECTION AND MONITORING EFFORTS, INVESTING IN THE CONTROL OF ESTABLISHED ALIEN AND INVASIVE SPECIES CAN BE VALUABLE IN PREVENTING PERMANENT DELETERIOUS EFFECTS TO HAWAIIS AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS, LOCAL ECONOMY, AND ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH. THIS PROPOSAL AIMS TO ADDRESS ALL THREE MAIN COMPONENTS OF THE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PROGRAM INCLUDING PREVENTION, MONITORING, AND CONTROL.DAR PLANS TO COMPLETE WORK IN LINE WITH THE OBJECTIVES OUTLINED IN THE 2003 HAWAII AIS MANAGEMENT PLAN. FUNDING FROM THIS OPPORTUNITY WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT THE STATE OF HAWAII AIS PROGRAM AND THEIR PARTICIPATION IN PREVENTION, EARLY DETECTION AND RAPID RESPONSE, MONITORING AND CONTROL ACTIVITIES. ADDITIONAL BUDGETED ITEMS ARE OPERATION SUPPLIES, TRAVEL, AND TRAINING THAT WILL SUPPORT THE STATE OF HAWAII AIS PROGRAMS OPERATIONS.

THE ASSESSMENT OF ANADROMOUS SALMONID STOCKS IN BLUE CREEK ON THE LOWER KLAMATH RIVER NEAR KLAMATH, CALIFORNIA IS A PROJECT CARRIED OUT BY THE YUROK TRIBE. THIS PROJECT CONSISTS OF SPAWNING GROUND SURVEYS CONDUCTED ON A WEEKLY AND BI-WEEKLY BASIS. DATA IS COLLECTED ON EACH LIVE FISH, REDD AND CARCASS LOCATED.THIS PROJECT IS A CONTINUATION OF LONG-TERM MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT EFFORTS OF BLUE CREEK ANADROMOUS SALMONID RUNS. BLUE CREEK IS THE ONLY REMAINING DRAINAGE IN THE LOWER KLAMATH SUB-BASIN WHICH SUPPORTS SIZABLE RUNS OF CHINOOK SALMON.THIS DATA ALLOWS FOR AN ASSESSMENT OF ANADROMOUS SALMONID POPULATION TRENDS WITHIN THE BASIN AS WELL AS CONTINUED ASSESSMENT AND REFINEMENT OF ANADROMOUS SALMONID DISTRIBUTION, IMMIGRATION TIMING, AND HABITAT USAGE THROUGHOUT THE BLUE CREEK DRAINAGE. THIS TREND DATA IS AN INTEGRAL COMPONENT OF THE MEGA-TABLE AND PROVIDES A MORE ACCURATE ASSESSMENT OF WILD SALMONID POPULATION NUMBERS THROUGHOUT THE KLAMATH BASIN, WHICH ALLOWS FOR MORE ACCURATE PREDICTIONS OF FUTURE CHINOOK RUN SIZES AND CORRESPONDING ALLOWABLE HARVEST NUMBERS.THE KLAMATH FALL CHINOOK AGE COMPOSITION STUDY IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT CARRIED OUT BY THE FORMER KLAMATH RIVER TECHNICAL TEAM (KRTT), AN INTERAGENCY TRIBAL GROUP. THIS TASK INCLUDES AGING SCALES FROM FALL CHINOOK SALMON COLLECTED DURING THE SPAWNING SEASON IN THE KLAMATH RIVER NET AND SPORT FISHERIES, SPAWNING GROUND SURVEYS FROM VARIOUS TRIBUTARIES THROUGHOUT THE KLAMATH BASIN, FISH THAT RETURN TO IRON GATE HATCHERY, AND WEIRS LOCATED IN THE SHASTA RIVER AND BOGUS CREEK. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS TASK IS TO USE THE AGE COMPOSITION INFORMATION FROM THE 2023 FALL CHINOOK RUN TO PREDICT THE ABUNDANCE FROM THAT RUN, AS WELL AS ASSESS THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN INDIVIDUAL COHORTS AND ENVIRONMENTAL PARAMETERS.THE ESCAPEMENT ENUMERATION PROJECT, OR MAINSTEM KLAMATH CARCASS SURVEY IS A COOPERATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN THE YUROK TRIBE, KARUK TRIBE AND USFWS, ARCATA FIELD OFFICE, CARRIED OUT IN THE UPPER-MOST REACHES OF THE KLAMATH RIVER IN CALIFORNIA. THE YUROK TRIBE SAMPLES THE UPPER 18 MILES OF THE KLAMATH RIVER IN CONJUNCTION WITH USFWS. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS STUDY IS TO ASSESS FALL CHINOOK ESCAPEMENT IN THE KLAMATH RIVER FROM IRON GATE DAM DOWNSTREAM TO INDIAN CREEK. THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED BY DIRECTLY SAMPLING AND COLLECTING DATA FROM SALMON CARCASSES. THIS DATA ALLOWS FOR AN ASSESSMENT OF ANADROMOUS SALMONID POPULATION TRENDS WITHIN THE BASIN, PROVIDING VITAL INFORMATION AND MORE ACCURATE PREDICTIONS OF FUTURE CHINOOK RUN SIZES AND CORRESPONDING ALLOWABLE HARVEST NUMBERS.

INVASIVE CARP POSE A SERIOUS RISK TO THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI AND MISSOURI RIVER BASINS. WE HAVEDEVELOPED FOUR PROJECTS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE SPREAD, POPULATION DYNAMICS, AND EFFECTS OF INVASIVE CARP IN THESE SYSTEMS. FIRST, HYBRIDIZATION BETWEEN SILVER CARP AND BIGHEAD CARP IN THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED FROM DISTINCTIVE HYBRID GILL MORPHOLOGY, BUT THE GENETIC AND ECOLOGICAL MECHANISMS UNDERLYING HYBRIDIZATION REMAIN ELUSIVE. FURTHER, THE EXTENT OF BIGHEADED CARP HYBRIDIZATION COULD BE CHANGING THROUGH TIME BUT HAS NOT BEEN ASSESSED. THIS WORK IS IMPORTANT AS HYBRIDIZATION MAY DAMPEN POPULATION GROWTH IF HYBRIDS CONTRIBUTE FEWER OFFSPRING TO THE NEXT GENERATION RELATIVE TO THE PARENTAL SPECIES. THEREFORE, WE WILL ASSESS THE EXTENT INTROGRESSIVE HYBRIDIZATION VARIES TEMPORALLY IN PORTIONS OF THE UMR, EXAMINE POTENTIAL ENVIRONMENTAL DRIVERS OF HYBRIDIZATION, AND POTENTIAL EFFECTS TO FITNESS LINKED CHARACTERISTICS SUCH AS BODY CONDITION.NEXT, INVASIVE CARP ARE EXPANDING UPSTREAM IN THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN. HOWEVER, OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE FULL IMPACTS OF BIGHEADED CARP INVASIONS TO RIVER ECOSYSTEMS AT DIFFERENT DENSITIES IS INCOMPLETE WHICH HAMPERS OUR ABILITY TO CONTROL THEIR POPULATIONS THROUGH EARLY DETECTION, BARRIER MANAGEMENT, AND REMOVAL. PREVIOUS RESEARCH FOCUSED ON TROPHIC COMPETITION BETWEEN BIGHEADED CARP AND NATIVE PLANKTIVORES AND FOUND HIGH DIET OVERLAP. HOWEVER, POTENTIAL FOOD WEB CONSEQUENCES OF INVASIVE CARP ON OTHER FISHES ARE UNKNOWN. GRADIENTS OF BIGHEADED CARP ABUNDANCE RANGE FROM ABSENT UPSTREAM OF TRIBUTARY DAMS TO DOMINANT IN DOWNSTREAM REACHES OF SOUTHERN TRIBUTARIES. THIS ESTABLISHES A SPATIALLY REPLICATED GRADIENT OF CARP ABUNDANCE ACROSS THE REGION AND PRESENTS A TIMELY OPPORTUNITY TO ACQUIRE INFORMATION ABOUT HOW INVASIVE SPECIES ABUNDANCE MAY INFLUENCE FOOD WEBS DYNAMICS. THIRD, THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER INVASIVE CARP PARTNERSHIP HAS IDENTIFIED THE AREA FROM LD 15 DOWNSTREAM TO LD 19 AS THE INTENSIVE MANAGEMENT ZONE (IMZ) FOR BIGHEAD CARP AND SILVER CARP. CONTRACTED REMOVAL EFFORTS HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTED IN THIS ZONE SINCE 2016, BUT THE IMPACTS OF THOSE EFFORTS ARE LARGELY UNKNOWN. FURTHERMORE, ADDITIONAL CONTRACT REMOVALS IN POOLS 20-22 BEGAN IN FY21, AND VARIOUS LEVELS OF INDEPENDENT COMMERCIAL FISHING FOR INVASIVE CARP ALSO OCCUR, PRIMARILY BELOW LD 19. A ROBUST STOCK ASSESSMENT PROGRAM IS NEEDED TO MORE DIRECTLY EVALUATE HOW POPULATIONS OF INVASIVE CARPS MAY BE AFFECTED BY CURRENT CONTRACT REMOVALS AND CONTROL EFFORTS, AND TO FORECAST THEIR FUTURE RESPONSE TO ALTERNATIVE CONTROL STRATEGIES. FINALLY, INVASIVE CARP ARE WELL-ESTABLISHED THROUGHOUT THE MISSOURI RIVER AND TRIBUTARIES DOWNSTREAM OF GAVINS POINT DAM. KNOWING WHEN AND UNDER WHAT ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS ADULT BIGHEAD AND SILVER CARP ARE MOVING INTO THE TRIBUTARIES WILL HELP INFORM WHEN TO MONITOR THE POPULATION AS WELL AS IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. UNDERSTANDING THE MOVEMENT RANGE OF BIGHEAD AND SILVER CARP IN THE MISSOURI RIVER BASIN, THE ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS ASSOCIATED WITH MOVEMENTS, AND THE CONDITIONS ASSOCIATED WITH CONGREGATIONS AT DETERRENT BARRIERS CURRENTLY PRESENT IN THE MISSOURI RIVER BASIN WILL ALLOW FOR THE IDENTIFICATION OF LOCATIONS WHERE DETERRENCE TECHNOLOGIES, CONCENTRATED REMOVAL EFFORTS, PHYSICAL BARRIERS, OR OTHER EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES CAN BE UTILIZED FOR CONTAINMENT AND CONTROL. IDENTIFICATION AND EVALUATION OF CONTAINMENT OPPORTUNITIES CAN FACILITATE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF DETERRENT AND OR REMOVAL SYSTEMS THAT MAY LIMIT DISPERSAL, REPRODUCTION, OR RECRUITMENT OF INVASIVE CARP. A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE MOVEMENT AND BEHAVIOR OF INVASIVE CARP IN TRIBUTARIES AND IN ASSOCIATION WITH BARRIERS IS CRITICAL TO DEVISING STRATEGIES FOR SUCCESSFUL CONTAINMENT.

THE MIDDLE KLAMATH RIVER SUB-BASIN PLANNING CONTRIBUTES TO THE RESTORATION OF ANADROMOUS FISH AND ACHIEVE THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE KLAMATH RIVER BASIN CONSERVATION AREA FISHERY RESTORATION PROGRAM THROUGHOUT THE KLAMATH RIVER BY COORDINATING THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE MIDDLE KLAMATH RIVER SUB-BASIN PLAN, FISHERIES RESTORATION CANDIDATE ACTION TABLE, IN CONCERT WITH THE KLAMATH INTEGRATED RESTORATION AND MONITORING PLAN AND SIX RIVERS NATIONAL FOREST AQUATIC RESTORATION ACTION PLAN.TASKS INCLUDE CONTINUED ENGAGEMENT OF LOCAL COMMUNITIES, LANDOWNERS, AND PARTNERS TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT RESTORATION PROJECTS THAT RESPOND TO PROBLEMS RELATED TO FISHERY RECOVERY AND TO THE MIDDLE KLAMATH SUB-BASIN PLANNING PROCESS, AS WELL AS DISSEMINATE RESULTS RELATED TO RESTORATION AND MONITORING EFFORTS.

THE MID KLAMATH WATERSHED COUNCIL (MKWC)HAS BEEN A PART OF THE COOPERATIVE FALL CHINOOK SPAWNER SURVEYS FOR OVER 15 YEARS. THE COOPERATIVE SURVEYS ENTAIL WORKING WITH LOCAL FEDERAL, STATE, TRIBAL, AND NON-PROFIT GROUPS TO COLLECT POPULATION DATA ON RETURNING FALL ADULT CHINOOK SALMON ON TRIBUTARIES TO THE MID KLAMATH SUBBASIN.FOR OVER A DECADE, THE MID KLAMATH WATERSHED COUNCIL (MKWC) HAS SUCCESSFULLY IMPLEMENTED ITS PORTION OF THE COOPERATIVE FALL CHINOOK CARCASS SURVEY EFFORT WITH THE USDA FOREST SERVICE, CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AND OTHER PARTNERS TO ACHIEVE PROGRAM OBJECTIVES. THIS INCLUDES: 1.DETERMINING IN-RIVER RUN SIZE (ESCAPEMENT) OF CHINOOK SALMON WITHIN THE SALMON RIVER AND KLAMATH BASIN.2.DETERMINING RUN TIMING, SPAWNING DISTRIBUTION, LENGTH FREQUENCY, AND SEX RATIO FOR FALL CHINOOK SALMON. 3.COLLECTING FISH SCALE, TISSUE, AND OTOLITH SAMPLES, AND RECOVER HEADS FROM ADIPOSE FIN CLIPPED SALMON. 4.COLLECTING INCIDENTAL INFORMATION ON COHO SALMON AND STEELHEAD OBSERVED DURING THE COURSE OF THE STUDY.5.CONTRIBUTING TO REDD MAPPING EFFORTS BY ACQUIRING GPS WAYPOINTS AT ALL REDD LOCATIONS ON THE NORTH FORK, SOUTH FORK AND MAINSTEM SALMON RIVER.6.CONTINUING TO PROVIDE TRAINING AND EDUCATION TO VOLUNTEERS AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES.

THE SCOTT RIVER COORDINATION PROJECT WILL HELP SUPPORT THE CRITICAL EXCHANGE OF INFORMATION, DATA COLLECTION, RESTORATION PLANNING AND PHYSICAL RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WITHIN THE SCOTT RIVER WATERSHED, KLAMATH BASIN, SISKIYOU COUNTY, CALIFORNIA. THIS GRANT WILL HELP FUND ORGANIZATIONAL ELEMENTS OF THE SRWCS WORK IN ALL THESE AREAS OF RESTORATION.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS WORK IS TO PROVIDE FOR A LONG-TERM TREATY INDIAN CATCH MONITORING PROGRAM. CATCH DATA IS MAINTAINED IN A DATABASE COMPLIED FROM DATA INPUT BY STAFF AT THE NORTHWEST INDIAN FISHERIES COMMISSION AND TRIBAL STAFF, TAKEN DIRECTLY FROM FISH RECEIVING TICKETS THAT ALL FISH BUYERS ARE REQUIRED TO FILL OUT FOR EACH LANDING.THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS WORK IS TO PROVIDE FOR A LONG-TERM TREATY INDIAN CATCH MONITORING PROGRAM (TICMP). CATCH DATA IS MAINTAINED IN A DATABASE COMPILED FROM DATA INPUT BY STAFF AT THE NORTHWEST INDIAN FISHERIES COMMISSION (NWIFC) AND TRIBAL STAFF, TAKEN DIRECTLY FROM FISH RECEIVING TICKETS THAT ALL FISH BUYERS ARE REQUIRED TO FILL OUT FOR EACH LANDING. MANAGERS NEED ACCESS TO THIS DATA FOR PRE-SEASON PLANNING, IN-SEASON MANAGEMENT OF FISHERIES, AND FEDERAL REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.THE TICMP HAS PROVEN TO BE A SIGNIFICANT AREA OF COOPERATIVE WORKING RELATIONS BETWEEN THE TREATY TRIBES AND THE WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE SINCE 1978. CONTINUED SUPPORT FOR THIS PROGRAM WILL ENSURE CONTINUED COOPERATION IN THE COLLECTION AND RECONCILIATION OF FISHERIES CATCH AND EFFORT DATA.

THIS PROJECT IS SIGNIFICANT BECAUSE EVIDENCE INDICATES AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES (REFERRED TO AS AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES GOING FORWARD) CAN BE INTRODUCED AND SPREAD TO ALASKA THROUGH BOTH HUMAN-MEDIATED AND NATURAL PATHWAYS, E.G., OVERLAND TRANSPORT OF TRAILERED WATERCRAFT FROM DREISSENID MUSSEL INFESTED WATERS OR DISPERSAL OF EUROPEAN GREEN CRAB (CARCINUS MEANAS) LARVAE IN OCEAN CURRENTS. WARMING CLIMATE, INCLUDING SEA SURFACE TEMPERATURES, FACILITATE CHANGES IN HABITAT SUITABILITY FOR A SPECTRUM OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) NOT KNOW TO PRESENTLY OCCUR IN ALASKA. COLLABORATION ACROSS THE STATE WITH FEDERAL, STATE, TRIBAL, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTAL ENTITIES, LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS AND STAKEHOLDERS IS NECESSARY IN A STATE THE SIZE OF ALASKA AND WITH PATCHY DISTRIBUTION OF URBAN AREAS.

EVER INCREASING FRAGMENTATION AND HABITAT LOSS POSES SIGNIFICANT THREATS TO THE CONNECTIVITY OF AQUATIC ORGANISMS ACROSS THE BIODIVERSITY HOTSPOT OF THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES. CONSERVING AND RESTORING CONNECTIVITY WITHIN RIVERSCAPES BY REMOVING BARRIERS TO AQUATIC SPECIES MOVEMENT IS ONE OF THE MOST COST-EFFICIENT WAYS TO RESTORE PROPER ECOLOGICAL FUNCTION. RESTORING AQUATIC CONNECTIVITY OVER SMALL STREAM REACHES OR RIVER SEGMENTS HAS LIMITED VALUE IN MOST INSTANCES, SO MANAGERS AND SCIENTISTS HAVE INVESTED MORE RESOURCES IN RECENT DECADES TO BUILD SPATIAL TOOLS THAT EVALUATE BENEFITS OF RESTORING CONNECTIVITY ACROSS ENTIRE WATERSHEDS. BARRIER ASSESSMENT TOOLS HAVE IMPROVED PLANNING, DESIGN, AND THE SCALE OF EFFECTIVENESS OF RESTORATION. HOWEVER, AS WE PRIORITIZE RESTORATION OF LARGER WATERSHED AREAS IT BECOMES INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT TO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE RELATIVE INFLUENCE OF BARRIERS BY INCORPORATING BETTER BIOLOGICAL RANKING METRICS. STATIC MEASURES CAN MISS THE INFLUENCE OF TEMPORAL VARIATION IN HYDROLOGY THAT MAY PROVIDE TEMPORARY CONNECTIVITY ACROSS SOME BARRIERS. GENETIC INDICATORS CAN CAPTURE LONGER-TERM ISOLATION ACROSS BARRIERS AND HELP TO DECREASE UNCERTAINTY IN PRIORITIZING BARRIERS FOR REMOVAL.IN ADDITION TO VETTING A NEW APPROACH IN BARRIER ASSESSMENTS, THIS WORK ENHANCES ONGOING WORK THAT IS CURRENTLY ADDRESSING MULTIPLE RECOMMENDED RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR THE FEDERALLY THREATENED LOUISIANA PEARLSHELL MUSSEL (LPM  MARGARITIFERA HEMBELI). THE CURRENT RECOVERY PROJECT FOR THIS SPECIES IS JOINTLY FUNDED BY FAC AND ES AND ASSESSING THE IMPACT OF BARRIERS ON HOST FISH SPECIES AND RIVER NETWORK CONNECTIVITY BY MONITORING FISH MOVEMENT ACROSS PREVIOUSLY IDENTIFIED BARRIERS IN THE LPM MANAGEMENT AREA. BY INTEGRATING WITH THAT WORK, WE CAN VALIDATE THE USE OF RECENT ADVANCES IN CONSERVATION GENOMIC TOOLS AS A MEASURE OF STREAM NETWORK CONNECTIVITY. THE WORK WILL INFORM FUTURE MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION EFFORTS FOR LPM, EVALUATE THE EFFICACY OF GENETIC TOOLS TO ASSESS RESTORATION SUCCESS, AS WELL AS AID IN THE IMPROVEMENT OF A STRATEGIC BARRIER PRIORITIZATION FRAMEWORK. ADDITIONALLY, AS SUBSTANTIAL UNCERTAINTY REMAINS AROUND POTENTIAL HOST SPECIES OF LPM, WE PROPOSE TO UTILIZE GENETIC METABARCODING TO DETERMINE THE IDENTITY OF GLOCHIDIA ENCYSTED ON WILD CAUGHT FISH. RECOGNITION OF HOST SPECIES WILL SUPPORT AND FOCUS FUTURE RECOVERY EFFORTS AND ALLOW FOR A MORE HOLISTIC APPROACH TO LPM RESTORATION AND RECOVERY EFFORTS.

THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT VARIOUS IMPORTANT ADMINISTRATIVE AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE SHASTA RIVER. THE FOCUS IS ON GRANT WRITING, COOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT AND COMMUNICATIONS WITH RESOURCE PARTNERS, LANDOWNERS, AGENCIES AND GROUPS AS WELL AS BASIC STRUCTURAL MEETING SUPPORT.

THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT YUROK TRIBAL FISHERIES DEPARTMENT (YTFD) COORDINATE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WITHIN THE LOWER KLAMATH TO BENEFIT NATIVE ANADROMOUS FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC DEPENDENT WILDLIFE. YTFD WILL COORDINATE WITH NUMEROUS LOWER KLAMATH PARTNERS INCLUDING VARIOUS YUROK TRIBE NATURAL RESOURCE DEPARTMENTS, FIORI GEOSCIENCES, GREEN DIAMOND RESOURCE COMPANY, WESTERN RIVERS CONSERVANCY, STATE AND FEDERAL RESOURCE AGENCIES, AND OTHER PERTINENT BASIN PARTNERS. THE GOAL IS TO SUPPORT DEVELOPMENT   IMPLEMENTATION OF PRIORITY LOWER KLAMATH FISHERIES RESTORATION. ALL PROJECT ASPECTS WILL BE DOCUMENTED IN A FINAL PROGRESS REPORT THAT WILL CONTAIN: 1) A COMPARISON OF ACTUAL ACCOMPLISHMENTS WITH THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE APPROVED SCOPE OF WORK  2) A DESCRIPTION OF REASONS WHY ESTABLISHED GOALS WERE NOT MET, IF APPROPRIATE  AND 3) ANY OTHER PERTINENT INFORMATION RELEVANT TO THE PROJECT RESULTS.

THIS PROJECT IS A COOPERATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN THE U.S. FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICE, U. S. FOREST SERVICE, KLAMATH NATIONAL FOREST, SIX RIVER NATIONAL FOREST  THE SALMON RIVER RESTORATION COUNCIL  THE QUARTZ VALLEY INDIAN RESERVATION  THE NORTHERN CALIFORNIA RESOURCE CENTER  THE MID-KLAMATH WATERSHED COUNCIL  AND THE SISKIYOU RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICT. THE KARUK AND YUROK TRIBES AND THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (CDFWS) WILL DIRECT THIS SURVEY, AND ARE ALSO CONTRIBUTORS TO THIS EFFORT. THE CDFWS HAS BEEN CHARGED WITH DETERMINING CHINOOK SPAWNER ESCAPEMENT IN THE KLAMATH RIVER UPSTREAM OF WEITCHPEC SINCE 1978. THE DATA GENERATED BY CDFWS HAS BEEN AND CONTINUES TO BE VALUABLE FOR THE DETERMINATION OF HARVEST LEVELS FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF KLAMATH RIVER FISH STOCKS. CDFWS USES A COMBINATION OF COUNTING WEIRS, SPAWNER CARCASS SURVEYS, REDD SURVEYS, AND HATCHERY RETURNS TO DEVELOP THESE IMPORTANT ESTIMATES. THIS ONE YEAR SURVEY WILL DETERMINE IN-RIVER RUN SIZE (ESCAPEMENT) OF CHINOOK SALMON WITHIN THE SHASTA, SCOTT, AND SALMON RIVER BASINS AND OTHER MAJOR TRIBUTARIES TO THE MIDDLE KLAMATH RIVER DURING THE 2023 SEASON (OCTOBER THROUGH DECEMBER, 2023). INFORMATION WILL BE COLLECTED ON RUN TIMING, SPAWNING DISTRIBUTION, LENGTH FREQUENCY, AND SEX RATIO FOR FALL CHINOOK SALMON. THE SURVEY PROVIDES FOR THE RECOVERY OF CODED WIRE TAG INFORMATION AND SCALES FOR AGE CLASS DETERMINATION. ADDITIONALLY, INFORMATION ON COHO SALMON AND STEELHEAD OBSERVED DURING THE COURSE OF THE SURVEY WILL BE DOCUMENTED.

THIS ONE-YEAR SPAWNING GROUND STUDY WILL DETERMINE IN-RIVER RUN SIZE OF CHINOOK SALMON WITHIN THE SALMON RIVER BASINS DURING THE 2023 FALL SEASON (OCTOBER THROUGH DECEMBER) WITH COOPERATORS HOLDING PLANNING MEETINGS STARTING IN JULY OR AUGUST BEFORE THE SURVEY SEASON.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENABLE MICRA TO CONTINUE TO HOST AND SUPPORTTHE OPERATIONS OF THE MRBP IN 2023-2027. THE MRBP WILL HOLD IN-PERSON COORDINATION MEETINGSAT LEAST ONCE ANNUALLY TO IDENTIFY AND ADDRESS REGIONAL AIS PRIORITIES, PARTICULARLY RELATED TOPREVENTION AND CONTROL, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH, AND RESEARCH AND RISK ASSESSMENT, AND TOPROVIDE FOR COORDINATION OF AIS PROGRAMS IN THE REGION THAT ADDRESS THESE PRIORITIES. THE MRBPMEMBERS WILL DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE TASK FORCE TO ADDRESS AIS PRIORITIES ON REGIONALAND NATIONAL SCALES. THROUGH THE COORDINATION OF MRBP MEMBERS AND AIS PROGRAMS, THE PANELWILL DEVELOP AND PROVIDE ADVICE TO THE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE INDIVIDUALS AND ENTITIES ON METHODS TOPREVENT AND CONTROL AIS. MICRA WILL PROVIDE THE TASK FORCE WITH AN ANNUAL REPORT ON THEMRBPS ACTIVITIES

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO MINIMIZE THE HARMFUL ECOLOGICAL, ECONOMIC, AND HUMAN HEALTH IMPACTS OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES THROUGH THE PREVENTION AND MANAGEMENT OF THEIR INTRODUCTION, EXPANSION, AND DISPERSAL INTO, WITHIN AND FROM PENNSYLVANIA. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE LEADERSHIP, COORDINATION, AND POLICY ACTIVITIES THROUGH CONTINUED PARTICIPATION IN STATE, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES FORUMS  OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES THROUGH CONTINUED DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PROGRAMS AND MATERIALS TO PREVENT AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES INTRODUCTION AND SPREAD ACROSS PENNSYLVANIA  SUPPORT FOR A MOBILE SELF-SERVICE BOAT CLEANING FACILITY  DEVELOPING AND INSTALLING AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) INFORMATIONAL SIGNAGE  AND THE ACQUISITION OF BIOSECURITY GEAR AND SUPPLIES FOR STATE FISH HATCHERY STAFF PROPAGATING AND STOCKING SPORT FISH IN PENNSYLVANIA WATERS TO BETTER IMPLEMENT BIOSECURITY PLANS AND DEVELOP HAZARD ANALYSIS CRITICAL CONTROL POINT (HACCP) PLANS FOR STOCKING AND HATCHERY OPERATIONS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION OF PENNSYLVANIA INVASIVE SPECIES ISSUES WITH GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND INDUSTRY MEMBERS  PROVIDING EDUCATION AND INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC ABOUT INVASIVE SPECIES AND METHODS OF PREVENTING THEIR INTRODUCTION AND SPREAD  PROVIDING A MOBILE BOAT CLEANING STATION FOR BOATERS TO CLEAN AND DRY THEIR BOAT AND GEAR BEFORE DEPARTING A BOAT ACCESS AREA  PROVIDING REGIONALLY IMPORTANT AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) MESSAGING TO ANGLERS  AND TO FACILITATE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF HACCP PLANS FOR STATE FISH HATCHERY OPERATIONS AND ENHANCE BIOSECURITY OPERATIONS TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF AIS AND AQUATIC PATHOGENS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE CITIZENS AND WATERWAYS OF PENNSYLVANIA. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE LEADERSHIP, COORDINATION, AND POLICY ACTIVITIES, OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES, AND SUPPORT OF THE MOBILE SELF-SERVICE BOAT CLEANING FACILITY.

PURPOSE. SUBMERGED AQUATIC INVASIVE GRASSES (SAIG) POSE RISKS TO AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS SUPPORTING THE WORLD S MOST PRODUCTIVE WILD SALMON FISHERIES, WHICH PROVIDE ALASKA S SUBSISTENCE AND PERSONAL USE FISHERIES APPROXIMATELY 2 MILLION SALMON PER YEAR AND THE NATION NEARLY  2 BILLION IN ANNUAL LABOR INCOME. THE ESTABLISHMENT OF ELODIA (ELODEA SPP.) HAS SHOWN THAT ALASKA HAS A NARROWING WINDOW OF OPPORTUNITY PREVENTING THE FURTHER SPREAD OF ELODEA AND THE INTRODUCTION AND POTENTIAL ESTABLISHMENT OF OTHER SAIG SUCH AS HYDRILLA (HYDRILLA VERTICILLATA) AND MILFOIL (MYRIOPHYLLUM SPICATUM).HUMAN BEHAVIORS ARE AT THE CENTER OF HUMAN-MEDIATED SPREAD OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) AND ARE INFLUENCED BY A RANGE OF PSYCHOLOGICAL FACTORS THAT VARY ACROSS CONTEXTS AND POPULATIONS. OUTREACH AND EDUCATION HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED FOR EFFECTIVE PREVENTION OF AIS SPREAD AND ESTABLISHMENT IN ALASKA. BETTER UNDERSTANDING THE ALASKA-SPECIFIC DEMOGRAPHIC AND PSYCHOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS AND IMPEDIMENTS TO COMPLIANCE ARE A PREREQUISITE FOR TARGETED OUTREACH AND EDUCATION. IN ADDITION, QUANTIFYING THE ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF SAIG MANAGEMENT INFORMS PUBLIC POLICY, JUSTIFIES PUBLIC INVESTMENT, AND INFORMS FUNDING INNOVATION.THIS PROJECT ALIGNS WITH PRIORITY RESEARCH NEED 1 LISTED IN THE SOLICITATION:  VECTOR AND PATHWAY ASSESSMENT, SPECIFICALLY CONDUCTING SOCIAL SCIENCE ANALYSIS TO UNDERSTAND HOW TO IMPROVE BEHAVIOR CHANGE TO PREVENT FURTHER SPREAD.  THIS PROJECT ALSO SUPPORTS PRIORITIES LISTED IN THE ANSTF NATIONAL PRIORITIES LIST OF RESEARCH AND AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES 2021, THE ANSTF STRATEGIC PLAN FOR 2020-2025, AND THE ARCTIC INVASIVE ALIEN SPECIES (ARIAS) STRATEGY AND ACTION PLAN.ACTIVITIES. 10 01 23 - 09 30 26 WITH PARTNERS FROM STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES AND STAKEHOLDERS WE WILL LEVERAGE EXISTING RESOURCES, CROSS-AGENCY COLLABORATION TO ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES:1. ELICIT LOCAL ATTITUDES, AWARENESS, BELIEFS, AND BEHAVIORAL FACTORS RELATED TO SAIG MANAGEMENT AND PREVENTION.2. QUANTIFY THE ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF SAIG MANAGEMENT AND ANALYZE RESOURCE USER SUBGROUPS GIVEN BEHAVIORAL TRAITS, DEMOGRAPHICS, AND OTHER CHARACTERISTICS.DELIVERABLES.1. ONE PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATION, INCLUDING SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION DETAILING ANALYSIS OF SURVEY RESPONSES.2. PRESENTATION OF RESEARCH RESULTS AT AKISP ANNUAL INVASIVE SPECIES WORKSHOP.3. SURVEY DATASET AND CODE ARCHIVED WITH OPEN ACCESS AT THE NSF ARCTIC DATA CENTER.EXPECTED OUTCOMES.1) TARGETED OUTREACH AND MESSAGING THROUGH IDENTIFYING SUBGROUPS WITH COMMON CHARACTERISTICS.2) OPTIMIZED PUBLIC POLICY THROUGH QUANTIFYING THE PUBLIC ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF SAIG PREVENTION AND MANAGEMENT.3) INFORMED RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ACCOUNTING FOR PUBLIC PREFERENCES AND VALUES.4) RAISED AWARENESS AND IMPROVED PUBLIC OUTREACH THROUGH RESOURCE USER ENGAGEMENT.INCLUDED BENEFICIARIES. PEOPLE WHO DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY VALUE AND USER NATURAL AQUATIC RESOURCES, ESPECIALLY SALMON, BENEFIT FROM THIS RESEARCH AS IT INFORMS MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES IN PREVENTING SAIG FROM SPREADING AND ESTABLISHING IN ALASKA. OTHER JURISDICTIONS AND WESTERNS STATES BENEFIT FROM OUR APPROACH AS IT CAN BE APPLIED TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HUMAN BEHAVIOR REGARDING SPREAD OF INVASIVE SPECIES IN GENERAL. BENEFICIARIES OF FISHERIES AND AQUATIC RESOURCES INCLUDE INDIGENOUS POPULATIONS WHO PRACTICE SUBSISTENCE LIFESTYLES, WITH SALMON SERVICING A CENTRAL CULTURAL ROLE IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING FOOD SECURITY. ADDITIONAL BENEFICIARIES OF SAIG PREVENTION AND SALMON CONSERVATION INCLUDE: RECREATIONAL AND PERSONAL-USE ANGLERS, GUIDES, AND OUTFITTERS, PRIVATE AND PUBLIC MARINA OWNERS AND USERS, AS WELL AS COMMERCIAL SALMON FISHERIES STAKEHOLDERS INCLUDING PROCESSORS, HARVESTERS, SALMON PERMIT OWNERS, SALMON ENHANCEMENT ORGANIZATION AND HOUSEHOLDS THAT RELY ON HYDROPOWER. LASTLY, TRUST RESOURCES SUCH AS RESIDENT FRESHWATER FISH, BEARS, AND MIGRATORY BIRDS WILL INDIRECTLY BENEFIT FROM PREVENTION MEASURES INFORMED BY THE RESEARCH.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE TO EDUCATE, TRAIN AND INVOLVE COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND COORDINATE WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO PROTECT AND RESTORE ANADROMOUS FISHERIES IN THE SALMON RIVER SUBBASIN THROUGH COOPERATIVE PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION EFFORTS.SALMON RIVER RESTORATION COUNCIL (SRRC) IS CONTINUING TO WORK ON FOSTERING THE VISION, DIRECTION, GOALS, AND OBJECTIVES DEFINED BY THE SALMON RIVER COMMUNITY RESTORATION PROGRAM (CRP).  THE CRP ADDRESSES THE NEGATIVE IMPACTS OF PAST CATASTROPHIC FIRES AND FIRE MANAGEMENT, TIMBER HARVEST, ROAD CONSTRUCTION, MINING, GRAZING, FLOODS, RESIDENTIAL AND RECREATIONAL USE, AND THE INHERENT CHALLENGES FACE BY OUR COMMUNITY.THE SRRC IS A CHIEF PROMOTER OF COOPERATIVE ACTIONS WITHIN THE LOCAL COMMUNITY AND AMONG THE STAKEHOLDERS OF THE SALMON RIVER SUB-BASIN.  STAKEHOLDERS INCLUDE LOCAL RESIDENTS, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, THE KARUK TRIBE OF CALIFORNIA, MANAGING AGENCIES, AND OTHERS.  THE CRP HELPS TO FILL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT GAPS THROUGH SMALL AND NON-TRADITIONAL PROJECTS.  IT INVOLVES COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN AN EDUCATIONAL SERIES OF RESTORATION RELATED WORKSHOPS AND WORKDAYS.  IN ADDITION, IT MAINTAINS THE WATERSHED CENTER IN SAWYERS BAR, WHICH PROVIDES WATERSHED PROTECTION AND RESTORATION INFORMATION TO THE COMMUNITY, AGENCIES AND THE PUBLIC, AND PROVIDES A SPACE FOR MEETINGS AND WORKSHOPS.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS FOR THE VERMONT DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION TO SUPPORT EFFORTS IN THE LAKE CHAMPLAIN BASIN REGION TO REDUCE THE THREATS OF AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES (ANS) FOUND WITHIN AND OUTSIDE OF THE BASIN THROUGH SCIENCE-BASED AND ECOLOGICALLY ACCEPTED MANAGEMENT PRACTICES.
