ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE CONDUCTING EARLY DETECTION AND SPREAD PREVENTION ACTIVITIES THAT INCLUDED TRAINING AND EDUCATION OUTREACH ACTIVITIES FOR A WIDE VARIETY OF AUDIENCES  MONITORING, SURVEYING AND HARVESTING ANS BY STATE AGENTS AND TRAINED CONTRACTED STAFF  AND ACQUISITION AND DEVELOPMENT OF SUPPLIES, PUBLICATIONS, AND SIGNAGE, ETC. TO ASSIST THOSE INDIVIDUALS WHO DIRECTLY INTERACT WITH OR ARE RESPONSIBLE THESE ACTIVITIES. ADDITIONAL ACTIVITIES INCLUDE TRAINING AND SUPPORT FOR WATERCRAFT INSPECTIONS, RESEARCHING AND ANALYZING MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES WITHIN EXISTING WATERBODIES WITH ANS, AND PRIORITIZING AT-RISK WATERBODIES AND NEW POTENTIAL THREATS NOT YET FOUND IN THE BASIN. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE A REDUCTION IN ANS THREATS TO NON-INFESTED WATERBODIES, MAINTAINING HEALTHY AND SUSTAINABLE NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES POPULATIONS WITHIN ALL WATERBODIES AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS, AND A BROADER CAPACITY OF UNDERSTANDING OF ANS THREATS BY THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THERE ARE NO SUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES POSE SIGNIFICANT ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC THREATS TO AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS IN OKLAHOMA. INVASIVE CARP (SILVER AND BIGHEAD CARP) HAVE BEEN PRESENT IN THE LOWER RED RIVER WATERSHED AND ITS TRIBUTARIES SINCE AT LEAST 2012 AND BIGHEAD CARP IN THE NEOSHO RIVER GRAND LAKE SYSTEM SINCE 1992. BOTH SILVER AND BIGHEAD CARP ARE FOUND WITHIN THE ARKANSAS RIVER IN ARKANSAS, BUT NO REPORTS HAVE BEEN MADE IN OKLAHOMA THUS FAR. THESE SYSTEMS ARE ACTIVELY BEING STUDIED BY ODWC AND UNIVERSITIES. BIGHEADED CARP AS WELL AS OTHER INVASIVE SPECIES IN NEIGHBORING STATES POSE ECONOMIC AND ECOLOGICAL THREATS TO THE STATE S AQUATIC RESOURCES. IF ESTABLISHED, INVASIVE CARP COULD CAUSE SIGNIFICANT ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC HARM BY CAUSING UNPLEASANT EXPERIENCES FOR ANGLERS OR RECREATIONAL USERS. THE AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES COORDINATOR AND TECHNICIAN HAVE A VARIETY OF OTHER RESPONSIBILITIES TO REVIEW VARIOUS AQUATIC PERMITS FOR THE AGENCY, WRITE REGULATION CHANGES, IF NECESSARY, ATTEND CONFERENCES TO PARTICIPATE IN INVASIVE SPECIES COMMITTEES, DISSEMINATE INFORMATION, AND LEARN FROM OTHER STATES MANAGEMENT PRACTICES OF INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT. MEETINGS ARE ATTENDED OFTEN WEEKLY TO COORDINATE WITH LOCAL MUNICIPALITIES, NON-GOVERNMENTAL GROUPS, TRIBES, STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES REGARDING INVASIVE SPECIES. ADDITIONALLY, WE PLAN UPDATE AND INCREASE SIGNAGE STATEWIDE. WE ARE ALSO WORKING WITH OUR COMMUNICATIONS DEPARTMENT TO SEND OUT NEWSLETTERS, PRESS RELEASES, SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS AND INFORMATIONAL LETTERS TO OUR CONSTITUENTS. WE ARE ALSO RESPONSIBLE FOR ANSWERING VARIOUS REGULATION QUESTIONS FROM THE PUBLIC, PROVIDING TRAINING TO AGENCY STAFF ON THE DECONTAMINATION, REPORTING AND IDENTIFICATION OF AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES, AND REVIEW OUR STATE REGULATIONS.

USFWS HEREBY INCORPORATES THE RECIPIENTS APPLICATION, SUBMITTED TO AND APPROVED BY THE USFWS, INTO THESE AWARD TERMS AND CONDITIONS. SINCE WYOMING AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) PLAN S APPROVAL, WYOMING HAS BEEN AWARDED A TOTAL OF  610,203 FROM THE USFWS FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PLAN S OBJECTIVES.  THIS FUNDING WILL GREATLY INCREASE AIS PREVENTION ACTIVITIES BY ALLOWING WYOMING TO PROVIDE SIX ADDITIONAL SEASONAL EMPLOYEES TO CONDUCT WATERCRAFT INSPECTIONS AND DECONTAMINATIONS, AS WELL AS PROVIDE OUTREACH AND EDUCATION TO THE PUBLIC AND ASSIST IN MONITORING WATERS WITHIN THE STATE - AS OUTLINED IN THE WYOMING AIS PLAN . WYOMING AIS PLAN WAS APPROVED BY THE USFWS ANTSF IN 2012.

THE PROJECT PURPOSES ARE TO REDUCE THE SPREAD OF INVASIVE AQUATIC ORGANISMS AND TO TRAIN MAINE STATE BIOLOGISTS IN TECHNIQUES TO RECLAIM WATER BODIES OF INVASIVE FISH.  EACH PURPOSE CONTRIBUTES TO THE GOAL OF PROTECTING MAINES FRESHWATER NATIVE PLANT AND ANIMAL HABITAT.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE: 1. VOLUNTARY INSPECTIONS OF WATERCRAFT, TRAILERS AND EQUIPMENT AT BOAT ACCESS SITES  AND 2. FORMAL TRAINING OF STATE BIOLOGISTS IN RECLAMATION OF WATERS WHERE INVASIVE FISH HAVE BEEN ILLEGALLY INTRODUCED.  ONE EXPECTED OUTCOME IS TO MAKE BOATERS FAMILIAR WITH THE CLEAN, DRAIN DRY APPROACH TO PREVENTING SPREAD OF INVASIVE SPECIES SUCH THAT BOATERS TAKE INITIATIVE TO INSPECT BOATS AND GEAR EVEN IF NO INSPECTOR IS PRESENT.  A SECOND EXPECTED OUTCOME IS TO INCREASE THE ABILITY OF STATE BIOLOGISTS TO RESPOND TO ILLEGAL STOCKING OF INVASIVE FISH SPECIES.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE ALL USERS AND MANAGERS OF INLAND WATERS IN MAINE.  THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE FOURTH YEAR OF OUR LONG ISLAND AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) PROGRAM IS INTENDED TO CONTROL AND CONTAIN AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES IN NASSAU AND SUFFOLK COUNTIES. THE AIS COORDINATOR AND THREE-PERSON AIS TEAM WILL PROVIDE BOATER EDUCATION AND OUTREACH AS WELL AS BOAT INSPECTIONS AT BOTH MARINE AND FRESHWATER LAUNCHES. THE TEAM WILL MONITOR AND SURVEY AQUATIC PLANTS ACROSS LONG ISLAND THE TEAM WILL ALSO COLLABORATE WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO CONDUCT REMOVAL OF WATER CHESTNUT, SMALL POPULATIONS OF PURPLE LOOSESTRIFE, FLOATING WATER PRIMROSE, AND SMALL POPULATIONS OF PHRAGMITES. AQUATIC PLANT SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED AT ALL LOCATIONS TO MONITOR EFFICACY OF THE REMOVAL EFFORTS. IN ADDITION, THE TEAM WILL PROVIDE EDUCATION AND OUTREACH AT PUBLIC EVENTS IN AN EFFORT TO RAISE AWARENESS ABOUT AIS AND PROMOTE BEHAVIOR CHANGE (E.G., ADOPTING THE CLEAN, DRAIN, DRY PROTOCOL) ON LONG ISLAND. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE INCREASED PUBLIC AWARENESS ABOUT AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES, INCREASED COVERAGE BY NATIVE PLANTS, ALONG WITH INCREASES IN NATIVE ANIMALS, AT LOCATIONS WHERE REMOVAL EFFORTS HAVE OCCURRED, AND INCREASED ACCESS FOR WATER RECREATION. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE AQUATIC ENVIRONMENTS IN NEW YORK. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES IS REQUESTING FUNDING FOR THE STATEWIDE MANAGEMENT OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS). AIS MANAGEMENT IS A HIGH PRIORITY FOR ALL LAND MANAGERS IN ALASKA, AND IF LEFT UNMANAGED, AIS CAN SPREAD RAPIDLY AND DISPLACE NATIVE PLANTS, FISH, WILDLIFE, AND THEIR HABITATS.  ALASKA HAS ONLY ONE AIS (ELODEA SPP.) CURRENTLY, BUT THE THREAT OF OTHER AIS IS EMINENT. THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES IS THE AGENCY RESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGING ALASKAS INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES, INCLUDING AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES.  THIS GRANT WOULD BOLSTER ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES ABILITY TO LOCATE, MANAGE AND ERADICATE AIS THROUGH EARLY DETECTION SURVEYS, MONITORED EFFECTIVENESS OF CONTROL ACTIONS, AND ASSIST WITH TRAVEL, RESEARCH EQUIPMENT, AND OTHER POTENTIAL ACTIVITIES, SUCH AS OUTREACH AND COORDINATION EFFORTS THAT IMPROVE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. WE INTEND TO:1. CONDUCT SURVEYS TO MONITOR THE EFFECTIVENESS OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES HERBICIDE TREATMENTS STATEWIDE.2. CONDUCT STUDIES TO OBTAIN HYDROLOGIC DATA PRIOR TO HERBICIDE TREATMENTS, AND IN OTHER POTENTIALLY INFESTED WATER BODIES, AS NEEDED.3. PROVIDE TRANSPORTATION (GROUND, BOAT, AND AERIAL) FOR PERSONNEL TO TANANA RIVER, ALEXANDER LAKE, SUCKER LAKE, AND OTHER POTENTIALLY INFESTED REMOTE WATER BODIES, AS NEEDED, TO SURVEY AND MONITOR ELODEA AND OTHER AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES POPULATIONS.4. CONDUCT EARLY DETECTION AERIAL AND GROUND SURVEYS IN HIGH USE, HIGH-RISK WATER BODIES FOR ELODEA AND OTHER AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES IN SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA, INTERIOR ALASKA, AND THE KENAI PENINSULA.ELODEA ERADICATION IS CRUCIAL TO SUPPORT ALASKAS SUSTAINABLE NATURAL RESOURCES. ELODEA GROWS RAPIDLY, IS EASILY TRANSFERABLE, OVERTAKES NATIVE VEGETATION, REDUCES NATIVE FISH HABITAT, ALTERS FLOW PATTERNS, AND INCREASES SEDIMENTATION. ELODEA DISRUPTS NATURAL BIODIVERSITY, IS A NAVIGATION HAZARD TO BOATS AND FLOATPLANES, INTERFERES WITH WATER-BASED RECREATION, AND HAS THE POTENTIAL TO LOWER WATERFRONT PROPERTY VALUES. OVERALL THIS PROJECT IS A BENEFIT TO THE NATURAL RESOURCES OF ALASKA.

THE FOCUS OF THE GREAT LAKES PANEL ON AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES (GLP) IS TO BUILD REGIONAL CAPACITY FOR AIS PREVENTION AND CONTROL TARGETING POTENTIAL NEW INTRODUCTIONS AND ESTABLISHED POPULATIONS OF AIS IN THE GREAT LAKES-ST. LAWRENCE RIVER ECOSYSTEM. GLP INITIATIVES, SUPPORTED BY STAFF OF THE GREAT LAKES COMMISSION, ARE DEVELOPED AND IMPLEMENTED TO ADDRESS PRIORITY AIS PROBLEMS RENDERING NEGATIVE IMPACTS UPON THE ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC RESOURCES OF THE REGION. GLP COMMITTEES ARE ESTABLISHED TO SET PRIORITIES AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT IN THE SEARCH FOR SOLUTIONS TO THESE CHALLENGING PROBLEMS. THE GLP HAS PLAYED A SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN ADVANCING AIS PREVENTION AND CONTROL IN THE GREAT LAKES-ST. LAWRENCE RIVER REGION SINCE PASSAGE OF NANPCA, AND WILL CONTINUE TO DO SO UNDER THIS PROJECT WITH AN EMPHASIS ON REGIONAL COORDINATION AND COLLABORATION.THE GLP BENEFITS FROM FUNDING SUPPORT PROVIDED BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION. THIS REQUEST FOR SUPPORT FROM THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WILL SUPPORT BASELINE FUNCTIONS OF THE GLP FOR THE PERIOD OF JULY 1, 2023 - JUNE 30, 2028, INCLUDING BASIC OPERATIONS OF THE GLP AND ITS COMMITTEES, AND ADVISING THE FEDERAL ANSTF. THE PERFORMANCE OF THIS AGREEMENT SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE UPON SIGNATURE FOR A TOTAL PERIOD OF FIVE YEARS. FEDERAL FISCAL YEAR 2023 FUNDING IS REQUESTED IN THE AMOUNT OF  50,000 TO BEGIN THIS AGREEMENT, WITH FUTURE ADDITIONAL FUNDING CONTINGENT UPON THE AVAILABILITY OF ANNUAL FEDERAL APPROPRIATIONS.PROJECT GOALS   OBJECTIVESTHE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ADVANCE AIS PREVENTION AND CONTROL IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION THROUGH THE ACTIVITIES OF THE GLP, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON REGIONAL COORDINATION AND COLLABORATION. THIS GOAL WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH THREE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES, DESCRIBED IN MORE DETAIL BELOW:1. COORDINATE GLP OPERATIONS2. ADVISE THE FEDERAL ANSTF3. ESTABLISH AND SUPPORT GLP COMMITTEESTHE GLC WILL DESIGNATE ONE STAFF MEMBER TO SERVE AS GLP COORDINATOR, PROVIDING PRIMARY OPERATIONAL SUPPORT TO THE GLP AND MANAGING THE EXECUTION OF THIS PROJECT. OTHER GLC STAFF MAY ASSIST AS NEEDED AND AS FUNDING ALLOWS.

THE ANS TASK FORCE SERVES TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A PROGRAM FOR WATERS OF THE UNITED STATES TO PREVENT THE INTRODUCTION AND DISPERSAL OF ANS, MONITOR, CONTROL, AND STUDY SUCH SPECIES AND DISSEMINATE RELATED INFORMATION. THE WESTERN REGIONAL PANEL ON ANS (WRP), ONE OF 6 REGIONAL PANELS OF THE ANS TASK FORCE, HELPS IDENTIFY AND ADDRESS LARGE-SCALE REGIONAL AIS MANAGEMENT NEEDS ACROSS 19 WESTERN STATES OF THE US. THE WRP HAS AN ACTIVE MEMBERSHIP REPRESENTING STATE, FEDERAL, TRIBAL, ACADEMIC, NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION, AND BUSINESS ENTITIES WITH SHARED INTEREST IN WESTERN AIS MANAGEMENT ISSUES. THE BROAD LANDSCAPE FOOTPRINT AND LARGE MEMBERSHIP PARTICIPATION OF THE WRP REQUIRES STRONG STRATEGIC COMMUNICATION TO EFFECTIVELY ADDRESS AIS ACROSS THE WEST AND WORK RESPONSIVELY WITH THE ANS TASK FORCE. THIS PROJECT, COORDINATION OF THE WESTERN REGIONAL PANEL ON ANS, WILL BRING CONSISTENT AND LONG-TERM COORDINATION TO PROVIDE INSTITUTIONAL KNOWLEDGE, MAINTAIN AND SHARE THE BEST AVAILABLE AIS MANAGEMENT INFORMATION AND ADVANCE NEW AIS MANAGEMENT NEEDS. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE HIGH-QUALITY COORDINATION TO ENSURE THAT THE DAILY FUNCTIONING AND ANNUAL OBJECTIVES ARE FULFILLED. THE COORDINATION OF THE WRP IS THE PRIMARY NEED FULFILLED BY THIS OPPORTUNITY. THE WRP LEADERSHIP AND MEMBERSHIP IS AN ALL-VOLUNTEER BODY, WITH CONSERVATION COLLABORATIONS PROVIDING QUALITY COORDINATION OF FOLLOW-THROUGH AND CONSISTENCY WHERE AND WHEN IT IS NEEDED MOST. SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES INCLUDE A. PROVIDE CONSISTENT AND ACCURATE INFORMATION ABOUT THE WRP ACTIVITIES AND BUSINESS, AND B. CONDUCT WRP BUSINESS ACTIVITIES AS DIRECTED BY THE WRP LEADERSHIP.THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE IMPLEMENTATION OF COORDINATION AND COMMUNICATION OF THE WESTERN REGIONAL PANEL ON ANS ARE WESTERN NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, AND THE PUBLIC WITH SUBSEQUENT IMPROVED MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL AQUATIC RESOURCES ACROSS THE WESTERN UNITED STATES FROM AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES.

SECTION 1203(C) OF THE NONINDIGENOUS AQUATIC NUISANCE PREVENTION AND CONTROL ACT OF 1990 (AS AMENDED, 1996) (NANPCA) REQUIRES THAT THE AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES (ANS) TASK FORCE ENCOURAGE THE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF THE PARTICIPATION AND ADVICE FROM REGIONAL PANELS. IN 1998, THE ANS TASK FORCE ADDRESSED CONCERNS REGARDING THE GEOGRAPHIC SCOPE OF REGIONAL PANELS BY PROPOSING A CONFIGURATION OF SEVEN GEOGRAPHIC AREAS. THE NORTHEAST WAS IDENTIFIED AT THAT TIME AS A GEOGRAPHIC AREA FOR PANEL REPRESENTATION. THE NORTHEAST AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES PANEL (NEANS PANEL) OF THE AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES TASK FORCE WAS APPROVED IN JULY 2001. PURSUANT TO SECTION 1203 OF NANPCA, THE NEANS PANEL ADVISES AND MAKES RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES TAKE FORCE ON ISSUES RELATING TO THE NORTHEAST REGION OF THE UNITED STATES. THE NEANS PANEL IS COMPOSED OF REPRESENTATIVES FROM AGENCIES AND OTHER ORGANIZATIONS FROM THE STATES OF CONNECTICUT, MAINE, MASSACHUSETTS, NEW HAMPSHIRE, NEW YORK, RHODE ISLAND, AND VERMONT AND AS OBSERVERS FROM THE CANADIAN PROVINCES OF NEW BRUNSWICK, NOVA SCOTIA, QUEBEC, AND PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND. SINCE ITS FORMATION, THE PANEL HAS HOSTED TWENTY-EIGHT SEMI-ANNUAL MEETINGS, MONTHLY (OR AS NEEDED) STEERING COMMITTEE CONFERENCE CALLS, TWO RAPID RESPONSE WORKSHOPS, TWO VOLUNTEER MONITORING WORKSHOPS, ONE SOCIAL-BASED MARKETING WORKSHOP, AND TWO STEERING COMMITTEE RETREATS. THE NEANS PANEL WILL CONTINUE TO INVITE REPRESENTATIVES FROM FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL AGENCIES  ACADEMIA  AND PRIVATE ENVIRONMENTAL AND COMMERCIAL INTERESTS TO: 1) IDENTIFY PRIORITIES FOR THE NORTHEAST REGION RELATIVE TO AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES 2) MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE ANS TASK FORCE REGARDING PROGRAMS TO CARRY OUT SECTION 1202 OF THE NAPCA (AS AMENDED, 1996) 3) ASSIST THE ANS TASK FORCE IN COORDINATING FEDERAL ANS PROGRAM ACTIVITIES IN THE NORTHEAST REGION 4) COORDINATE, WHERE POSSIBLE, ANS PROGRAM ACTIVITIES IN THE NORTHEAST REGION THAT ARE NOT CONDUCTED PURSUANT TO THE NANPCA (AS AMENDED, 1996) 5) PROVIDE ADVICE TO PUBLIC AND PRIVATE INDIVIDUALS AND ENTITIES CONCERNING METHODS OF PREVENTING AND CONTROLLING ANS INFESTATIONS AND 6) SUBMIT ANNUALLY A REPORT TO THE ANS TASK FORCE DESCRIBING ACTIVITIES WITHIN THE NORTHEAST REGION RELATED TO ANS PREVENTION, RESEARCH, AND CONTROL.TO ADDRESS ANS CONCERNS EFFECTIVELY WITHIN THE NORTHEAST REGION, THE NEANS PANEL HAS CREATED A FRAMEWORK OF APPROACHES WITH COMMITTEES AND WORKGROUPS TO APPROACH INVASIVE SPECIES ISSUES THROUGH COMMUNICATION, EDUCATION, AND OUTREACH  POLICY AND LEGISLATION  SHIPPING  AND SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY.

THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES PROGRAM CONSISTS OF A FULL-TIME COORDINATOR BIOLOGIST AND A FULL-TIME TECHNICIAN. AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES POSE SIGNIFICANT ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC THREATS TO AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS IN OKLAHOMA. ZEBRA MUSSELS, HYDRILLA, INVASIVE CARP, GOLDEN ALGA, YELLOW FLOATING HEART, AMONG OTHERS HAVE ALREADY BECOME ESTABLISHED IN OKLAHOMA S LAKES AND RIVERS. THESE SPECIES AS WELL AS SPECIES IN NEIGHBORING STATES POSE ECONOMIC AND ECOLOGICAL THREATS TO THE STATE S AQUATIC RESOURCES. BIGHEADED CARP (SILVER AND BIGHEAD CARP) HAVE BEEN PRESENT IN THE LOWER RED RIVER WATERSHED AND ITS TRIBUTARIES SINCE AT LEAST 2012 AND BIGHEAD CARP IN THE NEOSHO RIVER GRAND LAKE SYSTEM SINCE 1992. BOTH SYSTEMS ARE ACTIVELY BEING STUDIED BY ODWC AND UNIVERSITIES. WE EXPECT TO INCREASE OUR EARLY DETECTION SAMPLING FOR ZEBRA MUSSELS THROUGHOUT THE STATE BY SURVEYING 36 WATER BODIES DURING THE CALENDAR YEAR 2023. PLANKTON SAMPLES WILL BE SENT TO THE BUREAU OF RECLAMATION LAB IN DENVER, COLORADO FOR ANALYSIS USING LIGHT MICROSCOPY AND PCR TECHNIQUES. OBTAINING RESULTS FROM PLANKTON SAMPLES WILL HELP INFORM IF THERE HAVE BEEN ANY NEW WATER BODIES CONTAMINATED WITH ZEBRA MUSSELS. IF THERE ARE NEW CONTAMINATIONS, WE PLAN TO INFORM THE PUBLIC AS WELL AS OTHER ASSOCIATED AGENCIES TO HELP PREVENT THE SPREAD OF ZEBRA MUSSELS TO OTHER PARTS OF THE STATES OR EVEN OTHER STATES. THE AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES PROGRAM ASSISTS, WHEN NECESSARY, WITH THE MANAGEMENT OF AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANTS SUCH AS HYDRILLA, YELLOW FLOATING HEART, AND ALLIGATOR WEED. IF ESTABLISHED, INVASIVE AQUATIC PLANTS COULD CAUSE SIGNIFICANT ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC HARM BY CAUSING UNPLEASANT EXPERIENCES FOR ANGLERS OR RECREATIONAL USERS. IF USED FOR DRINKING WATER, PLANTS CAN ALSO AFFECT WATER INTAKE INFRASTRUCTURE. THE AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES COORDINATOR AND TECHNICIAN HAVE A VARIETY OF OTHER RESPONSIBILITIES TO REVIEW VARIOUS AQUATIC PERMITS FOR THE AGENCY, WRITE REGULATION CHANGES, IF NECESSARY, ATTEND CONFERENCES TO PARTICIPATE IN INVASIVE SPECIES COMMITTEES, DISSEMINATE INFORMATION, AND LEARN FROM OTHER STATES MANAGEMENT PRACTICES OF INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT. MEETINGS ARE ATTENDED OFTEN WEEKLY TO COORDINATE WITH LOCAL MUNICIPALITIES, NON-GOVERNMENTAL GROUPS, TRIBES, STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES REGARDING INVASIVE SPECIES. ADDITIONALLY, WE PLAN UPDATE AND INCREASE SIGNAGE STATEWIDE. WE ARE ALSO WORKING WITH OUR COMMUNICATIONS DEPARTMENT TO SEND OUT NEWSLETTERS, PRESS RELEASES, SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS AND INFORMATIONAL LETTERS TO OUR CONSTITUENTS. WE ARE ALSO RESPONSIBLE FOR ANSWERING VARIOUS REGULATION QUESTIONS FROM THE PUBLIC, PROVIDING TRAINING TO AGENCY STAFF ON THE DECONTAMINATION, REPORTING AND IDENTIFICATION OF AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES, AND REVIEW OUR STATE REGULATIONS.

THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS IMPLEMENTATION OF KEY ASPECTS OF TEXAS  STATE AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN. KEY AREAS OF FOCUS ARE INTERSTATE REGIONAL COORDINATION, EARLY DETECTION AND MONITORING, AND OUTREACH AND PREVENTION. KEY STAFF WILL ATTEND ALL MEETINGS OF THE WESTERN, MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN, AND GULF AND SOUTH ATLANTIC REGIONAL PANELS OF THE ANS TASK FORCE TO ENHANCE INTERSTATE AND REGIONAL COORDINATION ON CRITICAL ANS ISSUES. EDUCATION AND OUTREACH IS OFTEN CONSIDERED THE FIRST LINE OF DEFENSE AGAINST ANS, AND THIS PROJECT WILL LEVERAGE FEDERAL, STATE, AND PARTNER CAMPAIGNS TO IMPLEMENT A MULTIMODAL, TARGETED OUTREACH CAMPAIGN ENCOMPASSING THE WATERCRAFT, AQUARIUM DUMPING, AND LIVE BAIT PATHWAYS FOR ANS. MONITORING IS ALSO A KEY ASPECT OF ANY ANS PROGRAM, AND EARLY DETECTION AIDS IN GUIDING OUTREACH AND PREVENTION EFFORTS. THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT ZEBRA QUAGGA MUSSEL EARLY DETECTION AND POPULATION MONITORING AS PART OF A STATEWIDE PARTNERSHIP EFFORT TO MONITOR MORE THAN 40 WATER BODIES.

THE ARIZONA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT (AZGFD) IS REQUESTING FUNDING FROM THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO MAINTAIN CRITICAL STAFFING AND SUPPLIES TO CONTINUE TO IMPLEMENT THE GOALS OF THE ARIZONA AIS MANAGEMENT PLAN (AZAISMP). THIS WILL ALLOW AZGFD TO MAINTAIN EXISTING PARTNERSHIPS AND BUILD NEW RELATIONSHIPS WITH LOCAL AND FEDERAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES AS WELL AS PRIVATE INDUSTRY, NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS AND STAKEHOLDER GROUPS. FUNDING FROM FWS STATE AND INTERSTATE AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN GRANT PROGRAM PROVIDES FOR PROGRAM PERSONNEL TO REMAIN THE LEAD AGENCY FOR AIS MANAGEMENT AND TO CONTINUE TO PROVIDE OVERSIGHT, TRAINING AND TECHNICAL EXPERTISE FOR PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PARTNERS IMPLEMENTING PROGRAMS AT LOCAL LEVELS. AS MUCH OF THE MUSSEL FOULED WATERCRAFT DECONTAMINATIONS HAVE SHIFTED TO PRIVATE INDUSTRY, THIS FUNDING ALSO ALLOWS AZGFD PERSONNEL TO FOCUS ON OTHER AIS ACTIVITIES SUCH AS OUTREACH, EXPAND MONITORING ACTIVITIES, SURVEYS AND REMOVALS. THE GOAL OF THE AZAISMP IS TO PREVENT NEW, UNINTENDED INTRODUCTIONS OF AIS INTO ALL OF OUR STATE WATERS, TO LIMIT THE SPREAD OF ESTABLISHED POPULATIONS OF AIS INTO UNINFESTED WATERS OF THE STATE, AND TO ABATE HARMFUL ECOLOGICAL, ECONOMIC, SOCIAL AND PUBLIC HEALTH IMPACTS RESULTING FROM INFESTATION OF AIS.

THE USFWS FUNDED AND IDFG OPERATED MITIGATION RAINBOW TROUT PROGRAM REARS AND RELEASES TROUT AS A SERVICE TO THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS AS PARTIAL MITIGATION FOR IMPACTS OF THE DWORSHAK DAM UPON IDAHO FISHERIES.

THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PLAN FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES IN IOWA FOCUS ON PUBLIC OUTREACH TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF ANS, MONITORING STATE WATERBODIES FOR EARLY DETECTION OF ANS INTRODUCTIONS, AND MANAGEMENT OF ANS INFESTATIONS. THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES ANS PROGRAM USES GRANT FUNDS TO SUPPORT IMPLEMENTATION ACTIVITIES OF THE PLAN RELATED TO COORDINATION, PUBLIC OUTREACH AND MONITORING. THE IOWA DNR ANS PROGRAM COORDINATOR DIRECTS IMPLEMENTATION OF ALL ASPECTS OF THE PLAN. TASKS THAT WILL BE SPECIFICALLY ADDRESSED IN 2024 INCLUDE REVIEWING AND UPDATING THE IOWA AIS RULE, EXPANDING OUTREACH TO TARGET AIS IN COMMERCE, CONTINUING PARTICIPATION ON TEAMS WORKING ON INVASIVE CARP PROJECTS IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN AND MISSOURI RIVER BASIN, AND SUPPORTING SEASONAL STAFF. THE PROGRAM COORDINATOR AND STAFF ALSO SUPPORT REGIONAL AND NATIONAL ANS COORDINATION AND PLAN TO ATTEND TWO ANS TASK FORCE MEETINGS, THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN PANEL ON ANS MEETING, THE MISSOURI RIVER ANS WORKING GROUP MEETING, THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN AND MISSOURI RIVER BASIN INVASIVE CARP TEAMS MEETINGS, AND TWO MEETINGS OF THE ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES INVASIVE SPECIES COMMITTEE. STAFF OF THE IOWA ANS PROGRAM WILL SURVEY LAKES, PONDS, AND RIVERS IN IOWA TO DETECT INTRODUCTIONS, MONITOR SPREAD, AND DETERMINE CURRENT STATUS OF EURASIAN WATERMILFOIL, BRITTLE NAIAD, CURLYLEAF PONDWEED, ZEBRA MUSSELS, RUSTY CRAYFISH, BIGHEAD AND SILVER CARP, AND OTHER ANS IN 2024.

EQUIPPING MICHIGAN S STATE AGENCIES WITH AIS PREVENTION MATERIALS AND CONTINUATION OF MICHIGAN S CLEAN BOATS, CLEAN WATER PROGRAM. PROJECT ABSTRACT: THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE AND ENHANCE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) STATEWIDE EDUCATION AND OUTREACH EFFORTS BY EQUIPPING RELEVANT STATE OF MICHIGAN AGENCIES AND PARTNERS WITH THE EDUCATION AND OUTREACH MATERIALS THEY NEED TO HELP PREVENT AIS INTRODUCTION AND SPREAD (ACTIVITY 1).  THIS PROPOSAL WILL ALSO FUND THE CONTINUED IMPLEMENTATION AND GROWTH OF MICHIGANS CLEAN BOATS, CLEAN WATERS (CBCW) PROGRAM MINI-GRANT PROGRAM (ACTIVITY 2). ACTIVITY 1) EQUIPPING STATE OF MICHIGAN AGENCIES AND PARTNERS WITH AIS EDUCATION AND OUTREACH MATERIALS  MICHIGAN WILL CONTINUE EDUCATION AND OUTREACH INITIATIVES FOCUSED ON DELIVERING CONSISTENT MESSAGING ON AIS PREVENTION, EARLY DETECTION, AND MANAGEMENT TO INDIVIDUAL CITIZENS, PARTNERS, AND ORGANIZATIONS. MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT, GREAT LAKES, AND ENERGY (EGLE) IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DNR) AND OTHER PARTNERS SUCH AS MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY EXTENSION WILL DEVELOP, PURCHASE, AND PRINT A VARIETY INFORMATIONAL MATERIALS.  MANY OF THESE MATERIALS WILL THEN BE DISTRIBUTED TO THE RECREATIONAL BOATERS, ANGLERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.  OTHER MATERIALS WILL BE USED AS KEY PIECES OF EDUCATIONAL DISPLAYS IN PROMINENT LOCATIONS AROUND THE STATE.  ADDITIONALLY, FUNDS WILL BE USED TO CONTINUE TO MAINTAIN AND REPAIR TWO MOBILE BOAT WASH SYSTEMS OWNED BY EGLE THAT ARE AN INTEGRAL PART OF AIS EDUCATION AND OUTREACH THROUGHOUT THE STATE FOR BOATERS AND ANGLERS DURING EVENTS AT BOATING ACCESS SITES.  REQUIRED MAINTENANCE DURING THE PROJECT PERIOD IS LIKELY TO INCLUDE NEW TRAILER TIRES, TUNE-UPS (OIL SPARK PLUGS FILTERS), AND PART AND EQUIPMENT REPLACEMENT (TOOL SETS, BOOTS, JUMP STARTERS, BATTERIES, ETC.). ACTIVITY 2) CLEAN BOATS, CLEAN WATERS MINI-GRANTS MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY (MSU) EMPLOYS AN EXTENSION EDUCATOR THAT LEADS MICHIGANS CLEAN BOATS, CLEAN WATERS (CBCW) PROGRAM. CBCW INCLUDES A MINI-GRANTS PROGRAM FOR STRATEGIC PARTNERS WHO USE GRANT THE FUNDS FOR AIS EDUCATION AND OUTREACH TARGETING BOATERS AND ANGLERS AT THE LOCAL SCALE. DURING THE INITIAL YEAR OF THE MINI-GRANT PROGRAM IN 2021 USING A SEPARATE FUNDING SOURCE, SEVEN PROJECTS WERE FUNDED ACROSS THE STATE THAT INCLUDED CONDUCTING OUTREACH EVENTS FOR BOATERS, INSTALLING SIGNAGE AND DECONTAMINATION TOOLS AT BOAT RAMPS, CREATING A VIDEO DEMONSTRATING PROPER AIS DECONTAMINATION TECHNIQUES FOR BOATERS, AND INSTALLATION OF A USER-OPERATED WATERLESS CLEANING STATION FOR BOATS. IN 2022, THE MINI-GRANTS PROGRAM WAS EXPANDED AND DEMAND CONTINUED TO EXCEED THE AVAILABLE FUNDING  12 GRANTS WERE RECENTLY AWARDED. THE CBCW MINI-GRANT PROGRAM AGAIN SAW INCREASED INTEREST IN 2023 AND WAS ABLE TO FUND 13 PROJECTS.  FUNDS FROM THIS PROPOSAL ARE NEEDED TO CONTINUE MEETING DEMAND FOR THESE IMPORTANT LOCAL AIS EDUCATION, OUTREACH, AND PREVENTION PROJECTS IN 2024.

SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKAS BIG LAKE IS THE STATES BUSIEST INLAND BOAT LAUNCH AND THE AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANT ELODEA CANADENSIS (ELODEA) WAS FIRST DISCOVERED IN BIG LAKE IN 2019. IN 2022, ELODEA HAD SPREAD UP TO FIVE MILES AWAY FROM THE SITE OF THE INITIAL INFESTATION, AND FLOATING MATS OF ELODEA WERE OBSERVED. DUE TO THIS SPREADING INFESTATION AND THE RECREATIONAL POPULARITY OF BIG LAKE, THERE IS A CONSIDERABLE RISK OF ELODEA BEING TRANSPORTED TO OTHER REGIONAL WATERBODIES ON BOAT PROPELLERS, TRAILERS, OR FLOATPLANE RUDDERS. TYONEK TRIBAL CONSERVATION DISTRICT (TTCD) AND KNIK TRIBE (KT) PROPOSE TO JOINTLY CONDUCT RESEARCH TO IDENTIFY BOAT AND FLOATPLANE VECTORS AND ELODEA DISPERSAL PATHWAYS FROM ELODEA-INFESTED BIG LAKE IN BIG LAKE, ALASKA, THROUGH FLOATPLANE PILOT AND BOATER SURVEY AND OUTREACH TO BETTER IDENTIFY AT-RISK WATERBODIES DUE TO THE SPREADING ELODEA INFESTATION IN BIG LAKE. WE WILL CONDUCT ADDITIONAL VIDEO AND PRINTED OUTREACH TO THE BIG LAKE COMMUNITY TO INCREASE LOCAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ELODEA AND PREVENT SPREAD AND NEW INFESTATIONS. WE PROPOSE TO INCORPORATE THIS INFORMATION TO INFORM REGIONAL WATERBODY PRIORITIZATION EFFORTS THAT WILL ALLOW PROJECT PARTNERS TO BETTER TARGET AT-RISK WATERS, INCREASING REGIONAL CAPACITY FOR SUCCESSFUL ELODEA EARLY DETECTION RAPID RESPONSE (EDRR) TO CONSERVE AND PROTECT SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKAS FISHERIES AND FISH HABITAT FROM ELODEA-CAUSED HABITAT DEGRADATION.

THIS PROGRAM PROVIDES FULL OR PARTIAL FUNDING FOR EIGHT PROGRAMS OPERATED BY THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (ADF G) THAT SUPPORT MANAGEMENT OF YUKON RIVER SALMON FISHERIES TO ACHIEVE MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES OF THE YUKON RIVER SALMON AGREEMENT, AN ANNEX OF THE PACIFIC SALMON TREATY BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND CANADA. ADF G IS THE DESIGNATED RESPONSIBLE MANAGEMENT ENTITY FOR THE UNITED STATES AS ESTABLISHED BY THE YUKON RIVER SALMON ACT (16 USC 5724) FOR THE PURPOSES OF IMPLEMENTATION OF THE YUKON RIVER SALMON AGREEMENT. THE EIGHT PROJECTS ARE 1) EAGLE SONAR OPERATIONS, 2) LOWER YUKON HARVEST MONITORING, 3) YUKON RIVER STOCK BIOLOGY, 4) LOWER YUKON TEST FISHERY, 5) COMPREHENSIVE SUBSISTENCE SURVEYS, 6) CHINOOK ENHANCEMENT OUTREACH, 7)CHINOOK RESEARCH AND ASSESSMENT, AND 8) PORCUPINE RIVER FALL CHUM RESEARCH.

PRODUCE 650,000 SPRING CHINOOK SALMON SMOLTS, ACCLIMATE AND RELEASE 1.0 MILLION SPRING CHINOOK SALMON SMOLTS FROM CLEARWATER HATCHERY, ACCLIMATE AND RELEASE 775,000 COHO SALMON SMOLTS FROM DWORSHAK AND EAGLE CREEK NATIONAL FISH HATCHERIES, RELEASE 300,000 STEELHEAD SMOLTS FROM DWORSHAK NFH. ADULT TRAPPING AND HOLDING OF SPRING CHINOOK, COHO AND STEELHEAD FOR BROODSTOCK. OPERATE AND MAINTAIN KOOSKIA NFH INFRASTRUCTURE.

THE MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DNR) IS REQUESTING FUNDS IN FEDERAL FISCAL YEAR 2023 FROM THE STATE INTERSTATE AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN PROGRAM GRANT TO SUPPORT STATE AQUATIC INVASIVE NUISANCE SPECIES MANAGEMENT WITHIN MINNESOTA. THESE FUNDS WILL ALLOW THE MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES TO CONTINUE IMPLEMENTATION OF ACTIONS IN THE STATE PLAN THROUGH SEVERAL PROJECTS: (1) PROVIDE ONGOING SUPPORT OF THE MN DNR MUSSEL DETECTOR CANINE PROGRAM  (2) DESIGN AND PRINT INVASIVE SPECIES WATCH CARDS, WHICH ARE WALLET-SIZED IDENTIFICATION CARDS WITH PREVENTION ACTIONS FOR VARIOUS INVASIVE SPECIES  (3) PROVIDING AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES SIGNS, SIGN DECALS, AND SIGN GRAPHICS FOR POSTING AT WATER ACCESS POINTS AROUND MINNESOTA  (4) DESIGNING AND IMPLEMENTING A CAMPAIGN TO INCREASE AWARENESS ABOUT - AND PROMOTE ALTERNATIVES TO RELEASING - GOLDFISH  (5) CREATE A SERIES OF SHORT ANIMATED VIDEOS ABOUT AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES, INFORMED BY THE DNR S RESEARCH ON EFFECTIVE MESSAGING TO MOTIVATE BEHAVIOR CHANGE  AND (6) DESIGN AND PRODUCE GIVEAWAY ITEMS FOR THE 2024 MINNESOTA STATE FAIR INVASIVE SPECIES DISPLAY.

THIS GRANT FUNDS THE EARLY DETECTION AND RAPID RESPONSE OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES, BAIT INSPECTIONS AND OUTREACH, HYDRILLA SURVEILLANCE, AND RISK ASSESSMENT OFAQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES IN THE OHIO RIVER WATERSHED.

INDIANA S FUNDING NEEDS AND GOALS UNDER THIS GRANT FOCUSES STRICTLY ON COORDINATION OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) ACTIVITIES BY THE INDIANA AIS COORDINATOR AS WELL AS PROVIDING ADDITIONAL FUNDS SUPPORTING THE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PROGRAM AND OUR ADDITIONAL WORK FOCUSING ON AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANT AND INVASIVE MUSSEL AWARENESS ACTIONS.FIRST GOAL IS TO IMPLEMENT THE AIS MANAGEMENT PLAN BY DEVELOPING THE NECESSARY MANAGEMENT TOOLS AND CAPABILITIES TO ADDRESS ALL TYPES OF AIS ISSUES. THROUGH THE FUNDING OF STAFF SPECIFICALLY FOCUSING ON AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES AWARENESS, CONTROL, PREVENTION AND REGIONAL COORDINATION.THE SECONDARY GOAL OF THIS FUNDING IS TO FOCUS TIME AND ACTIVITIES ON A COUPLE OF AIS PATHWAYS INCLUDING AN EMPHASIS ON ORGANISMS IN TRADE AND RECREATIONAL BOATING. FUNDING THE IMPLEMENTATION OF EARLY DETECTION EFFORTS AND TO DEVELOP RESPONSE STRATEGIES IS IMPORTANT WHEN WORKING ON FOCUSING OUTREACH AND EDUCATION. IN REGARD TO ALL AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES INCLUDING HIGH PRIORITY AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANTS AND ZEBRA MUSSELS (ZM) THROUGH THE AIS MANAGEMENT PLAN WE ARE GOING TO TARGET BETTER COMMUNICATION STRATEGIES AND COORDINATION AMONG PARTNERS AND THE AGENCY.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION REGARDING THE CURRENT STATUS OF VHS IN ILLINOIS WATERS TO ASSIST WITH DEVELOPMENT OF STRATEGIES FOR MANAGING THIS FISH DISEASE AND TO PROVIDE INFORMATION REGARDING DISEASE STATUS OF BIGHEADED CARPS.TASK 1: MONITORING VHS STATUS OF FISH POPULATIONS IN ILLINOIS LAKES AND RIVERS 2024BIGHEAD CARP (HYPOPHTHALMICHTHYS NOBILIS) AND SILVER CARP (H. MOLITRIX), COLLECTIVELY KNOWN AS BIGHEADED CARPS, ARE INVASIVE SPECIES IN ILLINOIS RIVERS  EFFORTS TO CONTROL ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF THESE NON-NATIVE SPECIES INCLUDE CONTRACTED HARVEST IN THE UPPER ILLINOIS RIVER AND COMMERCIAL HARVEST IN THE LOWER ILLINOIS RIVER AND OTHER LARGE RIVERS IN THE STATE. EFFORTS TO DEVELOP COMMERCIAL MARKETS FOR BIGHEADED CARPS ARE ONGOING AND ARE NEEDED TO PROMOTE HARVEST OF THESE SPECIES BY INCREASING PROFITABILITY OF BIGHEADED CARP FISHERIES  INCREASED HARVEST WOULD ENHANCE THE POTENTIAL FOR CONTROLLING BIGHEADED CARP ABUNDANCE IN ILLINOIS RIVERS. ONE EMERGING COMMERCIAL MARKET FOR BIGHEADED CARP S IS THE SALE OF CARP CARCASSES FOR USE AS BAIT IN FISHERIES OUTSIDE OF ILLINOIS WHICH TARGET SPECIES THAT ARE COMMERCIALLY VALUABLE AS FOOD, SUCH AS MERICAN LOBSTER. ONE POTENTIAL IMPEDIMENT TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF A COMMERCIAL MARKET FOR BIGHEADED CARPS AS DEAD BAIT IS CONCERNS FROM OTHER STATES REGARDING POTENTIAL SPREAD OF FISH DISEASES (INCLUDING VHS AND SPRING VIRAEMIA OF CARP (SVC)). SIU BEGAN TESTING BIGHEADED CARPS COLLECTED FROM THE LOWER ILLINOIS RIVER FOR VHS AND SVC IN 2018. HOWEVER, THERE IS A NEED FOR ADDITIONAL TESTING OF BIGHEADED CARPS FOR VHS AND SVC FROM OTHER SECTIONS OF THE ILLINOIS RIVER AND OTHER RIVERS IN ILLINOIS WHERE THESE SPECIES ARE COMMERCIALLY HARVESTED OR SUBJECT TO CONTRACTED HARVEST TO CONFIRM THAT NEITHER DISEASE IS PRESENT IN BIGHEADED CARPS IN ILLINOIS RIVERS.TASK 2: AIS OUTREACH IN LAKE COUNTY, ILLINOISTHE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT WOULD BE TO FOCUS ON DETECTION OUTREACH IN LAKE COUNTY WITH THE GOAL TO EMPOWER LAKE USERS TO IDENTIFY AND REPORT AIS SPECIES. WITH THE DEFUNCT VOLUNTEER LAKE MONITORING PROGRAM THROUGH ILLINOIS, THERE ARE LESS EYES ON THE WATER THAN PREVIOUSLY, HOWEVER, NEW AIS SPECIES ARE STILL BEING INTRODUCED.

CHINOOK AND CHUM SALMON ARE TWO IMPORTANT SUBSISTENCE RESOURCES FOR COMMUNITIES LOCATED IN THE ARCTIC-YUKON-KUSKOKWIM (AYK) REGION OF ALASKA. HISTORICALLY, SUBSISTENCE HARVESTS IN THE AYK REGION ACCOUNT FOR 83  OF THE TOTAL ALASKAN SUBSISTENCE HARVEST OF CHINOOK SALMON AND 97  OF THE SUBSISTENCE HARVEST OF CHUM SALMON. FOR OVER A DECADE, CHINOOK SALMON RUN SIZES TO THE AYK REGION HAVE BEEN CHRONICALLY POOR. WHILE CHUM SALMON RUN SIZES TO THE AYK REGION HAVE BEEN VARIABLE OVER TIME, CHUM SALMON RUNS TO THE AYK REGION IN 2020, 2021, AND 2022 WERE THREE OF THE LOWEST ON RECORD. CONCURRENTLY POOR RUN SIZES OF CHINOOK AND CHUM SALMON CAUSE HARDSHIP TO THE SUBSISTENCE USERS OF THE AYK REGION, ESPECIALLY WHEN ANOMALOUSLY LOW RUN SIZES ARE NOT ANTICIPATED. FOR SUBSISTENCE FISHERMEN AND AYK FISHERY MANAGERS, UNDERSTANDING THE CAUSES OF THESE DECLINES AND BEING ABLE TO ANTICIPATE AND PLAN FOR LOW RUN SIZES ARE OF UPMOST IMPORTANCE. NEW AND ONGOING MARINE RESEARCH SURVEYS AIMED AT STUDYING THE MARINE LIFE HISTORY OF CHINOOK AND CHUM SALMON HAVE PROVIDED IMPORTANT INSIGHTS INTO THE FACTORS AFFECTING CHINOOK AND CHUM SALMON PRODUCTION AND HOW CHANGING MARINE CONDITIONS MAY IMPACT FUTURE SURVIVAL.THIS PROGRAM PROVIDES FUNDING TO SUPPORT MARINE RESEARCH SURVEYS AIMED AT MONITORING JUVENILE CHINOOK AND CHUM SALMON FROM THE ARCTIC-YUKON-KUSKOKWIM (AYK) REGION IN ALASKA. THE JUVENILE LIFE STAGE (I.E., THE FIRST SUMMER IN THE OCEAN) IS A CRITICAL PERIOD WITHIN THE SALMON LIFE CYCLE. JUVENILE SALMON SURVEYS HAVE PROVEN EFFECTIVE FOR DEVELOPING PRESEASON FORECASTS, SOMETIMES UP TO THREE YEARS BEFORE THE ADULTS RETURN TO THE RIVERS. THESE SURVEYS ALSO PROVIDE VALUABLE INSIGHTS FOR UNDERSTANDING WHICH PARTS OF THE SALMON LIFE CYCLE ARE MOST CRITICAL FOR SURVIVAL. THESE BENEFITS CAN ONLY BE OBTAINED THROUGH CONTINUOUS LONG-TERM MONITORING USING ESTABLISHED SURVEY METHODOLOGIES. THE NORTHERN BERING SEA (NBS) SURVEY, CO-LED BY THE NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION (NOAA) AND THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (ADF G), BEGAN OVER 20 YEARS AGO. THIS SURVEY IS CRITICAL FOR FORECASTING YUKON SALMON STOCKS AND IMPROVING OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE MARINE SURVIVAL AND ECOLOGY OF SALMON STOCKS FROM THE YUKON RIVER AND NORTON SOUND. THE SOUTHERN BERING SEA (SBS) SURVEY IS A NEW PROJECT THAT WILL ENABLE SIMILAR INSIGHTS FOR KUSKOKWIM RIVER SALMON. FUNDS PROVIDED BY USFWS WILL HELP ADDRESS INCREASED FUEL AND VESSEL CHARTER COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH SURVEY OPERATIONS AND MAY BE USED FOR LABORATORY SAMPLING TO ASSESS DIET, PREY, AND COMPETITION.

CREATIVE RESOURCE STRATEGIES, LLC IS PROPOSING TO WORK WITH A TEAM CONSISTING OF THE INVASIVE SPECIES ACTIONNETWORK, NATIONAL SEA GRANT LAW CENTER, PACIFIC STATES MARINE FISHERIES COMMISSION, AND A CAREER ALASKANSEAPLANE PILOT AND INSTRUCTOR TO ENGAGE SEAPLANE OPERATORS AND SEAPLANE INDUSTRY REPRESENTATIVES IN ALASKA AND THELOWER 48 STATES TO ASSESS THE POTENTIAL TO SPREAD AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) VIA THE SEAPLANE PATHWAY, AND TODEVELOP A SUITE OF RECOMMENDATIONS THAT ENHANCE U.S. AIS SEAPLANE PREVENTION EFFORTS.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) LEADS MANY EFFORTS TO MANAGE AND CONTROL INVASIVE CARP(PREVIOUSLY ASIAN CARP) POPULATIONS IN THE UNITED STATES. THROUGH THE WATER RESOURCES REFORM ANDDEVELOPMENT ACT (WRRDA) OF 2014, CONGRESS DIRECTED THE USFWS TO LEAD MULTI-AGENCY EFFORTS TOMANAGE AND CONTROL INVASIVE CARP POPULATIONS IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER AND OHIO RIVER BASINS. THEOHIO RIVER BASIN ASIAN CARP CONTROL STRATEGY FRAMEWORK PROVIDES A MULTITUDE OF STATE AND FEDERALAGENCIES WITH A COOPERATIVE STRATEGY TO MONITOR AND UNDERSTAND THE INVASION OF BIGHEADED CARPS IN THEOHIO RIVER. THE INTENTION OF THIS FRAMEWORK IS TO MINIMIZE THE SOCIAL, ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC IMPACTS OFTHESE INVASIVE FISHES. WORKING CLOSELY WITH THE MISSISSIPPI INTERSTATE COOPERATIVE RESOURCE ASSOCIATION(MICRA), THE OHIO RIVER BASIN PARTNERS ARE IMPLEMENTING AN ASIAN CARP MONITORING AND RESPONSE PLANFOR THE OHIO RIVER. AS A CONTRIBUTING MEMBER OF THE OHIO RIVER BASIN PARTNERS, THE WEST VIRGINIA DIVISIONOF NATURAL RESOURCE IS COMMITTED TO THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE ASIAN CARP MONITORING AND RESPONSE PLANFOR THE OHIO RIVER. WITHIN THIS PLAN, FOUR INVASIVE CARP CONTROL PROJECTS ARE TO BE FUNDED BY THIS GRANT.THESE PROJECTS INCLUDE: EARLY DETECTION AND EVALUATION, CONTROL AND CONTAINMENT, DISTRIBUTION ANDMOVEMENT THROUGH TELEMETRY, AND EARLY LIFE HISTORY OF INVASIVE CARPS IN THE OHIO RIVER.

THIS PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO GATHER INFORMATION ON INVASIVE CARP DISTRIBUTIONS, BEHAVIOR, AND POPULATION CHARACTERISTICS IN THE OHIO RIVER BASIN, WHICH WILL BE USED TO ASSESS MANAGEMENT ACTIONS RELATED TO THEIR REMOVAL, SUPPRESSION, AND CONTAINMENT. THE PROPOSED WORK IS PART OF AN ONGOING MULTI AGENCY AND UNIVERSITY SURVEILLANCE AND DATA COLLECTION FOCUSED ON INVASIVE CARP EARLY DETECTION AND REMOVAL PRIMARILY ABOVE CANNELTON DAM. THE PRIMARY GOAL IS TO PROVIDE AN ACCURATE POPULATION TREND ASSESSMENT OF INVASIVE CARP CONTROL AND RESPONSE EFFORTS  FISH COMMUNITY DATA MAY ALSO AID IN DETERMINING IMPACTS OF CARP ON NATIVE FISH ASSEMBLAGES. PENNSYLVANIA FISH AND BOAT COMMISSION BIOLOGISTS WILL BE WORKING IN THE MONONGAHELA, OHIO, AND ALLEGHENY RIVERS. ALL GAME AND NON GAME FISH SPECIES WILL BE IDENTIFIED DURING SAMPLING AND ALL GAME FISH SPECIES WILL BE ENUMERATED, MEASURED, AND WEIGHED TO DETERMINE CATCH PER UNIT EFFORT AND CONDITION INDICES. THESE DATA WILL ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO FISH COMMUNITY STRUCTURE COMPILATION AND FOR COMPARISON IF INVASIVE CARP INVADE PENNSYLVANIA WATERS. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES AN ONGOING, COORDINATED APPROACH TO ASSESS INVASIVE CARP MANAGEMENT AND SUPPRESSION IN THE OHIO RIVER BASIN.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT THE NATIONAL FISH HABITAT PLAN IN THE SOUTHEAST UNITED STATES IN THE SARP WORK AREA. SCOPE OF THE PROJECT IS HIGH VALUE AQUATIC HABITAT IN THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES THAT IS DETERMINED BY PARTNER AGENCIES INCLUDING USFWS, OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES, STATE AGENCIES, NGOS AND CORPORATIONS. THIS PROJECT HAS TWO MAJOR SUB PROJECTS. 1)ENHANCEMENT OF STREAMBANK AND RIPARIAN HABITATS FOR NATIVE BLACK BASS PROTECTION IN THE UPPER CHATTAHOOCHEE AND  LAKE LANIER WATERSHED  AND 2) IMPLEMENTING THE NATIONAL FISH HABITAT ACTION PLAN IN THE SOUTHEAST UNITED STATES. SUB PROJECT 1 WILL FOCUS ON WORKING WITH AGRICULTURAL LANDOWNERS IN THE UPPDER CHATTAHOOCHEE WATERSHED IN GA TO IMPLEMENT BMPS ON AGRICULTURAL LANDS. THIS WILL IMPROVE PHYSICAL HABITAT AND WATER QUALITY FOR SHOAL BASS AND OTHER PRIORITY SPECIES AS WELL AS IMPROVE WATER QUALITY IN LANE LANIER. SUB PROJECT 2 WILL SUPPORT THE IDENTIFICATION OF PRIORITY AREAS THAT WILL DIRECT RESOURCE ALLOCATION SUPPORTED BY THE NATIONAL FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP (NFHP) AS WELL AS THE OPERATIONAL TRANSITIONS TO ALIGN WITH THE RECENTLY PASSED AMERICA S CONSERVATION AND ENHANCEMENT (ACE) ACT INCLUDING THE REVISION OF THE SOUTHEAST AQUATIC HABITAT PLAN AND OPERATIONAL GUIDELINES AS MANY OF THESE WERE PUBLISHED OVER 10 YEARS AGO. THESE ACTIVITIES ARE CRITICAL TO ALIGNING TO THE ACE ACT AND REMAINING A DESIGNATED FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP AS WELL AS A COMMITTEE OF THE SOUTHEASTERN ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES (SEAFWA). THESE ACTIVITIES WILL ALLOW SARP TO STRATEGICALLY ALLOCATE RESOURCES TO AREAS THAT ARE ECOLOGICALLY IMPORTANT AS WELL AS SOCIALLY IMPORTANT WITH THE NECESSARY CAPACITY TO BENEFIT HABITATS AND THE SPECIES THAT DEPEND ON THEM IN SUBSEQUENT YEARS. THIS PROJECT WILL PRIMARILY FOCUS ON INCREASING THE LEVEL OF ROBUSTNESS AND ABILITY TO TRACK ACCOMPLISHMENTS OF SARP AND THE WORK OF OUR PARTNERS THROUGH SUPPORTED COLLABORATIONS. THREE MAIN AREAS OF RE ALIGNMENT AND INCREASED ENGAGEMENT WILL CENTER AROUND THE DESIGNATION OF CONSERVATION OPPORTUNITY AREAS, THE REVISION AND UPDATE OF THE SOUTHEAST AQUATIC HABITAT PLAN, AND THE OVERALL OVERSIGHT AND OPERATIONS AS THE LEVEL OF ENGAGEMENT HAS DROPPED SIGNIFICANTLY OVER THE PAST TWO YEARS. ALL OF THESE ACTIVITIES DESCRIBE ARE CRITICAL TO STRATEGICALLY ALLOCATING RESOURCES TO BENEFIT SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS.

LAMPREYS HISTORICALLY REPRESENTED A CRITICAL NICHE IN WATERSHED ECOLOGY THROUGHOUT THE NORTHWEST. THEIR DECLINE HAS TRACKED THAT OF PACIFIC SALMONIDS THROUGHOUT MUCH OF THEIR RANGE. THE LARGE SCALE RESTORATION OF THE ELWHA RIVER HAS SHOWN THAT LAMPREY CAN RETURN AND CONTRIBUTE TO A RECOVERING ECOSYSTEM RELATIVELY QUICKLY WHEN CONDITIONS ARE FAVORABLE (LEKT UNPUBLISHED DATA). URBAN STREAMS, SUCH AS THOSE IN PORT ANGELES HAVE ADDITIONAL CONSTRAINTS ON LAMPREY SURVIVAL BEYOND HABITAT LOSS AND SITE ACCESS. STORMWATER RUNOFF, PESTICIDES, AND SEPTAGE RELEASES ARE ADDITIONAL FACTORS THAT CAN ADVERSELY AFFECT BOTH SALMONIDS AND LAMPREY. LAMPREY CONTRIBUTE VITAL MARINE DERIVED NUTRIENTS TO AREAS WHERE THEY SPAWN, FILTER WATER AND PROVIDE FOOD FOR NATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE, AND POTENTIALLY BUFFER PREDATION DURING CRITICAL SALMONID MIGRATION PERIODS. HOWEVER, THE DEGREE TO WHICH LAMPREY OCCUPY THE PORT ANGELES S URBAN STREAMS IS RELATIVELY UNKNOWN. WE PROPOSE TO DOCUMENT THE SPECIES AND POPULATION OF LAMPREY IN TUMWATER, VALLEY, PEABODY, ENNIS AND MORSE CREEKS.THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO GAIN INFORMATION ON LAMPREY DISTRIBUTION AND BEHAVIOR IN ORDER TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS WHICH WILL INCREASE RESILIENCE OF ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO OBTAIN A REPRESENTATIVE SAMPLE OF LARVAL LAMPREY DISTRIBUTION IN URBAN STREAMS IN THE NORTH COAST OF THE OLYMPIC PENINSULA TO AID IN REFINING DISTRIBUTION MAPS IN THE PUGET SOUND STRAIT OF JUAN DE FUCA RMU.

IN COLLABORATION WITH TRIBES, STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, NATURAL RESOURCE NONPROFITS, AND LANDOWNERS, THE UPPER KLAMATH BASIN LAND AND WATER CONSERVATION INCENTIVE ASSISTANCE PROJECT, LED BY SUSTAINABLE NORTHWEST (SNW), SEEKS TO INCREASE VOLUNTARY PRODUCER ENGAGEMENT IN LAND, WATER, AND ENERGY CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES IN THE UPPER KLAMATH BASIN (UKB.) PROJECT PARTNERS WILL WORK ON PRIORITY STREAM REACHES WITHIN THE UKB TO CLASSIFY PRIVATE LANDS FOR ENROLLMENT IN LAND, WATER, AND ENERGY CONSERVATION PROGRAMS. WE WILL CUSTOMIZE AND MATCH LANDOWNER NEEDS WITH FEDERAL AND STATE PROGRAMS, INCENTIVES, AND GRANTS THROUGH OUR COORDINATED EFFORTS, AND PROVIDE THE NECESSARY SUPPORT FOR ENROLLMENT, PROJECT TRACKING AND IMPLEMENTATION. AS PART OF THIS PROJECT, SNW WILL PROVIDE ANALYSIS, RECOMMENDATIONS, AND FEEDBACK TO STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES BASED ON LOCAL PARTNER AND LANDOWNER EXPERIENCES. SNW WILL EVALUATE WHICH PROGRAMS ARE UTILIZED, WHICH ARE NOT, AND, PERHAPS MOST IMPORTANTLY, WHY. WITH THE END GOAL OF IMPROVING NEAR AND LONG TERM CONDITIONS FOR HABITAT RESTORATION AND ECONOMIC STABILITY, SNW WILL USE THIS ANALYSIS AND WORK CLOSELY WITH PARTNERS TO HELP IMPROVE STATE AND FEDERAL PROGRAMS TO BROADEN THE PIPELINE OF PARTICIPATING PROPERTIES.

THE SOUTHEAST AQUATIC RESOURCES PARTNERSHIP (SARP), MAINTAINS THE MOST COMPREHENSIVE DATABASE OF DAMS AND OTHER POTENTIAL BARRIERS TO AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE IN THE SOUTHEAST REGION OF THE UNITED STATES. THIS DATABASE WAS DEVELOPED AND IS MAINTAINED BY SARP IN COOPERATION WITH THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND NUMEROUS OTHER PARTNERS. TO DATE, SARP HAS INVENTORIED OVER 196,000 DAMS IN THE SOUTHEAST STATES AND TERRITORIES. SARP ALSO ANALYSES THESE DAMS TO GET A SINCE OF THEIR ECOLOGICAL IMPACTS. TO DATE, OVER 173,000 DAMS HAS HAVE BEEN ANALYZED FOR THEIR IMPACTS TO AQUATIC CONNECTIVITY. THIS ANALYSIS ALLOWS FISHERIES MANAGERS TO EVALUATE THE SUITABILITY OF A DAM FOR POTENTIAL REMOVAL. THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW SARP TO CONTINUE TO LOCATE NEW DAMS TO INCLUDE IN ITS DATABASE AND ALLOW FOR CONTINUED EVALUATION OF THESE DAMS.PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO MAINTAIN, UPDATE, AND IMPROVE SARP S AQUATIC BARRIER TOOL. METHOD SARP WILL CONTINUE ITS CONTRACT WITH ASTUTE SPRUCE TO MAINTAIN, UPDATE, AND IMPROVE THE ONLINE CONNECTIVITY TOOL. THE FOLLOWING MAIN TASKS WILL BE COMPLETED VIA THIS PROJECT  1. ACQUIRE AND PREPROCESS UPDATED AQUATIC BARRIER INVENTORY DATA AGGREGATED BY SARP FOR EACH ANNUAL UPDATE CYCLE. 2. ACQUIRE AND PREPROCESS UPDATED NHDPLUS HR DATA AS PUBLICLY RELEASED AT THE TIME OF THE ANNUAL DATA UPDATE CYCLE FOR THIS PROJECT. 3. PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR SUMMARIZING FEDERALLY AND STATE THREATENED AND ENDANGERED AND SGCN SPECIES DATA AS UPDATED BY SARP PER YEAR. 4. RERUN AQUATIC NETWORK ANALYSIS AND RELEASE UPDATES THROUGH THE TOOL. 5. MAKE TARGETED IMPROVEMENTS TO THE TOOL AND   OR DATA PROCESSING METHODS BASED ON PARTNER FEEDBACK. SARP S GIS COORDINATOR AND CONTRACTORS WILL CONTINUE TO QA QC EXISTING DATA AS WELL ASNEW DATA.

THE PROJECT WILL BE LED BY THE NATURE CONSERVANCY (TNC) WHICH HAS DECADES OF EXPERIENCE IN RIVER AND LAND CONSERVATION IN ARKANSAS AND ACROSS THE GLOBE. WE HAVE A TEAM OF FINANCE AND GRANT SPECIALISTS TO ENSURE PROPER ADMINISTRATION AND STEWARDSHIP OF PUBLIC AWARDS. TNC HAS ROBUST SYSTEMS FOR TRACKING TIME AND EXPENSES RELATED TO PROJECTS. STONE COUNTY GOVERNMENT WILL COMPLETE THE REMEDIATION OF THE LYDALISK STREAM CROSSING AND FUNDING FOR MATERIALS WILL SUBAWARDED TO THEM. THEY HAVE EXTENSIVE EXPERIENCE IN ROAD AND STREAM CROSSING CONSTRUCTION AND HAVE BEEN A LEADER IN ADOPTING UNPAVED ROAD BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO REDUCE SEDIMENT LOADING TO STREAMS FROM ROADWAYS. TNC WILL SUBAWARD THE UPPER LITTLE RED RIVER BARRIER INVENTORY DELIVERABLE (3) TO THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL ARKANSAS. THIS WORK WILL BE LED BY DRS. GINNY AND REID ADAMS.

AWARD PURPOSE  THIS FUNDING PROPOSAL SUPPORTS A COLLABORATION TO IMPLEMENT LOW TECH PROCESS BASED RESTORATION TECHNIQUES (WHICH INCLUDE BEAVER DAM ANALOGS, POST ASSISTED WOODY STRUCTURES, AND OTHER SIMILAR STRUCTURES) THROUGHOUT THE SPRAGUE RIVER WATERSHED IN ORDER TO REDUCE SEDIMENTATION, INCREASE GROUNDWATER STORAGE, AND IMPROVE HABITAT CONDITIONS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE ADDITIONAL TECHNICAL SUPPORT TO LOCAL RESTORATION CREWS AND LOCAL RESTORATION PROFESSIONALS, STREAMLINE THE LTPBR PERMITTING PROCESS ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS, AND IMPLEMENT HIGH QUALITY LTPBR PROJECTS THROUGHOUT THE SPRAGUE RIVER BASIN. THIS EFFORT WILL INCLUDE VOLUNTARY RESTORATION ON PRIVATE LANDS AND RESTORATION ON PUBLIC LANDS (PRIMARILY USFS).EXPECTED DELIVERABLES OR OUTCOMES  THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL BUILD UPON ONGOING LTPBR EFFORTS THROUGHOUT THE SPRAGUE BASIN THAT HAVE ALREADY RESTORED 3.2 MILES OF STREAM LENGTH, IN ADDITION TO 12.1 MILES ANTICIPATED IN 2022. WITH ADDITIONAL FUNDING SUPPORT FOR THE COLLABORATION, PROJECT PARTNERS PLAN TO GREATLY INCREASE THE SCALE OF THIS WORK, TO AT LEAST 15 MILES PER YEAR. LTPBR, WHICH UTILIZES HAND BUILT NON PERMANENT STRUCTURES TO INCREASE SURFACE WATER RESIDENCE TIME, GROUNDWATER STORAGE, FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY, IN CHANNEL HABITAT COMPLEXITY, AND ECOSYSTEM RESILIENCE, IMPLEMENTED AT A WATERSHED SCALE WILL GREATLY IMPROVE HABITAT CONDITIONS FOR AQUATIC SPECIES AND IMPROVE RESILIENCY TO DROUGHT AND WILDFIRE. FURTHER, LTPBR EFFORTS WILL HELP REDUCE SUSPENDED SEDIMENT AND NUTRIENT CONCENTRATIONS IN THE SPRAGUE RIVER THAT CONTRIBUTE TO ALGAE BLOOMS AND ASSOCIATED POOR WATER QUALITY IN UPPER KLAMATH LAKE AND THE KLAMATH RIVER DOWNSTREAM.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  KLAMATH TRIBES, LOCAL COMMUNITIESSUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES  KLAMATH TRIBES   PROJECT PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION. KLAMATH WATERSHED PARTNERSHIP   PROJECT PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION. SUSTAINABLE NORTHWEST   OUTREACH AND EDUCATION COORDINATION. THE NATURE CONSERVANCY   TECHNICAL SUPPORT.

THE WILLIAMSON RIVER AND SPRING CREEK PROVIDE HIGH QUALITY SPAWNING HABITAT FOR REDBAND TROUT. MANY STAKEHOLDERS INCLUDING U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS), HAVE IMPLEMENTED A SPAWNING GRAVEL AUGMENTATION PROGRAM ON THE WILLIAMSON RIVER AND ON OTHER UPPER KLAMATH BASIN TRIBUTARIES SINCE THE MID 1970S WITH THE GOAL OF ADDRESSING LIMITED ADULT REDBAND TROUT SPAWNING, AND FRY AND JUVENILE REARING HABITAT. SPAWNING GRAVEL AUGMENTATION PROJECT SITES ON THE WILLIAMSON RIVER AND ON LOWER SPRING CREEK PROVIDE IMPORTANT SPAWNING HABITAT USED BY LARGE ADFLUVIAL REDBAND TROUT. THE PROJECT INCLUDES TWO PROJECT ELEMENTS  1) PLACE 200 CY OF SPAWNING GRAVEL IN THE WILLIAMSON RIVER DOWNSTREAM OF THE SPRING CREEK CONFLUENCE TO INCREASE SPAWNING HABITAT, AND 2) PLACE 80 LARGE WOOD STRUCTURES ON THE RIVER LEFT CHANNEL MARGIN OF THE WILLIAMSON RIVER TO INCREASE CHANNEL MARGIN HABITAT STRUCTURE FOR ADULT AND JUVENILE REDBAND TROUT. THE TREATMENTS WILL ALSO BENEFIT LOST RIVER SUCKER AND SHORTNOSE SUCKER, AND FOLLOWING THE REMOVAL OF THE LOWER KLAMATH RIVER DAMS, FALL AND SPRING CHINOOK SALMON, SUMMER STEELHEAD, AND PACIFIC LAMPREY. MAPS AND EXISTING CONDITION GROUND PHOTOS ARE INCLUDED IN THE ATTACHMENTS. THE PROJECT WILL ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS OUTLINED IN THE USFWS REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS.  AQUATIC HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS FOR NATIVE FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC SPECIES.  VOLUNTARY RESTORATION OF FISH, WATERFOWL AND OTHER NATIVE WILDLIFE HABITAT ON PRIVATE LANDS IN THE KLAMATH BASIN.  CLIMATE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES THAT RESULT IN IMPROVED CONDITIONS FOR NATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES IN THE KLAMATH BASIN. THE FOLLOWING SECTION PROVIDES SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION WILLIAMSON RIVER RESTORATION PRIORITIES, REDBAND TROUT SPAWNING HABITAT USE, AND THE PROPOSED HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIONS FOR THE PROPERTY ON THE WILLIAMSON RIVER.

THE PROJECT FOCUS IS IMPLEMENTATION OF A WATERCRAFT INSPECTION AND DECONTAMINATION PROGRAM IN 2022 FOR THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA. THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO INCREASE THE RATE AT WHICH BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO SLOW THE SPREAD OF ANS ARE ADOPTED BY THE BOATING PUBLIC STATEWIDE. THE SOUTH DAKOTA ANS MANAGEMENT PLAN PRIORITIES ADDRESSED BY THE PROJECT INCLUDE PREVENT NEW INTRODUCTIONS OF ANS TO SOUTH DAKOTA, EDUCATING ALL AQUATIC USERS ON ANS RISKS AND BEST PRACTICES TO REDUCE THE TRANSPORT OF ANS TO NEW WATER BODIES, LIMIT DISPERSAL OF ESTABLISHED POPULATIONS OF ANS INTO UNINFESTED WATERS OF SOUTH DAKOTA, SUPPORT RESEARCH OF ANS IN SOUTH DAKOTA, AND INCREASE WATERCRAFT INSPECTIONS AND DECONTAMINATIONS TO HELP SLOW THE SPREAD OF ZEBRA MUSSELS AND OTHER ANS.

THIS PROJECT WILL MAINTAIN THE CENTRAL COMMUNICATION AND ALERT SYSTEM FOR THE WESTERN USA TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF ZEBRA AND QUAGGA MUSSELS ON RECREATIONAL WATERCRAFT, AND TO CONTINUE FACILITATING IMPROVED COMMUNICATIONS RESULTING IN INCREASED RESOURCE PROTECTION, INCREASED OPERATIONAL EFFICACY OF FIELD STATIONS, AND IMPROVED CUSTOMER SERVICE FOR BOATERS AND ANGLERS.

INVASIVE CARPS, BIGHEAD, BLACK, GRASS, AND SILVER CARPS, ESCAPED AQUACULTURE AND ENTERED THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER DURING FLOODS IN THE 1970S. SINCE THAT TIME THEY HAVE ADVANCED THROUGHOUT THE MISSISSIPPI BASIN, INCLUDING INTO THE OHIO RIVER. OUR PROPOSED WORK IS IN COLLABORATION WITH THE OHIO RIVER INVASIVE CARP PARTNERSHIP AND OUR PRIMARY OBJECTIVE IS TO MONITOR THE OHIO RIVER MAINSTEM AND KEY TRIBUTARIES FOR EVIDENCE OF SPAWNING SUCCESS IN AREAS UPSTREAM OF THE MARKLAND DAM WHERE THERE HAVE BEEN ONLY SPORADIC OBSERVATIONS OF ADULT INVASIVE CARPS. THIS AREA MARKS THE LEADING EDGE OF THE INVASION AND THEREFORE IS IMPORTANT TO MONITOR SO THAT RAPID RESPONSE AND SUSTAINED MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO REDUCE THE PROBABILITY OF SUCCESSFUL ADVANCEMENT AND ESTABLISHMENT. WE WILL1. CONTINUE PAST ICHTHYOPLANKTON SURVEYS TO IDENTIFY EVIDENCE OF REPRODUCTION UPSTREAM OF MARKLAND DAM,2. INITIATE JUVENILE INVASIVE CARP SURVEYS, AND3. APPLY COMMUNITY SIZE SPECTRA TO FISH ASSEMBLAGE DATA, I.E. COMMUNITY DATA, TO IDENTIFY TARGETS FOR INVASIVE CARP HARVEST AS A PROOF OF CONCEPT PROJECT.MONITORING AND DOCUMENTING THE EXISTENCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF EGGS, LARVAE, AND JUVENILE INVASIVE CARP IS CRITICAL FOR TRACKING THE STATUS AND RATE OF EXPANSION, OR CONTRACTION, OF THE ON GOING INVASION. UNDERSTANDING WHERE REPRODUCTION IS OCCURRING, THE HABITATS AND LOCATIONS WHERE EACH LIFE STAGE IS FOUND ALONG WITH RELATIVE ABUNDANCE WILL INFORM RAPID CONTROL MEASURES, E.G. TARGETED HARVEST, BARRIERS, OR DETERRENT PLACEMENTS. WITH LIMITED STAFF AND RESOURCES WE NEED STRONG MONITORING DATA TO ASSURE THAT EFFORTS AND RESOURCES ARE OPTIMALLY USED. WE INTEND TO SAMPLE JUVENILES AHEAD OF WHAT WE BELIEVE IS THEIR CURRENT ZONE OF REPRODUCTION, THIS WILL PROVIDE US CRITICAL BEFORE INVASION OR BASELINE INFORMATION INTO THE OTHER SPECIES UTILIZING THE SAME NURSERY HABITAT THAT MAY BE NEGATIVELY AFFECTED IF INVASIVE CARP REACH UPSTREAM CURRENTLY UNIVADED RIVER REACHES. THIS ALSO PROVIDES A ROBUST SECOND AVENUE TO MEASURE ACTIVE REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS, WHICH WE USE TO DETERMINE WHERE IMPACTED AND LEADING EDGE AREAS ARE, WHICH IN TURNS ALLOWS FOR THE OPTIMAL USE OF AVAILABLE CONTROL RESOURCES.AT THE OPPOSITE END OF THE INVASIVE CARP MANAGEMENT SPECTRUM ARE POLICIES AND METHODS TO CONTROL ADULT FISH IN AREAS WHERE THEY ARE FULLY ESTABLISHED. GREAT RESOURCES ARE GOING INTO COMMERCIAL HARVEST TO REDUCE DENSITIES, BUT WE ARE DOING SO WITHOUT CLEAR TARGETS OR HARVEST GOALS. WE ACCEPT THAT ERADICATION IS IMPOSSIBLE, SO WE NEED TO DETERMINE ACCEPTABLE DENSITIES TO PROTECT THE FOOD WEB AND NATIVE SPECIES FROM ADVERSE EFFECTS. WE ARE PROPOSING A COMMUNITY SIZE SPECTRA, CSS, FRAMEWORK TO ESTABLISH TARGETS FOR INVASIVE CARP REMOVALS. CSS DESCRIBE THE SIZE STRUCTURE OF COMMUNITIES BY QUANTIFYING THE DECREASE IN ABUNDANCE AMONG INCREASING BODY SIZE CLASSES. CSS HAVE BEEN USED EXTENSIVELY AS INDICATORS OF FISHERY SUSTAINABILITY, AND OVERFISHING, AND TO SET FISHING HARVEST LIMITS IN MARINE SYSTEMS, HOWEVER, TO DATE CSS HAVE NOT BEEN USED TO ADDRESS INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT. WE WILL COMPARE AND CONTRAST ANNUAL CSS AMONG OHIO RIVER POOLS AND OVER TIME TO EVALUATE HOW THEY HAVE RESPONDED TO INCREASES IN INVASIVE CARP FROM EXISTING PARTNER DATA. WE WILL UTILIZE EARLIER YEARS IN IMPACTED POOLS AS WELL AS LONG TERM AVERAGES IN UPSTREAM UNIMPACTED POOLS TO SERVE AS A REFERENCE OR THE HISTORIC TARGET CONDITION. UTILIZING THIS APPROACH AS A BACKDROP, WE WILL STRIVE TO ESTIMATE THE LEVEL TO WHICH INVASIVE CARP ABUNDANCE NEED TO BE REDUCED TO RESTORE THE CSS TO TARGET CONDITIONS. TARGETS ARE ENERGETICALLY BASED, SCIENTIFICALLY DEFENSIBLE, AND CONNECT TO BROADER FOOD WEB PROPERTIES THUS PROVIDE DIRECT CONNECTIONS BETWEEN INVASIVE CARP MANAGEMENT AND ECOLOGICAL SERVICES.

WITH CONTAMINATED WATERCRAFT CONTINUALLY TRANSITING THE REGION, THE THREAT TO THE WESTERN US FROM ZEBRA AND QUAGGA MUSSELS HAS NEVER BEEN GREATER. IT IS GENERALLY AGREED THAT THE MOST EFFECTIVE MEANS TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF DREISSENID MUSSELS IS BY MANDATORY INSPECTION STATIONS AT KEY HIGHWAY POINTS (OR KEY WATERBODIES) FOR ALL RECREATIONAL WATERCRAFT. IN THE PAST SIX YEARS, STATE AGENCY MANAGED WATERCRAFT INSPECTION STATIONS AND HAVE INTERCEPTED THOUSANDS OF CONTAMINATED WATERCRAFT IN THE WESTERN U.S ALONE. THE VAST MAJORITY OF THESE INTERCEPTED BOATS CAME FROM THE LOWER COLORADO RIVER DRAINAGE AND THE GREAT LAKES. IN THE PAST 10 YEARS, STATE RUN WATERCRAFT INSPECTION PROGRAMS HAVE EXPANDED TO EVERY STATE IN THE FAR WEST. THE EXPANSION OF INSPECTION PROGRAMS HAS INCREASED THE NEED TO HAVE TRAINED INSPECTION STATION PROGRAM STAFF AND MANAGERS AS WELL AS REGIONALLY ADOPTED PROTOCOLS AND STANDARDS TO GUIDE WATERCRAFT DECONTAMINATIONS. TO SERVE THESE NEEDS THE PSMFC BEGAN THE WATERCRAFT INSPECTION TRAINING (WIT) PROGRAM IN 2006. TO DATE, NEARLY 160 WIT LEVEL I, II, III AND IV TRAINING CLASSES HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED IN 19 WESTERN STATES (AND BRITISH COLUMBIA) INVOLVING THOUSANDS OF PARTICIPANTS (AND THOSE THAT ARE TRAINED BY PSMFC AT THE LEVEL II AND III COURSES HAVE THEMSELVES TRAINED THOUSANDS MORE). THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO TEACH NATURAL RESOURCE PERSONNEL WATERCRAFT INSPECTION AND DECONTAMINATION TECHNIQUES AND METHODS UTILIZING THE UNIFORM MINIMUM PROTOCOLS AND STANDARDS FOR WATERCRAFT INTERCEPTION PROGRAMS FOR DREISSENID MUSSELS IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES.

THE HIGH MOUNTAIN LAKES ARE 33 RESERVOIRS LOCATED WITHIN THE MOUNTAIN RANGES SURROUNDING SCOTT VALLEY, AND MANY WITHIN THREE WILDERNESS AREAS, THE MARBLES, RUSSIANS, AND TRINITY MOUNTAIN WILDERNESSES. THESE RESERVOIRS ARE NATURALLY EXISTING, HOWEVER OUTFLOW AND MAINTENANCE STRUCTURES WERE CONSTRUCTED IN THE EARLY 1900 S BY HAND PRIOR TO THE WILDERNESS ACT. AFTER CONSTRUCTION OF THE OUTFLOW AND MAINTENANCE STRUCTURES, THESE RESERVOIRS WERE UTILIZED FOR IRRIGATION AND OR HYDRAULIC MINING. MANY OF THE CONSTRUCTED STRUCTURES WERE LATER DESTROYED DURING THE 1964 FLOODS AND WERE NOT REPAIRED AFTERWARDS AS THEY WERE NO LONGER BEING ACTIVELY USED FOR IRRIGATION OR MINING.THE RESERVOIRS CURRENTLY CONTINUE TO FILL THROUGH NATURAL INFLOW, HOWEVER OUTFLOW IS NO LONGER MAINTAINED AND STORAGE CAPACITY AS A RESULT OF THE DAMAGED MAINTENANCE STRUCTURES HAS DECREASED. FOR SEVERAL DECADES THE USE OF THE RESERVOIRS HAS COME UP IN DISCUSSION FOR POTENTIAL IN STREAM FLOW BENEFITS. THESE DISCUSSIONS HAVE CENTERED AROUND THE POSSIBILITY OF STORING WINTER PRECIPITATION AND INFLOW TO BE LATER UTILIZED TO SUPPLEMENT STREAM AND RIVER FLOWS DURING CRITICAL SALMON MIGRATION, IDEALLY JULY SEPTEMBER. PROPONENTS OF REPAIRING THE HIGH MOUNTAIN LAKES TO ENHANCE SUMMER FLOWS FOR SALMONIDS HAVE AGREED THAT ALL STORED WATER WOULD BE UTILIZED SOLELY FOR IN STREAM BENEFITS. IT IS ESTIMATED THAT THE 33 RESERVOIRS COULD PROVIDE UPWARDS OF 3,520 ACRE FEET OF ADDITIONAL FLOW TO THE TRIBUTARIES TO SCOTT RIVER AND THE MAIN STEM SCOTT RIVER, HOWEVER IN DEPTH ANALYSIS IS NEEDED TO VERIFY THIS INFORMATION.AS SOME OF THE RESERVOIRS ARE LOCATED IN THREE DIFFERENT WILDERNESSES LEGISLATION MAY BE NEEDED TO ALLOW FOR THEIR REPAIR AND USE. THE MARBLE MOUNTAIN WILDERNESS MAY BE THE MOST RESTRICTIVE AS IT WAS ESTABLISHED UNDER THE ORIGINAL 1964 ACT AND DESIGNATED AS A PRIMITIVE AREA IN 1935. HOWEVER, THESE RESERVOIRS WERE ALTERED AND USED PRIOR TO THE WILDERNESS ACT, AND THIS WILL BE HELPFUL IN ANY POTENTIAL LEGISLATION.THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL PROVIDE CLEAR AND DEFINED INFORMATION ON THE EFFORT AND RESOURCES NEEDED, AND BENEFITS OF, RESTORING THE HIGH MOUNTAIN LAKES, AND WILL DEFINE A CLEAR PATH FORWARD TO ACCOMPLISHING THEIR RESTORATION. THE FUTURE UTILIZATION OF THE HIGH MOUNTAIN LAKES COULD PROVIDE A DEPENDABLE SUPPLY OF UP TO, OR MORE THAN, 3,520 ACRE FEET OF COLD, CLEAN WATER TO THE TRIBUTARIES TO THE SCOTT RIVER AND THE SCOTT RIVER MAIN STEM. SUCH SUPPLY OF COLD, CLEAN WATER WOULD AIDE IN RESOLVING LONG STANDING ISSUES FOR SALMON FISHERIES DURING LATE SUMMER MONTHS.

THIS PROJECT WILL FUND THE CONTINUED IMPLEMENTATION OF THE APPROVED ALASKA AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN. THE PURPOSES OF THE AK ANSMP IS TO PREVENT, DETECT, AND MANAGE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES STATEWIDE THROUGH COORDINATION AND COLLABORATION.THE PURPOSE OF THIS YEAR S WORK IS TO CONTINUE COORDINATION THROUGH ENGAGEMENT WITH NATIONAL, REGIONAL AND STATEWIDE INVASIVE SPECIES CONSORTIA. ALSO TO IMPROVE PREVENTION TACTICS THROUGH DIRECTED OUTREACH BY PRESENTING AT MEETING, DISTRIBUTING MATERIALS AND COMMUNICATING WITH STAKEHOLDERS. FURTHER, ONE SIGNIFICANT PROJECT TO BE FUNDED WILL INCREASE DREISSENID MUSSEL EARLY DETECTION MONITORING IN WATER BODIES WITHIN ALASKA. PART OF DREISSENID MONITORING INCLUDES INCREASING DATASETS FOR WATER QUALITY TO IMPROVE EVALUATION OF RISK FOR ESTABLISHMENT. INTERIM AND FINAL REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED FOR THIS GRANT ACCORDING TO GRANT REQUIREMENTS.

THE PROJECT ALIGNS WITH QUAGGA ZEBRA ACTION PLAN 2.0 SECTION E.1. AND THE AQUATICNUISANCE SPECIES TASK FORCE 2021 AIS RESEARCH PRIORITIES. IT SUPPORTS THE FOLLOWING PRIORITIES FROMTHE NOTICE OF FUNDING OPPORTUNITY - LIMITING SPREAD OF ZQM BY INFORMING INSPECTION AND DECONTAMINATION OF WATERCRAFT MOVING FROMINVADED TO CURRENTLY FREE JURISDICTIONS- COORDINATING BETWEEN STATE AND OTHER JURISDICTIONS- IDENTIFYING HIGH RISK CONTROL POINTS AND PROTECTING WESTERN ECOSYSTEMS THROUGH FORMATION OFPREVENTION PROGRAMS- INCREASING EFFECTIVENESS OF OUTREACH AND EDUCATION EFFORTS TO ADVANCE PREVENTION.

PROJECT DELIVERABLESINCLUDE QUAGGA AND ZEBRA SAMPLING DATABASE FOR OVER 120 OREGON PRIORITY WATERBODIES, ANNUALWATERBODY SURVEY REPORT AND SAMPLE ANALYSIS FOR 2023, EDUCATIONAL AND TRAINING VIDEOS FOR COMMUNITYSCIENTISTS AND VOLUNTEERS, AND A COMPREHENSIVE QUAGGA AND ZEBRA MUSSELS RISK MAPFOR THE STATE OF OREGON.
