WDFW IS REQUESTING A CONTINUATION GRANT TO CONTINUE AIS WATERCRAFT INSPECTION OPERATIONS AND PROVIDE PROTECTIONS FROM ZQM ON THE LOWER SNAKE RIVER IN THE COLUMBIA RIVER WATERSHED. THE COLUMBIA RIVER WATERSHED IS THE LAST MAJOR WATERWAY IN THE CONTINENTAL UNITED STATES NOT INFESTED WITH ZQM. MITIGATION OF AN INFESTATION OF ZQM WOULD COST NEARLY  100 MILLION PER YEAR TO KEEP OUR HYDROELECTRIC INFRASTRUCTURE OPERATIONAL, AND WOULD DECIMATE RUNS OF ESA LISTED FISH SPECIES SUCH AS SALMON AND STEELHEAD IN THE WATERSHED.

PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE FOCUSED ON LEVERAGING THE RESOURCES NECESSARY TO EXPAND CAPACITY TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES  AIS  TO THE PYRAMID LAKE PAIUTE RESERVATION AND CONDUCT EARLY-DETECTION MONITORING ON THE LOWER TRUCKEE RIVER AND PYRAMID LAKE. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROPOSAL CONCENTRATE ON THE PRESERVATION OF THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED CUI-UI AND THREATENED LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT TROUT AND THE NATURAL, CULTURAL, RECREATIONAL, AND ECONOMIC RESOURCES OF THE PYRAMID LAKE PAIUTE TRIBE. THROUGH THIS PROPOSED PROJECT, THE PLPT S AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PROGRAM WILL BE ABLE TO INCREASE CAPACITY FOR SUSTAINABILITY AND EFFECTIVE IMPLEMENTATION OF AIS PREVENTION THROUGH MORE CONSISTENT DAILY OPERATION OF THE WATERCRAFT INSPECTION AND DECONTAMINATION STATION IN SUTCLIFFE, NV, INCREASE THE NUMBER HOURS SPENT PROVIDING PUBLIC OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ON INVASIVE MUSSELS, AND CONDUCT EARLY-DETECTION MONITORING TO PROVIDE COMPLETE AIS MANAGEMENT ON THE PYRAMID LAKE PAIUTE RESERVATION.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO PROMOTE THE PREVENTION PRACTICES OF CLEAN DRAIN DRY AMONG NON-MOTORIZED RECREATIONISTS TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES SPREAD AND INTRODUCTION. THE PRIMARY ACTIVITIES OF THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE WORKING CLOSELY WITH NON-MOTORIZED BOATING MANUFACTURERS TO DISTRIBUTE CLEAN DRAIN DRY MESSAGING IN PRINT AND DIGITAL FORMATS TO THEIR CUSTOMERS, CONDUCT TARGETED MEDIA CAMPAIGNS BASED ON ONLINE USER ACTIVITIES, AND COLLABORATE WITH INDUSTRY PARTNERS AND MEDIA INFLUENCERS TO PROMOTE NON-MOTORIZED BOATER BEHAVIORS THAT PREVENT THE SPREAD OF INVASIVE SPECIES.THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE, A  AT LEAST 420 THOUSAND NON-MOTORIZED BOATERS EXPOSED TO CLEAN DRAIN DRY MESSAGING THROUGH DIRECT CONTACT WITH PRODUCTS AND INDUSTRY OUTREACH, B  AT LEAST 15 THOUSAND PEOPLE EXPOSED TO INFLUENCER MESSAGING VIA ONLINE MEDIA PLATFORMS, C  AT LEAST 10 MILLION ONLINE DIGITAL IMPRESSIONS OF CLEAN DRAIN DY VIA ADVERTISING.PROMOTING BEHAVIORS THAT LIMIT THE SPREAD OF UNWANTED INVASIVE SPECIES WILL BENEFIT AND PROTECT OUR NATURAL RESOURCES, SUCH AS LAKES, RIVERS AND RESERVOIRS FOR THE BENEFIT OF PUBLIC ACCESS AND RECREATION, IRRIGATION, GENERATING UTILITIES, AND HEALTHY HABITATS FOR WILDLIFE. MINIMIZING THE SPREAD AND ESTABLISHMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES, BENEFITS OUR NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS BY ALLOWING PROGRAM FOCUS TO REMAIN ON PREVENTION STRATEGIES TO PROTECT RESOURCES RATHER THAN COSTLY CONTROL STRATEGIES.

UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES  UDWR  WILL IMPLEMENT THE APPROVED UTAH AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN, IN PART USING FUNDS PROVIDED BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE USFWS  FOR INTERDICTION OF POTENTIALLY DREISSENA MUSSEL ENCRUSTED WATERCRAFT FROM INTERSTATE WATERBODIES OR FEDERALLY AFFECTED WATERBODIES. THE PLAN PRIMARILY TARGETS CONTROL FOR SPREAD OF DREISSENA MUSSELS AND OTHER AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES THROUGH INTERCEPTION OF WATERCRAFT EXPOSED TO QUAGGA MUSSEL INFESTED WATERBODIES  INSPECTION OF THE WATERCRAFT  WATERCRAFT DECONTAMINATION WHEN DEEMED NECESSARY  AND EDUCATION OF BOATERS ABOUT THE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES ISSUE. PUBLIC EDUCATION EMPHASIZES THE NEED TO ROUTINELY  CLEAN, DRAIN AND  DRY  WATERCRAFT FOLLOWING EVERY EXCURSION. WATERCRAFT EXITING LAKE POWELL AT TWO MAIN LAUNCH RAMPS DOWNLAKE  STATELINE AND WAHWEAP  WILL BE INSPECTED BY UDWR TECHNICIANS FOR ATTACHED MUSSELS, DRAINED OF ALL WATER, AND TAGGED AS LEAVING AN INFESTED WATERBODY. ALL INSPECTION AND DECONTAMINATION RECORDS WILL BE INPUT INTO THE REGIONAL WATERCRAFT INSPECTION AND DECONTAMINATION  WID  DATABASE SO THAT AIS STAFF FROM OTHER ENTITIES, INCLUDING OTHER WESTERN STATES, CAN ACCESS SEARCH THE RECORDS AND TAKE THE NECESSARY STEPS TO PREVENT QUAGGA MUSSEL INTRODUCTION INTO THEIR WATERS. IN ADDITION, WATERCRAFT WILL BE INTERDICTED AT THE NEWLY ESTABLISHED MANDATORY INSPECTION STATION IN KANAB, UT, ABOUT 70 MILES FROM THE TWO AFOREMENTIONED LAUNCH RAMPS AT LAKE POWELL. THIS NEW INSPECTION STATION WAS ESTABLISHED TO MORE EFFECTIVELY INTERDICT BOATS LEAVING ANTELOPE POINT MARINA ON THE ARIZONA SIDE OF LAKE POWELL, ALONG WITH WATERCRAFT USING HIGHWAY 89 TO TRAVEL NORTH FROM INFESTED AREAS WITHIN THE STATE OF ARIZONA. LASTLY, THE MANDATORY WATERCRAFT INSPECTION STATION ALONG INTERSTATE 15 OUTSIDE ST. GEORGE, UTAH, CONTINUES TO BE A CRITICAL PINCH POINT FOR WATERCRAFT HEADING NORTH FROM THE INFESTED LOWER COLORADO RIVER REGION. WATERCRAFT DECONTAMINATIONS WILL BE PERFORMED AS RESOURCES ALLOW AND AS DEEMED NECESSARY.

THE KLAMATH BASIN ECOSYSTEM HAS HISTORICALLY BEEN ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT WETLAND COMPLEXES FOR WATERFOWL AND WETLAND-ASSOCIATED BIRDS IN NORTH AMERICA. HOWEVER, IN THE FIRST HALF OF THE TWENTIETH CENTURY, MUCH OF THE HISTORICAL WETLAND HABITAT WAS DRAINED WITH THE AUTHORIZATION OF THE KLAMATH PROJECT, WITH MUCH OF THE REMAINING HABITAT ON THE LOWER KLAMATH NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE  LKNWR  AND TULE LAKE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE  TLNWR . PRESENTLY, BOTH REFUGES ARE NEARLY ENTIRELY DRY AND SERVE LITTLE FUNCTIONAL VALUE FOR WATERFOWL AND OTHER WETLAND-ASSOCIATED SPECIES. WETLAND HABITAT ON THE REFUGES HAS BEEN SUBJECT TO CHRONIC WATER SHORTAGES DUE TO LIMITED WATER SUPPLIES, WHICH HAS BEEN ESPECIALLY TRUE ON LKNWR. TLNWR, ON THE OTHER HAND, HAS GENERALLY AVOIDED THE IMPACT OF WATER SHORTAGES AS IRRIGATION RETURN FLOWS HAD HISTORICALLY PROVIDED THE SUMPS WITH ENOUGH WATER. DUCKS UNLIMITED AND PARTNERS, AIM TO IMPROVE WETLAND HABITAT ON BOTH LKNWR AND TLNWR FOR WATERFOWL, WETLAND-ASSOCIATED BIRDS, AND OTHER FISH AND WILDLIFE BY IMPROVING ACCESS TO AN ALTERNATIVE SOURCE OF WATER  DRAINAGE AND IRRIGATION RETURN FLOWS  AND INCREASING CAPACITY TO MANAGE AND MOVE WATER THROUGH DIFFERENT PARTS OF THE REFUGES. THESE OPERATIONAL IMPROVEMENTS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY THE CONSTRUCTION OF FOUR PUMPING STATIONS, TWO EACH IN BOTH LKNWR AND TLNWR. TOGETHER, THESE PUMPING STATIONS WILL IMPROVE WATER SUPPLY RELIABILITY AND FUNCTIONALITY ON OVER 20,000 ACRES OF WETLAND HABITAT ON BOTH REFUGES, WHILE ALSO IMPROVING IRRIGATION EFFICIENCY, BY PROVIDING FLEXIBILITY IN MANAGEMENT AND DECREASING OPERATIONAL COSTS FOR OVER 20,000 ACRES OF IRRIGATED AGRICULTURE.

ANGLO-AMERICAN SETTLEMENT OF THE UPPER KLAMATH BASIN BEGAN IN THE MID-19TH CENTURY. THE BUREAU OF RECLAMATION  2005  ESTIMATES THAT BY AROUND 1960, NO LAND IN THE UPPER BASIN, ASIDE FROM SOME REMOTE ALPINE AND SUB-ALPINE WATERSHEDS REMAINED UNTOUCHED BY AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES. BETWEEN 1905 AND THE 1960S, WETLANDS IN THE UPPER KLAMATH BASIN WERE REDUCED FROM APPROXIMATELY 350,000 ACRES TO 75,000 ACRES AS THESE AREAS WERE DRAINED, DIKED, AND CONVERTED TO AGRICULTURE  BOR, 2005 . THE MAJORITY OF THE REMAINING 75,000 WETLAND ACRES ARE CONTAINED WITHIN THE LOWER KLAMATH, TULE LAKE, AND UPPER KLAMATH NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES. OTHER WETLANDS ARE OWNED AND MANAGED BY THE STATE OF OREGON  KLAMATH WILDLIFE AREA, MILLER ISLAND UNIT . THE REMAINING WETLANDS ARE OWNED AND MANAGED PRIVATELY. THE FRINGE WETLAND MASTER PLAN FOR THE KENO REACH OF THE KLAMATH RIVER WOULD IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE CREATION, RESTORATION, AND ENHANCEMENT OF LITTORAL WETLANDS AND OTHER FLOODPLAIN WETLANDS ALONG AND WITHIN THE KENO REACH. RESTORATION OF WETLANDS WITHIN THIS REACH IS EXPECTED TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY BY REMOVING NUTRIENTS, SUSPENDED SOLIDS, AND OTHER POLLUTANTS FROM WATER IN THE KLAMATH RIVER, AND WATER FLOWS DOWNSTREAM THROUGH THE REACH. FURTHER, WETLAND CREATION, RESTORATION, AND ENHANCEMENT WILL IMPROVE THE QUALITY AND AVAILABILITY OF HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY WATERFOWL AND OTHER NATIVE WILDLIFE SUCH AS FISH  INCLUDING ESA ENDANGERED SHORTNOSE AND LOST RIVER SUCKERS AND CRITICAL HABITAT , SONGBIRDS, MIGRATORY SHOREBIRDS, AMPHIBIANS, REPTILES, INVERTEBRATES, AND MAMMALS. FOLLOWING DAM REMOVAL ON THE KLAMATH RIVER, SALMON AND STEELHEAD ARE EXPECTED TO RETURN TO THE UPPER KLAMATH BASIN. CREATION, EXPANSION, AND IMPROVEMENT OF WETLANDS WITHIN THE REACH, AS WELL AS THE RESULTING WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENTS, WOULD BENEFIT ANADROMOUS FISH ENTERING THE REACH. THE PLAN WILL ALSO IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF DIFFUSE SOURCE TREATMENT WETLANDS TO LOCALLY TREAT AGRICULTURAL RUNOFF FROM ADJACENT AGRICULTURAL DRAINS. MORE SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL FIRST ANALYSIS EXISTING TOPOGRAPHIC AND BATHYMETRIC DATA IN THE PROJECT REACH TO IDENTIFY AREAS WHERE FRINGE WETLAND CREATION, RESTORATION, AND OR ENHANCEMENT ARE POSSIBLE. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL THEN INITIATE AN OUTREACH EFFORT TO LANDOWNERS ALONG THE PROJECT REACH TO GAUGE INTEREST IN FUTURE PARTICIPATION IN WETLAND RESTORATION ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS. DATA FROM THESE FIRST TASKS WILL BE CAPTURED AND STORED IN A DATABASE THAT SERVE AS THE BASIS FOR FUTURE WETLAND PROJECT DEVELOPMENT. THE PROJECT TEAM ALSO INTENDS TO PARTNER WITH THE TULE SMOKE HUNT CLUB TO EVALUATE WETLAND ENHANCEMENT AND RESTORATION OPPORTUNITIES ON CLUB PROPERTY. THIS WILL INCLUDE HIGH-RESOLUTION TOPO-BATHYMETRIC DATA COLLECTION FOLLOWING A CONTROLLED BURN IN THE SPRING OF 2023, EVALUATION AND MODELING OF SITE HYDROLOGY, AND IDENTIFICATION OF ALTERNATIVES FOR IMPROVING WATER CIRCULATION THROUGH THE EXISTING WETLANDS. ENGINEERING DESIGN DRAWINGS WILL BE COMPLETED FOR THE PREFERRED ALTERNATIVE, AND THE DESIGN DRAWINGS WILL BE USED TO APPLY FOR LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL REGULATORY APPROVALS NECESSARY FOR IMPLEMENTING THE PROJECT. THE TEAM WILL UNDERTAKE AN INVASIVE EXOTIC VEGETATION  IEV  MAPPING EXERCISE ON THE PROPERTY TO IDENTIFY PRIORITY AREAS FOR IEV PRE-TREATMENT PRIOR TO THE INITIATION OF A FUTURE WETLAND RESTORATION PROJECT. THE PROPOSED PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES DEVELOPMENT OF AN ADVANCED IEV PRETREATMENT PLAN, APPLICATION FOR NECESSARY REGULATORY APPROVALS FOR HERBICIDE APPLICATION, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PLAN FOR THREE YEARS. THE PLAN WILL BE DEVELOPED TO BE FLEXIBLE AND ADAPTABLE TO OTHER AREAS IN ANTICIPATION OF FUTURE USE ACROSS TO ENTIRE LENGTH OF THE KENO REACH.

THE STEARNS COUNTY SHORELINE HABITAT PROJECTS   2022 WILL CONTINUE TO BUILD ON THE STRONG HABITAT RESTORATION ANDPROTECTION EFFORT ON GLACIAL LAKES IN STEARNS COUNTY.THE STEARNS COUNTY SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT SWCD  HAS A DEDICATED LAKESHED SPECIALIST TO WORK WITH LAKESHORE OWNERS ON HABITAT PROJECTS THAT RESTORE ANDPROTECT FISH AND WILDLIFE COMMUNITIES.LANDOWNERS FOR EACH PROJECT PROPOSED ARE COMMITTED TO COMPLETING ASHORELINE RESTORATION.EACH OF THESE PROJECTS WILL USE NATURAL TECHNIQUES  NATIVE GRASSES, WILDFLOWERS, TREES,SHRUBS, VINES AND VARIOUS BIO-ENGINEERING TECHNIQUES THAT USE WOOD AND FOOTER ROCK ABOVE AND BELOW THE ORDINARYHIGH WATER  OHW  LEVEL TO EXPAND AND PROTECT FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT.WITH THE RESTORATION OR PROTECTION OFNATURAL SHORELINES MANY NATIVE FISH SPECIES WILL ENJOY ADDITIONAL AND IMPROVED HABITAT.THE PROPERTY OWNERSPERSONAL EXPERIENCE WILL ALSO BE USED TO PROMOTE ADDITIONAL PROJECTS AND HABITAT CONNECTIONS.THIS WILL BE DONEBY ALLOWING OTHER LANDOWNERS AND CONTRACTORS TO VIEW PROJECT SITES BEFORE, DURING AND AFTER PROJECT COMPLETION. ONCE COMPLETE, LANDOWNERS ROUTINELY WELCOME OTHER PROPERTY OWNERS TO VIEW THEIR PROPERTIES TO UNDERSTAND THE BENEFITS AND VISUALLY SEE WHAT CHANGES HAVE BEEN MADE. ON AVERAGE, COORDINATED SITE VISITS LIKE THIS HAPPEN 12 TIMES A YEAR AND ARE A VERY EFFECTIVE TECHNIQUE IN GIVING SHORELINE PROPERTY OWNERS A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE SCOPE OF A PROJECT AND THE MULTIPLE BENEFITS.

THE WASHOE TRIBE OF NEVADA AND CALIFORNIA (THE TRIBE) IS A FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBE ORGANIZED PURSUANT TO THE INDIAN REORGANIZATION ACT OF JUNE 18, 1934, AS AMENDED. LAKE TAHOE IS THE HEART OF THE TRIBE S ABORIGINAL PROPERTY AND IS THE TRIBE S TRADITIONAL SUMMER HOME (I.E., TRADITIONAL CULTURAL PROPERTY). ALTHOUGH NAMED IN THE LAKE TAHOE RESTORATION ACT (THE ACT), THE TRIBE HAS HAD THE LEAST AMOUNT OF INVOLVEMENT AMONG THE LISTED ORGANIZATIONS IN SETTING PRIORITIES FOR IMPLEMENTING THE ACT. THIS SITUATION IS UNFORTUNATE BECAUSE THE TRIBE HAS MUCH TO CONTRIBUTE WITH A FAR LONGER AND MORE SUCCESSFUL TENURE OF MANAGING THE LAKE TAHOE WATERSHED THAN ANY OTHER ORGANIZATION NAMED IN THE ACT. IN RECENT DECADES,  CHANGING ATTITUDES AND ASSUMPTIONS ABOUT TAHOE S ENVIRONMENT HAVE BOTH ENSHRINED AND DESECRATED ITS LANDSCAPE  (LAKE TAHOE WATERSHED ASSESSMENT). THE SPREAD AND CONTROL OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) AND THE EXTIRPATION AND REINTRODUCTION OF LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT TROUT (LCT) ARE EMBLEMATIC OF THESE CHANGES. THIS PROJECT PROPOSAL IS TO FACILITATE MORE ACTIVE PARTICIPATION OF THE TRIBE IN SETTING THE PRIORITIES FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE ACT AND OVERSEEING RESTORATION EFFORTS IN THE LAKE TAHOE WATERSHED, ESPECIALLY, RELATED TO AIS AND LCT.

THE YY MALE CONSORTIUM IS AN INITIATIVE SPONSORED BY THE WESTERN ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES (WAFWA) TO DEVELOP NEW APPROACHES FOR ERADICATING INVASIVE FISH SPECIES FOR THE BENEFIT OF SPORTFISHING AND NATIVE FISH. ANNUALLY, FISH MANAGERS SPEND MILLIONS OF DOLLARS ATTEMPTING TO ERADICATE INVASIVE FISH SPECIES THROUGH CHEMICAL AND MECHANICAL REMOVAL, WITH FEW DOCUMENTED CASES OF SUCCESS. IN ADDITION, WITH NEW INTRODUCTIONS OF INVASIVE FISH, MANAGERS HAVE FEW TOOLS TO STOP AN INTRODUCTION BEFORE THE INVASIVE FISH GETS ESTABLISHED. THE YY MALE CONSORTIUM WAS FORMED IN 2018 UNDER THE DIRECTION OF WAFWA AND HAS CONTINUED TO PIONEER THE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF YY MALE FISH AS A TOOL TO COMBAT INVASIVE FISHES.MALE FISH TYPICALLY HAVE AN X AND A Y CHROMOSOME, BUT IN THE HATCHERY, SCIENTISTS HAVE DEVELOPED GENETICALLY ALL YY MALE BROODSTOCKS CAPABLE OF PRODUCING LARGE NUMBERS OF YY MALE FISH FOR USE IN COMBATING INVASIVE FISH. THE BASIC APPROACH IS SIMPLE. FOR ERADICATION EFFORTS, YOU REMOVE 25-50  OF THE INVASIVE FISH SPECIES ANNUALLY AND THEN STOCK AN EQUIVALENT NUMBER OF YY MALES TO REPLACE FISH THAT ARE REMOVED. THE YY MALES BREED WITH WILD FEMALES AND PRODUCE ONLY MALE OFFSPRING. OVER TIME, THE INVASIVE POPULATION BECOME ALL MALES. WHEN THIS OCCURS, YOU CONTINUE STOCKING YY MALES UNTIL THE INVASIVE POPULATION DIES OUT IN A MATTER OF YEARS, DEPENDING ON HOW LONG LIVED THE SPECIES IS. BECAUSE THE YY MALES ARE NOT GENETICALLY MODIFIED ORGANISMS (GMO), IF THE DECISION IS MADE TO STOP THE PROGRAM, THE SEX RATIO WILL RETURN TO 50:50 MALE TO FEMALE AND CONTINUE ON  COMPLETELY REVERSIBLE. IN THE CASE OF NEW INTRODUCTIONS, IF THEY ARE DETECTED EARLY AND THERE IS A YY MALE BROODSTOCK AVAILABLE FOR THE INVASIVE FISH, YOU SIMPLY STOCK THE YY MALES WITH THE INVASIVE POPULATION AND CONVERT THEM TO ALL MALES QUICKLY, NEVER ALLOWING THE INTRODUCTION TO GET GOING. NUMEROUS PUBLISHED STUDIES THAT SIMULATE USING YY MALES IN STREAMS, PARTICULARLY THOSE WHERE INVASIVE FISH REMOVAL OCCURS SIMULTANEOUSLY, SHOW THAT OVER TIME YY MALES WILL SHIFT THE SEX RATIO TO ALL MALES, RESULTING IN COMPLETE ERADICATION OF THE TARGET SPECIES. ON-GOING FIELD STUDIES ARE NOW DEMONSTRATING THAT INVASIVE BROOK TROUT CAN BE ERADICATED FROM SMALL STREAMS IN LESS THAN 10 YEARS. CURRENTLY THE YY MALE BROOK TROUT HATCHERY STOCK IS THE ONLY ONE FULLY DEVELOPED.WITH ANNUAL FUNDING FROM WAFWA AND NEW FUNDING THROUGH THIS GRANT AND FROM THE US FOREST SERVICE, THE YY MALE CONSORTIUM PLANS TO ACCELERATE THE DEVELOPMENT AND EVALUATION OF YY MALE HATCHERY BROODSTOCKS OVER THE NEXT 4 YEARS WITH THE FOLLOWING ACTIONS, DELIVERABLES, AND OUTCOMES: (1) WORK WITH THE AQUATIC ANIMAL DRUG APPROVAL PROJECT AND THE FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION TO COORDINATE DISTRIBUTION OF YY MALE BROOK TROUT EGGS TO COOPERATORS, (2) PROVIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE ON FIELD EVALUATIONS OF YY BROOK TROUT TO PARTNERS RECEIVING EGGS AND CONTINUE COORDINATION OF THE YY BROOK TROUT TECHNICAL TEAM, (3) COMPLETE THE SCIENCE FOR BROWN TROUT, LAKE TROUT AND COMMON CARP YY MALE BROODSTOCKS AND DEVELOP THE SCIENCE FOR WALLEYE AND NORTHERN PIKE, (4) CONTINUE TO DOCUMENT TIME TO ERADICATION IN FIELD STUDIES OF YY MALE BROOK TROUT ON TWO IDAHO STREAMS, (5) IDENTIFY WAFWA PARTNERS OR OTHER COLLABORATORS WILLING TO DEVELOP YY MALE BROODSTOCKS FOR THE ABOVE SPECIES AT THEIR HATCHERIES, (6) COMMUNICATE PROGRAM OBJECTIVES AND FINDINGS VERBALLY AND IN WRITING, (7) WORK WITH AADAP AND THE FDA TO PROVIDE REGULATORY APPROVAL FOR DEVELOPMENT OF NEW YY MALE BROODSTOCKS, AND (8) WITH FDA APPROVAL, BEGIN DEVELOPMENT OF A YY MALE BROWN TROUT BROODSTOCK BY 2024. BENEFICIARIES WILL INCLUDE THE GENERAL PUBLIC, WHO WILL BENEFIT WITH THE RESTORATION OF NATIVE FISHES AND THEIR ASSOCIATED FISHERIES, ALONG WITH FISHERIES MANAGERS, WHO WILL HAVE NEW TOOLS TO COMBAT ONE OF THE MOST PERVASIVE IMPACTS TO THE RIVERS AND LAKES THEY MANAGE FOR THE PUBLIC.

GENETICS MANAGEMENT IS A CRITICALLY IMPORTANT COMPONENT OF SPECIES CONSERVATION, ESPECIALLY WHEN CAPTIVE PROPAGATION AND REINTRODUCTION IS A POSSIBLE MANAGEMENT TOOL. TRIPOT DARTER (ETHEOSTOMA TRISELLA) IS A FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES THAT HAS NOT BEEN SUBJECT TO ADEQUATE GENETICS RESEARCH. FURTHERMORE, US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE IS CONSIDERING CAPTIVE PROPAGATION AND REINTRODUCTION FOR TRISPOT DARTER. TO ENSURE THAT REINTRODUCTION EFFORTS ARE EFFECTIVE, WE WILL DEVELOP A GENETICS MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR TRISPOT DARTER. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL CHARACTERIZE GENOMIC DIVERSITY AND STRUCTURE FOR ALL KNOWN TRISPOT DARTER POPULATIONS, GENERATE BASELINE GENETIC DATA, AND DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS FOR BROODSTOCK SOURCES. GENOTYPING WILL BE DONE USING THE 3RAD APPROACH. DATA ANALYSES WILL FOLLOW STANDARD METHODS. RESULTS WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP GUIDELINES FOR CAPTIVE PROPAGATION AND FUTURE MONITORING EFFORTS. A GENETICS MANAGEMENT PLAN WILL BE WRITTEN FOR LONG-TERM CONSERVATION EFFORTS FORTRISPOT DARTER.

TYONEK TRIBAL CONSERVATION DISTRICT (TTCD) IS A TRIBAL NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION FORMED IN 2005 TO CONSERVE,ENHANCE, AND ENCOURAGE THE WISE USE OF NATURAL RESOURCES. TTCD WORKS WITH LOCAL, STATE, AND NATIONAL PARTNERS TOACHIEVE OUR MISSION THROUGH COMMUNITY-DRIVEN CONSERVATION. TYONEK IS HOME TO THE TEBUGHNA, OR BEACH PEOPLE.SUBSISTENCE RESOURCES, INCLUDING SALMON, ARE A SIGNIFICANT COMPONENT OF THE DIET AND CULTURAL IDENTITY OF THETEBUGHNA. FOR THIS REASON, PROTECTING AND IMPROVING FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT HAS BEEN A PRIORITY FOR TTCD SINCEOUR FORMATION.INVASIVE SPECIES, INCLUDING NORTHERN PIKE, ELODEA, AND HIGH-PRIORITY TERRESTRIAL PLANTS, ARE SIGNIFICANT THREATSTO SUBSISTENCE RESOURCES WITHIN THE DISTRICT AND TO THE SURROUNDING FEDERAL, PRIVATE, AND STATE LANDS WHERE THESEINVASIVE SPECIES HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO SPREAD. TTCD HAS WORKED WITH THE US FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) ANDOTHER PARTNERS SINCE 2011 TO ADDRESS THESE THREATS. MULTIPLE PARTNERS, INCLUDING THE USFWS, HAVE SIGNIFICANTLYAND EFFECTIVELY INVESTED IN FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS IN THE TTCD AREA. EARLY DETECTIONSURVEYS, RAPID RESPONSE, AND OUTREACH ON INVASIVE SPECIES ARE NEEDED TO SECURE THESE INVESTMENTS AND TO PREVENTNEW INTRODUCTIONS INTO FEDERAL, PRIVATE, STATE, AND TRIBAL LANDS.IN 2023-2026, THE TYONEK TRIBAL CONSERVATION DISTRICT WILL EXPAND AN AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS) PARTNERSHIPACROSS THE MATANUSKA-SUSITNA BASIN TO ADVANCE PREVENTION, EARLY DETECTION, AND RAPID RESPONSE ACROSS THE TTCD AND THE MAT-SU BOROUGH. TTCD WILL ADDRESS NORTHERN PIKE WITHIN THE DISTRICT THROUGH PREVENTION, EARLY DETECTIONSURVEYS, NORTHERN PIKE SUPPRESSION AND ERADICATION, AND POST-TREATMENT SALMON POPULATION MONITORING. TTCD WILLADDRESS ELODEA BY ADVANCING AN ELODEA WATERBODY PRIORITIZATION PROCESS AND PARTNERSHIP EVENTS TO BUILD THECAPACITY FOR LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS TO ASSIST IN PREVENTION, EARLY DETECTION SURVEYS, CONTAINMENT, ERADICATION, ANDPOST-TREATMENT MONITORING. THE PRIORITIZATION PROCESS AND RESULTING TOOLS WILL INFORM FUTURE IMPLEMENTATIONPLANS, PARTNERSHIPS, AND FUNDING PROPOSALS. TTCD WILL CONTINUE TO LEAD THE MAT-SU ELODEA TASK FORCE, CONDUCTEARLY DETECTION SURVEYS THROUGHOUT THE MAT-SU AND TTCD AREAS, AND FACILITATE RAPID RESPONSE OF INFESTATIONS. FORTERRESTRIAL INVASIVE PLANTS, TTCD WILL CONTINUE TO ADMINISTER ITS SUCCESSFUL EARLY DETECTION RAPID RESPONSEPROGRAM TO ERADICATE NOVEL INFESTATIONS ALONG THE WESTSIDE ROAD SYSTEM BEFORE ESTABLISHMENT.THROUGH THESE EFFORTS, TTCD WILL CONTINUE TO LEAD INVASIVE SPECIES PREVENTION, EARLY DETECTION, AND RAPIDRESPONSE IN WESTERN COOK INLET AND THE SUSITNA BASIN TO CONSERVE AND RESTORE SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKAS NATIVE FISHPOPULATIONS, VEGETATION COMMUNITIES, AND PRODUCTIVE AQUATIC AND TERRESTRIAL ECOSYSTEMS.

THE PEOPLE OF THE YUKON RIVER RELY HEAVILY ON THE WATERSHEDS NATURAL RESOURCES TO FEED THEIR FAMILIES AND SUPPORT THEIR CULTURE. ANNUAL CHINOOK AND CHUM SALMON HARVEST IS ESSENTIAL FOR THE LIVELIHOOD OF THE 76 SMALL, RURAL VILLAGES SCATTERED AROUND THE APPROXIMATELY 330,000 SQUARE MILE WATERSHED. SINCE 1997, CHINOOK SALMON RUNS AND HARVEST HAVE DECLINED. IN RECENT YEARS, BOTH CHINOOK AND CHUM SALMON RUNS FAILED COMPLETELY WITH DEVASTATING CONSEQUENCES TO YUKON RIVER WATERSHED PEOPLE, FAMILIES, COMMUNITY AND CULTURE. SIGNIFICANT HABITAT ALTERATION HAS OCCURRED THROUGHOUT PORTIONS OF THE YUKON RIVER WATERSHED THAT COULD BE IMPACTING SALMON RECRUITMENT, YET NO COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT OF THESE ALTERATIONS AND THEIR POTENTIAL IMPACT TO WILD SALMON RUNS HAS BEEN COMPLETED. THE YUKON RIVER DRAINAGE FISHERIES ASSOCIATION (YRDFA) WILL CONSULT DIRECTLY WITH YUKON RIVER WATERSHED COMMUNITIES AND INCORPORATE TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE (TEK) TO COMPLETE A COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT AND PRIORITIZATION OF HABITAT RESTORATION NEEDS DOCUMENTED IN A WATERSHED-WIDE ECOSYSTEM ACTION PLAN. YRDFA WILL EMPLOY RESIDENTS OF THE RURAL YUKON VILLAGES TO CARRY OUT THIS EFFORT TO THE GREATEST EXTENT POSSIBLE. THIS PROJECT WILL TAKE PLACE OVER AN 18-MONTH TIME PERIOD AND WILL RESULT IN A WRITTEN PLANNING DOCUMENT AND GEOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION SYSTEM (GIS) PLANNING TOOL WHICH WILL BE USED TO UNDERSTAND AND DEVELOP ACTIONS TO ADDRESS THE ONGOING CRISIS OF SALMON DECLINES. THE GIS TOOL WILL BE A WEB BASED, PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE GIS STORY MAP WHICH COLLATES AND PRIORITIZES EXISTING AVAILABLE GIS DATA REGARDING WATERSHED VALUES AND THREATS, INCORPORATES TEK COLLECTED THROUGH COMMUNITY MEETINGS AND INTERVIEWS, AND ON-THE-GROUND ASSESSMENTS CONDUCTED BY TRAINED FIELD TECHNICIANS.  THE WATERSHED ECOSYSTEM ACTION PLAN WILL ADDRESS FRESHWATER HABITAT IMPACTS THAT ARE CONTRIBUTING TO THE DEGRADATION OF PACIFIC SALMON FRESHWATER REARING AND SPAWNING HABITATS IN THE YUKON RIVER DRAINAGE.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO BRING MORE IMAGERY, VISUAL MEDIA, AND EDUCATIONAL STORIES TO IMPERILED FISHES AND AQUATIC LIFE OF THE COLORADO RIVER BASIN AND THE BROADER SOUTHWEST, SUCH AS THE RAZORBACK SUCKER AND APACHE TROUT. IMAGERY AND FILMS WILL RAISE AWARENESS OF CONSERVATION NEEDS OF THESE FISHES, AND THE WORK OF USFWS AND PARTNERS TO ADDRESS THESE NEEDS. FRESHWATERS LLLUSTRATED BRINGS UNIQUE MISSION-DRIVEN SKILLS AND APPROACHES TO THIS PARTNERSHIP, AND ALSO OFFERS IN-KIND SERVICES AND RESOURCES TO THIS COOPARATIVE AGREEMENT

NATURAL RESOURCES INCLUDING KODIAK BROWN BEAR, PACIFIC SALMON, AND SEABIRDS HAVE GREAT SOCIOECOLOGICAL IMPORTANCE TO THE KODIAK ARCHIPELAGO (ARCHIPELAGO). INVASIVE PLANTS AND ANIMALS PRESENT ON AND ADJACENT TO THE ARCHIPELAGO THREATEN THE WELLBEING OF THE ARCHIPELAGOS NATURAL RESOURCES.  CAPACITY TO ADDRESS THE THREATS FROM THESE INVASIVE SPECIES IS LACKING. CONSEQUENTLY, KODIAK SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT WILL CONDUCT INVASIVE SPECIES PREVENTION, EARLY DETECTION AND RAPID RESPONSE AND INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES THROUGHOUT THE  ARCHIPELAGO WHERE CAPACITY GAPS ARE MOST IMPACTFUL AS A METHOD OF PROTECTING THE IMPORTANT NATURAL RESOURCES.

CONSISTENT WITH THE SNAKE RIVER BASIN ADJUDICATION AGREEMENT, U.S. FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) ADMINISTERS FUNDING TO THE NEZ PERCE TRIBE (TRIBE) TO JOINTLY MANAGE AND OPERATE DWORSHAK NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY (NFH). FUNDING FOR PRODUCING APPROXIMATELY 2.1 MILLION STEELHEAD JUVENILES AT DWORSHAK NFH IS PROVIDED BY THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS (COE) TO THE TRIBE THROUGH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE).

QUINAULT NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY PRODUCES OVER 3.5 MILLION JUVENILE SALMON AND STEELHEAD ANNUALLY FOR FRESHWATER RELEASE OR TRANSFER TO QUINAULT INDIAN NATION OWNED FACILITIES. WITH FIVE DIFFERENT REARING STOCKS REQUIRING HUSBANDRY ON A DAY TO DAYBASIS, FISH MARKING REQUIREMENTS, AND APPROXIMATELY 20 TO 40 THOUSAND RETURNING ADULT SALMON NEEDING PROCESSED THROUGHTHE FALL AND WINTER MONTHS, THE HANDS-ON WORKLOAD IS SUBSTANTIAL, AND COULD NOT BE ACHIEVED WITHOUT CONTINUED QUINAULTINDIAN NATION TRIBAL EMPLOYMENT RIGHTS OFFICE (TERO) WORKERS, AND THEIR SPECIFIC SKILL SETS.

THERE ARE TWO FISH PASSAGEWAY ASSESSMENT PROJECTS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS INITIATIVE. THEFIRST IS A PROPOSED ENGINEERING BIOLOGICAL SURVEY FOR A FISH PASSAGEWAY AROUND THE LOWHEADDAM AT DUNDEE, MICHIGAN IN THE RIVER RAISIN. THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON A DETAILEDSITE ENGINEERING SURVEY, A HYDROLOGIC SURVEY, AND A BIOLOGICAL SURVEY OF THE RIVER RAISINON THE LEFT DESCENDING STREAMBANK OF THE DAM AND ABOVE AND BELOW THE DAM. OUR STAFFWILL INCLUDE A STRUCTURAL ENGINEER WHO DESIGNED THE INSTALLATION OF THE FISH PASSAGEWAY ATTHE STOCKDALE MILL DAM IN THE EEL RIVER OF NORTHERN INDIANA, BOYD KYNARD (B-KRIVERFISH, LLC) AND INVENTOR OF THE PASSAGEWAY FOR PASSAGEWAY DESIGN, AND SCIENTISTSFROM ECOSYSTEMS CONNECTIONS INSTITUTE WHO ASSISTED IN INSTALLATION OF THE FISHPASSAGEWAY AT THE STOCKDALE MILL DAM AND WHO HAVE COMPLETED ALL PHASES OF MANAGINGTHE PROJECT INCLUDING ALL THE FISH ASSESSMENT, HYDROLOGY, AND EFFICACY OF THE PASSAGEWAY.WE PROPOSE A TWO-DAY ONSITE VISIT WITH OUR TEAM TO CONDUCT THESE SURVEYS TO DETERMINETHE SPECIFICATIONS FOR THE FISH PASSAGEWAY AND FOR AN ENGINEERED INSTALLATION DESIGN. THEFEASIBILITY STUDY WILL ALSO PROVIDE A DESIGN TO ASSESS THE EFFICACY OF THE PASSAGEWAY, COSTESTIMATE, AND IDEAS FOR EDUCATION OUTREACH.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ESTABLISH BASELINE MUSSEL SURVEYS IN THE DOWAGIAC RIVER AND ITS TRIBUTARIES ON AND AROUND POKAGON BAND TRIBAL LANDS OVER TWO YEARS TO COLLECT POPULATION DATA (I.E., DENSITY, DIVERSITY, AGE STRUCTURE). THESE SURVEYS WILL BE REPEATED AT REGULAR INTERVALS--IDEALLY 5, 10, AND 15 YEARS--TO ASSESS HOW MUSSEL POPULATIONS CHANGE OVER TIME IN RESPONSE TO RIVER RESTORATION PROJECTS. MUSSEL SURVEYS WILL TAKE PLACE IN THE DOWAGIAC RIVER WATERSHED (DRW) IN BERRIEN AND CASS COUNTIES IN MICHIGAN. SITE LOCATIONS INCLUDE THE DOWAGIAC RIVER UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE PUCKER STREET DAM REMOVAL SITE, UPSTREAM THROUGH THE MEANDER RESTORATION PROJECT, AND IN DOWAGIAC RIVER TRIBUTARIES INCLUDING MCKINZIE CREEK, POKAGON CREEK, PEAVINE CREEK, AND DOWAGIAC CREEK. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO:1. CONDUCT MUSSEL SURVEYS AT SELECT SITES IN THE DRW TO COLLECT BASELINE POPULATION INFORMATION FOR THE MUSSEL COMMUNITY TO USE AS A COMPARISON FOR FUTURE POPULATION CHANGES WITHIN THE SYSTEM.2. THROUGH REPEATED SURVEYS, TRACK CHANGES IN THE MUSSEL COMMUNITY POPULATION STRUCTURE TO UNDERSTAND HOW RESTORATION EFFORTS CONTRIBUTE TO RECOLONIZATION AND EXPANSION OF MUSSELS INTO AND THROUGHOUT THE DRW.

THE USFWS PROPOSES TO ENTER INTO A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH DR. CAITLIN GABOR TO DETERMINE IF ANTIBIOTIC AND ANTIFUNGAL EGG TREATMENTS INFLUENCE HORMONE FUNCTION IN ENDANGERED DEVILS HOLE PUPFISH. EXCEPTIONAL DIFFICULTY IN CAPTIVE REARING AND CAPTIVE BREEDING OF THIS SPECIES UNDERLIES OUR NEED TO UNDERSTAND REPRODUCTIVE PHYSIOLOGY, AND ANY POTENTIALLY HARMFUL EFFECTS OF STANDARD AQUACULTURE METHODS. GIVEN THE DEVELOPMENT OF NON-INVASIVE METHODS TO SAMPLE HORMONES IN THIS SPECIES, THE USFWS WISHES TO FUND AND COOPERATE IN THIS PHYSIOLOGICAL RESEARCH.

THE USFWS PROPOSES TO ENTER INTO A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH DR. CHRISTOPHER MARTIN TO SCREEN THE GENOMES OF ENDANGERED DEVILS HOLE PUPFISH SAMPLES THAT EXPRESS DELETERIOUS PHENOTYPES TO IDENTIFY GENETIC MUTATIONS RELATED TO THE SURVIVAL OF THIS SPECIES. THE NUMEROUS AND SEVERE BOTTLENECKS IN POPULATION SIZE, EXCEPTIONAL DIFFICULTIES IN PROPAGATION, AND OTHER LIFE-HISTORY TRAITS HEIGHTEN OUR NEED TO UNDERSTAND THE ROLES OF GENETIC VARIATION AND MUTATION IN THIS SPECIES. GIVEN THE ADVENT OF ECONOMICALLY FEASIBLE DE NOVO AND POPULATION-LEVEL RESEQUENCING OF GENOMES, USFWS WISHES TO FUND AND COOPERATE ON THIS GENOME RESEARCH.

DEVILS HOLE IS THE ONLY NATURAL HABITAT OF THE ENDANGERED DEVILS HOLE PUPFISH (CYPRINODON DIABOLIS). TO ESTABLISH A BACKUP POPULATION, THE ASH MEADOWS FISH CONSERVATION FACILITY (AMFCF), A BATHYMETRIC REPLICA OF THE UPPERMOST 6.7 M OF DEVILS HOLE, WAS CONSTRUCTED IN THE MID 2010S. DESPITE RIGOROUS EFFORTS TO REPLICATE THE PHYSICAL DETAILS, CHEMISTRY, AND FOOD WEB OF THE DEVILS HOLE ENVIRONMENT, THE BIOGEOCHEMISTRY AND MICROBIOLOGY OF THE AMFCF REFUGE TANK REMAINS LITTLE STUDIED. IN 2016, DRI S ENVIRONMENTAL MICROBOLOGY LABORATORY EVALUATED WATER AND SEDIMENT PHYSICOCHEMISTRY IN RELATION TO 16S RRNA GENE LIBRARIES FOR PLANKTONIC AND BENTHIC BACTERIAL AND ARCHAEAL COMMUNITY COMPOSITION IN DEVILS HOLE AND THE AMFCF. MAJOR ION CHEMISTRIES WERE CONSISTENT BETWEEN THE TWO SYSTEMS, BUT WATER TEMPERATURE, NUTRIENT CHEMISTRY, AND DISSOLVED OXYGEN DYNAMICS DIFFERED, AS DID THE ABUNDANCE AND COMPOSITION OF PREDICTED PRIMARY PRODUCERS (CYANOBACTERIA). WITH THIS STUDY, THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE SEEKS TO DEVELOP A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE MICROBIAL AND MICROALGAL ECOLOGY OF THE AMFCF IN COMPARISON TO DEVILS HOLE BY OBTAINING A SECOND TIMEPOINT TO COMPARE WITH THE PRIOR STUDY. HOWEVER, THE NEW STUDY WILL EXPAND ON THE PRIOR STUDY BY EXPANDING MOLECULAR TARGETS TO INCLUDE EUKARYOTIC ORGANISMS, ESPECIALLY FUNGI AND ALGAE). A NEW TASK HAS ALSO BEEN PROPOSED BY THE COOPERATORS, NAMELY, TO EXAMINE THE INTERNAL MICROBIOTA OF C. DIABOLIS. THE GUT MICROBIOME HAS BEN HYPOTHESIZED TO PLAY A ROLE IN REGULATING METABOLIC PROCESSES, FISH HEALTH, IMMUNE FUNCTION, AND REPRODUCTION IN C. DIABOLIS. SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT AIMS TO UTILIZE DNA BASED TOOLS (16S RRNA GENE LIBRARIES) TO ELUCIDATE THE IMPACTS OF DIFFERENT ANTIBIOTIC AND ANTIFUNGAL TREATMENTS APPLIED TO FISH EGGS AS PART OF THE REARING PROCESS. ESTABLISHING IF EGG TREATMENTS INFLUENCE THE GUT MICROBIOME AND UNDERSTANDING THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF THESE PROTOCOLS ON HEALTH OF THE MICROBIOME WILL GUIDE FUTURE EGG TREATMENTS USED IN AQUACULTURE OF C. DIABOLIS.

THE GREAT LAKES SECTION WILL MONITOR TRIBUTARIES TO LAKE SUPERIOR FIVE DAYS PER WEEK FROM APRIL TO JULY IN COOPERATION WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  SEA LAMPREY CONTROL PROGRAM (USFWS). SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO MONITOR THE UPSTREAM SPAWNING MOVEMENTS OF SEA LAMPREY, TO COLLECT DATA ON THE BIOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF SPAWNING SEA LAMPREY (SEX, LENGTH AND WEIGHT), TO ESTIMATE THE NUMBER OF LAMPREY SPAWNING IN EACH TRIBUTARY, AND TO REDUCE THE SPAWNING POTENTIAL OF SEA LAMPREY BY REMOVING A PORTION OF THE RUN.

THE GREAT LAKES SECTION WILL MONITOR TRIBUTARIES TO LAKE SUPERIOR AND WORK WITH THE KEWEENAW BAY INDIAN COMMUNITY TO IMPLEMENT SUPPLEMENTAL CONTROL FROM SEPTEMBER TO DECEMBER IN COOPERATION WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  SEA LAMPREY CONTROL PROGRAM (USFWS). SUPPLEMENTAL CONTROLS ARE METHODS THAT SUPPLEMENT THE TWO PRIMARY SEA LAMPREY CONTROL TOOLS  LAMPRICIDES AND SEA LAMPREY BARRIERS. THIS CONTROL STRATEGY IS BASED ON THEINTEGRATION AND SYNERGY OF MULTIPLE METHODS TO REDIRECT OR REMOVE UPSTREAM MIGRATING ADULTS, DOWNSTREAM MIGRATINGJUVENILES, OR LARVAL SEA LAMPREYS. SUPPLEMENTAL CONTROLS ARE NOT EXPECTED TO BE AN ALTERNATIVE TO EFFECTIVELAMPRICIDE APPLICATIONS OR BARRIERS, BUT INSTEAD WOULD BE USED TO ENHANCE CONTROL WHERE LAMPRICIDES OR BARRIERSARE LESS EFFECTIVE DUE TO PHYSICAL, BIOLOGICAL, CHEMICAL, OR SOCIAL CHALLENGES.

THE INTENTION OF THIS PARTNERSHIP IS FOR GREAT BASIN INSTITUTE (GBI) TO RECRUIT TO HIRE A RESEARCH ASSOCIATE (RA) TO SERVE AS A PROPAGATION SUPPORT SPECIALIST AT THE ASH MEADOWS FISH CONSERVATION FACILITY (AMFCF) IN AMARGOSA VALLEY, NV. THE PRIMARY DUTIES INCLUDE CARE OF CAPTIVE FISH, MAINTENANCE OF PROPAGATION SYSTEMS, AND MONITORING A VARIETY OF BIOLOGICAL CONDITIONS TO SUCCESSFULLY ESTABLISH A BACK-UP POPULATION OF ENDANGERED DEVILS HOLE PUPFISH (INCLUDING HYBRIDS) AND THE DEVILS HOLE BIOLOGICAL COMMUNITY (ALGAE AND AQUATIC INVERTEBRATES), AS WELL AS OTHER FEDERALLY LISTED AND OR IMPERILED AQUATIC SPECIES. ASSISTANCE IS PROVIDED TO ALL PHASES OF FACILITY OPERATIONS NECESSARY TO SUCCESSFULLY PROPAGATE AQUATIC ORGANISMS. THE RECIPIENT WILL WORK DIRECTLY UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE FACILITY MANAGER FISH BIOLOGIST AND WITH RESEARCH INSTITUTIONS, STATE, LOCAL, AND FEDERAL COOPERATORS.

LAKE SUPERIOR STATE UNIVERSITY WILL SUPPLY TWO STUDENTS OVER A 12 WEEK PERIOD TO ASSIST THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WITH MONITORING THE MIGRATION OF ADULT SEA LAMPREYS IN THE ST. MARYS RIVER. THE LAKE SUPERIOR STATE UNIVERSITY CENTER FOR FRESHWATER RESEARCH AND EDUCATION (FORMERLY AQUATIC RESEARCH LAB) IS LOCATED DIRECTLY ON THE ST. MARYS RIVER AND ALLOWS THE STUDENTS TO MONITOR TRAPS CONTINUOUSLY. THE INFORMATION COLLECTED DURING THE MONITORING PERIOD IS USED TO ESTIMATE THE ADULT SEA LAMPREY POPULATION IN THE ST. MARYS RIVER AND ULTIMATELY THE LAKE HURON ESTIMATE, WHICH IS USED TO MAKE DECISIONS ON BUDGET AND TREATMENT ALLOCATION ACROSS THE GREAT LAKES.

THE SENECA NATION CONSERVATION FISH AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT WILL ASSESS THE POPULATION OF SEA LAMPREY INHABITING LAKE ERIE BY MONITORING ITS TRIBUTARIES DURING THE SPAWNING SEASON. THE DEPARTMENT WILL SUPPLY THREE WORKERS OVER A 9 WEEK PERIOD TO ASSIST THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WITH MONITORING THE MIGRATION OF ADULT SEA LAMPREYS IN THE CATTARAUGUS CREEK. CONTINUED MONITORING OF SEA LAMPREY ABUNDANCE IN THIS TRIBUTARY IS CRITICAL TO ASSESSMENT OF SUCCESS OF SEA LAMPREY CONTROL IN LAKE ERIE. THE INFORMATION COLLECTED DURING THE MONITORING PERIOD IS USED TO ESTIMATE THE ADULT SEA LAMPREY POPULATION IN EASTERN LAKE ERIE AND ULTIMATELY THE LAKE ERIE ESTIMATE, WHICH IS USED TO MAKE DECISIONS ON BUDGET AND TREATMENT ALLOCATION ACROSS THE GREAT LAKES.

THE GRAND TRAVERSE BAND OF OTTAWA AND CHIPPEWA INDIANS   NATURAL RESOURCES DEPARTMENT WILL ASSESS THE POPULATION OF SEA LAMPREY INHABITING LAKE MICHIGAN BY MONITORING ITS TRIBUTARIES DURING THE SPAWNING SEASON. THE DEPARTMENT WILL SUPPLY TWO WORKERS OVER A 9 WEEK PERIOD TO ASSIST THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WITH MONITORING THE MIGRATION OF ADULT SEA LAMPREYS IN THE BOARDMAN RIVER. CONTINUED MONITORING OF SEA LAMPREY ABUNDANCE IN THIS TRIBUTARY IS CRITICAL TO ASSESSMENT OF SUCCESS OF SEA LAMPREY CONTROL IN LAKE MICHIGAN. THE INFORMATION COLLECTED DURING THE MONITORING PERIOD IS USED TO ESTIMATE THE ADULT SEA LAMPREY POPULATION IN NORTHERN LAKE MICHIGAN AND ULTIMATELY THE LAKE MICHIGAN ESTIMATE, WHICH IS USED TO MAKE DECISIONS ON BUDGET AND TREATMENT ALLOCATION ACROSS THE GREAT LAKES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE SUPPORT FROM MAKAH TRIBAL EMPLOYMENT RIGHTS OFFICE (TERO) WORKERS TO COMPLETE THE FISH MARKING AND TAGGING AT THE MAKAH NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY WHILE WORKING WITH STAFF FROM THE WESTERN WASHINGTON FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION OFFICE. ALL SALMON AND STEELHEAD REARED AT THE MAKAH NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY WILL BE MARKED WITH A FIN CLIP, TAGGED WITH A CODED WIRE TAG, OR BOTH PRIOR TO RELEASE FROM THE HATCHERY. MARKING SALMON AND STEELHEAD RELEASED FROM FEDERALLY OPERATED OR FUNDED HATCHERIES IS A FEDERAL REQUIREMENT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO AWARD FUNDS TO THE COUNTY OF OZAUKEE TO COMPLETE A FLOODWAY RECONNECTION CONSTRUCTION PROJECT ON THE MILWAUKEE RIVER.THE PRIMARY GOALS OF THE PROJECT ARE TO RECONNECT IMPORTANT MILWAUKEE RIVER RIVERINE, FLOODPLAIN AND WETLAND HABITATS, WHICH INCLUDES A CURRENTLY ISOLATED OXBOW, AND TO ALLEVIATE FLOODING OF THE ACTIVE ROADWAY BY RECONSTRUCTING COUNTY HIGHWAY (CTH) W IN THE VILLAGE OF SAUKVILLE, OZAUKEE COUNTY, WI. A SECONDARY GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF THE ADJACENT RIPARIAN, FLOODPLAIN, AND WETLAND HABITAT THROUGH THE REMOVAL OF INVASIVE SPECIES AND PLANTING OF NATIVE VEGETATION TO INCREASE ECOLOGICAL VALUE FOR NATIVE MIGRATORY FISH, BIRDS, WILDLIFE, AND POLLINATORS.THE PROPOSED OBJECTIVES AND ACTIVITIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE  1. ACQUIRE PROPERTY (OR PORTIONS OF) ADJACENT TO THE HIGHWAY RIGHT OF WAY AND PROJECT AREA ALONG THE MILWAUKEE RIVER FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF PROJECT PLANS (THIS ACTION WILL NOT BE COMPLETED WITH USFWS FUNDING) 2. DESIGN AND ENGINEER A NEW CTH W ROADWAY WITH SUFFICIENT FLOOD CAPACITY THAT ALLOWS THE RECONNECTION OF THE ISOLATED FLOODPLAIN AND OXBOW 3. ROADWAY RECONSTRUCTION THAT PRIORITIZES AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE AND RIVERINE CONNECTIVITY INTO HISTORIC FLOODPLAIN, WETLAND, AND OXBOW HABITAT, TO MAXIMIZE SUITABLE HYDROPERIOD USING APPROPRIATELY SIZED CULVERTS 4. HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS THROUGH PLANTING OF NATIVE VEGETATION, INVASIVE VEGETATION REMOVALS, AND INSTALLATION OF AQUATIC AND SEMI AQUATIC FEATURES TO IMPROVE FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT AND OVERALL ECOLOGIC FUNCTION OF THE WATERSHED 5. CONDUCT ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING TO DOCUMENT THE LONG TERM SUCCESS OF THE PROJECT IN THE FORM OF FISHERIES MONITORING, PRE AND POST CONSTRUCTION, TO ASSESS THE CURRENT FISH COMMUNITY AND UTILIZATION OF THE RESTORED FLOODPLAIN, AS WELL AS TARGETED AVIAN AND WILDLIFE MONITORING, TO THE EXTENT PRACTICAL, THROUGH VISUAL, ACOUSTIC AND OR POINT COUNT SURVEYS.EXPECTED DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED ROAD SAFETY AND INFRASTRUCTURE THROUGH FLOOD RESILIENT CONSTRUCTION DESIGNS, RECONNECTION AND RESTORATION OF IMPORTANT AQUATIC AND TERRESTRIAL HABITATS, AND INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL AND CONTROL.THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE ALL PUBLIC STAKEHOLDERS WHO USE CTH W, RECREATION RIVER USERS, AND THE LOCAL GOVERNMENTS WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM THE UPDATED AND IMPROVED INFRASTRUCTURE.SUB RECIPIENTS OF THIS AWARD WILL INCLUDE THE OZAUKEE COUNTY HIGHWAY DEPARTMENT WHO WILL BE CONTRACTED TO COMPLETE THE HIGHWAY CONSTRUCTION.

AS GLOBAL BIODIVERSITY IS DISAPPEARING AT ALARMING RATES, CONSERVATION PROGRAMS SUCH AS CAPTIVE BREEDING AND PROPAGATION HAVE BECOME COMMON PRACTICES IN SPECIES CONSERVATION. CAPTIVE REARED INDIVIDUALS ARE TYPICALLY RELEASED TO AUGMENT EXISTING POPULATIONS, REINTRODUCED TO THEIR HISTORICALLY OCCUPIED HABITATS, OR INTRODUCED TO LOCATIONS OUTSIDE OF THEIR HISTORICAL GEOGRAPHIC BOUNDARIES. FRESHWATER MUSSELS ARE AMONG THE MOST ENDANGERED ORGANISMS IN THE WORLD DUE TO HISTORIC AND ONGOING THREATS TO THEIR POPULATIONS INCLUDING HABITAT LOSS AND DEGRADATION, WATER POLLUTION, AND CLIMATE CHANGE. A GOAL OF CONSERVATION PROGRAMS IS TO PRESERVE NATURALLY OCCURRING GENETIC VARIABILITY WITHIN SPECIES, SO THAT THE SPECIES WOULD HAVE THE ABILITY TO ADAPT TO ONGOING AND FUTURE ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES. HOWEVER, GENETIC ASSESSMENTS ARE LARGELY MISSING IN MUSSEL PROPAGATION AND RELEASE PROGRAMS. AS A BROADCAST SPAWNER, FEMALE MUSSELS CAN FERTILIZE THEIR EGGS WITH AVAILABLE SPERM IN THE ENVIRONMENT. AS A RESULT, MULTIPLE PATERNITY WITHIN A SINGLE BROOD IS EXPECTED TO BE COMMON. HOWEVER, TO DATE, A LIMITED NUMBER OF STUDIES HAVE INVESTIGATED MULTIPLE PATERNITY IN FRESHWATER MUSSELS, AND THE ASSOCIATIONS BETWEEN MULTIPLE PATERNITY AND GENETIC VARIABILITY WITHIN BROODS ARE NOT WELL UNDERSTOOD. FURTHERMORE, CURRENT CAPTIVE PROPAGATION PROGRAMS FOR FRESHWATER MUSSELS OFTEN FAILED TO ADDRESS GENETIC STATUS OF BROODSTOCK FEMALES, CAPTIVE REARED STOCKS, AND BOTH SOURCE AND RECIPIENT POPULATIONS. WITHOUT PROPER UNDERSTANDING OF GENETIC VARIABILITY AND POTENTIAL IMPACTS, CAPTIVE PROPAGATION AND SUBSEQUENT RELEASE WOULD NOT ONLY WASTE LIMITED RESOURCES BUT ALSO HARM THE EXISTING POPULATIONS AND ECOSYSTEMS. GIVEN A GROWING NUMBER OF CAPTIVE PROPAGATION EFFORTS, GENETIC MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES BASED ON SCIENCE ARE URGENTLY NEEDED TO MAINTAIN GENETIC VARIABILITY WITHIN PROPAGATED JUVENILES WHILE MINIMIZING POTENTIAL NEGATIVE CONSEQUENCES, SUCH AS INBREEDING, ARTIFICIAL SELECTION DURING CAPTIVITY, AND DOMESTICATION. THE GOALS OF THIS STUDY ARE TO ASSESS GENETIC DIVERSITY AND STRUCTURE OF NATURAL POPULATIONS, AND CAPTIVE REARED JUVENILES, ACROSS MULTIPLE ENDANGERED FRESHWATER MUSSEL SPECIES IN THE MIDWESTERN U.S. THESE ASSESSMENTS ARE AIMED TO UNDERSTAND GENETIC VARIABILITY WITHIN PROPAGATED JUVENILES AND POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF CAPTIVE PROPAGATION AND SUBSEQUENT RELEASE ON NATURAL POPULATIONS. WE WILL THEN DEVELOP GENETIC MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES FOR CAPTIVE PROPAGATION AND RELEASE PROGRAMS. THE GUIDELINES WILL INCLUDE RECOMMENDATIONS SUCH AS THE MINIMUM NUMBER OF BROODSTOCK FEMALES NEEDED TO BE COLLECTED AND MINIMUM NUMBER OF PROPAGATED JUVENILES TO BE RELEASED. THIS WILL BE PROVIDED TO PROPAGATION PRACTITIONERS TO FACILITATE SUCCESSFUL CONSERVATION OF FRESHWATER MUSSELS. INITIALLY, WE WILL CONDUCT A RANGE WIDE POPULATION GENOMIC ANALYSES TO ASSESS THE PATTERN OF NATURALLY OCCURRING GENETIC DIVERSITY AND STRUCTURE ACROSS MULTIPLE POPULATIONS OF AT LEAST 2   3 MUSSEL SPECIES. SECOND, WE WILL QUANTIFY GENETIC VARIABILITY AND STRUCTURE OF BROODSTOCK FEMALES, DERIVED GLOCHIDIA, AND CAPTIVE PROPAGATED JUVENILES TO COMPARE WITH NATURAL POPULATIONS. POPULATION GENOMIC DATA DERIVED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE ROBUST AND INCREASE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF GENETIC VARIABILITY IN THE REPRODUCTIVE AND EARLY LIFE STAGES OF FRESHWATER MUSSELS, WHICH ARE CURRENTLY MISSING.

THE U. S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS), SOUTHERN NEVADA FIELD OFFICE, HAS A REQUIREMENT FOR ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA) RESEARCH TO COMPLETE A LABORATORY AND FIELD BASED SURVEYS OF THE MUDDY RIVER (MOAPA, NEVADA), WHERE NON NATIVE FISHES THREATEN NATIVE SPECIES. THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE WORK IS TO DETERMINE THE OCCURRENCE OF NON NATIVE FISHES IN THE MUDDY RIVER USING MOLECULAR SURVEYS OF EDNA, AND INCLUDES THE REFINEMENT OF EXISTING EDNA TECHNIQUES. DELIVERABLES FOR THIS AGREEMENT INCLUDE BOTH LAB AND FIELD WORK, AND INCLUDES A FINAL REPORT SUMMARIZING RESULTS.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROTECT AN INTACT HEALTHY RIVER THAT HAS A MIX OF EXCEPTIONAL AND DEGRADED HABITAT. THE WHITEWATER RIVER DRAINS 144 SQUARE MILES AND SEDIMENTATION IS A MAJOR PROBLEM. WE WILL INSTALL 5,500 LIVE STAKE TREES AND FORBS ALONG 3.3 MILES TO REDUCE SLUMP AND EROSION, AND CREATE FISH HABITAT. A PORTION OF THE PLANTED AREA WILL BE STUDIED FOR SUCCESS OF BARE ROOT VERSUS LIVE STAKE SPECIMENS. WE WILL ENGAGE COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS IN THE INSTALLATION OF THE LIVE STAKES AND PRODUCE A WEBINAR.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT WATER QUALITY IN A NEWLY BUILT RESERVOIR, WP 1, USING BEST MANAGEMENTPRACTICES THAT REDUCE SEDIMENT INPUT AND EXCESSIVE NUTRIENTS VIA CONSTRUCTION OF A SEDIMENT RETENTION STRUCTUREAND SHORELINE PROTECTION MEASURES. THE GOAL AND PRODUCTS OF THE PROJECT IS TO CREATE 2,000 FT. OF SHORELINEPROTECTION (RIP RAP) AND 8 BREAKWATER STRUCTURES (MODIFIED FOR ANGLER ACCESS) TO BE CONSTRUCTED BY 2024 TO REDUCEIN LAKE EROSION. STRATEGICALLY PLACED BREAKWATER STRUCTURES AND SHORELINE STABILIZATION WILL BE NEEDED TO PREVENTSHORELINE EROSION AND SLOUGHING WHICH COULD REDUCE OR ELIMINATE THE BENEFITS GAINED FROM IMPLEMENTING THESEDIMENT BASIN UPSTREAM OF THE RESERVOIR. THERE ARE NO SUB RECIPIENTS.

THE OVERALL PROJECT GOAL IS TO USE STREAM SIMULATION DESIGN TECHNIQUES TO RETROFIT AN EXISTING BARRIER CULVERT ON KIRBY BROOK, IN ORDER TO RESTORE FULL AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE THROUGH THE STRUCTURE, OPENING UP AN ADDITIONAL 1.8 MILES OF HIGH QUALITY FISH HABITAT IN KIRBY BROOK (WASHINGTON, CT) AND ITS TRIBUTARIES. THE TARGET BARRIER CULVERT IS APPROXIMATELY 50 FEET UPSTREAM OF THE CONFLUENCE WITH THE SHEPAUG RIVER, ONE OF THE HEALTHIEST MAJOR TRIBUTARIES OF THE HOUSATONIC RIVER. DESPITE THE STRUCTURE S STATUS AS A MAJOR BARRIER TO THE UPSTREAM MIGRATION OF FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC ORGANISMS, THE CULVERT IS STILL IN OVERALL GOOD CONDITION AND TOWN OF WASHINGTON HIGHWAY CREWS HAVE REPORTED THAT IT DOES NOT FLOOD THE ROADWAY OR REQUIRE FREQUENT MAINTENANCE OR DEBRIS REMOVAL. THEREFORE, THE HIGH COST OF A FULL STRUCTURE REPLACEMENT IS NOT FEASIBLE FOR THE TOWN AT THIS TIME, IF IT IS NOT NEEDED TO ACHIEVE MULTIPLE OBJECTIVES. THIS MAKES THE STRUCTURE A PERFECT CANDIDATE FOR A RETROFIT THAT RESTORES FULL PASSABILITY FOR AQUATIC ORGANISMS. THE RETROFIT TECHNIQUES WILL INCLUDE ROCK STEPS ARE INSTALLED DOWNSTREAM TO BACK UP WATER THROUGH THE STRUCTURE. THIS DESIGN WILL INCREASE SEDIMENTATION, NATURAL MATERIALS, AND THE DEPTH OF WATER THROUGH THE STRUCTURE AND ELIMINATE THE OUTLET DROP, FULLY RESTORING PASSAGE FOR FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC ORGANISMS. THE COMPLETION OF THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A TOTAL OF OVER 8 STREAM MILES OF OPEN AQUATIC HABITAT IN THE SHEPAUG RIVER AND KIRBY BROOK (WITH EVEN MORE OPEN STREAM MILES IN THE SHEPAUG RIVER, UPSTREAM OF THE KIRBY BROOK CONFLUENCE). FURTHERMORE, THE COMPLETED STRUCTURE WILL ACT AS A REGIONAL DEMONSTRATION SITE FOR AN INNOVATIVE STREAM PASSAGE RESTORATION RETROFIT.

NATIVE FISH AND SHRIMP SPECIES OF PUERTO RICO RELY ON A DIADROMOUS LIFE CYCLE THAT REQUIRES MIGRATION BETWEEN THE RIVER AND THE SEA. UNFORTUNATELY, DUE TO THE PRESENCE OF DAMS AND STREAM CROSSING STRUCTURES, SUCH AS CULVERTS AND BRIDGES, THE MIGRATORY PATTERN OF THESE SPECIES HAS BEEN DISRUPTED. WHEN TAILORED TO THE LOCATION AND AQUATIC SPECIES FOUND WITHIN A RIVER, FISH PASSAGE INSTALLATIONS CAN BE SUCCESSFUL IN INCREASING STREAM CONNECTIVITY. NON PROFIT ORGANIZATION PROTECTORES DE CUENCAS PROPOSES TO ADDRESS STREAM CONNECTIVITY LIMITATIONS AT THE CULEBRINAS RIVER DAM THROUGH THE DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION INSTALLATION OF A CUSTOMIZED FISH PASSAGE FOR NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES. THROUGH THIS PROCESS, PROTECTORES DE CUENCAS AND PROJECT PARTNERS WILL CONDUCT SURVEYS TO INFORM THE NEW FISH PASSAGE DESIGN, COMPLETE A FINAL PROJECT DESIGN, COMPLETE ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE AND PERMITTING REQUIREMENTS, AND ENHANCE SURROUNDING HABITAT THROUGH STREAMBANK STABILIZATION AND RESTORATION. ONCE IMPLEMENTED, THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE BOTH STREAM CONNECTIVITY AND FACILITATE MIGRATION FOR NATIVE FRESHWATER FISH IN THE CULEBRINAS RIVER. THIS PROJECT HAS AN ESTIMATED START DATE OF JANUARY 1, 2023 AND END DATE OF DECEMBER 31, 2025.

THE GOAL OF THIS FUNDING REQUEST IS TO IMPROVE RESTORE HABITAT FOR THE TRISPOT DARTER (ETHSOASTOMA TRISELLA) WITHIN THE PRIORITY MANAGEMENT UNITS (MU) AS IDENTIFIED IN THE SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT AND RECOVERY PLAN. SPECIFICALLY, FUNDS FROM THIS AWARD WILL BE USED TO IMPROVE UPSTREAM MIGRATION TO POTENTIAL SPAWNING HABITAT WITHIN THE LITTLE CANOE CREEK (LCC) MU IN ST. CLAIR COUNTY AND THE BALLPLAY CREEK MU IN ETOWAH AND CHEROKEE COUNTIES, ALABAMA. THE INTENT WILL BE TO REMOVE ENHANCE A MINIMUM OF TWO BARRIERS WITHIN THE LCC MU WITH THESE FUNDS. THESE EFFORTS WILL COMPLEMENT A RECENTLY COMPLETED (OCTOBER 2022) BARRIER REMOVAL ENHANCEMENT PROJECT WITHIN THE LCC MU THAT ALSO UTILIZED BIL FUNDS. TWO PROPOSED PROJECTS WILL BE SELECTED FROM SEVERAL POTENTIAL SITES IN THE LCC MU. THE TWO PROPOSED PROJECTS WILL BE DEPENDENT UPON TIMING OF THE POTENTIAL OPPORTUNITIES, COST EFFECTIVENESS, SOCIAL FEASIBILITY, AND WILLINGNESS OF RESPECTIVE LANDOWNERS. WITH THE SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF TWO PROPOSED PROJECTS WITHIN THE LCC MU, AND OR PROJECT LOGISTICS DICTATE OTHERWISE, THE INTENT WILL BE TO DIRECT ANY REMAINING FUNDS TO OTHER PROJECT SITES, AS APPROPRIATE. THESE POTENTIAL ADDITIONAL EFFORTS MAY INCLUDE THE OTHER PROJECT OPPORTUNITIES WITHIN THE LLC MU AND OR EMPHASIS MAY BE EXPANDED TO INCLUDE THE BALLPLAY CREEK MU.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EXAMINE METHODS FOR SUCCESSFULLY REDUCING ABUNDANCE OF NORTHERNSNAKEHEAD AND BLUE CATFISH, INVASIVE FISHES IN MARYLAND AND THE CHESAPEAKE BAY WATERSHED. THEOBJECTIVES THAT WILL ACHIEVE THE PURPOSE INCLUDE  1) HIRING CHARTER BOAT CAPTAINS TO BOWFISHNORTHERN SNAKEHEAD AND BLUE CATFISH  2) CREATE A COMPETITION FOR HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS TO INNOVATENEW TECHNOLOGY THAT INCREASES CAPTURE EFFICIENCY OF FISHING GEAR FOR NORTHERN SNAKEHEAD  AND 3)CONTINUE FUNDING OF HIGHLY SUCCESSFUL REMOVALS OF INVASIVE FISHES FROM FISH LIFTS AT CONOWINGODAM. ANCILLARY OBJECTIVES THAT SUPPORT OUR GOAL IN THE LONG TERM ARE TO  1) ENGAGE SCHOOL GROUPSAND CHARTER BOAT CAPTAINS WITH INFORMATION THAT DEMONSTRATES HARVEST REDUCES ABUNDANCE  AND 2)BUILD ON A STATE AND FEDERAL SHARED LIFE HISTORY DATABASE OF SNAKEHEADS FROM THE UPPERCHESAPEAKE BAY. FUNDING IS GREATLY NEEDED TO BROADEN THE REACH OF INVASIVE FISH MANAGEMENTPROGRAMS WITHIN THE CHESAPEAKE BAY WATERSHED, PARTICULARLY IN THE UPPER CHESAPEAKE BAYREGION, WHERE POPULATIONS HAVE BEEN STEADILY GROWING.

COLORADO PARKS AND WILDLIFE MAINTAINS A LOW HEAD DAM ON THE ARKANSAS RIVER NEAR MT. SHAVANO STATE FISH HATCHERY, NORTH OF SALIDA, COLORADO, THAT WAS HISTORICALLY USED TO DIVERT WATER FOR THE HATCHERY. ALTHOUGH THE STRUCTURE HAS NOT BEEN OPERATING SINCE 2000, IT IMPEDES THE NATURAL ECOLOGY OF THE RIVER AND POSES A SAFETY RISK FOR WHITEWATER RECREATIONISTS. THE DAM LIMITS UPSTREAM FISH MOVEMENT MIGRATION TO 85 MILES OF THE ARKANSAS RIVER MAINSTEM AND HUNDREDS IF NOT THOUSANDS OF MILES OF TRIBUTARIES. DESPITE HAVING A BOAT CHUTE ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE STRUCTURE, THE DAM ITSELF HAS ALWAYS BEEN A SAFETY CONCERN FOR WHITEWATER RECREATION AND HAS BEEN INVOLVED IN SEVERAL FATALITIES AND COUNTLESS NEAR DROWNINGS. CPW PROPOSES TO RESTORE THE RIVER TO ITS NATURAL STATE BY COMPLETELY REMOVING THE LOW HEAD DAM AND BOAT CHUTE AND INSTALLING SEVERAL NATURAL LOOKING CROSS VANES AND OR CONSTRUCTED ROCK RIFFLE STRUCTURES THAT WILL ALLOW FOR FISH PASSAGE AND SAFE BOAT PASSAGE. THIS PROJECT IS HIGHLY SUPPORTED BY CHAFFEE COUNTY AND THE LOCAL COMMUNITY. CPW HAS PERFORMED PRELIMINARY ENGINEERING DESIGN FOR THE DAM REMOVAL PROJECT. CPW NEEDS TO COMPLETE THE FINAL ENGINEERING DESIGN TO GENERATE DRAWINGS AND SPECIFICATIONS FOR USE IN BIDDING THE CONSTRUCTION PORTION OF THE PROJECT. RECEIVING THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY WOULD ENABLE CPW TO HIRE AN ENGINEERING CONSULTANT TO COMPLETE THE FINAL DESIGN AND DEVELOP BIDDING DOCUMENTS FOR THE CONSTRUCTION PORTION OF THE PROJECT.

CONSISTENT WITH THE SNAKE RIVER BASIN ADJUDICATION AGREEMENT, U.S. FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) PROVIDES FUNDING TO THE NEZ PERCE TRIBE (TRIBE) TO JOINTLY MANAGE AND OPERATE DWORSHAK NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY (NFH). FUNDING FOR PRODUCING APPROXIMATELY 2 MILLION SPRING CHINOOK JUVENILES AT DWORSHAK NFH IS PROVIDED BY THE LOWER SNAKE RIVER COMPENSATION PLAN TO THE TRIBE THROUGH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE).THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES THE NECESSARY FUNDS FOR TRIBAL STAFF EMPLOYED AT DWORSHAK NFH OPERATING AND MAINTAINING THE HATCHERY TO PRODUCE SPRING CHINOOK JUVENILES AS MITIGATION FOR THE CONSTRUCTION AND OPERATION OF THE FOUR LOWER SNAKE RIVER DAMS.

DESPITE THE MANY ORGANIZATIONS, AGENCIES AND INDIVIDUALS THAT DESIRE AND WORK TO SEE DAMS REMOVED OR MODIFIED ACROSS THE STATE OF INDIANA, FEW PROJECTS HAVE BEEN UNDERTAKEN. THIS HAS PUT THE STATE BEHIND THE CURVE COMPARED TO OTHER MID WEST STATES INITIATIVES, SOME OF WHICH HAVE BEEN IN PLACE FOR DECADES. WHILE THE MOVEMENT TO UNDERTAKE THESE PROJECTS IS RELATIVELY NEW, THERE ARE ESTABLISHED FUNDING ORGANIZATIONS, BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE, THAT HAVE THE CAPACITY TO SUPPORT PROJECTS AT A MOMENT S NOTICE.IN OHIO, DAM REMOVAL AND MODIFICATION HAS BECOME A KEY ELEMENT IN REVITALIZATION EFFORTS IN URBAN AREAS (I.E., DAYTON AND COLUMBUS) AS WELL AS REMOVING UNSAFE BARRIERS ON HEAVILY RECREATED WATERWAYS ACROSS THE STATE. WITH THE ONGOING PROJECTS IN TROY AND PIQUA, THE MIAMI CONSERVANCY DISTRICT AND THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) HAVE BEGUN TO LOOK CLOSELY AT THE OTHER DAMS ALONG THE GREAT MIAMI RIVER, FROM HAMILTON TO THE HEADWATERS AT INDIAN LAKE, THAT COULD POSSIBLY BE REMOVED OR MODIFIED.IT IS OUR OBSERVATION THAT THE GAP BETWEEN AVAILABLE FUNDING AND PROJECTS UNDERTAKEN CAN BE BOILED DOWN TO THREE KEY FACTORS NO WIDELY AVAILABLE MATRIX PRIORITIZING DAM REMOVALS AND MODIFICATIONSLACK OF EDUCATION AND KNOWLEDGE OF DAM OWNERS REGARDING FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR REMOVALNO SYSTEM IN PLACE FOR SPONSORS WILLING TO BE THE FISCAL AGENT FOR PROJECTS TO CONNECT WITH DAM OWNERS (SPECIFICALLY RELATING TO INDIVIDUALS WHO ARE UNABLE TO APPLY FOR STATE AND FEDERAL FUNDING)THERE ARE INEVITABLY BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE DAM OWNERS WHO WISH TO REMOVE THE STRUCTURES BUT HAVE LITTLE KNOWLEDGE OR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW TO BEGIN AND CARRY OUT THE PROCESS. THE PROJECT WOULD HELP EDUCATE THESE OWNERS, STAKEHOLDERS, AND THE PUBLIC ON THE IMPORTANCE OF DAM REMOVAL MODIFICATION AND HELP CONNECT THE DOTS BETWEEN AVAILABLE FUNDING AND COMPLETION OF THE PROJECT(S).THE MATRIX RANKING LIST WOULD BE BASED ON MULTIPLE FACTORS SUCH AS PUBLIC SAFETY CONCERNS, RECREATIONAL USE AROUND THE DAM, AND HEALTH AQUATIC SPECIES AROUND THE DAM AND COULD BE UTILIZED BY THE FUNDING AGENCIES TO HELP PRIORITIZE PROJECTS TO CHASE. SPECIFICS OF THESE MATRIX FACTORS IS FURTHER DETAILED IN THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES SECTION.FINALLY, THE PROJECT WILL COORDINATE CLOSELY WITH THE INDIANA DNR AS THEY WORK TOWARDS DEVELOPING A STATEWIDE DAM REMOVAL PROGRAM REQUIRED BY HOUSE BILL 1099 PASSED IN 2020.

AFTER THE SUCCESSFUL REMOVAL OF TWO LOW HEAD DAMS AND MODIFICATION OF A THIRD IN 2019 AND A FOURTH IN2022, THE DELAWARE COUNTY SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT PURSUED INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF NATURA LRESOURCES LAKE AND RIVER ENHANCEMENT FUNDS TO STUDY THE OPTIONS OF REMOVAL OR MODIFICATION OF THE HIGH STREET DAM, LOCATED IN DOWNTOWN MUNCIE. THIS IS THE LAST OF FIVE DAMS WITHIN CITY LIMITS THAT NEEDS TO BE ADDRESSED. TWO SIGNIFICANT PIECES OF INFRASTRUCTURE, THE HIGH STREET BRIDGE AND A SEWER INTERCEPTOR SIT A FEW HUNDRED FEET UPSTREAM OF THE DAM AND UNDERSTANDING THE SPECIFICS OF THEIR LOCATION DEPTHS WITHIN THE RIVER ARE CRITICAL TO UNDERSTANDING THE POSSIBLE OUTCOMES REGARDING THE DAM. THROUGH OUR EXTENSIVE EXPERIENCE IN DAM REMOVALS AND MODIFICATIONS ACROSS INDIANA AND OHIO, SELLING THE VISION OF LANDSCAPE AFTER THE REMOVAL OR MODIFICATION OF THE STRUCTURE IS CRITICAL TO BUILDING PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR THE PROJECT. THEREFORE, ADDITIONAL FUNDS ARE BEING REQUESTED TO CREATE EXCEPTIONAL RENDERINGS GRAPHICS AND DIAGRAMS TO HELP SELL THE PROJECT TO STAKEHOLDERS AND BE COMPLETED WITHIN 2 YEARS OF RECEIVING FUNDS. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE DELAWARE COUNTY SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT, RESIDENT OF DELAWARE COUNTY AND THE WHITE RIVER IN DOWNTOWN MUNCIE, INDIANA.

THE WHITE RIVER IS THE LARGEST WABASH RIVER SUBWATERSHED IN INDIANA AND SUPPORTS OVER 100 FISH SPECIES INCLUDING LAKE STURGEON. THERE ARE 67 LOW-HEAD DAMS ACROSS THE WHITE RIVER BASIN AND CURRENTLY THERE IS A NEED TO EVALUATE EACH OF THESE DAMS FOR REMOVAL OR TO PROVIDE A FISH PASSAGEWAY. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PRIORITIZE FISH PASSAGE NEEDS ACROSS THE BASIN TO IMPROVE STREAM HABITAT AND IMPROVE FISH PASSAGE THROUGHOUT THE WHITE RIVER WATERSHED.THERE IS A NEED TO EXAMINE AND ASSESS QUANTIFY THE FEASIBILITY TO REMOVE OR PROVIDE FISH PASSAGE AROUND LOW-HEADDAMS IN THE WHITE RIVER BASIN OF CENTRAL INDIANA. THE WHITE RIVER IS THE SECOND LARGEST TRIBUTARY OF THE WABASHRIVER IN INDIANA WITH A WATERSHED AREA OF OVER 11,000 SQUARE MILES. IT IS WELL DOCUMENTED THAT LOW-HEAD DAMS POSE A HAZARDTO HUMANS WHO USE RIVERS FOR RECREATION, AND IT IS WIDELY KNOWN DAMS DISRUPT THE STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION OF STREAMECOLOGICAL PROCESSES THAT LIMIT FISH MIGRATION, ALTER FISH COMMUNITIES, AND ALTER HABITAT FOR FRESHWATER MUSSELS. THEREARE APPROXIMATELY 100 FISH SPECIES ACROSS THE WHITE RIVER BASIN INCLUDING A POPULATION OF LAKE STURGEON AND APPROXIMATELY 25 SPECIES OF FRESHWATER MUSSELS. WHILE IT IS PREFERABLE TO REMOVE DAMS WHENEVERPOSSIBLE, THERE MAY BE SOCIETAL LIMITATIONS, OR ECOLOGICAL CONSIDERATIONS THAT REQUIRES CAREFUL DELIBERATION BEFOREREMOVAL OF A DAM. THIS FEASIBILITY STUDY WILL USE SUBSETS OF ECOLOGICAL DATA, AND HUMAN DIMENSIONS DATA REGARDINGEACH IDENTIFIED LOW-HEAD DAM TO USE AN OBJECTIVE AND PRAGMATIC TOOL TO PRIORITIZE WHETHER TO REMOVE A DAM,CONSTRUCT A FISH LADDER TO PROVIDE FISH PASSAGE, OR TO LEAVE THE DAM INTACT WITH NO RESTORATION INITIATIVE.

THE CITY OF BATTLE CREEK  CITY  IS WORKING TO PROTECT AND IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY IN GOGUAC LAKE, A 352 ACRE LAKE LOCATED WITHIN THE CITY  GOGUAC LAKE IS A VALUED RESOURCE, PROVIDING RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, WILDLIFE HABITAT AND ECONOMIC HEALTH TO THE REGION  THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY AND FISHERIES HABITAT IN GOGUAC LAKE BY ELIMINATING STORMWATER ADDITIONS FROM 34 6 ACRES OF URBAN COMMERCIAL AND RESIDENTIAL AREAS WITHIN THE CITY, RESULTING IN A POLLUTANT LOAD REDUCTION TO THE LAKE OF 54 5 POUNDS OF PHOSPHORUS AND 14,678 POUNDS 7 3 TONS  OF SEDIMENT, ANNUALLY  THE STORMWATER WILL BE PIPED VIA THE CITY S STORM SEWER NETWORK TO AN EXISTING STORMWATER DETENTION POND WITH EXCESS CAPACITY TO INFILTRATE THE ADDITIONAL STORMWATER GENERATED FROM THE 34 6 ACRES  THE FUNDING WILL BE USED FOR ENGINEERING DESIGN,CONSTRUCTION AND RELATED INFRASTRUCTURE MODIFICATIONS

THE ARIZONA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT BEGAN A TARGETED NON NATIVE FISH REMOVAL PROJECT ON LOWER INDIAN CREEK ON THE AGUA FRIA NATIONAL MONUMENT IN 2019, WHICH CONTINUES TODAY  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REMOVE GREEN SUNFISH, A NON NATIVE AQUATIC STRESSOR, IN ORDER TO BENEFIT LOCAL FISH, AMPHIBIAN, AND REPTILE POPULATIONS  SINCE THERE IS NO NATURAL FISH PASSAGE BARRIER BETWEEN THE PERENNIAL PORTION OF LOWER INDIAN CREEK AND THE AGUA FRIA RIVER, THE THREAT OF UPSTREAM MIGRATION BY NON NATIVES DURING HIGH FLOW EVENTS REMAINS  REGULAR REMOVAL OF NON NATIVE FISHES IS COSTLY IN TERMS OF PERSONNEL TIME, TRAVEL, AND EQUIPMENT  THE DEPARTMENT IS PURSUING A PERMANENT SOLUTION TO THESE PROBLEMS BY CONSTRUCTING AN ARTIFICIAL FISH PASSAGE BARRIER WHICH WOULD ALLOW FOR A COMPLETE REMOVAL OF GREEN SUNFISH TO THE BENEFIT OF THE NATIVE FISH, AMPHIBIAN, AND REPTILE POPULATIONS ALREADY IN THE SYSTEM  IT WOULD ALSO ALLOW STAFF TO AUGMENT THESE POPULATIONS AS WELL AS INTRODUCE OTHER NATIVE SPECIES SUCH AS ROUNDTAIL CHUB, NORTHERN MEXICAN GARTERSNAKE, AND GILA TOPMINNOW  THE PHOENIX AREA OFFICE OF THE BUREAU OF RECLAMATION  BOR  FUNDED THE COST OF THE DESIGN FOR A BARRIER ALONG LOWER INDIAN CREEK  THE COST FOR THE DESIGN PHASE OF THIS PROJECT IS  54,900  NATURAL CHANNEL DESIGN IS CURRENTLY WORKING ON THE FISH BARRIER DESIGN WITH AN ANTICIPATED COMPLETION DATE OF DECEMBER 2022  THE  30,000 FROM THE DESERT FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP WILL NOW CONTRIBUTE TO CONSTRUCTION OF THE BARRIER

TROUT UNLIMITED IS WORKING WITH THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE AND THE UPPER BLACKFOOT CONFLUENCE PARTNERSHIP IN SOUTHEAST IDAHO TO RESTORE HABITATS AND FISH PASSAGE FOR MIGRATORY YELLOWSTONE CUTTHROAT TROUT IN THE BLACKFOOT RIVER WATERSHED. MIGRATORY ADULT FISH FROM BOTH BLACKFOOT RESERVOIR AND THE BLACKFOOT RIVER MOVE UPSTREAM INTO TRIBUTARY STREAMS EVERY YEAR TO SPAWN. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL REPLACE A CULVERT UNDER THE BLACKFOOT RIVER ROAD THAT IS PREVENTING ACCESS TO MILL CREEK, A SMALL TRIBUTARY TO THE BLACKFOOT RIVER LOCATED AT MILL CANYON CAMPGROUND NEAR THE BLACKFOOT RIVER NARROWS. THE CURRENT UNDERSIZED PIPE WILL BE REPLACED WITH A NEW CONCRETE BOX BRIDGE STRUCTURE DESIGNED TO MEET AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE  AOP  CRITERIA.

THE KLAMATH BASIN FISHERIES COLLABORATIVE  PIT TAG MONITORING AND DATABASE PROJECT  PROJECT  IS A KLAMATH BASIN WIDE FISH TRACKING INFRASTRUCTURE THAT WILL BE USED TO MONITOR AND EVALUATE THE SUCCESS THIS PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS FOR NATIVE FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC SPECIES  USING A HELICOPTER, THIS PROJECT WILL ADD 120 PIECES OF LARGE WOOD TO 2 1 2 MILES OF WEST FORK BEAVER CREEK IN SISKIYOU COUNTY, ON PRIVATELY OWNED LAND  THESE LARGE WOOD STRUCTURES WILL RESTORE STRUCTURE, SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT, AND FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY  THE WOOD STRUCTURES WILL PROVIDE IMMEDIATE BENEFITS TO NATIVE FISH BY PROVIDING COVER AND AREAS OF LOW VELOCITY HABITAT  TARGET SPECIES THAT WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT ARE CHINOOK SALMON  FALL RUN , COHO SALMON, STEELHEAD  SPRING SUMMER AND WINTER , AND PACIFIC LAMPREY  WITH DAM REMOVAL, THIS PROJECT IS ANTICIPATED TO BENEFIT SPRING RUN CHINOOK SALMON AS WELL  THIS PROJECT IS NEEDED BECAUSE CURRENT AND PAST LAND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES  INCLUDING LOGGING STREAMBANKS, ROAD AND BERM BUILDING, EXTIRPATION OF BEAVERS, FIRE SUPPRESSION  HAVE CHANNELIZED STREAMS WITHIN THE KLAMATH BASIN

LAKE STURGEON PASSAGE HAS BEEN EMBRACED AS A RESTORATION PRESCRIPTION IN THE GREAT LAKES. HOWEVER, ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES DICTATE THAT QUANTITATIVE ASSESSMENT OF PASSAGE BENEFITS BE PROVIDED TO MANAGERS. THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF DOWNSTREAM JUVENILE PASSAGE ON AN IMPORTANT GREAT LAKES TRIBUTARY, THE MENOMINEE RIVER, AND THROUGH THE PARK MILL AND MENOMINEE DAMS. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVE IS TO INVESTIGATE THE INTERACTION OF AGE-0 JUVENILES WITH DOWNSTREAM PASSAGE OPPORTUNITIES IN PLACE AT BOTH DAMS, QUANTIFY THE NUMBER OF TAGGED FISH THAT PASS EACH DAM, AND THE PROPORTION THAT SURVIVE DOWNSTREAM PASSAGE.OUR PROJECTED METHODS WILL FURTHER ALLOW FOR THE EXAMINATION OF FINE-SCALE MOVEMENTS AS INDIVIDUALS APPROACH HYDROELECTRIC INFRASTRUCTURE AND THE BEHAVIOR OF FISH IMMEDIATELY AFTER PASSAGE AS A FUNCTION OF SPECIFIC ROUTES INCLUDING DEDICATED BYPASS STRUCTURES, THE POWERHOUSE WITH TURBINES AND BOTTOM DRAW SPILL GATES. LARVAL LAKE STURGEON WILL BE COLLECTED IN THE EARLY SPRING  MAY - JUNE  IMMEDIATELY DOWNSTREAM FROM THE GRAND RAPIDS DAM DURING THEIR FIRST NIGHT OF ACTIVE DRIFT IN 2023 AND 2024. LARVAE WILL BE REARED ON SITE USING A STREAM SIDE REARING FACILITY AND UP TO 100 AGE - 0 JUVENILE LAKE STURGEON    50 YEAR  REPRESENTING THE APPROPRIATE RANGE OF SIZES HOUSED IN THE STREAM SIDE FACILITY WILL BE INTERNALLY IMPLANTED WITH AN ACOUSTIC TRANSMITTER. THE FIRST EXPERIMENTAL RELEASE  FALL 2023  OF   50 ACOUSTICALLY PIT TAGGED FISH WILL OCCUR IN THE FREE-FLOWING SECTION OF THE MENOMINEE RIVER UPSTREAM OF THE PARK MILL DAM AND THE MAIN RESERVOIR. FISH WILL BE MONITORED USING A COMBINATION OF PASSIVE SUBMERSIBLE BUOYS PLACED UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF BOTH DAMS AND ACTIVE DAILY TRACKING.TO SUPPLEMENT OUR PROJECTED ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY DATA, AND AS A PARTIAL BACKUP PLAN, LAKE STURGEON REMAINING IN THE STREAM SIDE FACILITY    1000 INDIVIDUALS  WILL BE PIT  PASSIVE INTEGRATED TRANSPONDER  TAGGED AND CO-RELEASED IN THE FALL AT THE TIME OF ACTIVE ACOUSTIC TRACKING  2023 AND 2024 . THIS STUDY WILL QUANTIFY ASPECTS OF JUVENILE DOWNSTREAM MIGRATION BEHAVIOR THAT CAN INFORM THE EFFICACY OF FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES IN TERMS OF RESTORING THE LARGE POPULATION IN THE MENOMINEE RIVER AND GROWING THE METAPOPULATION LARGELY RESIDENT TO GREEN BAY.TRACKING DATA WILL ULTIMATELY INFLUENCE FUTURE FISH PASSAGE OPERATION AT THE EXISTING FACILITY AND FUTURE DESIGN MODIFICATIONS FOR DOWNSTREAM PASSAGE AT THIS FACILITY AND OTHER FACILITIES. OTHER MANAGEMENT BENEFITS INCLUDE BUILDING JUSTIFICATION FOR THE RESTORATION OF SPAWNING HABITATS IN UPSTREAM AREAS WHERE FISH PASSAGE IS CURRENTLY DISCUSSED, AND OTHER TECHNOLOGIES RELATED TO DOWNSTREAM PASSAGE THAT MIGHT FURTHER INCREASE PROBABILITIES OF JUVENILE SURVIVAL.

THIS FUNDING SUPPORTS A PROGRAM TO COORDINATE ADULT AND JUVENILE FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES INSPECTIONS  SINCE 1986, THIS PROGRAM HAS BEEN JOINTLY FUNDED BY STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES THROUGH THE FISH PASSAGE CENTER BUDGET THE FOLLOWING AGENCIES HAVE HISTORICALLY EQUALLY SUPPORTED THIS PROGRAM  1 NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE,  2  IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME, 3  WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE   4  OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, AND  5  THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE THE FIELD OPERATIONS COORDINATOR, IS RESPONSIBLE FOR TASKS RELATED TO FACILITY INSPECTION COORDINATION  THESE TASKS OCCUPY 4 MAN MONTHS OF TIME  THEREFORE, THE SUPPORTING FUNDS FOR THIS PROGRAM REPRESENT 33 33  OF THE COORDINATOR S SALARY THE INSPECTION COORDINATOR, IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ADVISING THE FISHERY AGENCIES, TRIBES, AND THE FISH PASSAGE CENTER MANAGER ON FISH PASSAGE ISSUES RELATIVE TO THE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF ADULT AND JUVENILE FISH PASSAGE FACILITIES IN THE MAINSTEM SNAKE AND COLUMBIA RIVERS  THE INSPECTION COORDINATOR SERVES AS THE PRIMARY POINT OF CONTACT FOR THE RESOURCE AGENCIES REGARDING THE OPERATION OF JUVENILE AND ADULT FACILITIES  THIS POSITION REPORTS TO THE FISH PASSAGE ADVISORY COMMITTEE  FPAC  REPRESENTATIVES OF THE AGENCIES, AND IMPLEMENTS THEIR DECISIONS REGARDING OPERATION OF JUVENILE AND ADULT FACILITIES  THIS INCLUDES SPECIAL OPERATIONS SUCH AS OUTAGES AND EMERGENCY MAINTENANCE  THE INSPECTION PROGRAM IS LIMITED TO MAINSTEM COLUMBIA AND SNAKE RIVER PROJECTS  THE DUTIES CARRIED OUT BY THIS POSITION ARE SPECIFIED BELOW

MOST OF LAKE SUPERIOR S WALLEYE  SANDER VITREUS  OJIBWE  OGAA  POPULATIONS HAVE DECLINED FROM HISTORIC LEVELS DUE TO PAST OVERHARVEST AND HABITAT DEGRADATION. A DESIRE TO RESTORE THIS ECOLOGICALLY AND CULTURALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES WAS FORMALLY RECOGNIZED BY THE LAKE SUPERIOR TECHNICAL COMMITTEE IN THE 1990S AND A LAKE SUPERIOR WALLEYE REHABILITATION PLAN WAS RELEASED IN 2001 THAT HAS BEEN REAFFIRMED BY STATE MANAGEMENT PLANS. LAKEWIDE SPATIAL STRUCTURE OF LAKE SUPERIOR S WALLEYE STOCKS WAS RECOGNIZED AS A CRITICAL KNOWLEDGE GAP IN THE REHABILITATION PLAN AND IT REMAINS UNADDRESSED.WE PROPOSE USING HIGH-RESOLUTION GENOMIC TOOLS TO QUANTIFY GENETIC STOCK STRUCTURE AND DIVERSITY AMONG LAKE SUPERIOR WALLEYE SPAWNING AGGREGATES AND DETERMINE STOCK-SPECIFIC HABITAT OCCUPANCY. IN ACCOMPLISHING RESTORATION OBJECTIVES, STOCK DELINEATION PROVIDES A BASIS FOR IDENTIFYING AT-RISK POPULATIONS, INFORMING STOCK ASSESSMENT SURVEYS, ESTABLISHING BIOLOGICALLY MEANINGFUL MANAGEMENT UNITS, AND IDENTIFYING HATCHERY BROODSTOCK SOURCES THAT WOULD PRESERVE LOCALLY ENDEMIC GENETIC VARIATION. STOCK DELINEATION WILL ENABLE US TO PERFORM MIXED STOCK ANALYSES THAT PROVIDE A MEANS OF DETERMINING STOCK-SPECIFIC HABITAT USE OUTSIDE OF SPAWNING TIMES AND QUANTIFYING SPATIALLY EXPLICIT STOCK-SPECIFIC HARVEST RATES. A WIDE RANGE OF FISH CONSUMPTION ADVISORIES EXIST FOR WALLEYE ACROSS LAKE SUPERIOR THAT ASSUME THE LOCATION OF A HARVEST IS REFLECTIVE OF WHERE A FISH SPENDS MOST OF ITS LIFETIME EXPERIENCING UPTAKE OF LOCAL CONTAMINANTS.OUR PROPOSAL WILL PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO THE RELIABILITY OF THIS ASSUMPTION BY IDENTIFYING THE REGIONS OF THE LAKE OCCUPIED BY EACH STOCK DURING NON-SPAWNING TIMES. BECAUSE STOCKING IS A PROMINENT LAKE SUPERIOR WALLEYE REHABILITATION STRATEGY, INCORPORATING PAST BROODSTOCK SOURCES INTO OUR MIXED STOCK ANALYSIS REFERENCE SAMPLE SET WILL ALSO ALLOW FOR AN ASSESSMENT OF STOCKING SUCCESS AND DISPERSAL PATTERNS OF STOCKED FISH. OUR RESEARCH TEAM REPRESENTS EIGHT STATE, PROVINCIAL, FEDERAL, AND TRIBAL AGENCIES, UNDERSCORING THE IMPORTANCE OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH TO THE REGIONAL MANAGEMENT COMMUNITY AND EMPHASIZING THE ACTIVE ROLE THAT MANAGERS WILL HAVE IN THIS PROPOSAL S DESIGN, EXECUTION, INTERPRETATION, AND IMPLEMENTATION OUTCOMES.OBJECTIVES 1  DETERMINE THE DEGREE OF GENETIC DIFFERENTIATION AMONG KNOWN SPAWNING AGGREGATES OF LAKE SUPERIOR WALLEYE AND DETERMINE MIXED STOCK ANALYSIS REFERENCE POPULATION GROUPINGS. 2  DETERMINE EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZES AND LEVELS OF GENETIC DIVERSITY FOR EACH SPAWNING AGGREGATE. 3  IDENTIFY STOCK-SPECIFIC CONTRIBUTIONS TO MIXED STOCK SAMPLES COLLECTED THROUGHOUT LAKE SUPERIOR.DELIVERABLES  1  DATA AND CODE DISSEMINATION  ALL ANALYTICAL CODE AND RESULTS WILL BE PUBLISHED ALONGSIDE ASSOCIATED JOURNAL ARTICLES VIA THE PROPOSAL S GITHUB REPOSITORY OR SCIENCEBASE. 2  ESTABLISHMENT OF RESOURCES FOR FUTURE BIOLOGICAL RESEARCH  SAMPLES COLLECTED FOR THIS PROPOSAL WILL BE OFFERED FOR DONATION TO THE CRYOGENICS FACILITY AT THE FIELD MUSEUM IN CHICAGO, TO ESTABLISH A MOLECULAR SNAPSHOT OF CONTEMPORARY WALLEYE BIODIVERSITY IN LAKE SUPERIOR TO BENEFIT FUTURE RESEARCH. 3  ORAL PRESENTATIONS  WE WILL PRESENT OUR RESEARCH TO MANAGERS AND BIOLOGISTS AT LOCAL, STATE, AND REGIONAL CONFERENCES  AMERICAN FISHERIES SOCIETY CHAPTER MEETINGS IN WISCONSIN AND MICHIGAN, MIDWEST FISH AND WILDLIFE CONFERENCE . 4  OPPORTUNITIES FOR ADVANCING INTER-JURISDICTIONAL SPECIES MANAGEMENT  WE HAVE INVESTIGATORS FROM EIGHT STATE, PROVINCIAL, FEDERAL, AND TRIBAL AGENCIES THAT REPRESENT COMPLETE COVERAGE OF THE WATERS OF LAKE SUPERIOR. THIS PROPOSAL PROVIDES AN EXCEPTIONAL OPPORTUNITY FOR THESE ENTITIES TO SHARE INFORMATION RESOURCES, FORMULATE RESTORATION GOALS AND PRIORITIES, AND BUILD A FOUNDATION FOR ADVANCING MANAGEMENT AND RECOVERY OF LAKE SUPERIOR S WALLEYE POPULATIONS. 5  PUBLICATIONS AND REPORTS  THIS PROPOSAL WILL GENERATE AT LEAST ONE JOURNAL PUBLICATION.

THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO TEST AND REFINE A PREDICTIVE MODEL FOR ANNELID HOSTS IN THE KLAMATH RIVER HYDROELECTRIC REACH  THE ANNELID, MANAYUNKIA OCCIDENTALIS, IS THE BENTHIC INVERTEBRATE HOST OF THE MYXOZOAN PARASITE CERATONOVA SHASTA, THE MOST SIGNIFICANT PATHOGEN LIMITING SALMON RECOVERY IN THE KLAMATH RIVER  HIGH ANNELID HOST DENSITIES HAVE BEEN DESCRIBED IN THE J C  BOYLE BYPASS AND KENO REACHES OF THE KLAMATH RIVER HYDROELECTRIC REACH  UNDERSTANDING THE FACTORS DRIVING ANNELID HOST DISTRIBUTION AND DENSITY IN THE HYDROELECTRIC REACH IS CRITICAL TO THE SUCCESS OF SALMON RECOVERY AND FUTURE HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS  A PREDICTIVE MODEL WAS PREVIOUSLY DEVELOPED FOR ANNELIDS LOCATED IN THE CURRENT INFECTIOUS ZONE, DOWNSTREAM FROM IRON GATE DAM  THE MODEL HAS BEEN USED TO PREDICT THE DISTRIBUTION AND DENSITY OF INFECTED ANNELIDS AND EVALUATE EFFECTS OF MANAGED FLOW EVENTS DOWNSTREAM FROM IRON GATE DAM  THIS APPROACH CAN BE APPLIED IN THE HYDROELECTRIC REACH, HOWEVER MODEL PERFORMANCE SHOULD FIRST BE EVALUATED BECAUSE THE MODEL MAY REQUIRE REFINEMENT DUE TO THE UNIQUE HYDRAULIC AND SEDIMENT CONDITIONS THAT CHARACTERIZE THE KLAMATH RIVER HYDROELECTRIC REACHES    THE PROPOSED WORK WILL BUILD ON THE PREVIOUS MODEL TO 1  TEST AND REFINE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN FLOW VARIABILITY AND THE DISTRIBUTION AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF M  OCCIDENTALIS IN VARIOUS HABITAT TYPES, 2  CONTRIBUTE TO A LONG TERM DATA SET QUANTIFYING THE CONDITIONS LEADING TO THE PRESENCE OF ANNELIDS AND C  SHASTA INFECTION, AND 3  PROVIDE A TOOL FOR EVALUATING THE POTENTIAL SUCCESSES PROPOSED OF FLOW CONTROL OR HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIONS  E G , GRAVEL AUGMENTATION  TARGETED TOWARD SALMON HABITAT IN THE KLAMATH RIVER HYDROELECTRIC REACH   WE WILL BUILD TWO DIMENSIONAL HYDRAULIC MODELS FOR THREE SITES RELEVANT FOR SALMON SPAWNING AND REARING IN THE HYDROELECTRIC REACH AND WILL TEST AND REFINE OUR PREDICTIVE MODEL AT EACH SITE TO DELIVER A TOOL FOR PREDICTING ANNELID DISTRIBUTION UNDER VARIOUS DISCHARGE SCENARIOS  E G , DAMS OUT, DROUGHT, FLOW MANIPULATION  FROM KENO DAM  DATA COLLECTION CAN BEGIN IMMEDIATELY AND WILL PROVIDE SPATIALLY GEO REFERENCED BASELINE DATA ON ANNELID HOST DENSITIES AND PREVALENCE OF INFECTION, WHICH REPRESENT A CURRENT AND IMPORTANT DATA GAP IN THESE REACHES  ACCOMPLISHING THIS WORK WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH A COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH APPROACH INVOLVING INVESTIGATORS FROM A LONG TERM PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN OREGON STATE UNIVERSITY AND THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE ARCATA OFFICE  METHODS HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED AND PROTOCOLS AND TEAMS ARE ALREADY IN PLACE, MAKING THIS PROJECT SHOVEL READY   THE RESULTS WILL ADVANCE RESTORATION ACTIONS THROUGH THE PROVISION OF CURRENTLY LACKING BASELINE DATA AND A TOOL FOR USE IN EVALUATING THE POTENTIAL SUCCESSES PROPOSED OF FLOW MODIFICATION OR HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIONS

THE PROJECT AIMS TO SUPPORT ECOLOGICALLY SOUND, SCIENCE BASED CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS  REGARDING INVASIVE AQUATIC SPECIES  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE RESEARCH, FIELD SURVEYS, MAPPING,  MONITORING, AND CONTROLLING PHRAGMITES, ALLIGATORWEED, AND TWO HORNED TRAPA IN VIRGINIA  OTHER ACTIVITIES  INCLUDE ORGANIZING AND FACILITATING THE INVASIVE SPECIES WORKING GROUP MEETINGS, OFFERING INVASIVE  SPECIES WORKSHOPS FOR RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS AND COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS, AND CREATING AND MAINTAINING  GIS TOOLS AND DATA  EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE STAKEHOLDERS WHO ARE BETTER INFORMED AND EQUIPPED TO  ADDRESS INVASIVE SPECIES AND STRENGTHEN NATURAL COMMUNITIES WITHIN BIOLOGICAL AND CULTURAL LIMITS, WHICH  SUPPORTS THE DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION AND RECREATION S MISSION  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE  PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE VIRGINIA RIVERS, STREAMS, AND WETLANDS  THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT  ACTIVITIES

NORTHERN WATERS LAND TRUST  NWLT  HAS EXPERIENCED GREAT CONSERVATION SUCCESS WITH OUR CLEAN WATER CRITICAL HABITAT  CWCH  INTERACTIVE MAP TOOL  OVER THE PAST 7 YEARS, NWLT HAS PERPETUALLY PROTECTED OVER 3,463 ACRES OF LAND WITH APPROXIMATELY 160,000 FEET OF SHORELINE, WITHIN ITS SERVICE AREA CURRENTLY, OUR GIS MAPPING TOOL IDENTIFIES PROPERTIES WITHIN COLD WATER REFUGE LAKE WATERSHEDS AND SCORES THEIR NEED FOR PROTECTION  WITH ADDITIONAL RESOURCES FROM MGLP, OUR GOAL TO EXPAND THIS SCORING FRAMEWORK TO INCLUDE LAKES OF BIOLOGICAL SIGNIFICANCE AND PRIORITIZE CONSERVATION OF SPECIFIC PARCELS WITHIN THESE SENSITIVE WATERSHEDS A LAKE OF BIOLOGICAL SIGNIFICANCE  LBS , AS DEFINED BY MN DNR, IS A LAKE WITH UNIQUE PLANT OR ANIMAL PRESENCE, SUCH AS  AQUATIC PLANTS, FISH, BIRDS, AND AMPHIBIANS  CURRENTLY, OUR SERVICE AREA INCLUDES 391 LBS AND THERE IS NO PRIORITIZATION METHOD FOR PARCELS ON OR WITHIN THE WATERSHEDS OF THESE LBS  NWLT S PROPOSED METHODOLOGY IS ESSENTIAL FOR CONSERVATION EFFORTS DIRECTED AT MITIGATING THE IMPACTS OF SHORELINE DEVELOPMENT, CLIMATE CHANGE, DEFORESTATION, AND MORE  THE RESULTS OF THIS MGLP GRANT WILL BE ESSENTIAL IN HELPING NWLT CONTINUE ITS PERMANENT LAND CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN THIS DEVELOPING REGION NORTHERN WATERS LAND TRUST WILL IDENTIFY ANDPRIORITIZE 20 40 PRIORITY LAKES OF BIOLOGICAL SIGNIFICANCE AND THEIR ASSOCIATED WATERSHEDS, WITHINTHE SERVICE AREA OF AITKIN, CASS, CROW WING, AND HUBBARD COUNTIES, WILL FACILITATE OUTREACH MEETINGS TO DEVELOP AND REFINE A SCORINGFRAMEWORK TO PRIORITIZE PARCELS WITHIN THESE WATERSHEDS REFINED DATA WILL BE INPUT ONTO NWLT S ONLINE GIS MAPPING TOOL THE MGLP GRANT WILL BE USED SOLELY FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE LAKES OF BIOLOGICAL SIGNIFICANCEGIS MAPPING TOOL

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO IMPLEMENT A COORDINATED APPROACH TO MINIMIZING THE ECONOMIC, ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIAL IMPACTS OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES  AIS  ON THE MARINE AND FRESHWATER ECOSYSTEMS AND RESOURCES OF RHODE ISLAND  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE  PUBLIC OUTREACH AND EDUCATION, MONITORING, REMOVING AND SURVEYING FOR AIS IN MARINE AND FRESHWATER SYSTEMS, AND RECOMMENDING ACTIONS TO RESTORE CONDITIONS AND CONTROL FUTURE AIS GROWTH  EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE TO REDUCE THE RISK OF SPREADING AIS, HAVE AN INFORMED PUBLIC, AND CREATE A HEALTHIER ECOSYSTEM  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE ALL USERS OF INLAND AND MARINE WATERS IN RHODE ISLAND, AS WELL AS THE STATE S NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES  THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES

THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES SEVERAL IMPAIRMENTS ON COCHITI LAKE, NEW MEXICO  SEDIMENTATION, AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES AND INITIAL VEGETATION REMOVAL AND EARTH SCOURING DURING DAM CONSTRUCTION  THE LAKE HAS ALSO BEEN SUBJECT TO HAZARDOUS ALGAE BLOOMS  THIS GRANT WILL BE DIRECTED TOWARDS THE PROPAGATION OF NATIVE AQUATIC AND SHORELINE VEGETATION AND FISH HABITAT PLACEMENT WITH AN EMPHASIS ON SPAWNING ENHANCEMENT FOR BOTH GAME AND FORAGE FISH SPECIES SEVERE WILDFIRES IN THE ADJACENT JEMEZ MOUNTAINS HAVE EXACERBATED AND ACCELERATED THE RATE OF SEDIMENT DEPOSITION AND COVE SILTATION IN COCHITI LAKE  OVER 8 MILES OF PRIME SPAWNING SHORELINE HAS BEEN DESTROYED AND AN ADDITIONAL ONE TO TWO MILES OF SPAWNING HABITAT IS LOST EACH YEAR  THE ADDITIONAL SEDIMENTATION AND LOCAL EROSION HAS ALSO LED TO AGGRESSIVE INVASION OF EURASIAN WATERMILFOIL, CHOKING OUT NATIVE AQUATIC PLANT SPECIES  ALSO AN UNRESOLVED IMPAIRMENT IS THE CLEARCUTTING AND LEVELING OF THE ENTIRE AREA NEAR THE EARTHEN DAM  THE BARREN COVES HAVE ALMOST NO STRUCTURE NOR VEGETATION EXCEPT THE EURASIAN WATERMILFOIL  THEREFORE, THE MAJOR OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE  1  TO IMPROVE AND REVITALIZE DEGRADED AQUATIC HABITAT AND ENHANCE LOCAL AQUATIC COMMUNITIES THROUGH AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL, 2  IMPROVE AQUATIC HABITAT BY STABILIZING ERODED SHORELINES AND IMPROVING BANK SHADING THROUGH NATIVE VEGETATION ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT, 3  CREATE SPAWNING AND PRODUCTION FISH HABITAT BY DEPLOYING FISH HABITAT STRUCTURES ADJACENT TO RESTORATION SITES, CHANNELS, AND BARREN CONSTRUCTION SCARS, 4  ENHANCE SPAWNING SITES FOR PREY BASE SPECIES INCLUDING GIZZARD SHAD AND YELLOW PERCH  5  INCREASE ANGLER USE OF FISH HABITAT SITES  BOAT AND SHORELINE ANGLERS  TO INCREASE AWARENESS AND SUPPORT, AND 6  INCREASE ANGLER USER AND PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE VALUE AND BENEFIT OF A HEALTHY RESERVOIR ECOSYSTEM THROUGH PROJECT OUTREACH EVENTS AND MEDIA COVERAGE  WHILE IT IS NOT EXPLICITLY AN OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT, THERE IS REASON TO BELIEVE THAT SUCCESS WITH THE PROJECT WILL ALSO REDUCE THE EXCESS NUTRIENTS THAT LEAD TO HAZARDOUS ALGAE BLOOMS THIS PROJECT GRANT WILL SUPPORT CONTINUATION OF A PROJECT THAT HAS BEGUN WITH A THOROUGH EVALUATION OF THE RESERVOIR, DOCUMENTATION OF SEDIMENTATION AND EURASIAN WATERMILFOIL IMPAIRMENTS, OPTIONS FOR WATER MANIPULATION, AND REVIEWS OF MULTIPLE FISH ELECTROSHOCKING SURVEYS  THE PROJECT IS CURRENTLY CONSTRUCTING AN ON SITE GREENHOUSE FOR PROPAGATION OF NATIVE AQUATIC PLANTS TO BE USED AS PART OF AN EXTENSIVE AIS ERADICATION AND REPLACEMENT STRATEGY FUNDED BY THE CORPS, PARTNERS AND AN AFTCO GRANT THIS GRANT WILL BE DIRECTED TOWARDS THE FOLLOWING METHODS 1  CONSTRUCTION AND PLACEMENT OF SPECIFICALLY DESIGNED OR SELECTED FISH HABITAT WITH AN EMPHASIS ON SPAWNING ENHANCEMENT FOR BOTH GAME AND PREY BASE SPECIES,2  CONTINUE EFFORTS TO ERADICATE THE EURASIAN WATERMILFOIL AND REPLACE IT WITH NATIVE VEGETATION, AND3  INCREASE PUBLIC USER INTEREST AND SATISFACTION THROUGH EDUCATION, PARTICIPATION AND ENHANCED ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN EMPHASIS ON YOUTH INVOLVEMENT
