RAYSTOWN LAKE IS AN 8,300 ACRE LAKE THAT IS OWNED AND OPERATED BY THE USACE  IT S ONE OFPENNSYLVANIA S LARGEST LAKES AND IS HEAVILY USED BY RECREATIONAL BOATERS AND ANGLERS  THE PARKRECEIVES OVER 1 6 MILLION VISITORS ANNUALLY  IN 2020, SEVEN POINTS CAMPGROUND BECAME THEHIGHEST REVENUE GENERATING CAMPGROUND OF ALL THE USACE PROJECTS  ERODED SHORELINES HAVERESULTED IN CREATION OF MUDFLATS, INCREASED TURBIDITY, DECLINING LITTORAL HABITAT AND IMPAIRED BANKACCESS FOR ANGLERS  PFBC RECEIVED  1 15 MILLION IN NONFEDERAL FUNDS TO ADDRESS THE SHORELINEEROSION ISSUES ON RAYSTOWN  THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE TO STABILIZE ERODED BANKS AND IMPROVESTRUCTURAL HABITAT  WALLEYE SPAWNING HABITAT IS BECOMING LIMITING IN RAYSTOWN AND OFFSHORESPAWNING REEFS WILL BE BUILT  PARTNER FUNDING WILL ALSO BE USED TO INSTALL A HANDICAPPED FISHINGDOCK TO IMPROVE SHORELINE ANGLER ACCESS THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND ON PREVIOUSLY COMPLETED STRUCTURAL HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS BY 1  RESHAPING AND ARMORING ERODED SHORELINES AND RESTORING NATIVE VEGETATION TO THERIPARIAN AREA AFFECTED BY THE RESTORATION EFFORTS2  INSTALLING ROOT WADS AND FELLED TREES TO THE SHORELINE WAVE DEFLECTOR STRUCTURES3  INSTALLING SHORT VERTICAL PLANK STRUCTURES4  INSTALLING PORCUPINE CRIBS  INSTALLING FELLED TREES TO ENHANCE LITTORAL STRUCTURE6  ESTABLISHING OFFSHORE ROCK REEFS TO ENHANCE WALLEYE SPAWNING HABITAT RAYSTOWN IS A MAJOR RECREATIONAL DESTINATION FOR THE CITIZENS OF PENNSYLVANIA  THE HABITATRESTORATION EFFORTS WILL IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF THE LAKE  REDUCED TURBIDITY  AND PROVIDESTRUCTURAL HABITAT FOR A VARIETY OF SPORTFISH SPECIES  BASS, CRAPPIE, SUNFISH, STRIPED BASS ANDWALLEYE   INCREASING BANK FISHING ACCESS SHOULD RESULT IN INCREASED PUBLIC VISITATION AND THERESULTANT INCREASES IN ASSOCIATED ECONOMIC ACTIVITY

THE SOUTHEAST AQUATIC RESOURCES PARTNERSHIP  SARP  IS PROPOSING TO WORK TO EXPAND OUR EXISTING DATABASE OF AQUATIC BARRIER INVENTORY AND PRIORITIZATION INTO THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE S MIDWEST REGION  USFWS REGION 3   ESTIMATED AT OVER 150,000 POTENTIAL SITES, THE COMPLETION OF THIS DATABASE WILL BE THE FIRST COMPREHENSIVE EFFORT TO REFLECT THE LEVEL OF AQUATIC HABITAT FRAGMENTATION IN THIS NEW REGION AND CAN IDENTIFY WHICH OF THESE BARRIERS MAY HAVE THE GREATEST BENEFIT FOR LISTED, AT RISK AND RECREATIONAL SPECIES  STATES COVERED WILL INCLUDE MINNESOTA, WISCONSIN, MICHIGAN, INDIANA, ILLINOIS AND OHIO  IOWA WILL ALSO BE INCLUDED IN THIS LARGER EXPANSION YET MUCH OF THE INITIAL DATABASE ACQUISITION IN IOWA HAS ALREADY BEEN STARTED THROUGH ANOTHER RELATED BY SEPARATE EFFORT  COORDINATION WILL BE CONDUCTED AMONG STATES, US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND OTHER AGENCIES AS WELL AS TROUT UNLIMITED AND OTHER NONPROFITS WHO MAY HAVE DATA TO CONTRIBUTE AS WELL AS ASSIST IN DISSEMINATION OF PROJECT RESULTS  BARRIERS THAT WILL BE ASSESSED INCLUDE DAMS AND ROAD RELATED BARRIERS SUCH AS CULVERTS  A PRIORITIZATION SCHEME WILL BE DEVELOPED TO ALLOW MANAGERS TO QUICKLY RANK BARRIERS BASED ON VARIOUS CRITERIA

THE MIDWEST GLACIAL LAKES PARTNERSHIP WORKS TO PROTECT, REHABILITATE, AND ENHANCE SUSTAINABLE FISH HABITATS IN GLACIAL LAKES OF THE MIDWEST FOR THE USE AND ENJOYMENT OF CURRENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS  PARTNERSHIP STAFFING IS LIMITED TO THE COORDINATOR, AND FUNDING FOR THAT POSITION IS REQUIRED TO COORDINATE THE PARTNERSHIP S THREE COMMITTEES, IMPLEMENT TASKS DELEGATED BY THE COMMITTEES TO THE COORDINATOR, AND MAINTAIN PARTNERSHIP OPERATIONS IN SUPPORT OF THE PARTNERSHIP S MISSION, GOALS, AND OBJECTIVES  THIS PROJECT WILL PARTIALLY FUND THE COORDINATOR AND PROVIDE A SMALL OPERATIONS BUDGET FOR PARTNERSHIP ACTIVITIES  ADDITIONAL OBJECTIVES WILL INCLUDE IMPLEMENTATION OF MIDWEST GLACIAL LAKES PARTNERSHIP OBJECTIVES ON INLAND LAKE MANAGEMENT, CLIMATE CHANGE, AND HABITAT CONSERVATION GRANT OBJECTIVES WITHIN MICHIGAN

AQUATIC VEGETATION PROVIDES ESSENTIAL HABITAT FOR FISH IN LAKES AT ALL STAGES OF THEIR LIVES  HOWEVER,SPECIFICALLY WHAT CHARACTERISTICS OF AQUATIC VEGETATION HAVE THE STRONGEST INFLUENCES ON FISH POPULATIONS ISPOORLY UNDERSTOOD, LEADING TO SUBSTANTIAL UNCERTAINTY IN HOW TO MANAGE AQUATIC PLANTS TO BEST SUPPORT FISHERIESGOALS, SUCH AS IMPROVING WALLEYE RECRUITMENT, INCREASING OR PANFISH GROWTH AND SIZE STRUCTURE  BY COMBININGEXTENSIVE DATASETS FOR AQUATIC VEGETATION AND FISH COMMUNITIES ACROSS THOUSANDS OF LAKES IN THE MIDWEST GLACIALLAKES PARTNERSHIP FOOTPRINT, INCLUDING LAKES IN MINNESOTA, WISCONSIN, AND MICHIGAN, WE AIM TO ADD ANOTHER HABITATMANAGEMENT TOOL TO THE LAKE MANAGEMENT TOOLBOX BY CLARIFYING LINKAGES BETWEEN AQUATIC VEGETATION AND IMPORTANTRECREATIONAL FISHERIES  WE WILL ADDRESS TWO SPECIFIC QUESTIONS THAT ARE HIGH PRIORITIES FOR NATURAL RESOURCEAGENCIES  1  WHAT IS THE IMPORTANCE OF AQUATIC VEGETATION FOR WALLEYE RECRUITMENT, EITHER AS SPAWNING OR JUVENILEHABITATS  AND 2  HOW CAN AQUATIC VEGETATION MANAGEMENT BE USED TO MANAGE AND SUPPORT POPULAR RECREATIONALFISHERIES, INCLUDING PANFISH, BASS, AND WALLEYE  IN ANSWERING THESE QUESTIONS, WE WILL ASSESS RELATIONSHIPSBETWEEN PLANT COMMUNITY STRUCTURE AND FISH POPULATION ABUNDANCE, SIZE STRUCTURE, GROWTH, AND RECRUITMENT USINGDATA ANALYSIS AND MODELING, LEADING TO PRACTICABLE GUIDANCE FOR HOW PLANT AND FISH COMMUNITIES CAN BEHOLISTICALLY MANAGED TOGETHER  THIS INFORMATION WOULD BE DELIVERED TO BIOLOGISTS, LAKE ASSOCIATIONS, AND OTHERSTAKEHOLDERS USING WORKSHOPS, SEMINARS, FACTSHEETS, AND DATA VISUALIZATION TOOLS, ALLOWING MANAGERS TO PUT THEIRLAKE S PERFORMANCE IN CONTEXT, IDENTIFY LAKES WHERE HABITAT MANAGEMENT COULD YIELD THE MOST BENEFITS TOFISHERIES, AND LEARN ABOUT THE BENEFITS AQUATIC VEGETATION CAN PROVIDE TOWARD MEETING LAKE MANAGEMENT GOALS

COORDINATION AND OPERATIONAL SUPPORT FOR THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE RESERVOIR FISHERIES HABITAT PARTNERSHIP IS CRITICAL TO IT BEING ABLE TO MEET IS MISSION  TO PROMOTE THE PROTECTION, RESTORATION, AND ENHANCEMENT OF HABITAT FOR FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC SPECIES IN RESERVOIR SYSTEMS  RFHP SEEKS TO ENGAGE BROAD BASED PARTNERS IN RESTORING AND ENHANCING AQUATIC HABITAT AS WELL AS PROMOTING AWARENESS OF RESERVOIR HABITAT ISSUES AND ENGAGING LOCAL CITIZENS IN RESTORATION EFFORTS  OPERATIONAL SUPPORT IS VITAL TO MAINTAIN RFHP S EFFORTS TO IMPROVE FISH HABITAT, SUPPORT BROAD BASED PARTNERSHIPS, AND ENGAGE LOCAL CITIZENS, STATE RESOURCE AGENCIES, AND INDUSTRY IN PROTECTING AND RESTORING RESERVOIR FISHERIES HABITAT ACROSS THE UNITED STATES  FRIENDS OF RESERVOIRS  FOR  IS A 501 C  3  THAT SERVES AS THE OUTREACH ARM OF RFHP  COORDINATION AND OPERATION ACTIVITIES INCLUDE   CONDUCTING ROUTINE ADMINISTRATIVE DUTIES THAT MEET THE REQUIREMENTS OF CONTINUED OPERATIONS OF THE PARTNERSHIP  PRODUCING AND UPDATING A HIGH QUALITY WEBSITE  WWW FRIENDSOFRESERVOIRS COM   MAINTAINING AN ACTIVE SOCIAL MEDIA PRESENCE  ATTENDING SCIENTIFIC MEETINGS TO INFORM NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS ABOUT RFHP NFHP ACTIVITIES  ROUTINELY ENGAGE EXISTING AND NEW PARTNERS TO EXPAND THE RESERVOIR HABITAT RESTORATION COMMUNITY  PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PARTNERS ENGAGED IN HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIVITIES  CONDUCT AN ANNUAL MEETING TO DISTRIBUTE INFORMATION ON PROJECT SUCCESSES AND LATEST DEVELOPMENT OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES

THE PROJECT IS LOCATED ON CHAMBERS CREEK ESTUARY IN SOUTH PUGET SOUND NEAR THE CITY OF UNIVERSITY PLACE AND THE TOWN OF STELIACOOM IN PIERCE COUNTY, WASHINGTON  CHAMBERS CREEK DAM STANDS 12 FEET TALL, THREE QUARTERS OF A MILE UPSTREAM OF THE CHAMBERS CREEK DELTA IN PUGET SOUND  THE DAM, CONSTRUCTED IN THE MID 1930S, IMPOUNDS APPROXIMATELY 40  OF THE HISTORIC ESTUARY   20 ACRES   THE DAM DELAYS UPSTREAM ADULT FISH MIGRATION, INCREASING PREDATION AND PRE SPAWNING MORTALITY RATES  POOR DOWNSTREAM FISH PASSAGE OVER THE DAM CREST AND FACE RESULTS IN INJURY AND REDUCED SURVIVAL OF JUVENILE SALMON AND TROUT LEAVING CHAMBERS CREEK FOR THE OCEAN  THE DAM IMPEDES TIDAL HYDROLOGY, SEDIMENT TRANSPORT, TIDAL MARSH HABITAT, AND FOOD WEB PRODUCTION  RESTORATION OF CHAMBERS BAY AND REMOVAL OF THE DAM IS OF LOCAL IMPORTANCE FOR SURVIVAL AND PRODUCTION OF CHAMBERS CREEK SALMON AND TROUT AND IS REGIONALLY IMPORTANT AS WELL TO PROVIDE CRITICAL REARING HABITAT FOR ALL PUGET SOUND SALMON AND TROUT POPULATIONS ALONG A SECTION OF SHORELINE BETWEEN THE PUYALLUP AND NISQUALLY RIVERS WHERE FORAGING AND REFUGE OPPORTUNITIES ARE LIMITED  IN ADDITIONAL TO THE DAM, TWO BARRIERS CULVERTS AT THE MOUTHS OF GARRISON SPRINGS AND A UNNAMED SPRING CREEK ENTERING CHAMBERS BAY DOWNSTREAM OF THE DAM LIMIT FISH PASSAGE, FRESHWATER MIXING, AND SEDIMENT TRANSPORT PROCESSES FOR FORAGING AND DELTA FISH REARING LIFE CHIMNEY ROCK AND BRUCE VALLEY CREEKS ARE TRIBUTARIES TO ELK CREEK AND ARE BOTH CLASS II TROUT STREAMS LOCATED IN THE MIDDLE TREMPEALEAU WATERSHED, A PRIORITY WATERSHED FOR THE DRIFTLESS AREA RESTORATION EFFORT PARTNERSHIP  BOTH STREAMS HAVE EXCESSIVE SEDIMENT ENTERING THE STREAMS FROM OVERLAND AND BANK EROSION  THIS HAS RESULTED IN POOR WATER QUALITY AND UNSUITABLE HABITAT FOR FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC ORGANISMS  OBJECTIVES ARE TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND IN STREAM HABITAT PRIMARILY FOR BROOK TROUT  BOXELDER, SNAGS, AND LOGS WILL BE REMOVED FROM 1 2 AND 0 5 RIPARIAN MILES ON CHIMNEY ROCK CREEK AND BRUCE VALLEY CREEK, RESPECTIVELY  PROJECT AREA STREAM BANKS WILL BE SLOPED AND STABILIZED TO REDUCE SEDIMENT LOADS TO THE STREAM  A 40 FT RIPARIAN CORRIDOR WILL BE SEEDED WITH A MIX OF GRASSES AND EACH LANDOWNER WILL MAINTAIN THE GRASSES BUFFER TO KEEP LONG TERM BANK STABILITY AND WATER INFILTRATION  ADDITIONALLY, 0 60 MILES OF IN STREAM HABITAT STRUCTURES WILL BE INSTALLED IN CHIMNEY ROCK CREEK AND 0 25 MILES IN BRUCE VALLEY CREEK  COMPLETION OF THE RIPARIAN AND IN STREAM WORK WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED WATER AND HABITAT QUALITY FOR BROOK TROUT, DACE, OTHER FISH SPECIES, INVERTEBRATES, AND WILDLIFE  THE PUBLIC WILL HAVE FISHING ACCESS TO EACH PROJECT STREAM AREA VIA A DONATED EASEMENT

AMERICAN RIVERS IS COLLABORATING WITH THE WESTERN PENNSYLVANIA CONSERVANCY FOR THE REMOVAL OF THE LOWER CALLEN RUN DAM IN JEFFERSON COUNTY, PENNSYLVANIA  CALLEN RUN IS A HIGH QUALITY COLDWATER FISHERY THAT PROVIDES HABITAT REFUGE FOR AN ARRAY OF AQUATIC SPECIES, INCLUDING NATURALLY REPRODUCING EASTERN BROOK TROUT  FEDERAL PRIORITY SPECIES  AND FISH HOST SPECIES FOR THE FRESHWATER MUSSELS FOUND IN THE CLARION RIVER  CURRENTLY, THE LOWER CALLEN RUN DAM IS CLASSIFIED AS A TIER 4 SEVERE PASSAGE BARRIER  FRESHWATER NETWORK AQUATIC BARRIER PRIORITIZATION , BLOCKING UPSTREAM SPAWNING AND NURSERY WATERS FOR IMPORTANT AQUATIC SPECIES  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REMOVE THE DAM AND RESTORE AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE TO RECONNECT 4 MILES OF THE CALLEN RUN WATERSHED WITH THE WILD AND  SCENIC CLARION RIVER AND ITS MAINSTEM CORRIDOR  AMERICAN RIVERS WILL USE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO PROVIDE STREAMBANK STABILIZATION AND INSTREAM STRUCTURES FOR CALLEN RUN TO REGAIN A NATURAL AND UNIMPEDED FLOW INTO THE CLARION RIVER  SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THE PROJECT WILL NOT ONLY ESTABLISH RE CONNECTIVITY FOR IMPORTANT AQUATIC SPECIES ENDEMIC TO CALLEN RUN, BUT ALSO PROVIDE A SAFER RECREATIONAL ANGLING AND BOATING FOR THE PUBLIC COMMUNITY

THIS PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN THE CALIFORNIA ISLANDS BIOSECURITY PROGRAM AND LEVERAGE OUTCOMES FOR BIOSECURITY ON US DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR ISLANDS  THE PROJECT S TWO MAIN GOALS ARE TO 1  STRENGTHEN THE CAPACITY OF THE CALIFORNIA ISLANDS BIOSECURITY PROGRAM TO SERVE AS A MODEL FOR US DOI ARCHIPELAGOS AND 2  SCALE AND DISSEMINATE LESSONS AND TOOLS FROM CALIFORNIA ISLANDS FOR US DOI ARCHIPELAGOS US ISLANDS ARE ECOLOGICALLY DIVERSE AND HOST MANY RARE, SENSITIVE AND ESA LISTED POPULATIONS  INVASIVE ALIEN SPECIES  IAS  ARE A MAJOR THREAT TO ISLAND ECOSYSTEMS AND CREATE SIGNIFICANT HARM TO HUMAN HEALTH AND ECONOMIES ON ISLANDS  BIOSECURITY IS CRUCIAL AND THE MOST COST EFFECTIVE STRATEGY TO PROTECT ISLAND ECOSYSTEMS FROM INVASIVE SPECIES  THE US DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR IS A KEY STEWARD OF MANY US ISLANDS AND THUS ACCOUNTABLE FOR THEIR BIOSECURITY COMPARED TO OTHER ARCHIPELAGOS AND ISLAND REGIONS IN THE USA, THE CALIFORNIA CHANNEL ISLANDS HAVE THE SECOND HIGHEST NUMBERS OF ESA SPECIES AND MTBA SPECIES, HIGHLIGHTING THE NATIONAL PRIORITY OF BIOSECURITY FOR THIS REGION  THE NPS US NAVY TNC BIOSECURITY PARTNERSHIP IN THE CHANNEL ISLANDS HAS MADE SIGNIFICANT ACHIEVEMENTS SINCE 2016, AND IS UNIQUELY POSITIONED TO PROVIDE LESSONS LEARNED FOR SCALING BIOSECURITY OUTCOMES ON DOI ISLANDS IN PUBLIC PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS ELSEWHERE IN THE USA  STRENGTHENING AND LEVERAGING THE CALIFORNIA ISLANDS ORGANIZATION IMPLEMENTING THE PROJECT IS THE CALIFORNIA CHAPTER OF THE NATURE CONSERVANCY  TNC , IN COLLABORATION AND COORDINATION WITH FEDERAL ENTITIES INCLUDING THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE  NPS , US NAVY, US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS , AND NATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION S OFFICE OF NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARIES  NOAA , AND MULTIPLE OTHER PRIVATE ENTITIES SINCE 2013, THE CALIFORNIA CHAPTER OF TNC HAS PLAYED A KEY ROLE IN DEVELOPING, IMPLEMENTING, AND COORDINATING BIOSECURITY AMONG KEY STAKEHOLDERS FOR A US LANDSCAPE AT RISK FROM INVASIVE SPECIES INTRODUCTIONS  THE CALIFORNIA ISLANDS  FURTHER, TNC HAS CHAPTERS IN EVERY US STATE AND PROGRAMS IN MANY US TERRITORIES, AS WELL AS ESTABLISHED RELATIONSHIPS WITH A MULTITUDE OF NATIONAL DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR  DOI  OFFICES AND BUREAUS, AND SO IS WELL POSITIONED TO HELP DOI SCALE BIOSECURITY MEASURES ACROSS ITS HOLDINGS AND INTERESTS

THIS RESTORATION PROJECT WAS DEVELOPED AS PART OF THE SHORE FRIENDLY THURSTON PROGRAM IN SOUTH PUGET SOUND SHORE FRIENDLY THURSTON FOCUSES ON CONNECTING MARINE WATERFRONT LANDOWNERS WITH RESTORATION EXPERTS TO TAKESTEWARDSHIP ACTIONS THAT SUPPORT NEARSHORE PROCESSES AND HEALTHY MARINE ECOLOGY  THE RESTORATION PROJECT ISLOCATED ON A PRIVATE RESIDENTIAL WATERFRONT PROPERTY SITUATED ALONG DANA PASSAGE IN SOUTH PUGET SOUND  THEPROJECT INVOLVES BULKHEAD REMOVAL AND MARINE RIPARIAN VEGETATION RESTORATION TO SUPPORT NATURAL COASTALPROCESSES AND THE EXPANSION OF NEARSHORE HABITAT  ARMOR REMOVAL WILL ALLOW NORMAL COASTAL EROSION TORESUME, SUPPORTING MAINTENANCE OF A HEALTHIER BEACH AND NEARSHORE ECOSYSTEM  BEACH RESTORATION, INVASIVEWEED REMOVAL, AND ESTABLISHMENT OF NATIVE MARINE RIPARIAN VEGETATION WILL IMPROVE HABITAT FOR FORAGE FISH ANDSALMON POPULATIONS AS WELL AS OTHER NEARSHORE SPECIES  AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT, APPROXIMATELY 195 LINEARFEET OF MARINE SHORELINE ARMOR WILL BE REMOVED  GABION, CONCRETE, AND TIRES   AFTER BULKHEAD REMOVAL, THESHORELINE WILL REMAIN IN NATURAL CONDITION TO ADAPT AND RESUME NORMAL COASTAL PROCESSES

THE POLNELL POINT RESTORATION PROJECT IS A PARTNERSHIP OF THE NORTHWEST STRAITS FOUNDATION AND THE US NAVY  THE PROJECT AIMS TO RESTORE 1,400 LINEAR FEET OF SHORELINE AND FOUR ACRES OF NEARSHORE HABITAT ALONG THE TOMBOLO OF POLNELL POINT, WHIDBEY ISLAND  THE PROJECT WILL ACHIEVE THE GOALS OF RESTORING NATURAL SEDIMENT TRANSPORT PROCESSES AND IMPROVING NEARSHORE HABITATS FOR JUVENILE SALMONIDS AND FORAGE FISH SPAWNING THROUGH THE REMOVAL OF SHORE ARMOR AND DEBRIS, PLACEMENT OF BEACH NOURISHMENT MATERIALS, REMOVAL OF NON NATIVE FILL, AND RE ESTABLISHMENT OF THE MARINE RIPARIAN ZONE

THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT A FEASABILITY AND CONCEPTUAL DESIGN ALTERNATIVE ASSESSMENT TO PURSUE HIGH PRIORITYACTIONS TO BENEFIT ESA LISTED CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD ON THE SEQUALTITCHEW CREEK ESTUARY THIS WORK WILL ADDRESS THE RESTORATION OF FULL FISH PASSAGE THROUGH THE BURLINGTON NORTHERN AND SANTA FE RAILWAY, TIDAL HYDROLOGY AND SEDIMENT INPUTS TO THE SHORELINE, FLOODPLAIN CONNECTION AND OFF CHANNEL HABITAT, JUVENILE REARING, OSMOREGULATION, AND FORAGING HABITATS, AND SUBMERGED AQUATIC VEGETATION AND HABITATS TO SUPPORT FORAGE FISH AND NATURAL TIDAL MARSH HABITATS  ADDITIONALLY, BIOLOGICAL AND HYDROLOGICAL DATA WILL BE COLLECTED FOR THE SEQUALITCHEW CREEK BASIN, IMPROVING ESTABLISHED BASELINE CONDITIONS TO SUPPORT SUCCESSFUL RESTORATION AND MONITORING

PURPOSE BECAUSE INVASIVE CARP FEED LOW ON THE AQUATIC FOOD WEB, THEY ARE LIKELY TO IMPACT MANY NATIVE FISH SPECIES IN KENTUCKY LAKE AND LAKE BARKLEY  THUS, IT IS IMPORTANT THAT WE STUDY NOT ONLY THE INVASIVE CARP BUT ALSO THE NATIVE FISH WHICH ARE LIKELY TO BE INFLUENCED BY THOSE CARP  WE PROPOSE TO USE ACOUSTIC TAGS TO TRACK THE MOVEMENT OF BOTH INVASIVE CARP AND NATIVE SPECIES THROUGHOUT THESE RESERVOIRS, INCLUDING THE PASSAGE OF FISH ACROSS THE DAMS OF BOTH RESERVOIRS  ALSO, NATIVE GIZZARD SHAD AND THREADFIN SHAD ARE CRITICAL FORAGE FISH IN THESE RESERVOIRS AND ARE EXPECTED TO COMPETE DIRECTLY WITH INVASIVE CARP  THUS, WE ALSO PROPOSE TO STUDY THE POPULATION DYNAMICS OF THE NATIVE SHAD SPECIES SO THAT WE CAN CLOSELY MONITOR HOW THESE FISH ARE AFFECTED BY INVASIVE CARP ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED ACOUSTIC TAGS WILL BE IMPLANTED IN INVASIVE CARP, PADDLEFISH, AND SMALLMOUTH BUFFALO SO THAT THESE FISH CAN BE TRACKED THROUGHOUT EACH RESERVOIR  FISH MOVEMENT WILL BE MONITORED BOTH ON A LARGE SCALE VIA THE EXISTING NETWORK OF PASSIVE RECEIVERS, AND ALSO ON A SMALL SCALE BY MOAT MOUNTED TRACKING  BOAT MOUNTED TRACKING WILL FOCUS ON 24 HOUR MOVEMENT PATTERNS AND MACROHABITAT USE OF THESE SPECIES  SHAD SPECIES WILL BE PERIODICALLY SAMPLED BY A VARIETY OF GEARS TO COLLECT A REPRESENTATIVE SAMPLE OF THESE POPULATIONS  ALL SHAD WILL BE MEASURED, AND A SUBSAMPLE WILL BE AGED IN EACH RESERVOIR DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES WE WILL PROVIDE FINAL REPORTS CONCERNING THE MOVEMENT AND DAM CROSSING OF BOTH INVASIVE CARP AND THE NATIVE SPECIES  WE WILL ALSO PROVIDE FINAL REPORTS CONCERNING THE POPULATION CHARACTERISTICS OF BOTH SHAD SPECIES IN KENTUCKY LAKE AND LAKE BARKLEY INTENDED BENEFICIARIES FISHING AND RECREATION WITHIN THESE 2 RESERVOIRS ARE CRITICAL COMPONENTS OF THE CULTURE AND ECONOMY OF WESTERN KENTUCKY  THE INVASIVE CARP THREATEN TO DISRUPT THE ENTIRE AQUATIC COMMUNITY OF THESE SYSTEMS, AND THEY ALSO CREATE HAZARDS FOR RECREATIONAL BOATERS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO AID IN THE MANAGEMENT AND RESEARCH OF THE INVASIVE CARP SPECIES IN KENTUCKY S WATERS  THE KENTUCKY DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES HAS TWO CREWS DEDICATED TO THESE EFFORTS, ONE IN FRANKFORT, KY AND ONE CREW BASED IN MURRAY, KY  THESE STAFF ALSO WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH COMMERCIAL FISHERMEN ON THE OHIO RIVER AND KENTUCKY BARKLEY LAKES TO FURTHER MANAGEMENT EFFORTS  THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE A SUBSIDY TO COMMERCIAL FISHERMEN ON KENTUCKY BARKLEY LAKES AND A WILL ALSO PROVIDE A DAILY CONTRACT AMOUNT TO THOSE FISHERMEN ON THE  LEADING EDGE  OF THE OHIO RIVER  THIS FUNDING WILL CONTINUE THE WORK OF PREVIOUS GRANTS, AND WILL PROVIDE CRUCIAL FUNDING DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2023

WE HAVE IDENTIFIED A DOUBLE HEAD-GATE DIVERSION ON DUCK CREEK WHICH IS CURRENTLY PREVENTING FISH PASSAGE. DUCK CREEK IS A TRIBUTARY TO HENRYS LAKE LOCATED IN THE NORTHEASTERN TIP OF FREMONT COUNTY, IDAHO. THIS STRUCTURE WAS BUILT IN 2008 AND IS DAMNED WITH BOARDS TO PROVIDE WATER TO LIVESTOCK ON BOTH SIDES OF THE STREAM. THE CURRENT STRUCTURE IMPEDES BOTH UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM FISH PASSAGE IN DUCK CREEK AND IS LOCATED 2.2 MILES UPSTREAM OF THE MOUTH OF HENRYS LAKE. HISTORICALLY, DUCK CREEK SUPPORTED APPROXIMATELY 20% OF THE YELLOWSTONE CUTTHROAT TROUT ONCORHYNCHUS CLARKII BOUVIERI SPAWNING RUN. TODAY, DUCK CREEK IS STILL UTILIZED AS A SPAWNING AND REARING STREAM FOR YELLOWSTONE CUTTHROAT TROUT (YCT) AND A THERMAL REFUGE FROM HENRYS LAKE FOR HYBRID AND BROOK TROUT.MULTIPLE RESTORATION PROJECTS HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTED BOTH UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE PROJECT SITE WHICH INCLUDE LIVESTOCK ELECTRIC EXCLUSION FENCING, LIVESTOCK WATER CROSSING HARDENING, IRRIGATION DITCH SCREENING, CULVERT REPLACEMENT, AND BEAVER DAM ANALOG STRUCTURES TO INCREASE HYPORHEIC FLOW AND EXCHANGE, ENHANCE RIPARIAN ZONE, AND INCREASE FISH PASSAGE. BY RETROFITTING THIS HEAD-GATE STRUCTURE WE WILL REOPEN ACCESS TO DUCK CREEK. NORTH FORK DUCK, SOUTH FORK DUCK, RED ROCK, AND INGALLS CREEKS TOTALING 13.64 MILES OF POTENTIAL SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT FOR YCT YEAR ROUND.

THE NORTHERN POPULATION SEGMENT OF COPPERBELLY WATERSNAKES IS FEDERALLY THREATENED AND BLANDING S TURTLES ARE THREATENED IN THE STATE OF OHIO AND ARE CURRENTLY UNDER CONSIDERATION FOR LISTING UNDER THE U S  ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  RECENT SURVEYS FOR THESE SPECIES HAVE HIGHLIGHTED DECLINING POPULATIONS AND IDENTIFIED AREAS WHERE MANAGEMENT AND RECOVERY EFFORTS WOULD BE BENEFICIAL  FURTHERMORE, CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY PLANS FOR THESE SPECIES HAVE RECOMMENDED REPATRIATION AS A POTENTIAL MEANS OF STABILIZING DECLINING POPULATIONS  USING A DECISION MAKING FRAMEWORK, WE IDENTIFIED SITES WITHIN THE TARGET SPECIES  HISTORIC RANGE THAT HAD UNDERGONE RECENT HABITAT RESTORATION, MESOPREDATOR CONTROL, AND COULD BENEFIT FROM AUGMENTATION AND HEAD STARTING  THIS WORK WOULD CONTINUE AUGMENTATION OF BLANDING S TURTLES AT UP TO THREE SITES AND BE THE FIRST INSTANCE OF A CAPTIVE PROPAGATION AND RELEASE PROGRAM FOR COPPERBELLY WATERSNAKES AT THE ONLY KNOWN, EXTANT POPULATION IN OHIO  THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF HEAD STARTING THESE SPECIES IS TO AID IN RECOVERY EFFORTS BY AUGMENTING DECLINING POPULATIONS, SUCH THAT THEY BECOME SELF SUSTAINING THE GOALS OF THIS PROPOSAL ARE  1  ESTABLISH  SNAKES  AND REFINE  TURTLES  HUSBANDRY METHODS, AND 2  DETERMINE THE SHORT TERM SUCCESS OF CAPTIVE PROPAGATION AND HEAD STARTING EFFORTS BY MONITORING POST RELEASE MOVEMENTS, HABITAT USE, GROWTH, AND SURVIVAL  DATA COLLECTED FROM THIS PROPOSAL WILL BE USED TO INFORM CONSERVATION PLANNING, CAPTIVE REARING EFFORTS, POPULATION VIABILITY ANALYSES, AND STOCKING NUMBERS  LONG TERM, THE ANIMALS RELEASED FROM THIS PROPOSAL WILL HELP STABILIZE LOCAL POPULATIONS AND PREVENT EXTIRPATIONS  WE ANTICIPATE THIS RESEARCH YIELDING RESULTS THAT WILL INFLUENCE CAPTIVE REARING AND RELEASE EFFORTS OF THREATENED REPTILES

MARTEN S ARE SMALL BODIED CARNIVORES THAT INHABIT MATURE FORESTS THROUGHOUT THEIR DISTRIBUTIONAL RANGE  DUE TO THEIR HABITAT SPECIALIZATION, LARGE SPATIAL REQUIREMENTS, AND LONGEVITY, MARTEN HAVE BEEN USED AS SENTINEL SPECIES FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF STRUCTURALLY COMPLEX FORESTS THROUGHOUT NORTH AMERICA  ALONG THEIR SOUTHERN RANGE BOUNDARY IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION, MARTENS WERE LARGELY EXTIRPATED BY THE 1930S WITH ONLY A SMALL POPULATION REMAINING IN NORTHEASTERN MINNESOTA  BEGINNING IN THE 1950S,DOZENS OF REGIONAL TRANSLOCATIONS INVOLVING HUNDREDS OF INDIVIDUALS HAS CREATED A RECOVERY NETWORK FOR THIS SPECIES  SIMILAR TO NATURAL METAPOPULATIONS BUT EMERGING FROM HUMAN AGENCY  THAT FEATURES MULTIPLE SUB POPULATIONS OF MARTENS OCCURRING IN AREAS OF VARYING HABITAT QUALITY AND DEMOGRAPHIC POTENTIAL, BUT WITH UNKNOWN CONNECTIVITY AND UNCERTAIN REGIONAL VIABILITY OUR LACK OF INFORMATION ON THE TRAJECTORY, CONNECTIVITY AND VIABILITY OF AMERICAN MARTENS  MARTES AMERICANA  IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION HAS HAMPERED REGIONAL INFORMED MANAGEMENT OF THIS REINTRODUCED AND PUTATIVE RECOVERING METAPOPULATION  THIS IS PARTICULARLY RELEVANT GIVEN THE SPECIES IS ENDANGERED IN WISCONSIN AND RECOVERING IN NEIGHBORING STATES, THEIR ROLE AS AN INDICATOR SPECIES FOR THE USFS, AS WELL AS THEIR IMPORTANT STATUS AS A CLAN ANIMAL FOR THE OBJIBWE TRIBES THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE NEW INFORMATION ON THE ABUNDANCE, VITAL RATES, CONNECTIVITY, AND THE FIRST VIABILITY ANALYSIS FOR THIS RECOVERY NETWORK ACROSS THE GREAT LAKES REGION  BY LINKING OUR ANALYSES WITH LAND COVER DATA AND MANAGEMENT HISTORIES, OUR RESULTS WILL INFORM STATE, TRIBAL AND FEDERAL LAND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS TO ENHANCE THE CONNECTIVITY AND VIABILITY OF THESE POPULATIONS  ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL IDENTIFY LOCATIONS AND HABITATS FEATURING THE GREATEST POTENTIAL FOR FUTURE RECOVERY AS WELL AS HABITAT CORRIDORS CONNECTING THE RECOVERY NETWORK  OUR PROJECT WILL LEVERAGE AND UNITE MULTIPLE YEARS OF NON INVASIVE, GENETIC BASED DATA WITH GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM AND RADIO TELEMETRY DATA AND LAY THE GROUNDWORK FOR A LONG TERM AND REGIONAL MONITORING PLAN FOR THIS SPECIES  THIS PROJECT WILL FOSTER A COLLABORATION AMONG RED CLIFF BAND OF LAKE SUPERIOR CHIPPEWA, UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN MADISON, APOSTLE ISLANDS NATIONAL LAKESHORE, UNITED STATES FOREST SERVICE AND GREAT LAKES INDIAN FISH AND WILDLIFE COMMISSION, WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES AND MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES

DECLINING LAKE WHITEFISH RECRUITMENT IN LAKES HURON AND MICHIGAN HAS BEEN ATTRIBUTED TO DECLINES INICE COVER AND INCREASES IN DREISSENID MUSSELS  DREISSENA POLYMORPHA, D  BUGENSIS  THAT CONSUME ZOOPLANKTON PREYNECESSARY FOR THE SURVIVAL OF FIRST FEEDING LARVAE  SIMULTANEOUS STRONG TRENDS OF INCREASING WATERTRANSPARENCY HAVE ALSO BEEN OBSERVED IN RECENT DECADES  ONE POTENTIAL CONSEQUENCE OF INCREASED TRANSPARENCY IS INCREASED EXPOSURE TO ULTRA VIOLET  UV  RADIATION, WHICH IS KNOWN TO HAVE LETHAL AND SUBLETHAL EFFECTS ON THE EARLY LIFE STAGES OF SOME FISH SPECIES WE PROPOSE TO EXAMINE THIS PREVIOUSLY UNSTUDIED MECHANISM  UV EFFECTS ON LAKE WHITEFISH RECRUITMENT  SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL 1  ELUCIDATE THE ROLE OF UV EXPOSURE AS A PHYSICAL HABITAT FEATURE AND 2  IDENTIFY DIFFERENCES IN UV TOLERANCE OF LARVAE ACROSS DIFFERENT STOCKS, AND THUS PROVIDE INSIGHTS INTO WHETHER AND WHERE UV CONTRIBUTES TO RECRUITMENT BOTTLENECKS  IF UV REDUCES LARVAL SURVIVAL, THIS INFORMATION CAN BE USED TO DEVELOP ALTERNATIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO PROTECT THE CORRESPONDINGLY LOWER PRODUCTIVITY STOCKS FROM POTENTIAL OVEREXPLOITATION  THIS WILL ENABLE MORE EFFECTIVE PROTECTION OF SUITABLE REPRODUCTIVE HABITAT, AN IMPROVEMENT OF STOCK ASSESSMENT, AND WILL BETTER INFORM STOCK ASSESSMENT MODELS THAT PREDICT SUSTAINABLE HARVEST LEVELS IN DIFFERENT MANAGEMENT UNITS

LAKE WHITEFISH  COREGONUS CLUPEAFORMIS  ABUNDANCE HAS DECLINED THROUGHOUT MOST OF THE GREAT LAKES FOR TWO DECADES, AND RECRUITMENT HAS NEARLY COLLAPSED IN LAKE ERIE  EBNER ET AL , 2021   THOUGH LAKE WHITEFISH SPAWN THROUGHOUT LAKE ERIE, CURRENT MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES ASSUME THAT THERE IS A SINGLE SPAWNING STOCK OF LAKE WHITEFISH BASED IN THE WEST BASIN  EVALUATING CONNECTIVITY USING GENETIC STOCK IDENTIFICATION  GSI  WOULD TEST THIS ASSUMPTION AND HELP TO UNDERSTAND STOCK SPECIFIC POPULATION DYNAMICS TO ENSURE THAT RECOVERING STOCKS ARE PROTECTED  HOWEVER, COMPARED TO THE OTHER GREAT LAKES, LAKE WHITEFISH IN LAKE ERIE HAVE MODEST GENETIC STRUCTURE WHICH MAKES GSI DIFFICULT THE ABILITY TO IDENTIFY THE NATAL ORIGIN OF LAKE WHITEFISH WOULD ENABLE MIXED STOCK ASSESSMENTS AND ANALYSIS OF STRAYING BEHAVIOR, FACILITATING TARGETED MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR SPECIFIC SPAWNING SHOALS  BUT WITHOUT TOOLS CAPABLE OF DISTINGUISHING AMONG SPAWNING AGGREGATES  I E , STOCKS  THIS IS NOT POSSIBLE  HIGH THROUGHPUT SEQUENCING TECHNIQUES, SUCH AS RAPTURE AND GENOTYPING SEQUENCING  GT SEQ , OFFER NEW OPPORTUNITIES TO DISTINGUISH AMONG CLOSELY RELATED STOCKS WITH CONFIDENCE AND CONDUCT GSI  BOTH A RAPTURE AND GT SEQ PANEL HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED AND USED SUCCESSFULLY TO RE ASSESS GENETIC STRUCTURE AMONG LAKE WHITEFISH STOCKS IN LAKE MICHIGAN  SHI ET AL , IN PREP   AS A PRECURSOR TO THIS PROPOSAL, WE USED THIS RAPTURE PANEL TO GENOTYPE 96 LAKE WHITEFISH FROM LAKE ERIE  EUCLIDE ET AL , IN REVIEW   WE DETERMINED THAT DESPITE LOW ALLELE FREQUENCY DIFFERENCES ACROSS MUCH OF THE GENOME, LOCALIZED GENOMIC REGIONS OF ELEVATED THE PROPORTION OF THE TOTAL GENETIC VARIANCE CONTAINED IN A SUBPOPULATION RELATIVE TO THE TOTAL GENETIC VARIANCESUGGESTED THAT ACCURATE GSI MAY BE POSSIBLE  THESE DATA INDICATED THAT PHILOPATRIC LAKE WHITEFISH MAY BE LOCALLY ADAPTED TO THEIR NATAL REEFS SUGGESTING THAT IMPORTANT GENETIC OR PHENOTYPIC DIVERSITY MAY BE BEING OVERLOOKED  CONDUCTING A COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT OF LAKE WHITEFISH SPAWNING STOCK GENETIC DIVERSITY IN LAKE ERIE WOULD 1  DESCRIBE THE GENETIC RELATIONSHIPS AMONG SPAWNING AGGREGATION FOR THE FIRST TIME 2  DETERMINE WHETHER GENETIC TOOLS DEVELOPED FOR LAKE MICHIGAN COULD BE USED TO CONDUCT GSI IN LAKE ERIE AND 3  IDENTIFY ADAPTIVE GENETIC VARIATION AMONG SPAWNING REEFS IN LAKE MICHIGAN THAT COULD BE USED TO IMPROVE ASSIGNMENT ACCURACY IN LAKE ERIE

AN UNDERSIZED, PERCHED, AND FAILING CULVERT WHERE GREEN CREEK CROSSES TRASK RIVER ROAD IN TILLAMOOK, OREGON IS A FISH PASSAGE BARRIER TO PACIFIC LAMPREY, CHUM, CHINOOK, AND COHO SALMON, STEELHEAD, AND CUTTHROAT TROUT  THE CULVERT INHIBITS STREAM PROCESSES SUCH AS TRANSPORT OF SEDIMENT AND WOOD, AND IS AT RISK OF CATASTROPHIC FAILURE THIS PROJECT WILL REPLACE THE FISH PASSAGE BARRIER CULVERT WITH A 36  CLEAR SPAN BRIDGE AND RESTORE FULL PASSAGE FOR LAMPREY AND OTHER ANADROMOUS FISH TO 1 7 MILES OF HABITAT, RESTORE NATURAL STREAM PROCESSES, AND IMPROVE TRANSPORTATION INFRASTRUCTURE AND PUBLIC SAFETY

SOMERSET LAKE IS A 253 ACRE IMPOUNDMENT OWNED BY THE COMMONWEALTH OF PENNSYLVANIA  IT IS MANAGED BY THE FISH AND BOAT COMMISSION FOR PUBLIC FISHING AND RECREATION  IN 2012 WATER WAS DISCOVERED IN THE BREAST OF THE DAM, WHICH LED TO IT BEING LISTED AS A HIGH HAZARD  THE STATE DEDICATED  7 MILLION TO FUND THE DAM REPAIR AND THE LOCAL COMMUNITY RAISED  100,000 TO AUGMENT THAT FUNDING  THE LAKE WAS DRAINED IN OCTOBER 2017 AND WAS SCHEDULED FOR REPAIR IN THE FALL OF 2018  DUE TO UNEXPECTED PERMITTING DELAYS THE DAM REPAIR WAS DELAYED UNTIL THE SUMMER OF 2020  THE SOMERSET COUNTY CONSERVANCY CHARITABLE TRUST  SCC  APPLIED FOR NATIONAL FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP FUNDING IN 2020 AND 2021 BUT THE PROPOSALS WERE NOT FUNDED  THE LAKE BEGAN FILLING IN 2021 AND SCC, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH PENNSYLVANIA FISH AND BOAT COMMISSION S  PFBC  LAKE HABITAT PROGRAM, INITIATED HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS  THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND ON PREVIOUSLY COMPLETED STRUCTURAL HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS BY INSTALLING  1  8 STONED FRAMED DEFLECTORS 240 FEET OF SHORELINE WILL BE STABILIZED 2  6 MODIFIED MUD SILL, SAWTOOTH DEFLECTORS, OR STONE DEFLECTORS  SPECIFIC TECHNIQUE WILL DEPEND ON WATER LEVEL AT TIME OF STRUCTURE PLACEMENT 3  400 SHORT VERTICAL PLANK STRUCTURES 4  50 CATFISH BOXES 5  18 TURTLE BASKING PLATFORMS 6  300 PORCUPINE CRIBS 7  200 FELLED TREES  SOMERSET IS A MAJOR RECREATIONAL DESTINATION FOR THE LOCAL COMMUNITY  THE HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS WILL IMPROVE POPULATION STRUCTURE OF ALL MAJOR RECREATIONAL SPECIES  BASS, CRAPPIE, SUNFISH AND WALLEYE   THIS SHOULD RESULT IN INCREASED PUBLIC VISITATION AND THE RESULTANT INCREASES IN ASSOCIATED ECONOMIC ACTIVITY

THE WET FOUNDATION IS REQUESTING  1,200,000 00 OF U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICES ASSISTANCE TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE THE INVASIVE AQUATIC VEGETATION IN LAKE GUNTERSVILLE  WORKING IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY  TVA , AND LOCAL PARTNERS, THE WET FOUNDATION HAS DEVELOPED AN AQUATIC VEGETATION MANAGEMENT PLAN WHICH INCLUDES SUPPRESSING AQUATIC PLANS USING APPROVED METHODS IN DESIGNATED AREAS OF THE RESERVOIR WHERE THEY CAUSE CONFLICTS WITH RESERVOIR USE, WHILE PROTECTING FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO FUND TENNESSEE WILDLIFE RESOURCES AGENCY  TWRA  EFFORTS TO MANAGE AND CONTROL INVASIVE CARP IN THE STATE OF TENNESSEE  ACTIVITIES WILL BE PERFORMED IN THE LOWER MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN  REELFOOT LAKE , AND IN THE TENNESSEE CUMBERLAND RIVER BASIN INCLUDING KENTUCKY, PICKWICK, GUNTERSVILLE, NICKAJACK, CHICKAMAUGA, WATTS BAR, FORT LOUDOUN, BARKLEY, CHEATHAM, AND OLD HICKORY RESERVOIRS  PRIMARY ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE INCENTIVIZING REMOVAL OF INVASIVE CARP BY WORKING WITH WHOLESALE FISH DEALERS AND COMMERCIAL FISHERS, MONITORING POPULATION CHARACTERISTICS VIA FISHERIES SAMPLING TECHNIQUES  ELECTROFISHING, GILL NETS, HOOP NETS, DOZER TRAWLS, ETC  , MONITORING FOR NATURAL REPRODUCTION AND OR RANGE EXPANSION, AND TRACKING MOVEMENT OF INVASIVE CARP VIA ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY TECHNIQUES  ACTIVITIES WILL BE IMPERATIVE FOR PREVENTING FURTHER EXPANSION OF CARP IN TENNESSEE WATERS AND FOR BETTER UNDERSTANDING, AND ULTIMATELY MANAGING, CARP POPULATIONS  THIS PROJECT WILL WIDELY BENEFIT RESOURCE USERS THROUGHOUT TENNESSEE, AGENCIES MANAGING CARP POPULATIONS, AND NATIVE SPECIES  SUBRECIPIENTS MAY BE RESPONSIBLE FOR PORTIONS OF WORK COMPLETED   AT THIS TIME, EXPECTATIONS ARE THAT UNIVERSITIES MAY ASSIST WITH LARVAL FISH COLLECTION, POPULATION MONITORING, AND TELEMETRY ACTIVITIES  ALL ADDITIONAL REQUIRED STATEMENTS ARE INCLUDED IN THE APPLICATION SUBMISSION

THE INCREASE OF INVASIVE CARP POPULATIONS IS DOING HARM TO RECREATION ACTIVES AND IS LIKELY NEGATIVELY IMPACTING THE NATIVE FISHERY  WHILE COMPLETE ELIMINATION OF INVASIVE CARP IS NOT CURRENTLY FEASIBLE, MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL OF THESE FISH IS NECESSARY TO REDUCE THE IMPACT ON NATIVE SPECIES, THE ECOSYSTEM, AND THE ECONOMY  THERE IS A NEED TO IDENTIFY EFFECTIVE STRATEGIES TO REDUCE INVASIVE CARP NUMBERS AND CONTROL THE EXPANSION OF INVASIVE CARP INTO ADJACENT AQUATIC SYSTEMS WITHIN THE LMR BASIN  THIS PROJECT USES MULTIPLE METHODS FOR REMOVAL, IN A VARIETY OF AQUATIC HABITATS PROVIDING INSIGHTS INTO THE MOST EFFECTIVE AND EFFICIENT MEANS BY WHICH TO CONTROL INVASIVE CARP POPULATIONS  INVASIVE CARP POPULATIONS HAVE BEEN INCREASING IN MOST OF ARKANSAS S RIVERS  THE AGFC WILL CONTINUE TO USE CONTRACTED REMOVAL IN THE LMR BASIN ATTEMPTING TO REDUCE INVASIVE CARP POPULATIONS  HARVESTING FISH AND THE ASSOCIATED DATA COLLECTION SHOULD INCREASE OUR KNOWLEDGE OF INVASIVE CARP, REDUCING THE POPULATION SIZE, ALLOW US TO EXPLORE POSSIBLE DETERRENT LOCATIONS, AND REDUCE THE CHANCE FOR UPSTREAM RANGE EXPANSION

FUNDING PROVIDED THROUGH THIS GRANT WILL BE USED TO IDENTIFY AND MONITOR THE STATUS, DISTRIBUTION AND DIET COMPOSITION OF INVASIVE CARP THROUGHOUT LOUISIANA  FUNDING WILL ALSO BE USED TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVNESS OF NEW COMMERCIAL FISHING GEAR IN CAPTURING INVASIVE CARP  IN ADDITION, FUNDING WILL BE USED TO EVAULATE POTENTIAL MARKETS FOR PRODUCTS MADE WITH INVASIVE CARP  THE LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF WIDLIFE AND FISHERIES WILL WORK WITH VARIOUS ENTITIES SUCH AS LOUISIANA STATE UNIVERSITY, NICHOLLS STATE UNIVERSITY, THE LOUISIANA UNIVERSITY MARINE CONSORTIIUM, AQUARANGE RESEARCH LLC, AND THE UNIVERSITY OF LOUISIANA LAFAYETTE TO COMPLETE THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS GRANT

MINIMIZING THE RISK OF INVASIVE CARP FROM SPREADING TO NEW AREAS IN THE MISSOURI RIVER BASIN REQUIRES ANUNDERSTANDING OF WHICH SITES ARE MOST VULNERABLE TO INVASION THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS WORK IS TO LIMIT THE SPREAD OF INVASIVE CARP IN THE MISSOURI RIVER BASIN  THE TASKS DESCRIBED HERE WILL DEVELOP QUANTITATIVE RISK ASSESSMENTS THAT WILL IDENTIFY SITE VULNERABILITY TO INVASIVECARP IN THE MISSOURI RIVER BASIN  THESE RESULTS WILL ALLOW FOR THE EFFICIENT USE OF MANAGEMENT RESOURCES BY IDENTIFYING LOCATIONS WHERE MOVEMENT DETERRENTS CAN BE PLACED, DETERMINING LOCATIONS AND LIFESTAGES  EGGS, JUVENILES, ADULT SIZE CLASSES  MONITORING EFFORTS SHOULD TARGET AND APPROPRIATE SAMPLING GEARS TO USE, AND INFORMING OR DEVELOPING RESPONSE PLANS IF INVASIVE CARP ARE OBSERVED IN NEW LOCATIONS THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS STUDY IS TO ASSESS HYDROLOGIC CONNECTIVITY IN MISSOURI RIVER BASIN TO IDENTIFY LOCATIONS AT RISK OF RANGE EXPANSION TO SILVER AND BIGHEAD CARP MOVEMENT INTO NEW AREAS THIS DATA ASSESSMENT WILL INCORPORATE PAST INVASIVE CARP SAMPLING  I E , EDNA RESULTS AND TRADITIONAL FISHSAMPLING COLLECTIONS  AND OTHER OBSERVATIONS  I E , PROFESSIONAL AND CITIZEN SCIENTIST  TO DETAIL THE CURRENTINVASIVE CARP DISTRIBUTIONS THROUGHOUT NEBRASKA AND DOCUMENT THE CONNECTIVITY AMONG NEBRASKA SRIVERS AND STREAMS, SIDE CHANNELS AND LAKES, CANAL SYSTEMS, AND IMPOUNDMENTS ADDITIONAL ASSESSMENTSWILL INCLUDE DOCUMENTING BARRIERS FOR UPSTREAM MOVEMENT, IDENTIFY BARRIERS THAT MAY NOT IMPEDEINVASIVE CARP MOVEMENT ACROSS RANGE OF HYDROLOGIC CONDITIONS AND DETERMINE THE  RISK  ASSOCIATED WITH FURTHER INVASIVE CARP EXPANSION  ASSESSMENT METHODS WILL BE SHAREABLE WITH THE MISSOURI RIVER BASIN ASIAN CARP TECHNICAL COMMITTEE INTERIM AND FINAL REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO THE USFWS IN A TIMELY MANNER  DUE DATES DEPENDENT ON WHEN GRANT PERIOD OFFICIALLYBEGINS

INVASIVE CARP ARE WELL ESTABLISHED THROUGHOUT THE MISSOURI RIVER AND TRIBUTARIES DOWNSTREAM OF GAVINS POINT DAM  KNOWING WHEN AND UNDER WHAT ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS ADULT SILVER CARP ARE MOVING INTO THE TRIBUTARIES WILL HELP INFORM WHEN TO MONITOR THE POPULATION AS WELL AS IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS  UNDERSTANDING THE MOVEMENT RANGE OF SILVER CARP IN THE MISSOURI RIVER BASIN, THE ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS ASSOCIATED WITH MOVEMENTS, AND THE CONDITIONS ASSOCIATED WITH AGGREGATIONS WILL ALLOW FOR THE IDENTIFICATION OF LOCATIONS WHERE DETERRENCE TECHNOLOGIES, CONCENTRATED REMOVAL EFFORTS, PHYSICAL BARRIERS, OR OTHER EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES CAN BE UTILIZED FOR CONTAINMENT AND CONTROL  IDENTIFICATION AND EVALUATION OF CONTAINMENT OPPORTUNITIES CAN FACILITATE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF DETERRENT AND OR REMOVAL SYSTEMS THAT MAY LIMIT DISPERSAL, REPRODUCTION, OR RECRUITMENT OF INVASIVE CARP, INCLUDING SILVER CARP  A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE MOVEMENT AND BEHAVIOR OF INVASIVE CARP IN TRIBUTARIES IS CRITICAL TO DEVISING STRATEGIES FOR SUCCESSFUL CONTAINMENT  THIS RESEARCH WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP CRITERIA FOR DETERRENT BARRIERS, HARVEST REGULATIONS, OR OTHER MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES INVASIVE CARP POPULATIONS EXTEND INTO THE INTERIOR WATERS OF MISSOURI RIVER BASIN STATES INCLUDING SOUTH DAKOTA VIA THE JAMES RIVER  SDGFP IN COORDINATION WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH DAKOTA TRACKED SILVER CARP MOVEMENT IN THE JAMES RIVER, SD FROM MID 2021 THROUGH FALL 2022  MOVEMENT DATA WERE RECORDED USING A SERIES OF ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY RECEIVERS DEPLOYED IN THE LOWER 358 RIVER KILOMETERS  RKM  OF THE JAMES RIVER AND USING ANECDOTAL OBSERVATIONS FROM ACTIVE AND PASSIVE TRACKING OCCURRING AS PART OF OTHER RESEARCH PROJECTS IN THE LOWER JAMES RIVER, THE BIG SIOUX AND VERMILLION RIVER, AND THE SECTION OF MISSOURI RIVER ALONG THE SOUTH DAKOTA NEBRASKA BORDER  EARLY DATA RETURNS FROM 2021 AND EARLY 2022 INDICATED LIMITED MOVEMENT, WHICH MAY HAVE RESULTED FROM LOW WATER CONDITIONS FOLLOWING SEVERE DROUGHT IN EASTERN SOUTH DAKOTA  AS A RESULT, INFORMATION ON CUES FOR MOVEMENTS WITHIN, INTO, OR OUT OF THE JAMES RIVER WERE NOT OBSERVED DURING THE FIRST PORTION OF THIS STUDY  ADDITIONAL DATA ARE NEEDED TO ASSESS HOW ENVIRONMENTAL CUES INFLUENCE THE MOVEMENT AND CONGREGATION OF SILVER CARP IN EASTERN SOUTH DAKOTA TRIBUTARIES TO THE MISSOURI RIVER

THE USFWS AND THE AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES TASK FORCE, IN COLLABORATION WITH MULTIPLE STAKEHOLDERS, RELEASED A NATIONAL INVASIVE CARP MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL PLAN  NATIONAL PLAN  CONOVER ET AL  2007 OF INVASIVE CARP MANAGEMENT AND INFORM CONTROL EFFORTS, ESPECIALLY IN THE MISSOURI RIVER BASIN WHERE FUNDING FOR INVASIVE CARP RESEARCH HAS BEEN LACKING  THE TASKS OUTLINED IN THIS DOCUMENT ARE THE SAMPLING  I E , TRAWLING, NETTING, ELECTROFISHING  WILL FOCUS ON THE PRESENCE OF ALL LIFE STAGES AND SIZES  I E , LENGTHS  OF INVASIVE CARP  WE WILL FOCUS SAMPLING EFFORTS IN MID ORDER PRAIRIE STREAMS CONFIGURATIONS, AND DIFFERENT ELECTROFISHING METHODS, ETC   THAT CAN EFFECTIVELY SAMPLE THE INVASIVE CARP POPULATION AND DEVELOP SAMPLING PROTOCOL FOR USE IN PRAIRIE SYSTEMS THAT CAN TARGET DIFFERENT INTRODUCED INVASIVE CARPS  BIGHEAD CARP, BLACK CARP, GRASS CARP, AND SILVER CARP  HAVE BECOME ESTABLISHED IN MANY PORTIONS OF THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN, INCLUDING, WITHIN THE STATE OF KANSAS, BIGHEAD CARP AND SILVER CARP IN THE KANSAS RIVER BELOW THE BOWERSOCK DAM AND BIGHEAD CARP IN THE NEOSHO RIVER   GRAND LAKE SYSTEM  THE FEEDING HABITS AND POPULATION DENSITIES OF INVASIVE CARPS RESULT IN DIMINISHED OPPORTUNITIES FOR RECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL FISHING, BOATING, AND OTHER WILDLIFE ASSOCIATED RECREATION, WHICH CAUSES SIGNIFICANT NEGATIVE ECONOMIC IMPACTS KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND PARKS  KDWP  IS THE AGENCY OF THE STATE OF KANSAS CHARGED WITH MANAGING FISH AND WILDLIFE, INCLUDING MANAGEMENT OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES SUCH AS INVASIVE CARPS  KDWP INTENDS TO CONTINUE AND EXPAND INVASIVE CARP MANAGEMENT EFFORTS INCLUDING THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES REMOVE      INVASIVE CARP FROM THE KANSAS RIVER BELOW BOWERSOCK DAM TO PROVIDE A      BUFFER AGAINST RANGE EXPANSION SHOULD DAM BE INUNDATED DURING A HIGH FLOW      EVENT EXAMINE EFFECTS OF INVASIVE CARPS ON NATIVE SPECIES IN THE KANSAS RIVER  COMPARE KANSAS RIVER INVASIVE CARP IMPACTS RESULTS WITH SIMILAR STUDIES IN OTHER RIVER SYSTEMS REMOVE BIGHEAD CARP FROM WITHIN THE NEOSHO RIVER   GRAND LAKE SYSTEM FISH REMOVAL WILL BE CONDUCTED OR MONITORED BY KDWP  IF CONTRACTED FISHING IS UTILIZED, KDWP STAFF WILL VERIFY EFFORTS AND CATCH RATES OF CONTRACTOR  A REPORT DETAILING INVASIVE CARP IMPACTS TO NATIVE FISHES AND INVASIVE CARP REMOVAL EFFORTS WILL BE PROVIDED BY MARCH 2024  KDWP WILL USE INFORMATION AND EXPERIENCE GAINED DURING THESE PROJECTS TO GUIDE AND IMPROVE FUTURE INVASIVE CARP MANAGEMENT  KDWP WILL CONTINUE TO SEEK OPPORTUNITIES AND TAKE ACTION TO MINIMIZE THE IMPACTS OF INVASIVE CARPS TO KANSAS  NATURAL RESOURCES

INVASIVE CARP SPECIES, SUCH AS SILVER AND BIGHEAD CARP, ORIGINATED FROM ASIA, BUT THROUGH ESCAPEMENT FROM AQUACULTURE PONDS HAVE EXPANDED THEIR RANGE INTO THE MISSISSIPPI, OHIO, AND TENNESSEE RIVER SYSTEMS  ALTHOUGH THEIR CURRENT ABUNDANCE IN ALABAMA IS RELATIVELY LOW, THESE INVASIVE SPECIES POSE A SIGNIFICANT THREAT TO SPORTFISH POPULATIONS, AQUATIC INVERTEBRATES, RECREATION, AND THE ECONOMY  MONITORING POPULATIONS OF INVASIVE CARP AND TARGETING THEIR REMOVAL WILL HOPEFULLY KEEP THEIR ABUNDANCE AT LOW LEVELS AND SLOW THEIR EXPANSION UPSTREAM YOUNG OF YEAR CARP HAVE NOT BEEN OBSERVED ON ANY OF THE TENNESSEE RIVER RESERVOIRS IN ALABAMA  HOWEVER, AN IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF INVASIVE CARP REPRODUCTION WHERE THESE SPECIES ALREADY OCCUR AND INCREASED SURVEILLANCE FOR POPULATION EXPANSION WILL HAVE SIGNIFICANT IMPLICATIONS FOR INFORMING MANAGEMENT ACTIONS, SUCH AS TARGETED REMOVAL EFFORTS AND DETERRENT STRATEGIES  IN ADDITION TO MONITORING FOR INVASIVE CARP RECRUITMENT WHERE EXISTING POPULATIONS OCCUR, SURVEILLANCE AND MONITORING EFFORTS ARE ALSO NEEDED IN WATERS UPSTREAM OF THE EXISTING LEADING EDGE OF THE KNOWN INVASION FRONT, WHICH IS CURRENTLY PICKWICK RESERVOIR  REPORTS OR ENCOUNTERS WITH INVASIVE CARP IN UPSTREAM RESERVOIRS ARE INFREQUENT BUT INCREASING OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE INVASION FRONT AND DOCUMENTING RANGE EXPANSION IS OF CRITICAL IMPORTANCE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  1  ESTIMATE INVASIVE CARP RELATIVE ABUNDANCE AND POPULATION DEMOGRAPHICS IN THE TENNESSEE AND CUMBERLAND RIVER BASINS TO EVALUATE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS  2  TARGET AND REMOVE INVASIVE CARP TO SUPPRESS POPULATIONS AND REDUCE PROPAGULE PRESSURE IN THE TENNESSEE AND CUMBERLAND RIVER BASINS  3  DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT MONITORING PROGRAMS FOR EARLY DETECTION OF INVASIVE CARP IN WATERS UPSTREAM OF THE CURRENT LEADING EDGE

THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PLAN FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES IN IOWA FOCUS ON PUBLIC OUTREACH TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF ANS, MONITORING STATE WATERBODIES FOR EARLY DETECTION OF ANS INTRODUCTIONS, AND MANAGEMENT OF ANS INFESTATIONS  THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES ANS PROGRAM USES GRANT FUNDS TO SUPPORT IMPLEMENTATION ACTIVITIES OF THE PLAN RELATED TO COORDINATION, PUBLIC OUTREACH AND MONITORING  THE IOWA DNR ANS PROGRAM COORDINATOR DIRECTS IMPLEMENTATION OF ALL ASPECTS OF THE PLAN, AND TIME SPENT ON PLAN IMPLEMENTATION CODED TO THIS GRANT WILL COVER APPROXIMATELY 50  OF THE PROGRAM COORDINATORS SALARY AND BENEFITS  TASKS THAT WILL BE SPECIFICALLY ADDRESSED IN 2023 INCLUDE SUPPORTING INVASIVE CARP PROJECTS BEING CONDUCTED ON THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN AND MISSOURI RIVER BASIN, ANALYZING WATERCRAFT INSPECTION DATA TO OPTIMIZE EDUCATIONAL AND PREVENTION EFFORTS IN WATERBODIES ACROSS THE STATE AND INCREASING OUTREACH TO THE PADDLE SPORT COMMUNITY  THE PROGRAM COORDINATOR ALSO SUPPORTS REGIONAL AND NATIONAL ANS COORDINATION AND PLANS TO ATTEND TWO ANS TASK FORCE MEETINGS, THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN PANEL ON ANS MEETING, THE MISSOURI RIVER ANS WORKING GROUP MEETING, THE MISSOURI RIVER BASIN ASIAN CARP COMMITTEE MEETING AND TWO MEETINGS OF THE ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES INVASIVE SPECIES COMMITTEE  STAFF OF THE IOWA ANS PROGRAM INCLUDING A NATURAL RESOURCE BIOLOGIST, NATURAL RESOURCE TECHNICIAN AND FOUR SEASONAL WORKER TECHNICIANS WILL SURVEY UP TO 75 LAKES AND 10 INTERIOR RIVERS IN 2023 TO DETECT INTRODUCTIONS, MONITOR SPREAD, AND DETERMINE CURRENT STATUS OF EURASIAN WATERMILFOIL, BRITTLE NAIAD, ZEBRA MUSSELS, INVASIVE CARP, AND OTHER ANS IN IOWA

SEVEN MILE CREEK AND ROGERS CREEK ARE BOTH IMPAIRED FOR A LACK OF FISH AND MACROINVERTEBRATE ASSEMBLAGE  THE MINNESOTA POLLUTION CONTROL AGENCY IDENTIFIED MULTIPLE STRESSORS FOR EACH CREEK WITH EXCESS NUTRIENTS, SUSPENDED SOLIDS, AND ALTERED HYDROLOGY BEING STRESSORS FOR EACH CREEK  THE ST  PETER DWSMA, BETWEEN THE TWO CREEKS, HAS HIGH NITRATE CONCENTRATIONS AS WELL  WITH MANY EARLY ADOPTERS HAVING ALREADY IMPLEMENTED BMPS IN THE AREA, AND A STRONG DESIRE AMONG FARMERS FOR OTHER CROPS TO ADD TO THE ROTATION, PARTNERS ARE WORKING WITH FARMERS TO PILOT AND GROW CONTINUOUS LIVING COVER CROPS  KERNZA? AND WINTER CAMELINA  AND OTHER COVER CROPS IN 2022 2024, GREAT RIVER GREENING WILL WORK WITH NICOLLET COUNTY TO LEAD EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES  FIELD DAYS AND A PARTNERSHIP WITH THE LOCAL SCHOOL SYSTEM   THEY WILL COMMUNICATE THE MARKETABILITY OF THE NEW CROPS AS WELL AS THE SOIL HEALTH, WATER QUALITY, AND FISH HABITAT BENEFITS  MOST IMPORTANTLY, ADDING COVER CROPS AND PERENNIAL CROPS TO THE LOCAL ROTATIONS WILL IMPROVE WATER RETENTION AND WATER QUALITY WHERE RAVINE EROSION AND NUTRIENT LOSS HAVE BEEN IMPAIRING THE WATERWAYS DOWNSTREAM AND LOCAL DRINKING WATER SUPPLY  PARTNERS WILL ALSO COLLECT WATER SAMPLES FROM THE CREEKS AND OUTLETS OF FIELDS IMPLEMENTING THESE NEW CROPS  FIELD DAYS WILL OCCUR IN FALL 2022, SPRING 2023, AND FALL 2023 WHILE WATER SAMPLING TAKES PLACE FROM SUMMER 2022 TO FALL 2023  NOT MUCH IS KNOWN ABOUT THE LEVEL OF IMPACT THESE NEW CROPS HAVE ON NUTRIENT LOSS REDUCTIONS IN TILE DRAINAGE, BUT THIS PROJECT WILL MONITOR THOSE POTENTIAL BENEFITS ON SOME OF THE EARLY PILOTED FIELDS  FIELD DAYS WILL INCLUDE DEMONSTRATIONS ABOUT SOIL HEALTH, DESCRIPTIONS OF WATER QUALITY AND FISH HABITAT BENEFITS, FISH SHOCKING, NEW CROP MARKET REPRESENTATIVES, AND TASTINGS OF NEW PRODUCTS FROM THOSE CROPS

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTRIBUTE RESTORATION OF ANADROMOUS FISH AND ACHIEVE THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE KLAMATH RIVER BASIN CONSERVATION AREA FISHERY RESTORATION PROGRAM THROUGHOUT THE LOWER MID KLAMATH RIVER BY IMPLEMENTING THE MID KLAMATH RIVER SUB BASIN PLAN, AND ACCOMPANYING FISHERIES RESTORATION CANDIDATE ACTION TABLE, IN CONCERT WITH THE KLAMATH INTEGRATED RESTORATION AND MONITORING PLAN, AND SIX RIVERS NATIONAL FOREST AQUATIC RESTORATION ACTION PLAN TASKS1 CONTINUE COMMUNICATION AND OUTREACH ABOUT HABITAT PROTECTION AND RESTORATION EFFORTS THROUGH WORKSHOPS, CONFERENCE ATTENDANCE, A NEWSLETTER, A BLOG, OTHER FUNCTIONS OF OUR WEBSITE, OTHER MEDIA DISPATCHES SUCH AS VIA SOCIAL MEDIA, PRESS RELEASES AND PSAS, AND PERSONAL INTERFACE WITH MANAGING AGENCIES, STAKEHOLDERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC IN THE MID KLAMATH RIVER SUB BASIN 2 COORDINATE WITH MID KLAMATH LANDOWNERS, PRIVATE AND PUBLIC, FOR THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF RESTORATION PROJECTS THAT RESPOND TO PROBLEMS RELATED TO FISHERY RECOVERY AND TO THE MIDDLE KLAMATH SUB BASIN PLANNING AND PUBLIC REVIEW PROCESS  DEVELOPMENT INCLUDES LEVERAGING FEDERAL DOLLARS TO SECURE OTHER SOURCES OF FUNDING FOR PROJECTS THAT ADVANCE THE ECOLOGICAL HEALTH OF THE MID KLAMATH RIVER SUB BASIN 3 CONVENE THE MIDDLE KLAMATH INSTREAM WORKING GROUP IN ORDER TO PRIORITIZE, PLAN AND COORDINATE RESTORATION ACTIONS IN THE SUB BASIN WITH PARTNER GROUPS AS NEEDED  UPDATE THE MID KLAMATH SUB BASIN FISHERIES RESOURCE RECOVERY PLAN AS NEEDED AND APPROPRIATE 4 DEVELOP AND SUBMIT PROGRESS REPORTS AND A FINAL REPORT TO YREKA FWO

THE SISKIYOU RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICT  SRCD  HAS BEEN INVOLVED IN THE ANNUAL SPAWNING GROUND SURVEYS IN THE SCOTT RIVER VALLEY SINCE 2003  BETWEEN THE SCOTT RIVER FISH COUNTING FACILITY AND THE COOPERATIVE SPAWNING GROUND SURVEYS, A COMPREHENSIVE DATASET ON FALL RUN CHINOOK IS COLLECTED ANNUALLY  THIS INCLUDES INFORMATION ON THE RUN ABUNDANCE, TIMING, AGE SEX LENGTH COMPOSITION AND HATCHERY CONTRIBUTION AS WELL AS THE SPAWNING DISTRIBUTION AND RANGE  THE MONITORING OF THIS POPULATION PROVIDES VALUABLE TREND DATA LEADING TO ESCAPEMENT ESTIMATES, WHICH ARE USED BY THE PACIFIC FISHERIES MANAGEMENT COUNCIL FOR THE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT AND ALLOCATION OF KLAMATH BASIN FALL RUN CHINOOK SALMON  FURTHERMORE, THE REDD DISTRIBUTION IS UTILIZED BY LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS TO PRIORITIZE HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS ON THE SCOTT RIVER MAINSTEM AND MONITOR THEIR EFFECTIVENESS INCLUDING THE UTILIZATION OF SPAWNING GRAVEL SORTED BY LARGE WOOD AUGMENTATION AND HELP PROVIDE INFORMATION ON CONNECTIVITY IN AREAS IN THE UPPER REACHES OF THE WATERSHED THAT ARE OFTEN NOT PHYSICALLY ACCESSIBLE FOR SPAWNING DUE TO PASSAGE BARRIERS AT LOW FLOWS  SISKIYOU RCD WILL SURVEY MAINSTEM SCOTT RIVER REACHES 9 16 FOR CHINOOK SPAWNERS BETWEEN MID OCTOBER THROUGH DECEMBER 2022, CONDITIONS PERMITTING  A COMPREHENSIVE FINAL REPORT WILL FOLLOW  ALL CARCASS DATA AND SAMPLES COLLECTED WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE

THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT YUROK TRIBAL FISHERIES DEPARTMENT  YTFD  COORDINATE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WITHIN THE LOWER KLAMATH TO BENEFIT NATIVE ANADROMOUS FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC DEPENDENT WILDLIFE  YTFD WILL COORDINATE WITH NUMEROUS LOWER KLAMATH PARTNERS INCLUDING VARIOUS YUROK TRIBE S NATURAL RESOURCE DEPARTMENTS, FIORI GEOSCIENCES, GREEN DIAMOND RESOURCE COMPANY, WESTERN RIVERS CONSERVANCY, STATE AND FEDERAL RESOURCE AGENCIES, AND OTHER PERTINENT STAKEHOLDERS  THE GOAL IS TO HELP SUPPORT DEVELOPMENT AND  IMPLEMENTATION OF PRIORITY LOWER KLAMATH FISHERIES RESTORATION  ALL ASPECTS OF THE PROJECT WILL BE DOCUMENTED IN A FINAL PROGRESS REPORT THAT WILL CONTAIN  1  A COMPARISON OF ACTUAL ACCOMPLISHMENTS WITH THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE APPROVED SCOPE OF WORK  2  A DESCRIPTION OF REASONS WHY ESTABLISHED GOALS WERE NOT MET, IF APPROPRIATE  AND 3  ANY OTHER PERTINENT INFORMATION RELEVANT TO THE PROJECT RESULTS

THE ASSESSMENT OF ANADROMOUS SALMONID STOCKS IN BLUE CREEK ON THE LOWER KLAMATH RIVER NEAR KLAMATH, CALIFORNIA IS A PROJECT CARRIED OUT BY THE YUROK TRIBE  THIS PROJECT CONSISTS OF SPAWNING GROUND SURVEYS CONDUCTED ON A WEEKLY AND BI WEEKLY BASIS  DATA IS COLLECTED ON EACH LIVE FISH, REDD AND CARCASS LOCATED THIS PROJECT IS A CONTINUATION OF LONG TERM MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT EFFORTS OF BLUE CREEK ANADROMOUS SALMONID RUNS  BLUE CREEK IS THE ONLY REMAINING DRAINAGE IN THE LOWER KLAMATH SUB BASIN WHICH SUPPORTS SIZABLE RUNS OF CHINOOK SALMON THIS DATA ALLOWS FOR AN ASSESSMENT OF ANADROMOUS SALMONID POPULATION TRENDS WITHIN THE BASIN AS WELL AS CONTINUED ASSESSMENT AND REFINEMENT OF ANADROMOUS SALMONID DISTRIBUTION, IMMIGRATION TIMING, AND HABITAT USAGE THROUGHOUT THE BLUE CREEK DRAINAGE  THIS TREND DATA IS AN INTEGRAL COMPONENT OF THE MEGA TABLE AND PROVIDES A MORE ACCURATE ASSESSMENT OF WILD SALMONID POPULATION NUMBERS THROUGHOUT THE KLAMATH BASIN, WHICH ALLOWS FOR MORE ACCURATE PREDICTIONS OF FUTURE CHINOOK RUN SIZES AND CORRESPONDING ALLOWABLE HARVEST NUMBERS THE KLAMATH FALL CHINOOK AGE COMPOSITION STUDY IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT CARRIED OUT BY THE FORMER KLAMATH RIVER TECHNICAL TEAM  KRTT , AN INTERAGENCY TRIBAL GROUP  THIS TASK INCLUDES AGING SCALES FROM FALL CHINOOK SALMON COLLECTED DURING THE SPAWNING SEASON IN THE KLAMATH RIVER NET AND SPORT FISHERIES, SPAWNING GROUND SURVEYS FROM VARIOUS TRIBUTARIES THROUGHOUT THE KLAMATH BASIN, FISH THAT RETURN TO IRON GATE HATCHERY, AND WEIRS LOCATED IN THE SHASTA RIVER AND BOGUS CREEK  THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS TASK IS TO USE THE AGE COMPOSITION INFORMATION FROM THE 2022 FALL CHINOOK RUN TO PREDICT THE ABUNDANCE FROM THAT RUN, AS WELL AS ASSESS THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN INDIVIDUAL COHORTS AND ENVIRONMENTAL PARAMETERS THE ESCAPEMENT ENUMERATION PROJECT, OR MAINSTEM KLAMATH CARCASS SURVEY IS A COOPERATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN THE YUROK TRIBE, KARUK TRIBE AND USFWS, ARCATA FIELD OFFICE, CARRIED OUT IN THE UPPER MOST REACHES OF THE KLAMATH RIVER IN CALIFORNIA  THE YUROK TRIBE SAMPLES THE UPPER 18 MILES OF THE KLAMATH RIVER IN CONJUNCTION WITH USFWS  THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS STUDY IS TO ASSESS FALL CHINOOK ESCAPEMENT IN THE KLAMATH RIVER FROM IRON GATE DAM DOWNSTREAM TO INDIAN CREEK  THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED BY DIRECTLY SAMPLING AND COLLECTING DATA FROM SALMON CARCASSES  THIS DATA ALLOWS FOR AN ASSESSMENT OF ANADROMOUS SALMONID POPULATION TRENDS WITHIN THE BASIN, PROVIDING VITAL INFORMATION AND MORE ACCURATE PREDICTIONS OF FUTURE CHINOOK RUN SIZES AND CORRESPONDING ALLOWABLE HARVEST NUMBERS

THE SHASTA RIVER WATERSHED COORDINATOR IS A STAFF POSITION FOR THE SHASTA VALLEY RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICT  SVRCD , PROVIDING TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL SUPPORT TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN THE SHASTA VALLEY  WE WORK TO UNDERSTAND FACTORS THAT MIGHT BE RESPONSIBLE FOR CONTINUING DECLINES IN ANADROMOUS FISH POPULATIONS IN THE SHASTA RIVER, AND FINDING EFFECTIVE WAYS TO REVERSE THOSE DECLINES  THIS PROPOSAL WILL BE CONSISTENT WITH ONGOING EMPHASIS ON BIG PICTURE PROJECT PLANNING TO ADDRESS LAND AND WATER MANAGEMENT IMPACTS ON FISH HABITAT, WATER QUANTITY AND QUALITY, AND OTHER EMERGING ISSUES  WATER QUALITY MONITORING IS A KEY TASKS AND IS BENEFICIAL TO ALL OUR CLIENTS, PARTNERS AND COLLABORATORS TO MEASURE AND ASSESS CONDITIONS IN THE FIELD AND IN THE RIVER, ESPECIALLY DURING OUR ONGOING DROUGHT  WE ARE EXPLORING STRATEGIC ASSESSMENT AND STUDY TOOLS AND CONCEPTS WITH PARTNERS TO RESPOND TO DEVELOPING NATURAL RESOURCES CHALLENGES  THIS WORK INCLUDES EDUCATION, OUTREACH, COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATIVE TASKS STAFF WAGES WILL BE THE ONLY SPENDING CATEGORY OTHER THAN 10 PERCENT FOR ADMINISTRATION

THE SCOTT RIVER COORDINATION PROJECT WILL HELP SUPPORT THE CRITICAL EXCHANGE OF INFORMATION, DATA COLLECTION, RESTORATION PLANNING AND PHYSICAL RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WITHIN THE SCOTT RIVER WATERSHED, KLAMATH BASIN, SISKIYOU COUNTY, CALIFORNIA  THIS GRANT WILL HELP FUND ORGANIZATIONAL ELEMENTS OF THE SRWC S WORK IN ALL THESE AREAS OF RESTORATION  SRWC IS MAKING A REQUEST TO THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE IN THE AMOUNT OF  15,000  FIFTEEN THOUSAND DOLLARS  TO HELP SUPPORT THE WORK OF THE SRWC  THE FUNDS WOULD HELP COVER ADMINISTRATIVE PERSONNEL, DIRECT OFFICE EXPENSES AND INDIRECT EXPENSES

THIS PROJECT IS A COOPERATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN THE U  S  FOREST SERVICE, KLAMATH NATIONAL FOREST, SIX RIVER NATIONAL FOREST  THE SALMON RIVER RESTORATION COUNCIL  THE QUARTZ VALLEY INDIAN RESERVATION  THE NORTHERN CALIFORNIA RESOURCE CENTER  THE MID KLAMATH WATERSHED COUNCIL  AND THE SISKIYOU RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICT  THE KARUK AND YUROK TRIBES AND THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME  CDFWS  WILL DIRECT THIS SURVEY, AND ARE ALSO CONTRIBUTORS TO THIS EFFORT THIS ONE YEAR SURVEY WILL DETERMINE IN RIVER RUN SIZE  ESCAPEMENT  OF CHINOOK SALMON WITHIN THE SHASTA, SCOTT, AND SALMON RIVER BASINS AND OTHER MAJOR TRIBUTARIES TO THE MIDDLE KLAMATH RIVER DURING THE 2022 SEASON  OCTOBER THROUGH DECEMBER, 2022   INFORMATION WILL BE COLLECTED ON RUN TIMING, SPAWNING DISTRIBUTION, LENGTH FREQUENCY, AND SEX RATIO FOR FALL CHINOOK SALMON  THE SURVEY PROVIDES FOR THE RECOVERY OF CODED WIRE TAG INFORMATION AND SCALES FOR AGE CLASS DETERMINATION  ADDITIONALLY, INFORMATION ON COHO SALMON AND STEELHEAD OBSERVED DURING THE COURSE OF THE SURVEY WILL BE DOCUMENTED THE BENEFITS FROM THIS WORK WILL BE  1  ACCOUNTING OF NATURALLY SPAWNING CHINOOK SALMON ABOVE THE TRINITY RIVER CONFLUENCE  2  IMPROVED ACCURACY OF OCEAN STOCK ABUNDANCE ESTIMATES  3  IMPROVED ACCURACY OF PRE SEASON PROJECTIONS FOR THE 2022 HARVEST ALLOCATIONS  4  SYSTEMATIC RECOVERY OF CODED WIRE TAG INFORMATION ON CHINOOK SALMON  5  SCALE SAMPLE INFORMATION FOR AGE COMPOSITION DETERMINATION  AND 6  MAINTENANCE OF LONG TERM TREND DATA SETS FOR MIDDLE KLAMATH TRIBUTARIES

THE DRIFTLESS AREA IS A UNIQUE 24,000 SQUARE MILE NATURAL RESOURCE TREASURE LOCATED IN THE HEART OF THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN  THE STEEP HILLS AND ROCKY BLUFFS OF THE REGION IS HOME TO ONE OF THE COUNTRY S MOST REMARKABLE FRESHWATER RESOURCES   MORE THAN 600 COLD WATER LIMESTONE SPRING FED CREEKS SUPPORT A WORLD CLASS TROUT FISHERY  TROUT UNLIMITED SERVES AS COORDINATOR OF THE DRIFTLESS AREA RESTORATION EFFORT  DARE  PARTNERSHIP  FUNDS AUTHORIZED BY THE AMERICAN CONSERVATION ACT ARE USED TO COORDINATE, COLLABORATE, AND CARRY OUT SUPPORTING ACTIVITIES WITH CONSERVATION PARTNERS THAT HELP REDUCE SEDIMENT AND NUTRIENTS INPUTS TO DRIFTLESS AREA RIVERS AND STREAMS  CONSERVE, RESTORE AND EXPAND HABITATS THAT WILL INCREASE THE NATURAL ABUNDANCE, DIVERSITY, AND HEALTH OF RIVERINE FISHES AND OTHER AQUATIC LIFE  INCREASE THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF ANGLING AND OTHER RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES  AND INCREASE AWARENESS ABOUT DRIFTLESS AREA RESOURCES AND THE IMPORTANCE OF AQUATIC CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION THROUGH OUTREACH AND EDUCATION OVER THE PAST 14 YEARS, TROUT UNLIMITED HAS FOSTERED AND STRENGTHENED RELATIONSHIPS AMONG COUNTY, STATE, FEDERAL TROUT UNLIMITED CHAPTERS, AND ACADEMIA  TROUT UNLIMITED WILL CONTINUE TO BUILD UPON THE CAPACITY OF OUR PARTNERS TO IMPLEMENT IN STREAM AND RIPARIAN RESTORATION PROJECTS  TROUT UNLIMITED WILL  1 ORGANIZE AND HOST FIELD DAYS AND WORKSHOPS ENGAGING LOCAL CONSERVATION OFFICES, VOLUNTEERS, LANDOWNERS AND CONTRACTORS INCREASING THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND ABILITIES TO CARRY OUT HABITAT PROJECTS  2  ORGANIZE AND HOST HANDS OWN REGIONAL WORKSHOPS WHERE CONTRACTORS AND CONSERVATIONISTS CAN VIEW FIRST HAND HOW TO IMPLEMENT CONSTRUCTION OF A STREAM RESTORATION PROJECT  3  PROVIDE FINANCIAL AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO STATE FISH HABITAT CREWS, TU CHAPTERS AND OTHER CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS  4  EDUCATE PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO FARMERS LANDOWNERS ON TARGET STREAMS  5  WORK WITH LANDOWNERS TO ACQUIRE FISHING EASEMENTS WITH STREAM RESTORATION WORK  6 COORDINATE AND HOST THE ANNUAL DRIFTLESS SYMPOSIUM IN WHICH ITS PURPOSE IS TO SHARE THE LATEST IN SCIENCE, RESEARCH, HABIT PROJECTS AND THE MANAGEMENT OF COLD WATER RIPARIAN AREAS ACROSS THE 4 STATE REGION  7  ORGANIZE AND HOST AN ANNUAL BUS TOUR OF RECENTLY COMPLETED STREAM RESTORATION PROJECTS TO DEMONSTRATE SUCCESSES, AND EXPLAIN CHALLENGES AND LESSONS LEARNED TO INTERESTED LANDOWNERS AND CONSERVATION PARTNERS  AND 8  MAINTAIN A DARE WEBSITE, FACEBOOK AND YOUTUBE CHANNEL SHARING THE UNIQUENESS OF THE DRIFTLES AREA, UPCOMING EVENTS, AND CONSERVATION EFFORTS OCCURRING IN THE AREA TO A BROAD PUBLIC AUDIENCE

SALMON RIVER RESTORATION COUNCIL  SRRC  IS CONTINUING TO WORK ON FOSTERING THE VISION, DIRECTION, GOALS, AND OBJECTIVES DEFINED BY THE SALMON RIVER COMMUNITY RESTORATION PROGRAM  CRP   THE CRP ADDRESSES THE NEGATIVE IMPACTS OF PAST CATASTROPHIC FIRES AND FIRE MANAGEMENT, TIMBER HARVEST, ROAD CONSTRUCTION, MINING, GRAZING, FLOODS, RESIDENTIAL AND RECREATIONAL USE, AND THE INHERENT CHALLENGES FACE BY OUR COMMUNITY  THE SRRC IS A CHIEF PROMOTER OF COOPERATIVE ACTIONS WITHIN THE LOCAL COMMUNITY AND AMONG THE STAKEHOLDERS OF THE SALMON RIVER SUB BASIN  STAKEHOLDERS INCLUDE LOCAL RESIDENTS, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, THE KARUK TRIBE OF CALIFORNIA, MANAGING AGENCIES, AND OTHERS  THE CRP HELPS TO FILL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT GAPS THROUGH SMALL AND NON TRADITIONAL PROJECTS  IT INVOLVES COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN AN EDUCATIONAL SERIES OF RESTORATION RELATED WORKSHOPS AND WORKDAYS  IN ADDITION, IT MAINTAINS THE WATERSHED CENTER IN SAWYERS BAR, WHICH PROVIDES WATERSHED PROTECTION AND RESTORATION INFORMATION TO THE COMMUNITY, AGENCIES AND THE PUBLIC, AND PROVIDES A SPACE FOR MEETINGS AND WORKSHOPS

THIS PROPOSAL PREVENTS THE INTRODUCTION OF NEW AIS TO WI THROUGH EARLY DETECTION SURVEYS, NEW PATHWAY INTERVENTION STRATEGIES, AND AIS OUTREACH AND COMMUNICATION  IT CONTAINS THE SPREAD OF AIS IN WI  AND WORKS TO CONTROL EXISTING POPULATIONS OF AIS

THE MIDDLE KLAMATH FALL-RUN CHINOOK SPAWNER ESCAPEMENT AND REDD SURVEY IS A COOPERATIVE EFFORT BY THE US FOREST SERVICE (USFS) KLAMATH AND SIX RIVERS NATIONAL FORESTS, SALMON RIVER RESTORATION COUNCIL (SRRC), QUARTZ VALLEY INDIAN RESERVATION, NORTHERN CALIFORNIA RESOURCE CENTER, MID KLAMATH WATERSHED COUNCIL, SISKIYOU RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICT, KARUK AND YUROK TRIBES, AND CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW). CDFW HAS BEEN CHARGED WITH DETERMINING CHINOOK SPAWNER ESCAPEMENT IN THE KLAMATH RIVER UPSTREAM OF WEITCHPEC SINCE 1978. THE DATA GENERATED BY CDFW HAVE BEEN, AND CONTINUE TO BE, A KEY COMPONENT IN THE MANAGEMENT AND DETERMINATION OF HARVEST LEVELS FOR KLAMATH RIVER CHINOOK SALMON STOCKS. CDFW USES A COMBINATION OF COUNTING WEIRS, SPAWNER CARCASS SURVEYS, REDD SURVEYS, AND HATCHERY RETURNS TO DEVELOP THESE ESTIMATES.THIS ONE-YEAR STUDY WILL DETERMINE IN-RIVER RUN SIZE OF CHINOOK SALMON WITHIN THE SHASTA, SCOTT, AND SALMON RIVER BASINS AND OTHER MAJOR TRIBUTARIES TO THE MIDDLE KLAMATH RIVER DURING THE 2022 FALL SEASON (OCTOBER THROUGH DECEMBER) WITH COOPERATORS HOLDING PLANNING MEETINGS STARTING IN JULY OR AUGUST BEFORE THE SURVEY SEASON.

QUARTZ VALLEY INDIAN RESERVATION S ENVIRONMENTAL PROGRAM HAS BEEN A COOPERATOR TO THE FALL  CHINOOK SPAWNER ESCAPEMENT SURVEYS SINCE 2005  PROGRAM STAFF ANNUALLY CONTRIBUTES TO THE TRAINING AT INDIAN SCOTTY BY LEADING A STATION  A BIOLOGIST AND TECHNICIAN WILL COMPLETE REACHES IN THE SCOTT  RIVER CANYON  FROM THE USGS FLOW GAGE TO PAT FORD CREEK  TWICE A WEEK  SURVEYS BEGIN  APPROXIMATELY IN EARLY OCTOBER AND END AFTER THANKSGIVING, DEPENDING ON THE RUN SIZE AND DURATION

FOR OVER A DECADE, THE MID KLAMATH WATERSHED COUNCIL  MKWC  HAS SUCCESSFULLY IMPLEMENTED ITS PORTION OF THE COOPERATIVE FALL CHINOOK CARCASS SURVEY EFFORT WITH THE USDA FOREST SERVICE, CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AND OTHER PARTNERS TO ACHIEVE PROGRAM OBJECTIVES  THIS INCLUDES 1 DETERMINING IN RIVER RUN SIZE  ESCAPEMENT  OF CHINOOK SALMON WITHIN THE SALMON RIVER AND KLAMATH BASIN 2 DETERMINING RUN TIMING, SPAWNING DISTRIBUTION, LENGTH FREQUENCY, AND SEX RATIO FOR FALL CHINOOK SALMON 3 COLLECTING FISH SCALE, TISSUE, AND OTOLITH SAMPLES, AND RECOVER HEADS FROM ADIPOSE FIN CLIPPED SALMON 4 COLLECTING INCIDENTAL INFORMATION ON COHO SALMON AND STEELHEAD OBSERVED DURING THE COURSE OF THE STUDY 5 CONTRIBUTING TO REDD MAPPING EFFORTS BY ACQUIRING GPS WAYPOINTS AT ALL REDD LOCATIONS ON THE NORTH FORK, SOUTH FORK AND MAINSTEM SALMON RIVER 6 CONTINUING TO PROVIDE TRAINING AND EDUCATION TO VOLUNTEERS AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE THIS EFFORT FOR THE 2022 CHINOOK RUN

THIS PROPOSAL WILL REPLACE THE H 58 ROAD STREAM CROSSING ON THE SUCKER RIVER NEAR GRAND MARAIS, MICHIGAN WITH A FREE SPAN BRIDGE TO RECONNECT 115 MILES OF HABITAT FOR NATIVE BROOK TROUT AND BUILD A SEASONAL SEA LAMPREY BARRIER 20 MILES UPSTREAM OF THE ROAD STREAM CROSSING TO RESTRICT SEA LAMPREY TO THE LOWER RIVER DURING SPAWNING MIGRATION THIS IS A TWO STAGE PROJECT TO IMPROVE STREAM HEALTH AND CONNECTIVITY, AND ADDRESS SEA LAMPREY INFESTATION IN A DIFFICULT TO CONTROL STREAM  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REPLACE THE PERCHED CULVERT AT THE H 58 ROAD CROSSING OVER THE SUCKER RIVER WITH A FREE SPAN BRIDGE AND CONSTRUCT A SEASONAL SEA LAMPREY BARRIER FURTHER UPSTREAM  THE CURRENT CULVERT IS UNDERSIZED AND PERCHED, WHICH AT CERTAIN WATER LEVELS CAN SERVE AS A SEA LAMPREY BARRIER  HOWEVER, IT ALSO REDUCES THE UPSTREAM MOVEMENT OF DESIRABLE SPECIES WITHIN THE WATERSHED  ADDITIONALLY, THE CULVERT IS CAUSING SCOUR OF STREAM BANKS IMMEDIATELY DOWNSTREAM OF THE ROAD CROSSING, WHICH HAS LED TO INCREASED SEDIMENTATION IN THE SYSTEM  REPLACING THE H 58 CULVERT WITH A FREE SPAN BRIDGE AND CONSTRUCTING A SEASONAL SEA LAMPREY BARRIER FURTHER UPSTREAM IN THE WATERSHED WOULD PROVIDE FOR INCREASED MOVEMENT OF NON JUMPING FISH SPECIES FURTHER UPSTREAM AND REDUCE THE STREAM DISTANCE EXPOSED TO LAMPRICIDES USED TO CONTROL INVASIVE SEA LAMPREY, WHILE ALSO ADDRESSING STREAM BANK EROSION

INDIANA S FUNDING NEEDS AND GOALS UNDER THIS GRANT FOCUS STRICTLY ON COORDINATION OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES  AIS  ACTIVITIES BY THE INDIANA AIS COORDINATOR AS WELL AS PROVIDING ADDITIONAL FUNDS SUPPORTING THE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PROGRAM AND OUR ADDITIONAL WORK FOCUSING ON AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANT AND MUSSEL AWARENESS ACTIONS FIRST GOAL IS TO IMPLEMENT THE AIS MANAGEMENT PLAN BY DEVELOPING THE NECESSARY MANAGEMENT TOOLS AND CAPABILITIES TO ADDRESS ALL TYPES OF AIS ISSUES  THROUGH THE FUNDING OF STAFF SPECIFICALLY FOCUSING ON AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES AWARENESS, CONTROL, PREVENTION AND REGIONAL COORDINATION THE SECONDARY GOAL OF THIS FUNDING IS TO FOCUS TIME AND ACTIVITIES ON A COUPLE OF AIS PATHWAYS INCLUDING AN EMPHASIS ON ORGANISMS IN TRADE AND RECREATIONAL BOATING  FUNDING THE IMPLEMENTATION OF EARLY DETECTION EFFORTS AND TO DEVELOP RESPONSE STRATEGIES IS IMPORTANT WHEN WORKING ON FOCUSING OUTREACH AND EDUCATION  IN REGARD TO ALL AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES INCLUDING HIGH PRIORITY AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANTS AND ZEBRA MUSSELS  ZM  THROUGH THE AIS MANAGEMENT PLAN WE ARE GOING TO TARGET BETTER COMMUNICATION STRATEGIES AND COORDINATION AMONG PARTNERS AND THE AGENCY

RESTORING CONNECTIVITY OF THE UPPER JORDAN RIVER AND DEER CREEK  MI  PROJECT ENTAILS THE RESTORATION OF THREE SEVERE ROAD STREAM CROSSING SITES IN THE WATERSHED TO FULLY RECONNECT PRISTINE STRETCHES OF INSTREAM HABITAT FOR ALL AQUATIC LIFE AT ALL LIFE STAGES AND STREAM FLOWS, AND HALT THE EXCESS SEDIMENTATION OF STREAMS FROM RURAL ROADWAYS  THE SITES  WA 3,  WA 5 AND  WI 28 ARE ALL PRIORITIZED IN THE BOYNE AND JORDAN RIVERS ROAD STREAM CROSSING INVENTORY PROJECT REPORT AS PART OF THE GREATER LAKE CHARLEVOIX WATERSHED MANAGEMENT PLAN APPROVED BY THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY  ATTESTING TO ITS HIGH WATER QUALITY AND FORESTED CORRIDOR, THE JORDAN RIVER WAS MICHIGAN S FIRST WATERWAY TO BE OFFICIALLY DESIGNATED AS A WILD AND SCENIC RIVER UNDER THE STATE S NATURAL RIVERS PROGRAM  THE JORDAN RIVER IS 22 9 MILES LONG AND ITS 29 TRIBUTARIES COMPRISE AN ADDITIONAL 90 MILES OF STREAM, WITH DEER CREEK THE SECOND LARGEST TRIBUTARY TO THE JORDAN MAINSTEM  MUCH OF THIS COLDWATER STREAM AND DEER CREEK ARE STATE DESIGNATED AS BLUE RIBBON TROUT STREAM  THE WATERSHED IS COMPRISED OF APPROXIMATELY 127 SQUARE MILES AND THE JORDAN IS THE LARGEST TRIBUTARY TO LAKE CHARLEVOIX THAT CONNECTS TO LAKE MICHIGAN  IT IS HOME TO THE JORDAN RIVER VALLEY AND MANAGEMENT AREA, A 35,000 ACRE AREA OF CONTIGUOUS STATE OWNED FOREST, AND THE JORDAN RIVER PATHWAY, PART OF THE NORTH COUNTRY TRAIL  BROOK TROUT, BROWN TROUT, STEELHEAD, SALMON, MOTTLED SCULPIN AND 14 SPECIES OF MAYFLIES, CADDISFLIES, AND STONEFLIES ARE FOUND IN THE JORDAN MAINSTEMAND TRIBUTARIES THE PROJECT WILL REESTABLISH ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION IN MULTIPLE WAYS THROUGH CONSTRUCTING BANKFULL SPANNING BRIDGES IN PLACE OF CURRENT UNDERSIZED AND OUTDATED CULVERTS AND A BOILERPLATE PIPE, AND INCORPORATION OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR STABILIZATION, RUNOFF CONTROL, FLOODPLAIN AND STREAM RESTORATION AT ALL THREE SITES  COLLECTIVELY THE PROJECT WILL HALT THE INPUT OF 25 TONS OF EXCESS SEDIMENT FROM ROADWAYS ANNUALLY INTO THE STREAMS, REMOVE 5 UNDERSIZED CULVERTS AND REPLACE WITH 3 FULL SPANNING BRIDGE STRUCTURES, RETURN UP TO 1,000 LINEAR FEET OF A FLOODPLAIN BENCH ALONG THE STREAM CHANNEL THAT IS CURRENTLY IMPOUNDED, RECONNECT 7 MILES OF UPSTREAM REACHES TO 16 MILES DOWNSTREAM ON THE JORDAN RIVER, AND RECONNECT 5 1 MILES OF UPSTREAM REACHES TO 4 5 MILES DOWNSTREAM ON DEER CREEK  IN ADDITION,THE INITIATIVE WILL RESTORE HYDROLOGY, NORMAL STREAM VELOCITIES, NATURAL SEDIMENT MOVEMENT, NUTRIENT, AND WOOD TRANSPORT IN THE JORDAN RIVER HEADWATERS AND DEER CREEK AND REDUCE WATER TEMPERATURES ASSOCIATED WITH THE WARMING EFFECTS CAUSED BY IMPOUNDED WATERS AND ACCUMULATION OF EXCESS SEDIMENT FROM ROADBEDS AND SHOULDERS  CONSTRUCTING TIMBER BRIDGES AT ALL SITES WILL ALSO ENSURE SAFE CROSSINGS OVER THE STREAMS FOR THE LOCAL ENTITIES FOR THE PROJECT WITH DESIGN PHASE FUNDS SECURED IN 2020 FROM LOCAL AND PRIVATE FUNDERS  ENGINEERED, STAMPED DESIGN PLANS FOR FULLY SPANNING TIMBER BRIDGES ARE NOW COMPLETE, STATE PERMITS FOR PARTS 31, 301 AND 302 AND NATURAL RIVERS ARE SECURED, AND THE REMAINING FEDERAL PERMITS ARE IN PROCESS  CRA WAS AWARDED A  270,000 GRANT FROM THE NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION SUSTAIN OUR GREAT LAKES PROGRAM IN 2021 FOR THE CONSTRUCTION PHASE INITIATING THE FUNDRAISING EFFORT FOR ON THE GROUND WORK  CRA AND PARTNERS ARE SEEKING REMAINING FUNDS IN 2022 FOR THE  2 2 MILLION IMPLEMENTATION PHASE FROM UP TO 12 STATE, PRIVATE, FEDERAL, LOCAL, AND TRIBAL ENTITIES TO MAKE THIS RESTORATION PROJECT COME TO FRUITION

THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE CONSERVATION, SCIENTIFIC AND OUTREACH OBJECTIVES OF THE ATLANTIC COASTAL FISH HABITAT STRATEGIC PLAN INCLUDING AUGMENTATION OF EXISTING OYSTER REEFS THROUGH SPAT ON SHELL RESTORATION AND OYSTER GARDENING, SANCTUARY SCALE RESTORATION DESIGN AND MONITORING TO ESTABLISH AND QUANTIFY FISH HABITAT BENEFITS OF RESTORED REEFS  BUILDING ON ONGOING PARTNERSHIPS WITH ARUNDEL RIVERS FEDERATION AND SMITHSONIAN ENVIRONMENTAL RESEARCH CENTER, CBF WILL EXECUTE A COMPREHENSIVE LARGE SCALE OYSTER RESTORATION MONITORING PROJECT TO ANALYZE ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION BEFORE AND AFTER OYSTER RESTORATION WITHIN EXISTING SANCTUARIES

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE MONTANA FISH, WILDLIFE AND PARKS  FWP  ABILITY TO PROTECT MONTANA S  WATERS FROM THE IMPACTS OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES  AIS  BY PREVENTING THE SPREAD OF AIS INTO AND THROUGHOUT  THE STATE AND CONTINUING TO DETECT, MONITOR AND ERADICATE AIS.  ACTIVITIES PERFORMED WILL HELP TO RELIABLY DECONTAMINATE HIGH-RISK VESSELS, MAINTAIN AND IMPROVE MONITORING,  EARLY DETECTION AND LAB SAMPLE PROCESSING IN MONTANA. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE 1  MORE  EFFECTIVELY DECONTAMINATE VESSELS THROUGH INSTALLATION OF ON-DEMAND DECONTAMINATION UNITS AT INSPECTION  STATIONS, 2  CONDUCT TRAINING WORKSHOPS AND EQUIP PARTNERS IN AIS EARLY DETECTION SAMPLING, 3  REPLACE AGING  SAMPLING GEAR, 4  MAINTAIN AIS LAB OPERATION THROUGH SUPPLIES, MATERIALS, AND EXPANSION OF SEASONAL  TECHNICIAN WORK SEASON, 5  CONTRACT WITH OUTSIDE LABS TO PROCESS ENVIRONMENTAL DNA SAMPLES AND SERVE AS  BACKUP TO MICROSCOPY SAMPLE PROCESSING, 6  CONTROL AND ERADICATE AIS IN THE STATE WHERE FEASIBLE THROUGH  EFFORTS INCLUDING DELINEATION SURVEYS, PESTICIDE COSTS, BOTTOM BARRIERS AND HABITAT MANIPULATIONS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE IMPROVED EFFICACY IN VESSEL AIS DECONTAMINATION, INCREASED  PARTNERSHIPS WORKING ON AIS ISSUES, INCREASED SAMPLING EFFICACY, REDUCTION IN THE SPREAD OF AIS, INCREASED  EARLY DETECTION SAMPLING, AND OVERALL REDUCTION OR ERADICATION OF NEW AIS INVADERS. THIS WORK WILL PROVIDE  WATERS WITHOUT AIS INVADERS FOR MONTANA S CITIZENS AND VISITORS.

IMPLEMENTATION OF THE TEXAS STATE/INTERSTATE AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN SIANSMP IS AN ONGOING EFFORT DUE TO THE ESTABLISHMENT OF MULTIPLE ANS THAT ARE A SERIOUS PROBLEM IN TEXAS, RECENT INTRODUCTIONS OF OTHER ANS OF CONCERN, SPREAD OF ANS, AND NEED FOR RAPID RESPONSE. THE SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES TO BE COMPLETED UNDER THIS PROJECT ARE 1 REGIONAL AND INTERAGENCY COORDINATION AND INFORMATION GATHERING TO SUPPORT IMPLEMENTATION OF THE TEXAS SIANSMP, 2 ZEBRA/QUAGGA MUSSEL EARLY DETECTION AND POPULATION MONITORING, AND 3 IMPLEMENTATION OF THE TPWD AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES PUBLIC AWARENESS OUTREACH CAMPAIGN.PARTICIPATION IN REGIONAL AND INTERAGENCY COORDINATION ON ANS ISSUES IS ESSENTIAL FOR INFORMING IMPLEMENTATION OF THE TEXAS SIANSMP AND HAS A BROAD GEOGRAPHIC SCOPE THAT INCLUDES THREE REGIONS OF THE ANS TASK FORCE AS DESCRIBED HEREAFTER. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ATTENDANCE OF REGIONAL MEETINGS OF THE TASK FORCE AS WELL AS KEY CONFERENCES. ACHIEVING THIS OBJECTIVE WILL HELP INFORM DISCUSSIONS AT THOSE MEETINGS AS WELL AS INTERAGENCY/REGIONAL MEETINGS/DISCUSSIONS IN TEXAS.ZEBRA/QUAGGA MUSSEL EARLY DETECTION SAMPLING WILL BE CONDUCTED AT NUMEROUS WATER BODIES ACROSS SEVERAL RIVER BASINS IN TEXAS; THE SCOPE OF SAMPLING EFFORTS IS ADAPTIVE IN NATURE AND GUIDED BY SAMPLING GAPS AND NEW DETECTIONS WHEN APPLICABLE. EARLY DETECTION MONITORING FOR ZEBRA MUSSELS REMAINS AN IMPORTANT COMPONENT OF EFFORTS TO PREVENT THEIR SPREAD AND MINIMIZE IMPACTS. EARLY DETECTION HELPS TO GUIDE TARGETED OUTREACH EFFORTS TO PREVENT FURTHER SPREAD, INCLUDING INSTALLATION OF SIGNAGE AT INVADED WATER BODIES. EARLY DETECTION IS ALSO ESSENTIAL FOR MINIMIZING ECONOMIC DAMAGE CAUSED BY ANS BY PROVIDING RIVER AUTHORITIES AND OPERATORS OF FACILITIES THAT USE RAW SURFACE WATER WITH NOTICE OF ZEBRA MUSSEL DETECTION AND THE NEED FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF MITIGATION MEASURES. DUE TO TPWD EFFORTS TO COORDINATE MONITORING STRATEGIES AMONG PARTNERS, OUR CAPACITY TO MONITOR FOR NEW INFESTATIONS HAS SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASED OVER INITIAL EFFORTS. CONTINUED POPULATION MONITORING AT CANYON LAKE WILL ALSO AID IN BETTER UNDERSTANDING THE DYNAMICS OF ZEBRA MUSSELS AT THE SOUTHERN EXTENT OF THEIR RANGE TO LEARN MORE ABOUT INVASION AND IMPACT POTENTIAL. FUNDING FROM THIS GRANT HAS CONTRIBUTED TO SUPPORTING CONTRACTOR TIME, TRAVEL, AND SUPPLIES TO SUPPORT THESE EFFORTS AND FACILITATE EXPANSION OF SAMPLING EFFORTS.PREVENTION IS WIDELY RECOGNIZED AS THE MOST EFFECTIVE STRATEGY FOR MANAGING AQUATIC INVASIONS AND EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PLAY A VITAL ROLE IN PREVENTION. THIS IS ESPECIALLY THE CASE IN TEXAS DUE TO A LACK OF STATUTORY AUTHORITY OR RESOURCES FOR IMPLEMENTING WATERCRAFT INSPECTION AND DECONTAMINATION PROGRAMS TO DIRECTLY PREVENT THE SPREAD OF THE MOST PROBLEMATIC ANS. TEXAS IMPLEMENTS A CUTTING-EDGE OUTREACH CAMPAIGN EACH YEAR TO SEEK TO ENCOURAGE ANS PREVENTION BEHAVIORS, LEVERAGING STATE, PARTNER, AND FEDERAL FUNDS FOR MAXIMUM REACH. THIS YEAR, WE WILL ALSO SEEK TO DISTRIBUTE A NEW ZEBRA MUSSEL OUTREACH BOOK TO LIBRARIES AS A NOVEL OUTREACH TOOL FOR INCREASING AWARENESS.

SOME OF KANSAS S AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS HAVE ALREADY BEEN INVADED AND NEGATIVELY IMPACTED BY ANS SUCH AS ZEBRA MUSSELS, SILVER AND BIGHEAD CARP, WHITE PERCH, EURASIAN WATERMILFOIL, HYDRILLA, SALT CEDAR, AND RUSTY CRAYFISH THESE AND OTHER ANS POSE A SERIOUS THREAT TO MANY OTHER KANSAS WATERBODIES AND THOSE OF SURROUNDING STATES  IN MAY 2005, THE ANSTF AND GOVERNOR APPROVED KANSAS AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES  ANS  MANAGEMENT PLAN WAS COMPLETED  THE GOALS OF THE KANSAS ANS MANAGEMENT PLAN ARE 1  TO PREVENT NEW INTRODUCTIONS OF ANS TO KANSAS 2  TO PREVENT DISPERSAL OF ESTABLISHED POPULATIONS OF ANS INTO UNINFESTED WATERS  3  TO ERADICATE OR CONTROL TO MINIMIZE THE ADVERSE ECOLOGICAL, ECONOMIC, SOCIAL, AND PUBLIC HEALTH EFFECTS O ANS IN AN ENVIRONMENTALLY SOUND MANNER  4  TO EDUCATE ALL AQUATIC USERS OF ANS RISKS AND HOW TO REDUCE THE HARMFUL IMPACTS  5  TO SUPPORT RESEARCH ON ANS IN KANSAS AND DEVELOP SYSTEMS TO DISSEMINATE INFORMATION  FUNDING PROVIDED BY THIS OPPORTUNITY WILL BE USED TO MEET THESE GOALS  KANSAS IS COMMITTED TO ADDRESSING THEINVASIVE SPECIES PROBLEM  WITH THE SUPPORT OF THIS GRANT, WE MOVE CLOSER TO ACHIEVING THE GOALS OUTLINED IN THE KANSAS ANS MANAGEMENT PLAN

INVASIVE CARP CONTINUE TO INCREASE IN ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION UPSTREAM OF LOCK AND DAM  LD  19 IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER  UMR  AND SPREAD THROUGHOUT TRIBUTARIES OF THE UMR AND MISSOURI RIVER BASINS  INFORMATION ABOUT IF INVASIVE CARP SPREADING INTO TRIBUTARIES AND EXPANDING NORTH IN THE UMR ARE INDIVIDUALS MIGRATING FROM OTHER LOCATIONS OR ARE THE RESULT OF SUCCESSFUL REPRODUCTION IS NEEDED TO BETTER MANAGE THESE INVADERS  OUR FIRST OBJECTIVE IS TO ASSESS RECRUITMENT OF INVASIVE CARP ABOVE LD19 IN THE UMR TO DETERMINE IF, WHEN, AND UNDER WHAT CONDITIONS REPRODUCTION AND RECRUITMENT IS SUCCESSFUL NEAR THIS INVASION FRONT  TO ACHIEVE THIS OBJECTIVE, WE WILL COLLECT INVASIVE CARP ABOVE LD19 AND CONDUCT OTOLITH MICROCHEMISTRY THAT WILL TELL US GENERAL HATCHING LOCATIONS OF THESE FISH AS WELL AS THE YEAR THEY WERE BORN  OUR SECOND OBJECTIVE IS TO DETERMINE IF THERE ARE RESIDENT INVASIVE CARP THAT REMAIN IN TRIBUTARIES THROUGHOUT THE YEAR OR IF THEY ARE MIGRANTS THAT MOVE IN AND OUT OF TRIBUTARIES AND INTO THE UMR AND MISSOURI RIVER ON A REGULAR BASIS  TO ACCOMPLISH THIS OBJECTIVE, WE WILL CONDUCT ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY OF INVASIVE CARP IN FOUR TRIBUTARIES OF THE UMR AND MISSOURI RIVER  WE WILL ALSO BE ABLE TO ASSESS HOW MANY INVASIVE CARP ARE NEAR AN ELECTRIC BARRIER THAT PREVENTS THEIR MOVEMENTS FURTHER UPSTREAM, WHEN THEY ARE THERE, AND UNDER WHAT CONDITIONS  WE WILL DELIVER A TECHNICAL REPORT DOCUMENTING WORK COMPLETED, RESULTS, AND IMPLICATIONS FROM THIS WORK THAT WILL BENEFIT STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES MANAGING INVASIVE CARP IN THE UMR AND MISSOURI RIVER BASINS

MINNESOTA DNR AND PARTNERS CONTINUE ADAPTIVE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF A COMPREHENSIVE EARLY DETECTION AND RESPONSE PROGRAM FOR BIGHEAD, SILVER, GRASS, AND BLACK CARPS IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN  THIS EARLY DETECTION PROGRAM HELPS DEFINE THE CURRENT PRESENCE, INVASION, AND ESTABLISHED FRONTS AND EVALUATE HOW THESE FRONTS CHANGE THROUGH TIME, IMPORTANT KNOWLEDGE FOR MANAGEMENT DECISIONS  ADDITIONALLY, THIS EFFORT HELPS EVALUATE THE EFFECTS OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS SUCH AS COMMERCIAL HARVEST  SAMPLING USES A DIVERSE ARRAY OF TRADITIONAL AND NOVEL GEARS TO SAMPLE ALL POTENTIAL LIFE STAGES IN TARGETED AREAS  TAGGING AND TRACKING ADULT INVASIVE CARP REVEALS MOVEMENT PATTERNS AND HAS AIDED IN THE CAPTURE OF MULTIPLE INVASIVE CARP  RESPONDING TO INVASIVE CARP CAPTURES HAS ALSO BEEN PART OF THE PROGRAM BUT HAS TAKEN ON AN INCREASED SIGNIFICANCE SINCE CAPTURES BEGAN TO INCREASE IN 2020  NOW, MINNESOTA DNR IS PARTNERING WITH WISCONSIN DNR, USGS, USFWS, AND NPS TO IMPLEMENT MODIFIED UNIFIED METHOD  MUM  EVENTS, AND TO TEST NOVEL METHODS THAT ENHANCE OUR ABILITY TO CAPTURE INVASIVE CARP  INCREASED COMMERCIAL FISHING WILL ALSO BE UTILIZED TO REMOVE INVASIVE CARP FROM THE SYSTEM TO REDUCE RISK OF SPAWNING IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER  FINAL SAMPLING REPORTS WILL BE AVAILABLE AT THE CONCLUSION OF THIS PROJECT, AS WELL AS DATA FROM INVASIVE CARP CAPTURES

ILLINOIS WILL SUBGRANT TO ILLINOIS NATURAL HISTORY SURVEY TO CONDUCT MONITORING AND TARGETED REMOVAL OF INVASIVE CARP IN THE ILLINOIS PORTION OF THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER  THE TARGETED REMOVAL OF 200,000 300,000 LBS OF INVASIVE CARP ANNUALLY WILL HELP REDUCE THEIR ECOLOGICAL IMPACT, SLOW THEIR SPREAD AND ESTABLISHMENT IN THE UMR ABOVE LD19 AND DECREASE THEIR EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZE  TOTAL COUNTS AND BIOMASS WILL BE RECORDED FROM ALL LOCATIONS AND FISH WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR FURTHER SCIENTIFIC INQUIRY  TO MONITOR FOR REPRODUCTION LARVAL LIGHT TRAPS WILL BE DEPLOYED IN BACKWATERS OF POOL 19  MONITORING INVASIVE CARP REPRODUCTION AND THE DETECTION OF LARVAL CARP WILL BE IMPERATIVE FOR INFORMING THE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN THE UMR ABOVE LD19  WE PROPOSE TO CONTINUE TO EVALUATE THE PASSAGE OF BIGMOUTH BUFFALO, PADDLEFISH, AND INVASIVE CARP THROUGH LOCK AND DAMS 14 AND 15, WHICH ARE ALL HIGHLY MOBILE AND MIGRATORY FISH SPECIES THAT OFTEN EXPERIENCE HABITAT OVERLAP IN THE UMR THROUGH THE USE OF HYDROACOUSTICS  MONITORING OF EXISTING BIGMOUTH BUFFALO, PADDLEFISH, AND INVASIVE CARP TO ASSESS FISH PASSAGE AT LOCK AND DAMS 14 AND 15 WILL SERVE A DUAL PURPOSE  FIRST, PRE DETERRENT DATA WILL INFORM THE PARTNERSHIP TO THE FREQUENCY THAT NATIVE FISH ARE ABLE TO MAKE SUCCESSFUL PASSAGE AND IDENTIFY THE ABIOTIC AND BIOTIC FACTORS THAT CONTRIBUTE OR HINDER SUCCESSFUL PASSAGE  SECONDLY, GIVEN THE LONG BATTERY LIFE  5  YEARS  OF THESE TAGS AND THE POTENTIAL ADDITION OF TAGS IN THE FUTURE, THESE FISH AND SUPPORT NETWORK CAN POTENTIALLY ALSO BE USED TO EVALUATE THE EFFECT DETERRENTS HAVE ON NATIVE FISH PASSAGE
