THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO FULLY IMPLEMENT THE NEBRASKA AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES (ANS) MANAGEMENT PLAN AND PREVENT THE SPREAD OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES IN THE STATE AND TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE THE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PRESENT WITHIN ITS BORDERS. THE THREE MAIN OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROPOSAL ARE TO 1) PREVENT THE SPREAD OF ZEBRA MUSSELS IN NEBRASKA BY INSPECTING GREATER THAN 5,000 WATERCRAFT DURING THE GRANT PERIOD, 2) SURVEY AT LEAST 30 WATERBODIES FOR THE DETECTION OF INVASIVE AQUATIC PLANT SPECIES AND 3) CONDUCT EARLY DETECTION OF ZEBRA MUSSEL INFESTATIONS BY SURVEYING GREATER THAN 40 LAKES MONTHLY DURING THE FIELD SEASON FOR VELIGERS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE A REDUCTION OF THE SPREAD OF AQUATIC INVASIVES AND INCREASED PUBLIC EDUCATION. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE CITIZENS OF NEBRASKA AND GENERAL PUBLIC.

GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF PROPOSED PROJECT ARE TO INCREASE RESILIENCY IN PRIORITY NATIVE BROOK TROUT HEADWATER STREAM BY IMPROVING NATURAL STREAM HYDROLOGY, FLOW CONVEYANCE, PASSAGE OF BROOK TROUT AND OTHER AQUATIC ORGANISMS UNDER ALL STREAM FLOWS, AND PROVIDING A SAFER ROAD CROSSING FOR VEHICLE TRAFFIC  TO MEET OBJECTIVES, BUFFALO COUNTY AND TOWNSHIP OF MONTANA ARE PROPOSING TO REMOVE TWO UNDERSIZED PIPE CULVERTS AND REPLACE THEM WITH A BRIDGE THAT SPANS DANUSER CREEK  REPLACEMENT OF CULVERTS WITH A BRIDGE WILL RECONNECT 4 1 MILES OF STREAM FOR NATIVE BROOK TROUT AND SCULPIN  IMPROVED HYDROLOGY AND UNINTERRUPTED FLOW ON THIS STATE DESIGNATED RESERVE STREAM WILL ALLOW BROOK TROUT TO FREELY MOVE TO SPAWNING, REARING, AND OVERWINTERING HABITAT  REDUCTION IN STREAMBANK EROSION FROM CULVERTS AND IMPROVED SEDIMENT TRANSPORT WILL RESTORE NATURAL SUBSTRATE FOR TROUT SPAWNING AND RECOLONIZATION OF INVERTEBRATES THAT FISH AND OTHER ORGANISM FEED UPON  THE BRIDGE WILL ALSO BENEFIT THE LOCAL COMMUNITY, REDUCING FLOODING EVENTS THAT IMPACT THE PRODUCTIVITY OF CROP FIELDS AND A LOW MAINTENANCE CROSSING THAT IS MUCH SAFER FOR LOCAL MOTORISTS AND USE BY HEAVY FARMING EQUIPMENT

THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  SERVICE , ON BEHALF OF THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR, WAS DIRECTED BY CONGRESS TO UNDERTAKE ADDITIONAL ACTIVITIES IN FY 1990 IN SUPPORT OF THE PACIFIC SALMON TREATY  P L  99 5   THE FUNDING PROVIDES SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE OF THE PACIFIC STATES MARINE FISHERIES COMMISSION S REGIONAL MARK PROCESSING CENTER  RMPC   THE RMPC HAS SERVED STATE, FEDERAL, TRIBAL, AND PRIVATE FISHERIES AGENCIES OF THE ENTIRE PACIFIC COAST FOR YEARS BY PROCESSING AND EXCHANGING CODED WIRE TAG  CWT  RELEASE, RECOVERY, AND ASSOCIATED CATCH AND SAMPLING INFORMATION  THE RMPC HAS ADOPTED NEW DATA FORMATS, AND HAS IMPLEMENTED SOFTWARE, HARDWARE AND PERSONNEL ENHANCEMENTS, IN ORDER TO MEET EVOLVING CWT DATA INFORMATIONAL NEEDS BY THE PACIFIC SALMON COMMISSION AND OTHER AGENCIES  AGENCY CONTRIBUTIONS AND THE PACIFIC STATES MARINE FISHERIES COMMISSION  PSMFC  PROVIDE THESE ENHANCEMENT FUNDS JOINTLY  THE PACIFIC STATES MARINE FISHERIES COMMISSION OPERATES THE REGIONAL MARK PROCESSING CENTER  THE RMPC PROVIDES ESSENTIAL SERVICES TO INTERNATIONAL, STATE, FEDERAL, AND TRIBAL FISHERIES ORGANIZATIONS INVOLVED IN TAGGING AND MARKING ANADROMOUS SALMONIDS THROUGHOUT THE PACIFIC REGION  THESE SERVICES INCLUDE REGIONAL COORDINATION OF TAGGING AND FIN MARKING PROGRAMS, MAINTENANCE OF DATABASES FOR CODED WIRE TAG RELEASES, RECOVERIES, LOCATIONS, AND CATCH AND  EFFORT DATA, AS WELL AS THE DISSEMINATION OF REPORTS OF THESE DATA IN ELECTRONIC OR PRINTED FORM WHEN REQUESTED

REQUESTED FUNDING FY 2022, WILL BE USED TO IMPLEMENT THE OBJECTIVES OUTLINED IN THE APPROVED WYOMING AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PLAN. CANAAN VALLEY INSTITUTE IS RESPECTFULLY REQUESTING  135,000 TO SUPPORT COORDINATION AND MANAGEMENT OF THE EASTERN BROOK TROUT JOINT VENTURE  EBTJV , WHICH INCLUDES  85,000 FOR BASE OPERATIONAL SUPPORT AND  50,000 FOR AN EDUCATIONAL MINI GRANT PROGRAM  THE EASTERN BROOK TROUT JOINT VENTURE  EBTJV  HAS DEVELOPED A ROADMAP FOR WILD BROOK TROUT CONSERVATION GROUNDED IN SCIENCE AND GUIDED BY ITS MISSION TO FACILITATE INTEGRATED APPROACHES TO CONSERVING HEALTHY COLDWATER AQUATIC RESOURCES AND FISHABLE WILD BROOK TROUT POPULATIONS  THE EBTJV COORDINATOR SUPPORTS THE GOALS AND OUTCOMES OF THE EBTJV  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE THE COORDINATION OF EBTJV TO ADVANCE ITS MISSION AND TO RECRUIT ON THE GROUND CONSERVATION PROJECTS  ANOTHER GOAL IS TO COORDINATE A MINI GRANT PROGRAM TO TRAIN AND EDUCATE INDIVIDUALS  PROFESSIONALS OR MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC  ON TOPICS RELATED TO COLD WATER AND BROOK TROUT STEWARDSHIP, PARTICULARLY ACTIONS THAT CAN BE TAKEN TO CONSERVE BROOK TROUT

THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT PERSONNEL SALARY AND PARTNER TRAVEL TO ALLOW THE ATLANTIC COASTAL FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP (ACFHP OR PARTNERSHIP) TO CARRY OUT ITS MISSION, GOALS, AND OBJECTIVES AS STATED IN ITS STRATEGIC AND ACTION PLANS (NOTE: NEW PLANS FOR 2022-2026 ARE IN DEVELOPMENT AND WILL BE RELEASED IN CALENDAR YEAR 2022). ACFHP HOLDS SPRING AND FALL MEETINGS OF ITS STEERING COMMITTEE, WITH THE SPRING MEETING TO BE SUPPORTED FROM THE GRANT. AN ACFHP SCIENCE AND DATA COMMITTEE MEETING WILL ALSO BE SUPPORTED. GRANT FUNDS WILL ALSO BE USED TO PROVIDE PARTIAL SALARY AND FRINGE SUPPORT FOR THE ACFHP COORDINATOR, WHO RUNS THE PARTNERSHIP ON A DAY-TO-DAY BASIS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING AGENDAS AND MATERIALS FOR MEETINGS, LEADING HABITAT SCIENCE AND ASSESSMENT PROJECTS, ORGANIZING AND PARTICIPATING IN ACFHP AND OTHER FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP WEBINARS AND CALLS, AND OUTREACH AND COMMUNICATIONS INITIATIVES. THE PARTNERSHIP WILL WORK ON FINALIZING ITS NEW FIVE-YEAR STRATEGIC AND ACTION PLANS, AND WILL INCORPORATE RECOMMENDATIONS FROM THE DEVELOPMENT STRATEGY COMPLETED IN 2021 IN ORDER TO EXPAND OUR FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES FROM FOR-PROFIT COMPANIES AND FOUNDATIONS. ACFHP IS WORKING CLOSELY WITH THE NATIONAL FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP (NFHP) BOARD AND STAFF AND TO CLOSELY ALIGN OUR GOALS AND OBJECTIVES WITH THOSE ON THE NATIONAL LEVEL. THIS IS THE NINTH YEAR ACFHP IS REQUESTING NFHP FUNDING FOR OPERATIONAL SUPPORT, AND HAS DEMONSTRATED SUCCESS EACH YEAR VIA SECTION 1 OF ITS ANNUAL REPORT TO NFHP (AND PREVIOUSLY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE).ACFHP'S OVERARCHING MISSION IS TO ACCELERATE THE CONSERVATION, PROTECTION, RESTORATION, AND ENHANCEMENT OF HABITAT FOR NATIVE ATLANTIC COASTAL, ESTUARINE-DEPENDENT, AND DIADROMOUS FISHES THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN FEDERAL, TRIBAL, STATE, LOCAL, AND OTHER ENTITIES. OPERATIONAL FUNDING WILL SUPPORT ACFHP, THROUGH PARTIAL FUNDING OF THE COORDINATOR AS WELL AS COMMITTEE MEETINGS, TO FINALIZE AND CARRY OUT THE NEW STRATEGIC AND ACTION PLANS. THE OBJECTIVES WITHIN THE PLANS WILL BE FINALIZED AT ACFHP'S STEERING COMMITTEE MEETING ON JULY 20-21, 2022 IN ARLINGTON, VA, AND ACTIONS WILL BE TAKEN BY THE ACFHP COORDINATOR, COMMITTEES, AND OUR PARTNERS TO CARRY MEET THE OBJECTIVES OVER THE NEXT FIVE YEARS.ACFHP CAN ONLY FUNCTION WITH OPERATIONAL SUPPORT, AND IT RELIES ON THIS SUPPORT FROM NFHP TO CARRY OUT THE MISSION AND VISION OF THE PARTNERSHIP. BENEFITS INCLUDE A STREAMLINED TRANSITION IN OPERATIONS FROM ITS PREVIOUS PLAN AND CONTINUED SUPPORT TO OUR PARTNERS WORKING ON-THE- GROUND. THIS SUPPORT COME VIA FUNDING, ENDORSEMENT, AND OUTREACH AND SCIENCE PRODUCTS. THE OUTCOME WILL BE IMPROVED FISH HABITAT ALONG THE ATLANTIC COAST. PROJECT SUCCESS IS MONITORED AND EVALUATED THROUGH ITS ANNUAL REPORT TO THE NFHP BOARD. IN THE ANNUAL REPORT, SECTION 1 CONTAINS JUSTIFICATION FOR CONTINUED OPERATIONAL SUPPORT, BASED ON THE PREVIOUS THREE YEARS OF ACCOMPLISHMENTS. ACFHP HAS BEEN REQUESTING OPERATIONAL SUPPORT EVERY YEAR SINCE FY14, AND HAS BEEN SUCCESSFUL EACH YEAR.

THE PROJECT OBJECTIVE IS TO CONSTRUCT A POOL AND WEIR FISHWAY AT THE CROOKED BROOK DAM ON BASKAHEGAN STREAM IN THE TOWN OF DANFORTH, MAINE  A SECONDARY OBJECTIVE IS TO IMPROVE PUBLIC ACCESS AND RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE LOCAL COMMUNITY AT THE SITE AND TO MAINTAIN THE 20 YEAR MOMENTUM TO REBUILD SEA RUN FISHERIES THROUGHOUT THEIR HISTORIC RANGE IN THE PENOBSCOT WATERSHED  THIS PROJECT CONTINUES SEVERAL DECADES OF FISHERIES RESTORATION WORK IN THE PENOBSCOT RIVER AND IS THE MOST SIGNIFICANT HABITAT CONNECTIVITY PROJECT UNDERTAKEN TO DATE IN THE UPPER WATERSHED  THE FISHWAY WILL RECONNECT 137 STREAM MILES AND 8,960 ACRES OF POND AND LAKE HABITAT FOR ATLANTIC SALMON, RIVER HERRING, SEA LAMPREY, AMERICAN EEL, AND BROOK TROUT  GIVEN THE VAST AMOUNT OF HABITAT THAT WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE, IT IS ESTIMATED THAT A RUN OF UP TO 2 MILLION ADULT RIVER HERRING WILL BE PRODUCED ANNUALLY AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT  IN ADDITION, ENDANGERED ATLANTIC SALMON WILL GAIN ACCESS TO AN ESTIMATED 557 REARING UNITS  1 UNIT  100M2  OF HABITAT ABOVE THE DAM  AMERICAN EEL WILL GET IMPROVED ACCESS TO A HUGE AREA OF REARING HABITAT  ATLANTIC SALMON FEDERATION PROJECT OFFICER WILL BE MARANDA NEMETH AND PROJECT CONSTRUCTION IS EXPECTED TO OCCUR BETWEEN JULY 15 AND SEPT 30, 2023  ALL FEDERAL PERMITS HAVE BEEN COMPLETED OBTAINED

THE ALBRIGHT POWER STATION DAM REMOVAL PROJECT ON THE CHEAT RIVER WILL IMPROVE WATERSHED CONNECTIVITY, WATER QUALITY, SENSITIVE SPECIES POPULATION HEALTH, AND FLOOD AND CLIMATE RESILIENCY FOR THE CHEAT RIVER AND ITS COMMUNITIES THROUGH THE REMOVAL OF AN OBSOLETE LOWHEAD DAM  THE PROJECT WILL RECONNECT 75 MILES OF MAINSTEM HABITAT AND HUNDREDS OF MILES OF TRIBUTARY RIVERS AND STREAMS FOR SENSITIVE SPECIES, SUCH AS EASTERN HELLBENDER, FRESHWATER MUSSELS, WALLEYE, AND BROOK TROUT  CURRENTLY, THE ALBRIGHT POWER STATION DAM BLOCKS NATIVE WALLEYE FROM RECOLONIZING THE CHEAT RIVER AFTER DECADES LONG POLLUTION CLEANUP EFFORTS HAVE RESULTED IN THE RESTORATION OF THEIR POPULATION IN CHEAT LAKE  THE DAM ALSO BLOCKS MAINSTEM CONNECTION BETWEEN LOCAL BROOK TROUT STREAMS UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE DAM  EASTERN HELLBENDER HAVE BEEN DETECTED UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE DAM, ISOLATING POPULATIONS FROM ONE ANOTHER  FRIENDS OF THE CHEAT IS PURSUING REINTRODUCTION EFFORTS FOR NATIVE FRESHWATER MUSSELS IN THE CHEAT RIVER, OF WHICH THE DAM WOULD IMPEDE THEIR SUCCESS  ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT WILL OPEN 6 MILES OF RIVER TO FLATWATER PADDLING OPPORTUNITIES, PREVIOUSLY INACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC, AND WILL ESTABLISH A NEW PUBLIC RIVER ACCESS POINT  THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE LOCAL COMMUNITIES IN PRESTON AND TUCKER COUNTIES, OF WHICH THE CHEAT RIVER FLOWS THROUGH  NEW OPPORTUNITIES FOR THESE COMMUNITIES INCLUDE INCREASED FISHING OPPORTUNITIES, ONE DAY OR MULTI DAY PADDLING TRIPS, AND NEW OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES TO OFFER RECREATION BASED TOURISM SERVICES  FOOD, LODGING, FISHING AND  BOATING SUPPLIES, ETC   ADDITIONALLY, REMOVING THE ALBRIGHT POWER STATION DAM WILL REDUCE THE RISK OF INFRASTRUCTURE FAILURE IN ALBRIGHT, WV, AS THE STRUCTURE IS OVER 70 YEARS OLD AND NO LONGER SERVES A PURPOSE  SPECIFICALLY, THE GOALS OF THE PROJECT ARE TO COMPLETE DESIGN AND PERMITTING FOR THE REMOVAL OF THE ALBRIGHT POWER STATION DAM AND REMOVE THE DAM AND RESTORE THE ADJACENT RIVER REACH  THE DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES CAN BE DESCRIBED AS THE FOLLOWING  1 AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE BARRIER RECTIFIED, 75 MILES OF RIVER RECONNECTED, 1 25 MILES OF IN STREAM HABITAT RESTORED, AND 7 MILES OF RIVER OPENED FOR PUBLIC ACCESS  FUNDS FOR THIS PROJECT   75,000 OF  585,700 TOTAL NEEDED TO COMPLETE ENGINEERING AND PROVIDE CONSTRUCTION OVERSIGHT  WILL BE USED TO ADVANCE FINAL DESIGN OF THE PROJECT

THIS PROJECT IS TO REMOVE THE CHAPEZE LOW HEAD DAM, LOCATED ON LONG LICK CREEK  ALSO KNOWN AS LONG LICK RUN   THE DAM IS AN OBSOLETE ROCK PILE DAM WITH A CONCRETE CAP AND SHEET PILING UPSTREAM FACE  THE DAM S PRIOR USE WAS FOR INDUSTRIAL WATER SUPPLY  THE UPSTREAM IMPOUNDMENT STRETCHES APPROXIMATELY 3 4 MILES  THE DAM IS IN POOR CONDITION, IS A SIGNIFICANT IMPEDIMENT TO FISH PASSAGE, AND THE UPSTREAM IMPOUNDED WATER IS PRONE TO ALGAL BLOOMS IS OF POOR WATER QUALITY  THE DAM S OWNER, JIM BEAM, SUPPORTS REMOVAL OF THIS STRUCTURE

AWARD PURPOSE  COLLECT SPAWNING INFORMATION ON COHO AND FALL CHINOOK SALMON WITHIN THE CHEHALIS RIVER SYSTEM THAT, WHEN COMBINED WITH THE INFORMATION COLLECTED BY WDFW, IS SUFFICIENT TO ESTIMATE THE ANNUAL SPAWNING ESCAPEMENT OF BOTH SPECIES ACTIVITIES  ANNUAL SURVEYS OF SPAWNING POPULATIONS OF COHO AND FALL CHINOOK SALMON IN THE CHEHALIS RIVER BASIN AS PART OF A LONG TERM HABITAT MONITORING PROJECT WITH US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND  WILDLIFE DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  DATA COLLECTED THROUGH THIS PROJECT HELP MANAGE THE RESOURCES WITH RELIABLE INFORMATION, AND A HIGH DEGREE OF CONFIDENCE  THE DATA REDUCE UNCERTAINTY IN MANAGEMENT MODELS AND DECISIONS, AND THEREBY CONTROL RISK TO PRODUCTIVITY OF THE SALMON STOCKS BENEFITS  CHEHALIS RIVER BASIN SALMONID SPECIES AND RECREATIONAL AND COMMERCIAL FISHERIES

THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE AND EXPAND AN ONGOING SURVEILLANCE EFFORT FOR INVASIVE CARP IN THE LOWER RED RIVER BASIN THAT WILL INCLUDE THE RED RIVER AND MAJOR TRIBUTARIES THEREOF IN TEXAS OKLAHOMA AND ARKANSAS THE PROJECT WILL ALSO ESTABLISH BASELINE DATA FOR NATIVE FISH ASSEMBLAGES POTENTIALLY IMPACTED BY INVASIVE CARP NEEDED FOR FUTURE EVALUATIONS OF DELETERIOUS IMPACTS THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE GENERAL LACK OF KNOWLEDGE OF INVASIVE CARP POPULATION DYNAMICS AND NATIVE FISH ASSEMBLAGES IN THIS SUBBASIN THE INTENTIONS OF THIS EFFORT ARE TO AID IN EARLY DETECTION ASSESS POPULATION DISTRIBUTION AND STATUS AND FACILITATE FUTURE EVALUATIONS OF DELETERIOUS IMPACTS TO NATIVE FISHES DATA ON INVASIVE CARP POPULATIONS WOULD ALSO INFORM POTENTIAL MANAGEMENT ACTIONS COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS OF MULTIPLE PARTNERS AND AGENCIES STATE FEDERAL AND UNIVERSITY WILL BE IMPLEMENTED TO ACCOMPLISH THE PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT AN ONGOING COORDINATED EFFORT TO EVALUATE INVASIVE CARP DISTRIBUTION AND STATUS IN THE LOWER RED RIVER BASIN THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE STATUS OF THESE SPECIES IN THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER BASIN AS A WHOLE

AS DESCRIBED IN OUR NATIONAL FISH HABITAT ACTION PLAN- EASTERN BROOK TROUT JOINT VENTURE PROPOSAL AND U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT SECTION 7 BIOLOGICAL OPINION 05E1ME00-2021-F-1078, PROJECT SHARE WILL USE HEAVY MACHINERY TO ADD WOOD AND BOULDER COMPLEXITY STRUCTURES TO A 0.4-MILE REACH OF THE MAINSTEM NARRAGUAGUS ABOVE BEDDINGTON LAKE. THE PROJECT (AND STRUCTURES) WAS DESIGNED USING A COMBINATION OF HIGH-RESOLUTION ORTHOPHOTOS (INCLUDING LIDAR (LIGHT DETECTION AND RANGING)), TOTAL STATION SURVEYS AND HYDROLOGIC MODELING UNDER THE GUIDANCE-APPROVAL OF TECHNICAL EXPERTS AT THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE. THE PROJECT IS LOCATED WITHIN DESIGNATED CRITICAL HABITAT FOR FEDERALLY LISTED ATLANTIC SALMON AND A BIOLOGICAL OPINION WAS REQUIRED TO ADDRESS IMPACTS TO THIS ENDANGERED SPECIES. WE EXPECT THIS STREAM RESTORATION PROJECT WILL BE COMPLETED BETWEEN AUGUST 15 AND SEPT. 30TH, 2022. THE MAIN OBJECTIVES ARE TO PROVIDE INCREASED QUALITY HABITAT AND FLOW DIVERSITY FOR NATIVE SALMONID SPECIES SUCH AS BROOK TROUT AND ATLANTIC SALMON. PRIMARY CONTACT FOR THIS AGREEMENT IS CHRISTOPHER FEDERICO- EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR PROJECT SHARE.

THE AMES POND DAM REMOVAL PROJECT IS PART OF THE OVERALL EFFORT TO RESTORE ANADROMOUS FISH PASSAGE IN THE FORE RIVER WATERSHED. THE PROJECT WILL REMOVE IMPEDIMENTS TO FISH PASSAGE ON THE MONATIQUOT RIVER IN BRAINTREE.STATEMENT OF NEED: THE AMES POND DAM REMOVAL PROJECT IS NECESSARY BECAUSE THE DAM IS AN IMPEDIMENT TO ANADROMOUS FISH PASSAGE ON THE MONATIQUOT RIVER IN BRAINTREE. EACH SPRING RIVER HERRING ARE VISUALLY OBSERVED AT THE DOWNSTREAM PROJECT LIMIT, BUT THE DAM PREVENTS THEM FROM ACCESSING THE PRIMARY SPAWNING HABITAT AT THE GREAT POND RESERVOIR. BY TAKING NO ACTION, DIADROMOUS FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC SPECIES WILL CONTINUE TO BE IMPACTED BY THE DAM. THE AMES POND DAM REMOVAL IS PART OF AN OVERALL EFFORT TO RESTORE THE MONATIQUOT RIVER FOR MIGRATORY FISH PASSAGE AND CLIMATE RESILIENCY.PURPOSE: THE AMES DAM REMOVAL PROJECT AIMS TO INCREASE RIVER HERRING (ALOSA PSEUDOHARENGUS & ALOSA AESTIVALIS), AMERICAN EEL (ANGUILLA ROSTRATA), AND SEA LAMPREY (PETROMYZON MARINUS) POPULATIONS IN THE WEYMOUTH-FORE RIVER AND MONATIQUOT RIVER WATERSHEDS.OBJECTIVES: THE PRIMARY PROJECT OBJECTIVE IS TO IMPLEMENT THE REMOVAL OF THE AMES POND DAM AND FOSTER DIADROMOUS FISH RECOVERY IN THE MONATIQUOT/FORE RIVER SYSTEM. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE DAM DEMOLITION AND BANK STABILIZATION. THE DAM NO LONGER IMPOUNDS WATER BUT IT SERVES AS AN IMPEDIMENT TO DIADROMOUS FISH.METHODS/APPROACH: THE AMES POND DAM REMOVAL PROJECT HAS BEEN IN DEVELOPMENT SINCE THE MID-2000S. PROJECT DESIGNS AND SPECIFICATIONS HAVE BEEN PREPARED BY SLR CONSULTING (FORMERLY MILONE & MACBROOM, INC.), A TOP DAM REMOVAL CONSULTING FIRM IN THE REGION. FINAL DESIGNS ARE COMPLETE AND MOST PERMITS REQUIRED FOR THE PROJECT HAVE BEEN SECURED. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH THE REMOVAL OF THE FULL REMOVAL OF THE REMAINING CONCRETE DAM. DELIVERABLES TO BE PROVIDED INCLUDE: - PHOTOGRAPHIC SITE DOCUMENTATION BEFORE AND AFTER DAM REMOVAL. - AS-BUILT / RECORD PLANS DEMONSTRATING DAM REMOVAL AND FINAL SITE CONDITIONS.TIMETABLE OR MILESTONES: A CONSTRUCTION BID READY PACKAGE WILL BE AVAILABLE IN AUGUST 2022. THE TOWN ANTICIPATES PUTTING THE AMES POND DAM REMOVAL OUT TO BID CONCURRENTLY WITH THE ARMSTRONG DAM AND BEGINNING CONSTRUCTION IN NOVEMBER, 2022. MOST PROJECT PERMITS ARE CURRENTLY IN HAND AND ANY REMAINING PERMITS WILL BE SECURED BY AUGUST, 2022.EXPECTED RESULTS, BENEFITS, OUTCOMES: REMOVAL OF AMES DAM, ALONG WITH THE REMOVAL OF ARMSTRONG DAM, THIS PROJECT WILL OPEN 36 MILES AND 180 ACRES FOR ANADROMOUS FISH, GIVING FULL AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE.PROJECT LOCATION:THE PROJECT IS ON THE MONATIQUOT RIVER, THE PRIMARY TRIBUTARY TO THE WEYMOUTH FORE RIVER. THIS SITE IS LOCATED NORTHEAST OF THE INTERSECTION HANCOCK STREET AND PLAIN STREET IN BRAINTREE, MA. THE PROPERTY IS PRIVATELY OWNED BY HOLLINGWORTH POND, LLC. THE TOWN AND THE LANDOWNER HAVE ESTABLISHED A CONSERVATION EASEMENT THE INCLUDES THE ENTIRE PROJECT CORRIDOR. PROJECT COORDINATES: LAT. 42.198106, LONG. -71.003489 TOWN: BRAINTREE; COUNTY: NORFOLK; STATE: MASSACHUSETTS.KEY PERSONNEL (PI/PD): LORRAINE SEE, KELLY PHALEN

THE PROJECT WILL RESTORE AQUATIC CONNECTIVITY BETWEEN BLUE LICK RUN AND AN UNNAMED TRIBUTARY, IMPROVING FISH PASSAGE TO LARGELY FORESTED UPSTREAM HABITAT WITHIN THE SAVAGE RIVER WATERSHED, MARYLAND S BEST EASTERN BROOK TROUT RESOURCE  CONNECTIVITY WILL INCREASE POPULATION RESILIENCE AND GENETIC DIVERSITY BY PROVIDING ACCESS TO COLD WATER REFUGIA DURING LOW FLOW PERIODS AND INCREASING FORAGING AND SPAWNING HABITAT AVAILABILITY  THE NEW OPEN BOTTOM STRUCTURE WILL REOPEN APPROXIMATELY 1 85 MILES OF UPSTREAM HABITAT FOR EBT  THE PROJECT WILL ALSO SERVE TO A  INCREASE HABITAT QUALITY BY REDUCING EROSION AND RESTORING NATURAL STREAM PROCESSES  B  MAINTAIN PUBLIC ACCESS  AND C  PROVIDE A DEMONSTRATION SITE WHERE WILLING PARTNERS, LAND OWNERS AND COUNTY DEPARTMENTS OF PUBLIC WORKS CAN SEE FIRSTHAND HOW FISH PASSAGE AND FLOOD RESILIENCY CAN BE ACHIEVED IN CONCERT

CRUSTACEANS OFTEN REPRESENT A LARGE PROPORTION OF THE NON NATIVE SPECIES IN MANY MARINE ENVIRONMENTS, BUT SINCE CRUSTACEANS ARE OFTEN RELATIVELY SMALL AND RESTRICTED TO AQUATIC HABITATS, THEIR INTRODUCTION AND DISPERSAL CAN SOMETIMES GO UNNOTICED UNTIL AFTER THEY ARE WELL ESTABLISHED IN THEIR NEW ENVIRONMENTS  THE IMPACTS OF THESE NON NATIVE CRUSTACEAN SPECIES, SUCH AS CRABS, LOBSTERS, AMPHIPODS, COPEPODS, AND CRAYFISH, CAN BE SIGNIFICANT, WHEREIN THEY CAN CAUSE LARGE SHIFTS IN BOTH THE STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION OF AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS THAT LEAD TO DIRECT AND INDIRECT ECONOMIC COST  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSESS THREATS AND MITIGATE POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF NON NATIVE CRUSTACEANS TO AQUATIC RESOURCES IN SOUTH CAROLINA

THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES DIVISION (GADNR) IS TASKED WITH MANAGING ALL WILDLIFE IN OUR STATE, INCLUDING BOTH NATIVE AND INTRODUCED SPECIES. TO AID OUR MANAGEMENT EFFORTS FOR INTRODUCED AQUATIC SPECIES, WE DEVELOPED THE GEORGIA AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN (ANS PLAN). THE GOAL OF THE ANS PLAN IS TO PREVENT AND CONTROL THE INTRODUCTION OF ANS INTO GEORGIA AND MINIMIZE THE FUTURE SPREAD AND IMPACTS OF EXISTING ANS POPULATIONS ON NATIVE SPECIES, ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY, HUMAN HEALTH, AND THE ECONOMY. PLANNED ACTIVITIES FOR THIS REPORTING PERIOD (10/1/2022 THROUGH 12/31/2027) WILL FOCUS ON TASK 2.0 IN THE ANS PLAN: CONTROL AND MANAGE THE INTRODUCTION AND SPREAD OF ANS IN GEORGIA THROUGH EDUCATION AND OUTREACH; AND TASK 4.0 IN ANS PLAN: CONTROL OR ERADICATE ESTABLISHED ANS IN GEORGIA THROUGH COOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES DESIGNED TO MINIMIZE IMPACTS TO NON-TARGET SPECIES.

THESE FUNDS ARE REQUESTED TO FULLY FUND THE RESTORATION OF A HUMAN ALTERED IMPASSABLE BARRIER ON THE DENNY'S RIVER IN MEDDYBEMPS, MAINE. THE PROJECT WILL REMOVE AN ABANDONED DAM AND COMPLETES ENGINEERED FISH PASSAGE IMPROVEMENTS FOR AQUATIC ORGANISMS INTO MEDDYBEMPS LAKE FROM THE DENNY'S RIVER. IN THIS PHASE OF THE PROJECT THE RIVERBANKS WILL BE WIDENED, AND ENGINEERED STONE FISH PASSAGE WEIRS WILL BE INSTALLED TO ALLOW DIADROMOUS FISH FREE ACCESS THROUGH THE SITE. HUMAN ACCESS AND SAFETY ALONG THE RIVER WILL ALSO BE IMPROVED BY STREAM SIDE RESTORATION. THE RESTORATION WILL TAKE PLACE JUST ABOVE THE ROUTE 191 BRIDGE IN MEDDYBEMPS, MAINE. THE FINAL PHASE OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE COMPLETED DURING THE SUMMER OF 2022 DURING THE LOW WATER WORK WINDOW. DOWNEAST SALMON FEDERATION'S RESTORATION AND ENGAGEMENT COORDINATOR BRETT CICCOTELLI WILL MANAGE THIS PROJECT. HE HAS MANAGED DAM REMOVALS AND FISHWAY CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS PERVIOUSLY FUNDED BY THE USFWS. HE WILL WORK WITH AGENCY PARTNERS FROM THE MAINE DEPARTMENTS OF MARINE RESOURCES AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION.

INVASIVE SPECIES POSE A SIGNIFICANT THREAT TO SPORT FISH POPULATIONS, AQUATIC INVERTEBRATES, RECREATION, AND THE ECONOMY  OVER 50,000 NON NATIVE SPECIES HAVE BEEN INTRODUCED INTO NORTH AMERICA WITH INTRODUCTIONS OCCURRING AS SOON AS MIGRANTS BEGAN TO SETTLE THE NEW WORLD  OF THOSE, ABOUT 15  HAVE BECOME NUISANCE INVASIVE, LEADING TO ECONOMIC AND OR ECOLOGICAL IMPACTS  FIFTEEN PERCENT IS SIGNIFICANT, AS ALABAMA IS WELL KNOWN FOR ITS AQUATIC BIODIVERSITY  WITH A COMPLEX NETWORK OF SMALL RIVERS, TRIBUTARIES AND STREAMS DRAINING DIRECTLY INTO THE GULF OF MEXICO, ALABAMA HARBORS 60  OF THE MUSSEL SPECIES, 52  OF FRESHWATER TURTLES, 38  OF FRESHWATER FISHES, AND 20  OF THE CRAYFISH SPECIES IN NORTH AMERICA  AQUATIC ORGANISMS ARE FARING WORSE ACROSS THE U S , AS A VAST NUMBER OF MUSSELS  67   AND FISH  37   ARE SUSCEPTIBLE TO EITHER EXTIRPATION OR EXTINCTION  AS A CENTER OF BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY, ALABAMA AND ITS CITIZENS HAVE AN IMPORTANT ROLE TO PLAY CONTROLLING AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PREVENT, ELIMINATE, OR REDUCE THE ENVIRONMENTAL AND PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY RISKS ASSOCIATED WITH AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES

THE GOAL FOR THE ARKANSAS AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES  ANS  MANAGEMENT PLAN IS TO MINIMIZE THE HARMFUL ECOLOGICAL, ECONOMIC AND HUMAN HEALTH IMPACTS OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES THROUGH THE PREVENTION AND MANAGEMENT OF THEIR INTRODUCTION, EXPANSION AND DISPERSAL INTO, WITHIN AND FROM ARKANSAS ARKANSAS HAS DOCUMENTED 37 AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE  SEVERAL OF THESE SPECIES, SUCH AS GIANT SALVINIA, HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO SPREAD ACROSS THE STATE AND CAUSE SIGNIFICANT ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC DAMAGE  EDUCATION, MONITORING, REPORTING AND RAPID RESPONSE CAPABILITIES MUST BE IMPROVED TO HELP PREVENT NEW INTRODUCTIONS AND SPREAD OF EXISTING AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND THE IMPLEMENTATION OF STRATEGIES IDENTIFIED IN THE ARKANSAS ANS MANAGEMENT PLAN TO IMPROVE EDUCATION, MONITORING, EARLY DETECTION, AND RAPID RESPONSE CAPABILITIES IN ARKANSAS  SPECIFICALLY, FUNDS PROVIDED BY THIS AWARD WOULD BE USED TO 1 INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS OF ANS BY PROVIDING INVASIVE AQUATIC PLANT SPECIES IDENTIFICATION MATERIAL CURRENTLY FOUND IN ARKANSAS  WATERS AND INCREASED ANS PREVENTION SIGNAGE AT PUBLIC BOAT RAMPS  2  DEVELOP AN ANS REPORT APP FOR SMARTPHONES TO IMPROVE EARLY DETECTION AND RAPID RESPONSE EFFORTS, 3 IMPROVE MONITORING OF ZEBRA AND QUAGGA MUSSELS IN ARKANSAS WATERS BY PURCHASING SUPPLIES TO SAMPLE INVASIVE DREISSENID MUSSEL LARVAE, 4  ACQUIRE CONTAINMENT AND CONTROL SUPPLIES, SUCH AS CONTAINMENT BOOMING AND HIGH PRESSURE SPRAY RIGS, TO INCREASE RAPID RESPONSE AND CONTROL CAPABILITIES OF GIANT SALVINIA AND OTHER INVASIVE AQUATIC PLANTS, AND 5  PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE ANS PROGRAM COORDINATOR TO ATTEND CONFERENCES AND TRAINING RELATED TO ANS PREVENTION, MONITORING, CONTAINMENT, AND CONTROL CURRENTLY, ARKANSAS HAS NO PUBLICATIONS SPECIFIC TO IDENTIFICATION AND CONTROL OF INVASIVE AQUATIC PLANTS FOUND IN, OR THAT COULD LIKELY BE INTRODUCED INTO, STATE WATERS  DEVELOPMENT OF ARKANSAS ANS IDENTIFICATION MATERIALS WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND REPORTING, AND AID FUTURE DEVELOPMENT OF TRAINING PROGRAMS FOR STATE AGENCY STAFF AND THE PUBLIC  THE ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSION NEEDS AN ANS REPORTING APP FOR SMARTPHONES TO MAKE IT CONVENIENT AND EASY FOR AGENCY STAFF AND THE PUBLIC TO ACCURATELY REPORT ANS IN A TIMELY MANNER  CURRENT SUBSTRATE SAMPLING FOR ZEBRA AND QUAGGA MUSSELS IS NOT AS EFFICIENT OR EFFECTIVE FOR EARLY DETECTION AS SAMPLING LARVAE  VELIGERS   THEREFORE, USE OF LARVAE NETS ARE REQUIRED TO INCREASE MONITORING EFFICIENCY  THE ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSION DOES NOT HAVE ADEQUATE EQUIPMENT, SUCH AS CONTAINMENT BOOMING OR HIGH PRESSURE SPRAY RIGS FOR BOATS, TO RAPIDLY RESPOND TO NEW GIANT SALVINIA INTRODUCTIONS  GIANT SALVINIA WAS FIRST INTRODUCE IN ARKANSAS IN 2017, AND CURRENTLY IS CONTAINED TO TWO LAKES IN SOUTHWEST ARKANSAS  GIANT SALVINIA IS PREVALENT IN WATERS NEAR THE STATES BORDER WITH LOUISIANA AND TEXAS  THESE TOOLS ARE NEEDED TO EFFECTIVELY RESPOND TO NEW GIANT SALVINIA INTRODUCTION AND WILL IMPROVE THE LIKELIHOOD OF SUCCESSFUL ERADICATION  THE ANS PROGRAM COORDINATOR IS NEW TO THIS POSITION AND NEEDS TO ATTEND STATE, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL MEETINGS TO LEARN MORE ABOUT ANS PREVENTION AND MANAGEMENT ALL PEOPLE WHO ENJOY OUTDOOR RECREATION IN ARKANSAS WATERS WILL BENEFIT FROM THESE PROJECTS  ALSO, STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES WILL BENEFIT BY PROVIDING REFERENCE MATERIAL TO DEVELOP FUTURE TRAINING PROGRAMS, INCREASE EARLY DETECTION AND RESPONSE CAPABILITIES FOR GIANT SALVINIA, ZEBRA MUSSELS AND QUAGGA MUSSELS, AND PROVIDE A MORE EFFECTIVE WAY FOR THEIR STAFF TO REPORT ANS  BY PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSION S ANS PROGRAM COORDINATOR TO STAY UP TO DATE ON THE LATEST RESEARCH AND TECHNIQUES FOR PREVENTING AND MANAGING ANS, AS WELL AS NETWORKING WITH OTHER STATE AND FEDERAL ANS MANAGERS AND RESEARCHERS, HE WILL BE BETTER PREPARED TO COORDINATE MANAGEMENT OF ANS IN ARKANSAS

MANAGE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES IN ARIZONA THROUGH MONITORING, OUTREACH AND TRAINING USING THE ARIZONA INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE COORDINATING AND IMPLEMENTING A COMPREHENSIVE ARIZONA AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN. PREVENTING THE INTRODUCTION OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES INTO ARIZONA. DETECTING AND ERADICATING PIONEERING AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES. WHERE FEASIBLE, CONTROLLING OR ERADICATING ESTABLISHED AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES THAT HAVE A SIGNIFICANT IMPACT. INCREASING THE KNOWLEDGE OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES IN ARIZONA THROUGH COMPILING DATA AND CONDUCTING RESEARCH. FINALLY, FUNDS WILL SUPPORT INFORMING THE PUBLIC, POLICY MAKERS, NATURAL RESOURCE WORKERS, PRIVATE INDUSTRY, AND USER GROUPS ABOUT THE RISKS AND IMPACTS OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES.

THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES PROGRAM CONSISTS OF A FULL-TIME COORDINATOR/BIOLOGIST AND A FULL-TIME TECHNICIAN. AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES POSE SIGNIFICANT ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC THREATS TO AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS IN OKLAHOMA. ZEBRA MUSSELS, HYDRILLA, INVASIVE CARP, GOLDEN ALGA, YELLOW FLOATING HEART, AMONG OTHERS HAVE ALREADY BECOME ESTABLISHED IN OKLAHOMA'S LAKES AND RIVERS. THESE SPECIES AS WELL AS SPECIES IN NEIGHBORING STATES POSE ECONOMIC AND ECOLOGICAL THREATS TO THE STATE'S AQUATIC RESOURCES. BIGHEADED CARP (SILVER AND BIGHEAD CARP) HAVE BEEN PRESENT IN THE LOWER RED RIVER WATERSHED AND ITS TRIBUTARIES SINCE AT LEAST 2012 AND BIGHEAD CARP IN THE NEOSHO RIVER/GRAND LAKE SYSTEM SINCE 1992.WHEN POSSIBLE, WE PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND COORDINATION BETWEEN UNIVERSITIES AND STATE AGENCY COLLABORATORS. BOTH SYSTEMS ARE ACTIVELY BEING STUDIED AND WE ANTICIPATE RESEARCH RESULTS TO ASSIST FUTURE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS AS WELL AS INVASIVE SPECIES IMPLICATIONS ON OTHER NATIVE SPECIES. WE EXPECT TO INCREASE OUR EARLY DETECTION SAMPLING FOR ZEBRA MUSSELS THROUGHOUT THE STATE BY SURVEYING 29 WATER BODIES DURING THE CALENDAR YEAR 2022. PLANKTON SAMPLES WILL BE SENT TO THE BUREAU OF RECLAMATION LAB IN DENVER, COLORADO FOR ANALYSIS USING LIGHT MICROSCOPY AND PCR TECHNIQUES. OBTAINING RESULTS FROM PLANKTON SAMPLES WILL HELP INFORM IF THERE HAVE BEEN ANY NEW WATER BODIES CONTAMINATED WITH ZEBRA MUSSELS. IF THERE ARE NEW CONTAMINATIONS, WE PLAN TO INFORM THE PUBLIC AS WELL AS OTHER ASSOCIATED AGENCIES TO HELP PREVENT THE SPREAD OF ZEBRA MUSSELS TO OTHER PARTS OF THE STATES OR EVEN OTHER STATES. THE AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES PROGRAM ASSISTS WITH THE MANAGEMENT OF AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANTS SUCH AS HYDRILLA, YELLOW FLOATING HEART, AND ALLIGATOR WEED. WE PLAN TO ASSIST WATER BODY MANAGERS WITH SURVEYS, TREATMENT AND CONTROL INVASIVE AQUATIC VEGETATION THAT COULD RESULT IN INCREASED INVASION OR SPREAD TO OTHER WATER BODIES. IF ESTABLISHED, INVASIVE AQUATIC PLANTS COULD CAUSE SIGNIFICANT ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC HARM BY CAUSING UNPLEASANT EXPERIENCES FOR ANGLERS OR RECREATIONAL USERS. IF USED FOR DRINKING WATER, PLANTS CAN ALSO AFFECT WATER INTAKE INFRASTRUCTURE. THE AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES COORDINATOR AND TECHNICIAN HAVE A VARIETY OF OTHER RESPONSIBILITIES TO REVIEW VARIOUS AQUATIC PERMITS FOR THE AGENCY, WRITE REGULATION CHANGES IF NECESSARY, ATTEND CONFERENCES TO PARTICIPATE IN INVASIVE SPECIES COMMITTEES, DISSEMINATE INFORMATION, AND LEARN FROM OTHER STATES MANAGEMENT PRACTICES OF INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT. MEETINGS ARE ATTENDED OFTEN WEEKLY TO COORDINATE WITH LOCAL MUNICIPALITIES, NON-GOVERNMENTAL GROUPS, TRIBES, STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES IN REGARD TO INVASIVE SPECIES. AS A PART OF THE PROGRAM GOALS TO EDUCATE TARGETED USER GROUPS ABOUT AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES AND HOW TO PREVENT THE SPREAD, WE ARE FOCUSING ON LAUNCHING A NEW OUTREACH CAMPAIGN. WE HAVE INCREASED SIGNAGE PRESENCE AT DIFFERENT LAKES THROUGHOUT THE NORTH EAST AND CENTRAL REGION OF THE STATE AND PLAN TO CONTINUE TO DO SO STATEWIDE. WE ARE ALSO WORKING WITH OUR COMMUNICATIONS DEPARTMENT TO SEND OUT NEWSLETTERS, PRESS RELEASES, SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS AND INFORMATIONAL LETTERS TO OUR CONSTITUENTS. WE ARE ALSO RESPONSIBLE FOR ANSWERING VARIOUS REGULATION QUESTIONS FROM THE PUBLIC, PROVIDING TRAINING TO AGENCY STAFF ON THE DECONTAMINATION, REPORTING AND IDENTIFICATION OF AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES, AND REVIEW OUR STATE REGULATIONS.

THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO REMOVE A DAM ON BIG WILLS CREEK, OWNED BY THE CITY OF GADSDEN IN ETOWAH COUNTY, ALABAMA. THE DAM POSES HAZARDOUS CONDITIONS. REMOVAL OF THE DAM WILL ALLOW FOR ADDRESS OF THE HAZARDOUS CONDITION AND PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY TO ENHANCE OR RESTORE HABITAT CONNECTIVITY AND IMPROVE FISH PASSAGE. PROJECT OBJECTIVES: CAWACO RC&D PLANS TO WORK WITH THE CITY OF GADSDEN, S&ME, USFWS PROGRAMS, AND ANY OTHER POTENTIAL PARTNERS TO HELP MEET TWO PRIMARY PROJECT OBJECTIVES:- PUBLIC SAFETY - MECHANICAL REMOVAL OF THE DAM TO A LEVEL (TBD) THAT MINIMIZES/NEGATES HUMAN HEALTH AND SAFETY RISKS ASSOCIATED WITH SEVERELY ALTERED HYDRAULICS OF THE STREAM, AND- AQUATIC HABITAT - ENHANCE/RESTORE HABITAT CONNECTIVITY FOR AQUATIC FAUNA BY PERMITTINGUPSTREAM MIGRATION.ACTIVITIES: ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE PRIMARY SCOPE OF WORK FOR THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE REMOVING MOST, OR ALL, OF THE INSTREAM STRUCTURES ASSOCIATED WITH THE DAM. THE GOALS ARE TO REDUCE, OR ELIMINATE, THE DAM'S IMPACT ON STREAM HYDRAULICS, AQUATIC ORGANISM UPSTREAM MIGRATION, AND HUMAN HEALTH AND SAFETY CONCERNS. THE SCOPE OF WORK WILL FOLLOW THE PROPOSED PROJECT PLANS AS FINALIZED AND AGREED UPON WITH ALL INVOLVED PARTIES. CAWACO RC&D WILL PROVIDE ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANCIAL OVERSIGHT DURING THE PROJECT. USFWS PERSONNEL WILL PROVIDE PROJECT CONSTRUCTION OVERSIGHT. CAWACO RC&D, USFWS, AND ANY OTHER PROJECT PARTNERS WILL BE PROVIDED PROJECT PLANS AND CLEAR DIRECTION AS TO ANY CHANGE IN THE PROJECT OBJECTIVES AND NEEDS. CAWACO RC&D, USFWS, AND ANY OTHER PARTNERS WILL COORDINATE ANY NEEDED CHANGES AND ADJUSTMENTS TO PROJECT PLANS WITH THE CITY OF GADSDEN AND S&ME STAFF REPRESENTATIVES. UPON COMPLETION OF THE PRIMARY SCOPE OF WORK, THE PROJECT SITE FOOTPRINT WILL BE RESTORED TO THE SAME OR BETTER CONDITIONS AS PRIOR TO CONSTRUCTION.THE CITY OF GADSDEN WILL ALLOW FOR EXISTING MATERIALS (E.G., TREES, ROCK, DAM DEBRIS, ETC.) TO BE HARVESTED AND REPURPOSED AT THE PROJECT SITE, WHEN AND WHERE APPROPRIATE. THIS ALSO INCLUDES THE RE-GRADING OF SOIL/DIRT, AND DISPOSAL OF SUCH MATERIAL WITHIN THE CONFINES OF THE CITY'S PROPERTY BOUNDARIES, ON OR OFF-SITE. THE CITY OF GADSDEN HAS AGREED TO PROVIDE ANY NECESSARY LOADING, HAULING, AND DISPOSAL OF EXCESS CONSTRUCTION DEBRIS GENERATED DURING THE REMOVAL OF THE DAM, FROM INITIATION TO COMPLETION OF PROJECT. THE CITY OWNS AND OPERATES A C&D LANDFILL.TIMELINE: THE PROJECT WILL BEGIN AS SOON AS ALL AGREEMENTS AND ASSOCIATED FINANCIALDOCUMENTATION ARE IN PLACE. TARGETED PROJECT CONSTRUCTION PHASE TIMELINE IS JUNE-SEPTEMBER 2022. ALL WORK MUST BE COMPLETED BY MARCH 17, 2023.

NUMEROUS AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES (ANS) THREATEN THE SURFACE WATERS OF NEW MEXICO. AMONG THE TAXA RANKED BY PRIORITY CLASSES IN THE NEW MEXICO AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT PLAN (NM PLAN), DREISSENID MUSSELS (ZEBRA AND QUAGGA) CURRENTLY REPRESENT THE MOST IMMINENT THREAT TO OUR ECONOMY (MUNICIPAL WATER SUPPLIES, WATER-BASED INDUSTRIES, RECREATION) AND AQUATIC RESOURCES.BASED ON THE RAPID SPREAD OF DREISSENID MUSSELS THROUGHOUT THE WEST SINCE JANUARY 2007, THIS REQUEST FOR FUNDING WILL ALLOW US TO CONTINUE ADDRESSING THE OBJECTIVES OF THE NM PLAN FOCUSING ON: (1) EARLY DETECTION OF AND RAPID RESPONSE FOR DREISSENID MUSSELS; AND (2) ANS PUBLIC EDUCATION AND OUTREACH.THIS PROPOSAL FOLLOWS THE PLANS SUBMITTED WITH THE INITIAL REQUEST FOR FUNDING IN 2009. THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY (F22AS00233) WILL ALLOW US TO CONTINUE THE EFFORTS INITIATED WITH THE FIRST ROUND OF FUNDING.

THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLETE THE ILLUSTRATED GUIDE TO LARVAL AND EARLY JUVENILE CATOSTOMIDS FROM THE UPPER KLAMATH BASIN - MORPHOLOGICAL DESCRIPTION OF SHORTNOSE SUCKER (CHASMISTES BREVIROSTRIS) AND COMPARISON WITH LOST RIVER SUCKER (DELTISTES LUXATUS). THE LARVAL FISH DESCRIPTION FOR LOST RIVER SUCKER WAS COMPLETED IN 2019 (BRANDENBURG AND PLATANIA 2019). THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLETE THE LARVAL AND EARLY JUVENILE DESCRIPTION OF SHORTNOSE SUCKER AND PERFORM AN ANALYTICAL COMPARISON BETWEEN LOST RIVER SUCKER AND SHORTNOSE SUCKER.

THE INTRODUCTION AND SPREAD OF INVASIVE SPECIES ARE COSTLY TO BOTH THE ENVIRONMENT AND ECONOMY. DETAILED RISK ANALYSES PROVIDE STAKEHOLDERS WITH THE NECESSARY FIRST STEP IN THOROUGHLY UNDERSTANDING A PATHWAY FOR AIS SPREAD. RECENT FOCUS ON THE SEAPLANE PATHWAY HAS HIGHLIGHTED THE NEED FOR A ROBUST ASSESSMENT OF THIS MODE OF TRANSPORTATION. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE A DETAILED ANALYSIS OF SEAPLANE TRAVEL AND THE RISKS POSED AS A PATHWAY FOR THE SPREAD OF AIS IN U.S. WATERWAYS. BY FILLING THIS KEY RESEARCH GAP, THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE STAKEHOLDERS WITH THE NECESSARY INFORMATION TO BETTER UNDERSTAND AIS RISKS. TO COMPLETE THIS ASSESSMENT, SEVERAL TASKS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED. FIRST, A COMPREHENSIVE DATABASE OF SEAPLANE BASES AND WATERWAYS WILL BE CONSTRUCTED. THE PRIMARY DATA FOR THIS DATABASE WILL BE CONSTRUCTED USING DATA FROM THE SEAPLANE PILOTS ASSOCIATION'S WATER LANDING DIRECTORY, AIRCRAFT OWNERS AND PILOTS ASSOCIATION (AOPA) AIRPORT DIRECTORY, AND THE FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION (FAA) AIRPORT MASTER RECORD DATABASE. A DATASET OF SEAPLANE FLIGHTS WILL BE BUILT USING AUTOMATIC DEPENDENT SURVEILLANCE-BROADCAST (ADS-B) FLIGHT TRACKING DATA FROM THE VENDORS FLIGHTRADAR24, FLIGHTAWARE, AND ADS-B EXCHANGE. TO SUPPLEMENT THE ADS-B DATA AND CAPTURE SEAPLANE TRAVEL IN AREAS THAT DO NOT REQUIRE ADS-B1 EQUIPMENT, A SURVEY OF PRIVATE AND COMMERCIAL SEAPLANE OPERATORS WILL BE CONDUCTED. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE AGGREGATED OVER SEVERAL SEASONS TO DEVELOP A DETAILED TRAVEL PATTERN OF SEAPLANE FLIGHTS AND INVENTORY OF AIRCRAFT IN THE U.S. AN ANALYSIS OF SEAPLANE TRAVEL WILL BE PERFORMED FOR ALL ORIGIN AND DESTINATION PAIRS IN THE U.S. FINALLY, AIRCRAFT SPECIFIC STRUCTURAL AND OPERATIONAL RISK FACTORS FOR AIS SPREAD WILL BE DISCUSSED. INTERVIEWS WITH SEAPLANE OPERATORS AND MANUFACTURERS WILL ASSIST IN DETERMINING THE OPERATIONAL, STRUCTURAL, AND ENVIRONMENTAL RISKS THAT INCREASE THE LIKELIHOOD OF AIS SPREAD. THESE RISK FACTORS WILL BE CATALOGED FOR EACH AIRCRAFT DETERMINED TO OPERATE IN THE U.S. AND USED IN THE FOLLOW-ON RISK ASSESSMENT. ALTOGETHER, THESE TASKS WILL RESULT IN A COMPREHENSIVE REPORT DETAILING THE TRAVEL PATTERN OF SEAPLANES AND PATHWAY RISK IN THE 48 CONTIGUOUS STATES AND ALASKA. THE FINDINGS OF THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE NECESSARY INFORMATION TO ASSIST MULTIPLE STAKEHOLDERS IN MINIMIZING THE RISK OF AIS INTRODUCTION FROM SEAPLANES.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS WORK IS TO PROVIDE FOR A LONG-TERM TREATY INDIAN CATCH MONITORINGPROGRAM (TICMP). CATCH DATA IS MAINTAINED IN A DATABASE COMPILED FROM DATA INPUT BYSTAFF AT THE NORTHWEST INDIAN FISHERIES COMMISSION (NWIFC) AND TRIBAL STAFF, TAKENDIRECTLY FROM FISH RECEIVING TICKETS THAT ALL FISH BUYERS ARE REQUIRED TO FILL OUT FOR EACHLANDING. MANAGERS NEED ACCESS TO THIS DATA FOR PRE-SEASON PLANNING, IN-SEASONMANAGEMENT OF FISHERIES, AND FEDERAL REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.

ORGANIZATIONS TO EMPOWER LANDOWNERS TO ACT FOR THEMSELVES AND THE GREATER GOOD  FUNDING WILL BE USED TO FUND COORDINATION AND COMMUNICATIONS

MUSKRATS  ONDATRA ZIBETHICUS  ARE SEMIAQUATIC HERBIVORES EXPERIENCING LONG-TERM POPULATION DECLINES IN NORTH AMERICA, INCLUDING THE GREAT LAKES BASIN. THIS ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT FURBEARING SPECIES IS ALSO CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT ACROSS NORTH AMERICA, INCLUDING WITHIN THE GREAT LAKES BASIN. AS A RESULT OF FORAGING BEHAVIORS THOUGHT TO LIMIT THE EXPANSION OF INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES AND PROMOTE WETLAND HETEROGENEITY, MUSKRATS POSITIVELY AFFECT WETLAND BIODIVERSITY IN WETLANDS WHICH THEY OCCUPY. THUS, THIS HISTORICALLY COMMON SPECIES MAY BE CONSIDERED AN ECOSYSTEM ENGINEER IN WETLAND COMMUNITIES. CONTINUED DECLINES IN MUSKRAT POPULATIONS WILL LIKELY HAVE ADVERSE EFFECTS ON MUSKRAT TRAPPERS, WETLAND BIODIVERSITY, AND OVERALL WETLAND CONSERVATION THAT WILL LAST DECADES. UNDERSTANDING THE CAUSES OF LOCAL POPULATION DECLINES WILL BE CRITICAL FOR INFORMING MANAGEMENT AND POPULATION RECOVERY AT THE REGIONAL LEVEL IN THE GREAT LAKES BASIN AND POSSIBLY BEYOND.REASONS FOR LONG-TERM REGIONAL DECLINES OF MUSKRAT POPULATIONS, INCLUDING IN THE GREAT LAKES BASIN, REMAIN UNKNOWN TO WILDLIFE PROFESSIONALS, TRAPPERS, AND OTHER INTERESTED GROUPS. HOWEVER, RECENT STUDIES HAVE REVEALED DIFFERENCES IN MUSKRAT POPULATION HEALTH AND DISEASE RISKS BETWEEN REGIONS WITH RELATIVELY PRISTINE WETLAND HABITATS  I.E., VOYAGEURS NATIONAL PARK, NORTHERN MN  AND HEAVILY DEGRADED WETLAND HABITATS  I.E., CENTRAL IL . IN ONE OF THE FIRST EFFORTS TO EVALUATE MUSKRAT DECLINES THROUGHOUT THE ENTIRE GREAT LAKE BASIN, THE PRELIMINARY RESULTS FROM OUR PREVIOUSLY GREAT LAKES FISH AND WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACT FUNDED PROPOSAL,  ASSESSING THE VALUE OF AN INDICATOR SPECIES FOR WETLAND QUALITY, CONNECTIVITY, AND WILDLIFE IN THE GREAT LAKES BASIN , PROVIDED A FOUNDATION FOR A FOCUSED INVESTIGATION FOR THESE POPULATION DECLINES. IN THAT PROPOSAL, WE COLLECTED, ORGANIZED, AND ANALYZED NUMEROUS LARGE-SCALE DATASETS TO ASSESS POTENTIAL FACTORS THAT MAY IMPACT MUSKRAT POPULATIONS OCCURRING THROUGHOUT THE GREAT LAKES BASIN. OUR RESULTS SUGGESTED AT LEAST TWO UNDERLYING DRIVERS OF MUSKRAT POPULATION DYNAMICS  AS INDEXED BY HARVEST   MULTI-YEAR DROUGHT CONDITIONS AND VEGETATIVE DISTURBANCE WITHIN WETLANDS  AS BROADLY MEASURED USING A FLORISTIC QUALITY INDEX . DEGRADATION OF WETLAND QUALITY, THROUGH DROUGHT AND ALTERED VEGETATION CHARACTERISTICS, CAN NEGATIVELY AFFECT MUSKRAT HEALTH AND REPRODUCTION, BOTH IMPORTANT TO MUSKRAT POPULATION GROWTH.GIVEN THE POTENTIAL RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN MUSKRAT POPULATIONS AND THESE FACTORS, THE NEXT STEP IN OUR INVESTIGATION IS A FIELD-BASED EFFORT TO COLLECT DATA ON MUSKRAT POPULATION HEALTH AND DEMOGRAPHY ACROSS A GRADIENT OF DROUGHT CONDITIONS AND VEGETATIVE DISTURBANCES THROUGHOUT THE GREAT LAKES BASIN. THESE DATA WILL HELP UNCOVER MECHANISTIC EXPLANATIONS FOR OBSERVED POPULATION DECLINES AND ALSO HELP INFORM REGIONAL MANAGEMENT EFFORTS FOR MUSKRAT POPULATIONS AND WETLAND COMPLEXES. OUR GOAL IS TO INVESTIGATE HOW WETLAND CONDITION  DETERMINED BY DROUGHT AND VEGETATION DISTURBANCES  IMPACT THE POPULATION STRUCTURE, REPRODUCTION, AND HEALTH OF MUSKRATS USING INFORMATION FROM CARCASSES COLLECTED FROM WETLAND SITES POSITIONED ACROSS A GRADIENT WETLAND QUALITY THROUGHOUT THE GREAT LAKES BASIN. OUR OBJECTIVES INCLUDE 1. TO ASSESS POPULATION STRUCTURE BASED ON SEX AND AGE RATIOS OF HARVESTED MUSKRATS.2. TO ASSESS REPRODUCTION BASED ON EXAMINATIONS OF CARCASSES OF FEMALE AND MALE MUSKRATS.3. TO ASSESS INDIVIDUAL AND POPULATION-LEVEL HEALTH BASED ON BODY-FAT CONTENT AND OR LEVELS OF CONTAMINANTS.4. TO COLLECT SITE-SPECIFIC WETLAND DATA, INCLUDING FLORISTIC QUALITY INDEX AND OTHER VARIABLES  E.G., HUT COUNTS  ASSOCIATED WITH WETLAND CONDITION AND INCORPORATE THESE VARIABLES INTO ALL ANALYSES.TO MEET OUR GOAL, THE PROJECT TEAM INCLUDES SEVERAL STATE, TRIBAL, AND FEDERAL AGENCY PARTNERS, AND COORDINATION WITH SEVERAL OTHER ORGANIZATIONS.

THE FY22 NATIONAL FISH PASSAGE PROGRAM FUNDING WILL COMPLETE THE CRIPPLE CREEK RESTORATION PROJECT  THIS PROJECT, HAS BEEN WORKING WITH PARTNERS SINCE 2010 TO RESTORE FLOW TO THE CRIPPLE CREEK CHANNEL  THIS CHANNEL WAS ABANDONED IN THE EARLY 1900S AS A RESULT OF SILTATION FROM GOLD MINING ACTIVITIES  RESTORATION OF FLOW WILL CREATE FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC HABITAT  TO DATE THE PROJECT HAS CONDUCTED EXTENSIVE HYDROLOGICAL STUDIES, REHABILITATED ONE PERCHED CULVERT, REPLACED TWO CULVERTS UNDER MAJOR ROADWAYS, AND RECONNECTED WATER FLOW BETWEEN THE CULVERTS AND THE ORIGINAL CHANNEL  DIVERSION STRUCTURES INSTALLED IN FALL OF 2020 FAILED DURING SPRING MELT IN 2021  A NEW DIVERSION PLAN HAS BEEN DESIGNED, AND WILL BE CONSTRUCTED  WITH THIS DIVERSION STRUCTURE IN PLACE, FLOW WILL BE RESTORED ALONG THE ENTIRE PROJECT AREA

WILSON CREEK IS A CLASS 1 COLDWATER TRIBUTARY TO THE BOIS BRULE RIVER LOCATED IN DOUGLAS COUNTY WISCONSIN  THE BRULE IS A FAMOUS DESTINATION FOR ANGLERS IN WISCONSIN, SUPPORTING NATIVE BROOK TROUT POPULATIONS THAT CAN REACH TROPHY SIZES IN THE UPSTREAM SECTIONS OF THE WATERSHED  WILSON CREEK IS LOCATED IN THE UPPER REACHES OF THE BOIS BRULE WATERSHED AND PROVIDES IMPORTANT SPAWNING AND COLDWATER REFUGIA HABITAT FOR BROOK TROUT, HABITAT TYPES THAT ARE CRITICAL TO SUPPORT WILD BROOK TROUT POPULATIONS NOW AND INTO THE FUTURE  DESPITE THE HIGH QUALITY HABITAT FOUND IN WILSON CREEK, TWO CROSSINGS ON COUNTY HIGHWAY P CREATE FULL AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE BARRIERS  AOP  FOR JUVENILE BROOK TROUT AND SEASONAL BARRIERS FOR ADULT BROOK TROUT  THIS PREVENTS BROOK TROUT FROM BEING ABLE TO FULLY UTILIZE HABITAT IN WILSON CREEK, HABITAT THAT WILL BECOME MORE IMPORTANT AS CLIMATE CHANGE CONTINUES TO RAISE STREAM TEMPERATURES MAKING COLD HEADWATER STREAMS LIKE WILSON CREEK PARAMOUNT FOR WILD BROOK TROUT POPULATION SURVIVABILITY  REPLACING THESE TWO CROSSINGS WITH AOP FRIENDLY ROAD STREAM CROSSINGS WILL RECONNECT OVER 2 MILES OF CLASS 1 TROUT STREAM  THIS PROJECT BUILD OFF A PREVIOUSLY FUNDING NFPP APPLICATION IN 2021 TO REPLACE A FULL AOP BARRIER ON WILSON CREEK LOCATED AT EAST STONE CHIMNEY ROAD  THAT CROSSING  PLANNED FOR CONSTRUCTION IN 2023  IS LOCATED UPSTREAM OF THESE TWO HIGHWAY 2 CROSSINGS, AND REPLACING ALL THREE BARRIERS WILL FULLY RECONNECT WILSON CREEK TO THE BOIS BRULE WATERSHED  THIS PROJECT INVOLVES PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN TROUT UNLIMITED, USFWS, TOWN OF SOLON SPRINGS, DOUGLAS COUNTY, WISCONSIN DNR, UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN SUPERIOR, AND OTHERS

I PROJECT SUMMARY  THIS PROJECT, LOCATED ON THE NORTH END OF SURPRISE VALLEY IN NORTH EAST CALIFORNIA, WILL PROVIDE FISH PASSAGE, STREAM FUNCTION, AND FISH SCREEN AN IRRIGATION DIVERSION FOR A LARGE STRUCTURE FOUND ON BIDWELL CREEK  THE MULTI STEP DIVERSION STRUCTURE IS A FISH PASSAGE BARRIER AND IS IN DANGER OF FAILING  PHASE ONE OF THIS PROJECT WILL DESIGN A FISH PASSAGE OPTION THAT RETAINS THE UPSTREAM DIVERSION AND ALLOWS SEDIMENT TRANSPORT TO DOWNSTREAM PROCESS BASED RESTORATION ACTIVITIES  II PROJECT NEED  BIDWELL CREEK IS A 12 MILE LONG PERENNIAL CREEK ON THE NORTH END OF SURPRISE VALLEY IN MODOC COUNTY, CA  THE CREEK SUPPLIES WATER TO THE UPPER ALKALI LAKE AND IS A VITAL CREEK TO SUPPORT THE FISHERIES IN SURPRISE VALLEY  BIDWELL CREEK S FISHES INCLUDE REDBAND TROUT, RAINBOW TROUT, AND MODOC SUCKER  COMPLETION OF THIS PROJECT WILL OPEN APPROXIMATELY 2 MILES OF BIDWELL CREEK ON PRIVATE PROPERTY BEFORE IT ENTERS THE MODOC FOREST SERVICE LANDS  THE EXISTING MULTI STEP DIVERSION WEAR POSES A SIGNIFICANT FISH BARRIER AND IS BEGINNING TO SHOW SIGNS OF FAILING  UNCONTROLLED LOSS OF THIS STRUCTURE WOULD RESULT IN STREAM INCISION OF FOUR OR MORE FEET, THE LOSS OF UPSTREAM SEDIMENT BEDS, AND THE DRYING OF SURROUNDING FIELDS AND RIPARIAN HABITAT  III PROJECT OBJECTIVES 1 WORK WITH A STREAM RESTORATION CONSULTING FIRM TO DESIGN A  A FISH SCREEN FOR THE UPSTREAM AGRICULTURAL DIVERSION  B  PREVENT FURTHER DEGRADATION OF THE INSTREAM STRUCTURE REQUIRED TO PROVIDE FLOWS TO THE DIVERSION STRUCTURE  C  ESTABLISH FISH PASSAGE BOTH UP AND DOWNSTREAM AND SEDIMENT TRANSPORT PAST THE STRUCTURE  2  PROCESS PERMITS REQUIRED TO COMPLETE THE PROJECT, INCLUDING NEPA, SECTION 7, ARMY CORP , AND STATE 401 PERMITS

THE COWLITZ INDIAN TRIBE PROPOSES TO REMOVE THE DERELICT WATER INTAKE INFRASTRUCTURE PREVIOUSLY OPERATED TO SUPPORT THE GRAYS RIVER STATE FISH HATCHERY, OWNED BY THE WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE  WDFW  AND LOCATED IN PACIFIC COUNTY, WASHINGTON  THE WATER INTAKE STRUCTURE WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 1961  WITH A CHANNEL SPANNING A CONCRETE DAM AND STEEL WEIR, OPERATED TO DIRECT MAINSTEM FLOW FROM THE WEST FORK GRAYS RIVER INTO A SCREENED INTAKE  RECENT FISH PASSAGE SURVEYS  FPSDI  983061  DOCUMENTED THE INTAKE AS A SEVERE PARTIAL BARRIER WITH A 33  PASSABILITY RATING DUE TO HIGH VELOCITIES, TURBULENCE AND A BARRIER DURING LOW FLOWS DUE TO A LACK OF DEPTH  THE SCREENED INTAKE OVERFLOW ALSO ACTIVATES AN EPHEMERAL 900 FOOT DIVERSION  SIDE  CHANNEL AND CREATES A SEASONAL ATTRACTIVE NUISANCE POTENTIALLY IMPACTING LOCAL SALMONID POPULATIONS  THE COWLITZ INDIAN TRIBE PROPOSES TO UTILIZE THE RECENTLY COMPLETED WEST FORK GRAYS DESIGN  RCO  19 1216  TO FACILITATE THE REMOVAL OF THE WEIR AND SURROUNDING CONCRETE INFRASTRUCTURE AND REPLACE THE DISTURBED AREAS WITH AN APEX LOG JAM TO RESTORE NATURAL PROCESSES, ATTENUATE SEDIMENT, SCOUR A DEEP POOL, CREATE HABITAT COMPLEXITY AND PROVIDE PERENNIAL FLOW TO THE DIVERSION SIDE CHANNEL  THE INTAKE REMOVAL WILL ALSO RESTORE FISH PASSAGE TO OVER 15 MILES OF UPSTREAM SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT  THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT ESA LISTED  THREATENED  GRAYS RIVER POPULATIONS OF WINTER STEELHEAD, COHO, FALL CHINOOK, AND CHUM SALMON

MALAMA MAUNALUA S  MM  PROJECT, WITH SUPPORT FROM THE HAWAI I FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP, IS TO GROW ITS HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECT IN MAUNALUA BAY S NEARSHORE REEF FLAT  IN PARTICULAR, MM SEEKS TO CONTINUE TO INNOVATE METHODS TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY IN THE NEARSHORE REEF FLAT TO IMPROVE HABITAT QUALITY FOR FISH, CORAL, AND NATIVE LIMU SEAGRASS  MM WILL 1  AUGMENT THE EXTENT OF OUR INVASIVE ALIEN ALGAE  IAA  REMOVAL EFFORT TO FOCUS ON NEW HOT SPOT SITES WITH THE PRIORITY AREA OF HIGH IAA ALGAE BIOMASS  VOLUNTEERS WILL PARTICIPATE IN IAA REMOVAL EFFORTS IN LOCATIONS NO PREVIOUSLY MANAGED 2  SCALE UP OUR STRATEGY TO USE THE NATIVE COLLECTOR SEA URCHIN AS A BIOLOGICAL METHOD FOR REMOVING MAINTAINING IAA GROWTH, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH DIVISION OF AQUATIC RESOURCES  DAR   URCHINS WILL BE PROVIDED BY DAR, AND TESTED IN CAGES PLACED IN THE NEARSHORE HABITAT TO DETERMINE THEIR EFFECTIVENESS AT REMOVING IAA  EVENTUALLY, A LARGER NUMBER OF URCHINS WILL BE RELEASED IN THE BAY IN LOCATIONS DETERMINED BASED ON THE INFORMATION ASCERTAINED FROM THE PREVIOUS TESTING 3  LAUNCH A PILOT PROJECT USING PACIFIC OYSTERS TO IMPROVE NEARSHORE WATER QUALITY, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII AT HILO PACIFIC AQUACULTURE AND  COASTAL RESOURCE CENTER  PARC  AND WATERKEEPER ALLIANCE  THE PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF PURCHASING BABY OYSTERS FROM PARC AND DEPLOYING THEM OFF DOCKS AND WALLS AROUND MAUNALUA BAY IN PARTNERSHIP WITH LOCAL RESIDENTS  THE PROJECT WILL HELP DETERMINE LABOR BURDENS, VIABILITY, OYSTER RESPONSE TO BAY CONDITIONS, AND BE USED FOR SIGNIFICANT OUTREACH ALL OF THE WORK WILL TAKE PLACE IN MAUNALUA BAY, AND BE CLOSELY MONITORED BY MM STAFF  THE RESULTS OF THE WORK WILL NOT ONLY INFORM FUTURE EFFORTS BY MM, BUT INFORM EFFORTS BY OTHER NON PROFITS AND THE GOVERNMENT STATEWIDE

ESSEX COUNTY NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION DISTRICT (ENRCD)AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) HAVE BEEN AND WILL CONTINUE WORKING COOPERATIVELY TO RESTORE, ENHANCE AND RECONNECT BROOK TROUT HABITAT WITHIN THE UPPER CONNECTICUT RIVER IN VERMONT. ENRCD WILL WORK ON TWO TASKS ASSOCIATED WITH HABITAT RESTORATION AND CONNECTIVITY. (1)ENRCD WILL FACILITATE THE DESIGN AND REMOVAL OF BARRIERS (DAMS AND/OR CULVERTS) TO AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE IN THE UPPER CONNECTICUT RIVER BASIN IN COORDINATION WITH USFWS BIOLOGISTS. (2)ENRCD WILL FACILITATE THE RESTORATION OF IN-STREAM HABITAT THROUGH RIPARIAN RESTORATION IN COORDINATION WITH LOCAL PARTNERS, LANDOWNERS AND USFWS BIOLOGISTS. FOLLOWING THIS COOPERATIVE PROJECT, ENRCD WILL CONTINUE TO WORK WITH PARTNERS AND LANDOWNERS THROUGHOUT THE WATERSHED TO ACHIEVE RESTORATION OUTCOMES DEVELOPED THROUGH THE WATERSHED MANAGEMENT PLAN AND OTHER SHARED OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED BY USFWS.

THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE  THE MYAKKA RIVER DOWNS DAM REMOVAL PROJECT WHICH WILL REMOVE THE LAST KNOWN BARRIER ON THE MYAKKA RIVER AND OPEN UP APPROXIMATELY 422 RIVER MILES  THE CROOKED CREEK DAM REMOVAL PROJECT WHICH WILL REMOVE A FAILING DAM ON PRIVATE PROPERTY THAT PREVENTS FISH PASSAGE ON CROOKED CREEK  AND ECONLOCKHATCHEE RIVER STREAM RESTORATION AND FISH PASSAGE PROJECT WHICH WILL MANAGE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES FOR THEIR LONG TERM WELL BEING AND THE BENEFIT OF PEOPLE BY STABILIZING AND RESTORING A 300 FOOT LONG ERODING STREAMBANK, ADJUSTING A CROSS SECTIONAL AREA TO NARROW RIVER REACH, AND REMOVE SEDIMENT PLUG FOR FISH PASSAGE

THE ARIZONA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT IS WORKING ON A PROJECT TO RECONNECT THE WEST FORK BLACK RIVER  WFBR  TO ITS TRIBUTARIES, HAYGROUND, HOME, AND STINKY CREEKS TO ESTABLISH A META POPULATION FOR APACHE TROUT  ONCORHYNCHUS APACHE , AND PROVIDE HABITAT FOR OTHER NATIVE FISH SPECIES, SUCH AS LOACH MINNOW  TIAROGA COBITIS , ROUNDTAIL CHUB  GILA ROBUSTA , SPECKLED DACE  RHINICHTHYS OSCULUS , DESERT SUCKER  CATOSTOMUS CLARKII , AND SONORA SUCKER  CATOSTOMUS INSIGNIS   THERE ARE CURRENTLY FOUR ARTIFICIAL FISH BARRIERS LOCATED IN THESE THREE TRIBUTARIES BLOCKING ACCESS TO THESE HABITATS FROM THE WFBR  REMOVING THESE BARRIERS WILL REESTABLISH THE CONNECTION BETWEEN THE WFBR AND ITS TRIBUTARIES ENABLING THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A META POPULATION OF APACHE TROUT  ESTABLISHING APACHE TROUT IN A COMPLEX HABITAT THAT ALLOWS FOR MOVEMENT BETWEEN THE WFBR AND ITS TRIBUTARIES WILL PROVIDE RESILIENCY FOR THE SPECIES IN THE FACE OF INCREASING THREATS LIKE CLIMATE CHANGE THIS WOULD ALSO BE A RARE ACCOMPLISHMENT FOR THIS SPECIES AS THEY ARE MOSTLY RESTRICTED TO SMALL HEADWATER STREAMS UPSTREAM OF ARTIFICIAL OR NATURAL FISH BARRIERS  THIS PROJECT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED IN FIVE PHASES  THE FIRST PHASE OF THIS PROJECT WAS TO ACQUIRE DESIGNS FOR THE REMOVAL OF THE FOUR TRIBUTARY BARRIERS LOCATED IN HAYGROUND, HOME, AND STINKY CREEKS  RECEIVED JUNE 2022   THE SECOND PHASE IS TO COMPLETE THE ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE  E G , NEPA  FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE REMOVALS AND IS EXPECTED TO BE COMPLETED BY THE END OF CALENDAR YEAR 2022  THE THIRD PHASE WILL BE THE ACTUAL IMPLEMENTATION OF THE REMOVALS AND THE RECONNECTION OF 20 1 KM  12 5 MI  OF HABITAT  THE FOURTH PHASE WILL BE THE REMOVAL OF NONNATIVE SPECIES FROM THE WFBR AND ITS TRIBUTARIES UPSTREAM OF AN ARTIFICIAL FISH BARRIER CONSTRUCTED IN 2015 IN THE LOWER MAINSTEM WFBR  THE FINAL PHASE OF THE PROJECT WILL BE TO REINTRODUCE APACHE TROUT, LOACH MINNOW, ROUNDTAIL CHUB, SPECKLED DACE, DESERT SUCKER AND SONORA SUCKER TO THE WFBR AND ITS TRIBUTARIES AND TO MONITOR THE SUCCESS OF THOSE REINTRODUCTIONS  THE FUNDING REQUESTED FROM THE INFRASTRUCTURE INVESTMENT AND JOBS ACT NATIONAL FISH PASSAGE PROGRAM  INFRASTRUCTURE THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO PROVIDE PASSAGE FOR MIGRATORY AND ANADROMOUS FISH IN JOHNSON CREEK BY CORRECTING PASSAGE IMPEDIMENTS AT THE SR 97 AND GREENACRES CROSSINGS  THE PROJECT WILL RESTORE FISH PASSAGE TO ROUGHLY 9 MILES OF HABITAT IN JOHNSON CREEK AND REPLACE OUTDATED, UNDERSIZED INFRASTRUCTURE AT THE CROSSINGS  PASSAGE AT THESE TWO SITES WILL BUILD ON ROUGHLY 7 YEARS OF PASSAGE WORK IN JOHNSON CREEK AND REPRESENT CORRECTION OF THE FINAL 3 PASSAGE BARRIERS IN THE LOWER 1 2 MILES OF THE STREAM

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE CONNECTIVITY IN LIBBY CREEK DURING IRRIGATION SEASON FOR ESA LISTED AND OTHER NATIVE FISH SPECIES  THE OBJECTIVE OF THE PROJECT IS TO REPLACE OR RELOCATE A 0  PASSABLE DIVERSION DAM AT ROUGHLY RIVERMILE 1 6, ENSURING FISH PASSAGE EXTENDS AN ADDITIONAL ROUGHLY 4 8MI UPSTREAM TO AN EXISTING 67  PASSABLE CULVERT, THE ONLY OTHER BARRIER IDENTIFIED ON THE MAINSTEM OF LIBBY CREEK  THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PARTICULAR FUNDING REQUEST IS TO DEVELOP A 60  PERMIT READY DESIGN FOR THIS DIVERSION  CF WILL WORK WITH USBR TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL SURVEY OF THIS SITE AND THEN WORK WITH USFWS FISH PASSAGE ENGINEER, WDFW, AND THE LANDOWNER TO DEVELOP A CONCEPT TO TAKE THROUGH 60  DESIGN SURVEY WORK COULD BEGIN IN FALL OF 2022, ALLOWING DESIGN THROUGH 2023 AND POSSIBLE CONSTRUCTION IN 2024 OR 2025, DEPENDING ON THE SPEED OF THE DESIGN PROCESS AND PROCUREMENT OF ADDITIONAL FUNDING FOR CONSTRUCTION  FUTURE FINAL DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION FUNDING REQUESTS WOULD POTENTIALLY BE DIRECTED TOWARD SEVERAL DIFFERENT SOURCES, INCLUDING USFWS, THE TRIBUTARY COMMITTEES, THE PRIEST RAPID CONSERVATION COUNCIL, THE MCNARY FUND, OR THE SALMON RECOVERY FUNDING BOARD

THE UPPER KACHESS RIVER RESTORATION PROJECT WILL IMPROVE REARING AND MIGRATORY CONDITIONS FOR ESA LISTED BULL TROUT  UPPER KACHESS RIVER IS HOME TO AN ISOLATED AND GENETICALLY DISTINCT BULL TROUT POPULATION  THIS POPULATION S NUMBERS ARE LOW, AND THEIR SURVIVAL IS COMPROMISED BY IMPAIRED HABITAT, A RESULT OF HUMAN ALTERATIONS TO THE ENVIRONMENT THAT INCLUDED LOGGING, ROAD BUILDING, AND DAM CONSTRUCTION  AS A RESULT OF THESE IMPACTS, APPROXIMATELY HALF OF THE 2 6 MILES OF HABITAT AVAILABLE TO BULL TROUT IN THE UPPER KACHESS RIVER DEWATERS EVERY SUMMER DEWATERING NEGATIVELY AFFECTS BULL TROUT AT VARIOUS LIFE STAGES INCLUDING SPAWNING AND REARING JUVENILES  DEWATERING DIMINISHES THE CONDITION OF REARING HABITAT REDUCING THE CAPACITY OF YOUNG BULL TROUT TO GROW, RESULTS IN HIGH MORTALITY OF BOTH JUVENILE AND SPAWNING ADULTS DUE TO STRANDING IN DEWATERED STRETCHES, AND MAKES SPAWNING HABITAT INACCESSIBLE FOR WEEKS OR MORE AT A TIME RESULTING IN LOWER REDD NUMBERS AND REDD PLACEMENT IN LESS THAN SUITABLE LOCATIONS SUCH S THE RESERVOIR BED  GIVEN THE SMALL SIZE OF THE BULL TROUT POPULATION IN KACHESS RIVER, THESE IMPACTS ARE SIGNIFICANT TO THE SUSTAINABILITY OF THIS POPULACE THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO REDUCE THE TIMING AND DURATION OF DEWATERING ON 0 2 MILES OF KAHCESS RIVER  RM 0 7   0 9  AND WILL ENHANCE HABITAT SO THAT WHEN DEWATERING DOES OCCUR, THE CONDITIONS ARE MORE SUITABLE FOR BULL TROUT SURVIVAL  TO ACCOMPLISH THIS, WE WILL   CONSTRUCT 5 MID CHANNEL JAMS, 5 BAR STABILITY ROUGHNESS FEATURES, AND 2 BANK BURIED LOG JAMS  REVEGETATE 1 2 ACRES OF RIPARIAN AND UPLAND SITES  RECONNECT FLOODPLAIN TRIBUTARIES  MAGIC CREEK AND COLD CREEK

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO FACILITATE FISH MOVEMENT WITHIN BEAVER CREEK BY TREATING TWO IRRIGATION DIVERSIONS THAT ARE IDENTIFIED PASSAGE BARRIERS  BARRIERS 603181 AND 603183  THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO IMPROVE ACCESS TO APPROXIMATELY 3 6 MILES OF BEAVER CREEK BY SUMMER 2023 BY  1  REMOVING ONE OF THE DIVERSION FACILITIES FROM THE CREEK AND TRANSITIONING THAT IRRIGATION SYSTEM TO A GROUNDWATER SOURCE, AND  2  REPLACING THE OTHER FACILITY WITH AN IMPROVED SYSTEM THAT DOES NOT IMPEDE FISH PASSAGE AND PROTECTS JUVENILE FISHES FROM ENTRAINMENT AND IMPINGEMENT, WHILE MAINTAINING ACCESS TO IRRIGATION SURFACE WATER RIGHTS AND REDUCING MAINTENANCE NEEDS  THE PROJECT OCCURS IN TWO PHASES  DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION  THE DESIGN PHASE HAS ALREADY BEEN FUNDED AND CONSTRUCTION READY DESIGNS, A CULTURAL RESOURCES SURVEY AND REPORTING, AND PERMIT APPLICATIONS WILL BE COMPLETE BY THE END OF NOVEMBER, 2021  FUNDS IN SUPPORT OF CCNRD STAFF INVOLVEMENT IN THE IMPLEMENTATION PHASE AND PARTIAL FUNDING FOR WELL DRILLING ARE SECURED  THIS PROPOSAL SPECIFICALLY SEEKS FUNDING IN SUPPORT OF CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE IMPLEMENTATION PHASE  FOR BARRIER 603183, THIS REQUEST WILL SUPPORT DEMOLITION AND REMOVAL OF THE DIVERSION FACILITY  ROCK DAM, INTAKE PIPE, PUMP, PRESSURE TANK, POWER SUPPLY POST, ETC  , AND SEEDING MULCHING  PLANTING OF THE DISTURBED AREA  IT ALSO WILL PARTIALLY FUND DRILLING OF A WELL 250 300 FT FROM THE STREAM CHANNEL THAT WILL ALLOW THE IRRIGATION SYSTEM SUPPLIED BY THIS DIVERSION TO BE CONVERTED TO A GROUNDWATER SOURCE  OTHER THAN REMOVING THE ROCK DAM, WHICH WILL BE DONE BY HAND, NO OTHER IN STREAM WORK IS ANTICIPATED AT THIS SITE  FOR BARRIER 603181, THIS REQUEST SUPPORTS REMOVAL OF THE EXISTING FACILITY  REMOVING I BEAM ROCK DIVERSION DAM AND BACKFILLING EXISTING DIVERSION CHANNEL   RECONSTRUCTING AND RECONTOURING APPROXIMATELY 32 FT OF CHANNEL TO RESTORE NATURAL PROFILE AND PROVIDE FOR LONG TERM CHANNEL STABILITY AND SUFFICIENT DEPTH TO SUPPLY IRRIGATION INTAKE  INSTALLING A PRE CAST, VERTICAL PLATE SCREEN AND SUMP  AND SEEDING MULCHING AND PLANTING OF THE DISTURBED AREA  WORK AT THIS SITE WILL INCLUDE USE OF HEAVY EQUIPMENT IN STREAM AND ADJACENT TO THE STREAM, AND SOME MATERIALS WILL BE IMPORTED  STREAMBED SUBSTRATE, COMMON BORROW, ETC    THE FINAL DESIGN PACKAGE   THIS PROJECT IS ONE OF THREE CURRENT EFFORTS ON BEAVER CREEK THAT COLLECTIVELY ARE ADDRESSING FIVE REMAINING BARRIERS IN BEAVER CREEK  TOGETHER, THESE PROJECTS WILL PROVIDE FOR UNIMPEDED PASSAGE TO APPROXIMATELY SIX MILES OF GOOD QUALITY HABITATS  MOST OF THE BASIN   THIS PROJECT IS ADDRESSING THE TWO UPSTREAM MOST BARRIERS AND BENEFITS THE WATERSHED BY RESTORING UNIMPEDED ACCESS TO APPROXIMATELY 3 6 MILES OF SUITABLE HABITATS IN THE MIDDLE AND UPPER WATERSHED  BY REMOVING ONE OF THESE DIVERSIONS FROM THE CHANNEL AND CONVERTING THAT IRRIGATION SYSTEM TO A GROUNDWATER SOURCE THE PROJECT WILL ALSO BENEFIT IN STREAM FLOWS DURING THE SUMMER LOW FLOW PERIOD  BECAUSE IT MODERNIZES AND IMPROVES THE OTHER DIVERSION FACILITY BY PROVIDING AN UPGRADED SCREEN SYSTEM AND CREATING A FACILITY DESIGNED TO WITHSTAND HIGH DISCHARGE FLOW EVENTS, IT WILL ALSO ENHANCE FISH SAFETY AND MINIMIZE POTENTIAL FOR HABITAT IMPAIRMENT ASSOCIATED WITH CATASTROPHIC FACILITY FAILURE

THE CURRENT BRIDGE OVER THE SOUTH FORK TIETON RIVER ON THE TIETON RESERVOIR ROAD IS LOCATED IN THE TIETON RESERVOIR POOL  JUST DOWNSTREAM OF THE CURRENT BRIDGE, A WATERFALL WILL DEVELOP AS THE RESERVOIR IS DRAWN DOWN, CREATING A FISH PASSAGE BARRIER FOR BULL TROUT, A ESA LISTED THREATENED SPECIES  THE ORIGINAL COURSE OF THE RIVER WAS FILLED IN WHEN THEY CONSTRUCTED THE EXISTING BRIDGE  THIS PROJECT CONSTRUCTS A NEW BRIDGE ON THE ORIGINAL RIVER ALIGNMENT, WHICH RESTORES PASSAGE TO BULL TROUT OVER A LONGER MIGRATION WINDOW, BUT OTHER SPECIES AS WELL, RAISING OVERALL PRODUCTIVITY OF THE RESERVOIR

PROJECT WILL HELP TO   DECREASE SEDIMENT LOADING  DECREASE NITROGEN AND PHOSPHORUS LOADING  IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND FISH POPULATIONS  INCREASE UNDERSTANDING ABOUT THE POSITIVE IMPACT OF COVER CROPS OREGON SEA GRANT WILL LEAD A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT TO PRODUCE AN INVASIVE SPECIES RAPID RESPONSE AFTER ACTION REPORT THAT WILL DESCRIBE AND EVALUATE THE MULTI AGENCY RESPONSE TO THE DISCOVERY OF ZEBRA MUSSEL INFESTED MARIMO MOSS BALLS  MARIMO MOSS BALLS ARE A GREEN ALGA  AEGAGROPILA LINNAEI  NATIVE TO COOL, DEEP LAKES OF NORTHERN EUROPE, JAPAN, ICELAND, AUSTRALIA AND RARELY, NORTH AMERICA WITH MODERATE TO HIGH LEVELS OF CALCIUM, THAT IS FORMED INTO A SPHERE  BALL , COLLECTED FROM THE WILD, AND ARE POPULAR IN AQUARIUMS, WATER GARDENS, OR AS A DECORATIVE HOUSE PLANT  IN FEBRUARY 2021 A PETCO EMPLOYEE IN THE SEATTLE, WA AREA DISCOVERED THAT MARIMO MOSS BALLS IN THE STORE WERE CONTAMINATED WITH ZEBRA MUSSELS  DREISSENA POLYMORPHA , WHICH IS ONE OF OUR NATION S MOST COSTLY AND DESTRUCTIVE INVASIVE SPECIES, THREATENING ECOSYSTEMS AND INFRASTRUCTURE  ONCE ALERTED TO THE INTRODUCTION, INTERAGENCY AND INDUSTRY PARTNERS MOBILIZED TO A COLLABORATIVE INCIDENT COMMAND STRUCTURE TO IDENTIFY THE EXTENT OF THE ISSUE, ROLES, RESPONSIBILITIES AND REGULATORY AUTHORITIES TO STOP THE ADDITIONAL SPREAD, PREVENT ANY FURTHER INTRODUCTION, AND DEVELOP PROTOCOLS FOR DECONTAMINATION OF INTRODUCED SPECIMENS  THE INVASIVE SPECIES AFTER RESPONSE ACTION REPORT WILL USE A SWOT ANALYSIS  STRENGTHS, WEAKNESSES, OPPORTUNITIES, THREATS  TO  1  IDENTIFY AND CHRONICLE THE EVENTS AND ACTIONS TAKEN LEADING UP TO AND AFTER THE MOSS BALLS WERE DISCOVERED, 2  DESCRIBE ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF AGENCIES INVOLVED, 3  IDENTIFY GAPS IN FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATIONS, COMMUNICATIONS, AND OUTREACH AIMED AT PREVENTING THE INTRODUCTION AND SPREAD OF INVASIVE SPECIES, AND 4  DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPROVING COMMUNICATION CHANNELS, INFORMATION SHARING, AND POLICIES DIRECTED TOWARD PREVENTING INVASIVE SPECIES ASSOCIATED WITH ORGANISMS IN TRADE  OIT  FROM BEING INTRODUCED AND SPREADING IN NORTH AMERICA  THE REPORT WILL BE PRODUCED THROUGH DOCUMENT REVIEW AND STAKEHOLDER INTERVIEWS  OREGON SEA GRANT WILL PRODUCE THE REPORT IN COLLABORATION WITH THE NATIONAL SEA GRANT LAW CENTER AND THE NATIONAL AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES LIAISON FOR THE NATIONAL SEA GRANT OFFICE AND U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  THE NATIONAL SEA GRANT COLLEGE PROGRAM MISSION INTEGRATES RESEARCH, EXTENSION, EDUCATION AND COMMUNICATIONS THROUGH A COLLABORATIVE STAKEHOLDER BASED APPROACH TO ADDRESSING ISSUES THAT AFFECT OCEAN, COASTAL, WATERSHED, AND GREAT LAKES ECOSYSTEMS, ECONOMY, AND HUMAN HEALTH  WITH ESTABLISHED COLLABORATIONS WITH AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES TASK FORCE, NATIONAL COOPERATIVE EXTENSION, AQUATIC PET TRADE INDUSTRY, AND WITH EXPERTISE FROM THE NATIONAL SEA GRANT LAW CENTER, OREGON SEA GRANT HAS EXPERTISE AND IS WELL POSITIONED TO DEVELOP A SOUND ANALYSIS, AND PRODUCE FEASIBLE, ACTIONABLE RECOMMENDATIONS IN THE POLICY AND EDUCATIONAL ARENAS  BENEFICIARIES OF THIS REPORT INCLUDE AGENCIES WITH AUTHORITIES TO ADDRESS INVASIVE SPECIES THROUGH OIT, CHAIN OF CUSTODY INDUSTRIES, RETAILERS, FACILITIES, AND INDUSTRIES WHO WOULD EXPERIENCE INCREASED COSTS, SUPPLY DISRUPTIONS, COMPROMISED INFRASTRUCTURE, AND DAMAGED ECOSYSTEMS AS A RESULT OF AN INVASIVE SPECIES INTRODUCTION  THE REPORT WILL BE PRODUCED IN CONSULTATION WITH THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND DEVELOPED THROUGH ITERATIVE MULTIPLE FORUMS AND PRESENTED TO MULTIPLE STAKEHOLDERS AND AUDIENCES DESCRIBED ABOVE

THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES AND PARTNERS HAVE NOTED A MARKED DECLINE IN BROOK TROUT DENSITY IN THE NORTH BRANCH OF THE MANISTEE RIVER IN RECENT YEARS  IN ADDITION, DETERIORATION OF IN STREAM HABITAT AT FLOWING WELLS HAS BEEN OBSERVED  THIS PROJECT, SUBMITTED BY MICHIGAN TROUT UNLIMITED, WILL SEEK TO COLLECT THE DATA NECESSARY FOR THE IDENTIFICATION OF TREATMENTS NEEDED TO RESTORE IN STREAM BROOK TROUT HABITAT IN THE NORTH BRANCH OF THE MANISTEE RIVER NEAR FLOWING WELLS, IN KALKASKA COUNTY, MICHIGAN   DATA COLLECTED, INCLUDING CHANNEL SHAPE, RIVER SLOPE, SUBSTRATE, TEMPERATURE, AND LARGE WOOD COUNTS, WILL EVALUATE STREAM SHAPE AND HABITAT AS COMPARED TO A REFERENCE AREA TO AID IN THE CREATION OF AN IMPROVEMENT PLAN  IN ORDER TO IDENTIFY THE MOST APPROPRIATE TREATMENT PLAN, GEOMORPHIC ASSESSMENT  RIVER SHAPE AND STRUCTURE  OF THE SITE OF THE SITE IN ITS CURRENT CONDITION IS NEEDED TO DETERMINE WHERE DEVIATION FROM REFERENCE IS OCCURRING AND HOW THOSE DEVIATIONS CAN BE ADDRESSED  THE PRODUCT OF THIS WORK WILL BE A REPORT ON THE CURRENT CONDITION OF THE NORTH BRANCH AT FLOWING WELLS, INCLUDING A PLAN FOR IMPROVEMENT

THIS PROJECT INCLUDES IMPLEMENTATION OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL AT THE TAYLOR AND TALLAC CREEK ECOSYSTEMS, DEVELOPMENT OF PERMANENT WATERCRAFT INSPECTION STATIONS TO PREVENT INTRODUCTIONS OF HARMFUL AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES, DEVELOPMENT OF SPANISH LANGUAGE OUTREACH MATERIALS, AND COMMISSIONING A FEASIBILITY STUDY ON MARINA REDESIGN TO REDUCE HABITAT FOR AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES

THE CLAY CLIFFS NATURAL AREA IN THE CITY OF BIG RAPIDS, MI HAS ONE OF THE MOST SEVERELY ERODING STREAMBANKS IN THE MIDDLE SECTION OF THE MUSKEGON RIVER WATERSHED  THE BANK LACKS VEGETATION ON THE SLOPE, IS LARGELY DEVOID OF LARGE WOODY DEBRIS IN THE CHANNEL, AND POOL HABITAT IS BEING INUNDATED WITH SAND  THE BANK IS USED AS A FOOTPATH BY VISITORS AND DAMAGED CONSTANTLY  BY PROTECTING THE BANK WITH A FENCE, NATIVE VEGETATION, TOE STABILIZATION, AND INSTALLATION OF LARGE WOODY DEBRIS WE WILL ELIMINATE AN ESTIMATED 326 TONS OF SEDIMENT ENTERING THE RIVER AND WE WILL INCREASE HABITAT DIVERSITY FOR BOTH AQUATIC AND TERRESTRIAL SPECIES AND SPAWNING HABITAT FOR TROUT

THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  SERVICE , TAHOE REGIONAL PLANNING AGENCY  TRPA , AND ITS PARTNERS WORK TO PREVENT NEW INTRODUCTIONS OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES  AIS  AND TO CONTROL OR EXTIRPATE EXISTING AIS IN THE LAKE TAHOE REGION  TO PREVENT NEW INVASIONS, ALL MOTORIZED WATERCRAFT ARE REQUIRED TO BE INSPECTED, AND POTENTIALLY DECONTAMINATED PRIOR TO LAUNCHING IN THE WATERS OF LAKE TAHOE  SECTION 5 D  2  SUBPARAGRAPH B OF THE LAKE TAHOE RESTORATION ACT  LTRA  DIRECTS ALL ASPECTS OF THE WATERCRAFT INSPECTION PROGRAM, SUCH THAT THE INSPECTION AND DECONTAMINATION PROGRAM IS CONDUCTED BY TRPA THROUGH IMPLEMENTING ENTITIES WITH FUNDS AVAILABLE FROM A BROAD ARRAY OF SOURCES  FUNDS FROM THIS AGREEMENT WILL BE USED TO COMPLEMENT FUNDS FROM THESE OTHER SOURCES  THIS EXISTING PROGRAM FULLY SATISFIES THE REQUIREMENTS OF LTRA AND WILL COMPLEMENT OTHER CONTROL PROJECTS CONSISTENT WITH LTRA  IN ADDITION TO THE WATERCRAFT INSPECTION PROGRAM, CONTROL PROJECTS WILL BE PLANNED AND SUBSEQUENTLY PERFORMED IN THE LAKE TO KILL AND OR PHYSICALLY REMOVE INVASIVE AQUATIC PLANT AND FISH SPECIES, OR KILL INVASIVE MOLLUSKS SUCH AS ASIAN CLAMS  ADDITIONALLY, MONITORING OF AIS ON A LAKE WIDE BASIS, POST PROJECT SURVEILLANCE, AND EARLY DETECTION AND RAPID RESPONSE, IS CRITICAL TO PROTECT THE INVESTMENT OF THESE PROJECTS AND TO STRATEGICALLY PLAN FUTURE PROJECTS IDENTIFIED IN THE LAKE TAHOE AIS ACTION AGENDA  THE ACTION AGENDA PRESENTS THE FUNDING NEEDED TO IMPLEMENT AND OVERSEE PROJECTS TO ACHIEVE A 90  REDUCTION IN INVASIVE AQUATIC PLANTS OVER A TEN YEAR PLANNING HORIZON THAT STARTED IN 2021

BROOK TROUT OCCUR IN MANY OF THE HEADWATER STREAMS IN THE SIX MILE CREEK DRAINAGE  THE PROPOSED PROJECTS WOULD ADDRESS A LACK OF IN STREAM HABITAT AND OVERHEAD RIPARIAN COVER THAT IS ALLOWING THE SITES TO WARM DURING SUMMER MONTHS  WATER TEMPERATURES ARE A CONCERN FOR THE LONG TERM PERSISTENCE OF BROOK TROUT  THERE ARE TWO PROJECT SITES  ONE WOULD INVOLVE FENCING TO KEEP HORSES OUT OF THE STREAM ALONG WITH THE ADDITION OF IN STREAM WOOD STRUCTURES  THE SECOND SITE WAS IMPACTED BY A TORNADO THAT BLEW DOWN MANY TREES ALONG THE STREAM CORRIDOR  THE STREAM SUBSEQUENTLY DEGRADED CAUSING IT TO SHEET FLOW ACROSS A FIELD  THE PLAN IS TO RESTORE 1,500 LINEAR FEET OF IMPORTANT BROOK TROUT HEAD WATER HABITATION BY CREATING THE APPROPRIATE STREAM PATTERN, DIMENSION AND PROFILE AND ADD WOOD STRUCTURES  ROLLER LOGS AND ROOT WADS  TO IMPROVE HABITAT

THE WASHOE TRIBE OF NEVADA AND CALIFORNIA  THE TRIBE  IS A FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBE ORGANIZED PURSUANT TO THE INDIAN REORGANIZATION ACT OF JUNE 18, 1934, AS AMENDED  LAKE TAHOE IS THE HEART OF THE TRIBE S ABORIGINAL TERRITORY AND IS THE TRIBE S TRADITIONAL SUMMER HOME  I E , TRADITIONAL CULTURAL PROPERTY   ALTHOUGH NAMED IN THE LAKE TAHOE RESTORATION ACT  THE ACT , THE TRIBE HAS HAD THE LEAST AMOUNT OF OPPORTUNITY AMONG LISTED ORGANIZATIONS IN SETTING PRIORITIES FOR IMPLEMENTING THE ACT  THIS SITUATION IS UNFORTUNATE BECAUSE THE TRIBE HAS MUCH TO CONTRIBUTE WITH A FAR LONGER AND MORE SUCCESSFUL TENURE OF MANAGING THE LAKE TAHOE WATERSHED THAN ANY OTHER ORGANIZATION NAMED IN THE ACT  IN RECENT DECADES,  CHANGING ATTITUDES AND ASSUMPTIONS ABOUT LAKE TAHOE S ENVIRONMENT HAVE BOTH ENSHRINED AND DESECRATED ITS LANDSCAPE   LAKE TAHOE WATERSHED ASSESSMENT   THE SPREAD AND CONTROL OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES  AIS  AND THE EXTIRPATION AND REINTRODUCTION OF LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT TROUT  LCT  ARE EMBLEMATIC OF THESE CHANGES  THIS PROJECT PROPOSAL IS TO FACILITATE MORE ACTIVE PARTICIPATION OF THE TRIBE IN SETTING PRIORITIES FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF THE ACT AND OVERSEEING RESTORATION EFFORTS IN THE LAKE TAHOE WATERSHED, ESPECIALLY, RELATED TO AIS AND LCT

THIS PROJECT IS PART OF A LONGTERM PROGRAM TO ELIMINATE BARRIERS IN THE UPPER CLARK FORK WATERSHED FOR BULL TROUT AND WESTLOPE CUTTHROAT, WITH AN ANTICIPATION OF COMPLETION BY THE END OF 2023  THE PROJECT WILL REPLACE A DEGRADING, PRIVATE IRRIGATION DIVERSION TO REPLACE IT WITH A MORE NATURAL ROCKY RIFFLE FOR FISH PASSAGE AND INSTALL A FISH SCREEN IN THE IRRIGATION DITCH  THESE ACTIONS WILL CONNECT 30 MILES OF UPSTREAM HABITAT AND ELIMINATE ONE OF THE TWO HIGHEST DOCUMENTED ENTRAINMENT ISSUES FOR BULL TROUT AND WESTSLOPE CUTTHROAT IN THE WATERSHED

THIS REQUEST FOR FUNDING FOR THIS RESEARCH PROJECT WILL PROVIDE IMPORTANT INFORMATION TO GUIDE CONSERVATION ACTIONS TOWARDS MAJOR BARRIERS TO THE MOVEMENT OF STREAM FISHES BY RESTORING ACCESS TO FRAGMENTED HABITATS, ESPECIALLY FOR SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEEDS  SGCN   ANNUAL PROGRESS REPORTS AND A FINAL REPORT DETAILING THE EVALUATION OF FISH LADDERS AND FISH MOVEMENT THROUGH STEEL CULVERTS AT ROAD STREAM CROSSINGS IN NATURAL STREAMS AND FUTURE MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS WILL BE INCLUDED  THIS STUDY WILL ALSO PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR REDUCING FRAGMENTATION IN HIGH PRIORITY LOCATIONS WHERE CULVERT FISH LADDERS ARE NOT APPROPRIATE IN PARTS OF SOUTH DAHOTA

THE EEL RIVER OF NORTHERN INDIANA IS A 5TH ORDER STREAM WITH A WATERSHED AREA OF 827 SQUARE MILES  THE RIVER IS APPROXIMATELY 100 MILES IN LENGTH AND HISTORICALLY HAD 14 LOW HEAD DAMS  BY 2012, SEVEN OF THE 14 DAMS REMAINED  THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS WITH THE OHIO RIVER BASIN FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP, NATIONAL FISH PASSAGE PROGRAM, AND NATIONAL FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP, FOUR OF THESE LOW HEAD DAMS HAVE BEEN REMOVED AND WE HAVE INSTALLED A PROTOTYPE FISH PASSAGEWAY AROUND THE STOCKDALE MILL DAM  RM 32  THAT COULD NOT BE REMOVED  OVER 1,100 STREAM MILES HAVE BEEN RECONNECTED THROUGH THESE PARTNERSHIPS  FISH INDICES IMPROVED A MINIMUM OF 30  AFTER REMOVAL OF EACH OF THE FOUR DAMS, AND WE DOCUMENTED AN INCREASE IN SMALLMOUTH BASS NESTING AT EACH REMOVAL SITE ONE YEAR AFTER THE DAMS WERE REMOVED  IN 2020, FUNDING WAS SECURED TO REMOVE THE MOST DOWNSTREAM TWO DAMS IN THE EEL RIVER AT THE CITY OF LOGANSPORT  RIVER MILE 1   REMOVAL OF THESE DAMS OCCURED IN THE FALL OF 2021  FOLLOWING REMOVAL, THE ENTIRE EEL RIVER BASIN IS RECONNECTED FOR FISH PASSAGE  OVER 1,200 STREAM MILES  WITH THE WABASH RIVER THE GOAL OF THIS PROPOSAL AND NOVEL OPPORTUNITY IS TO DESCRIBE RECOLONIZATION OF AND USE OF HISTORIC HABITAT BY FISH THAT HAVE NOT HAD ACCESS TO THE EEL BASIN FOR OVER 100 YEARS  WE PROPOSE TO DOCUMENT THE RECOLONIZATION RESPONSE OF NATIVE FISHES BY ELECTROFISHING SIX MAINSTEM AND 20 TRIBUTARY HISTORIC SAMPLE SITES ACROSS THE BASIN  WE ALSO PROPOSE TO USE THE EXISTING BIOMARK PASSIVE INTEGRATED TRANSPONDERS TAG ANTENNA SYSTEM ALONG WITH TRAP NETTING AT THE STOCKDALE MILL DAM FISH PASSAGEWAY
