TROUT UNLIMITED PROPOSES TO REVEGETATE AREAS WITHIN THE LNFH INTAKE CONSTRUCTION AREA TO OFFSET IMPACTS TO UPLAND AND RIPARIAN VEGETATION DUE TO REPLACEMENT AND RESTORATION OF THE LNFH INTAKE FACILITIES  CONSTRUCTION BEGAN IN THE SPRING OF 2022 AND IS EXPECTED TO BE COMPLETED BY SPRING 2023  THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PLAN IS TO REVEGETATE, RESTORE AND IMPROVE RIPARIAN ZONE CONDITIONS OF ABOUT 0 71 ACRES OF USFWS LANDS ADJACENT TO THE LNFH INTAKE FACILITIES FOR APPROXIMATELY 700 FEET ALONG THE NORTH BANK OF ICICLE CREEK, NEAR LEAVENWORTH, WASHINGTON  LNFH IS REQUIRED TO REPLANT ALL TREES AND SHRUBS THAT WERE DESTROYED WITHIN THE CONSTRUCTION ZONE AT A 2 TO 1 RATIO  FOR EVERY ONE PLANT AFFECTED, TWO WILL BE REPLANTED   A BASELINE PRE CONSTRUCTION VEGETATION SURVEY OF THE INTAKE CONSTRUCTION ZONE WAS COMPLETED IN MAY 2022, WHICH WILL BE USED TO CALCULATE THE SPECIES AND QUANTITIES OF TREES AND SHRUBS TO BE REPLACED SUCCESSFUL IMPLEMENTATION OF THE LNFH INTAKE REVEGETATION EFFORT WILL BE CHARACTERIZED BY GREATER NATIVE RIPARIAN TREE, SHRUB, AND HERBACEOUS SPECIES COMPOSITION AND INCREASED STRUCTURAL DIVERSITY  AS NATIVE PLANTS GROW LARGER AND OUTCOMPETE NON NATIVE SPECIES, TREES AND SHRUBS WILL PROVIDE SHADE, COVER, AND HABITAT DIVERSITY IN THE RIPARIAN CORRIDOR ALONG CREEK WITHIN THE PROJECT AREA

THE IMPROVEMENT OF BAYNE ROAD CROSSING   FUNDING FOR ENGINEERING AND DESIGN PROPOSAL AIMS TORECONNECT 2 5 MILES OF INSTREAM HABITAT ON THE MAPLE RIVER BY REMOVING UNDERSIZED AND MISALIGNED CULVERT  THE BAYNE ROAD CROSSING IS PART OF THE MAPLE RIVER SYSTEM IN THE MUSKEGON RIVER WATERSHED  THE CROSSING IS SEVERELY UNDERSIZED AND PERCHED AND POSES A FULL BLOCKAGE TO FISH PASSAGE DURING MOST FLOWS  BECAUSE OF THE UNDERSIZED CULVERT, DURING HIGH RAIN EVENTS THE ROAD TYPICALLY OVERTOPS WITH WATER AND HIGH AMOUNTS OF SAND ENTER THE RIVER CHANNEL  THIS PROPOSAL AIMS TO FUND THE DESIGN AND PERMITTING PHASE OF THE BAYNE ROAD PROJECT  OUR OBJECTIVE AT THIS STAGE IS TO SOLICIT BIDS AND CONTRACT THE ENGINEERING AND DESIGN FOR ROAD CROSSING REPLACEMENT THE BAYNE ROAD CROSSING IS THE LOWERMOST OF THREE BARRIERS ON THE MAIN BRANCH OF THE MAPLE RIVER  THE BARRIER AT THIS TIME IS THE FIRST FOR FISH MIGRATING IN FROM THE MUSKEGON RIVER  THIS PROJECT WILL RECONNECT 2 5 MILES OF INSTREAM HABITAT IN THE MAIN BRANCH  AN ADDITIONAL 2 MILES OF INSTREAM HABITAT WILL BE RECONNECTED WHEN THE OTHER BARRIERS ARE REMOVED THE MAPLE RIVER IS A VALUABLE NATURAL RESOURCE AND PRIZED RECREATIONAL DESTINATION FOR THE COMMUNITY BECAUSE OF THE MUSKEGON STATE GAME AREA THAT MAKES UP THE LOWERMOST PORTION OF THE PROJECT AREA  THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE IN STREAM HABITAT AND CONNECTIVITY FOR A SUITE OF SPECIES INCLUDING SMALLMOUTH BASS  ONCE THE OTHER BARRIERS ARE REMOVED THE RIVER IS ANTICIPATED TO PROVIDE BROOK TROUT, BROWN TROUT AND STEELHEAD HABITAT AND GREATLY ENHANCE RECREATIONAL AND FISHING OPPORTUNITIES  PERHAPS THE MOST IMMEDIATE IMPACT ON AREA RESIDENTS WILL BE THE CAPACITY OF THE RIVER TO ACCOMMODATE HIGHER FLOW CONDITIONS WITH LESS FLOODING AND WATER CRESTING OVER THE ROAD  THE ROAD HAS BEEN OVERTOPPED BY WATER ON MULTIPLE OCCASIONS OVER THE PAST 15 YEARS BECAUSE OF THE HYDRAULIC CONSTRICTION PRODUCED BY THE UNDERSIZED CULVERT THERE ARE MULTIPLE PARTNERS READY AND WILLING TO WORK ON THIS PROJECT INCLUDING THE AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITY WHO USE THE ROAD, THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RRESOURCES, THE MECOSTA COUNTY ROAD COMMISSION, THE LITTLE RIVER BAND OF OTTAWA INDIANS AND THE MUSKEGON RIVER WATERSHED ASSEMBLY

THIS PROJECT IS A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN COPPER RIVER WATERSHED PROJECT  CRWP , ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND  GAME  ADFG , ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION AND  PUBLIC FACILITIES  ADOT PF , U S  FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS , BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM , DENALI COMMISSION, AND CHUGACH ALASKA CORPORATION AND WILL RESTORE FISH PASSAGE AT THE HIGHEST PRIORITY CROSSING IN THE COPPER RIVER WATERSHED  THIS PROJECT WILL REMOVE A DUAL CULVERT STRUCTURE, THE ONLY BARRIER AT THE BOTTOM OF THE LITTLE TONSINA DRAINAGE  THE LITTLE TONSINA RIVER IS A LARGELY PRISTINE, INTACT SUB DRAINAGE IN THE COPPER RIVER WATERSHED THAT SUPPORTS BOTH CHINOOK AND COHO ADULT AND JUVENILE SALMON POPULATIONS  CURRENTLY THE CULVERTS ARE BLOCKING UP AND DOWNSTREAM MOVEMENT OF JUVENILE FISH AND ARE A PARTIAL BARRIER TO MIGRATING ADULTS  THIS PROJECT WILL REPLACE TWO ADJACENT UNDERSIZED CULVERTS WITH A BRIDGE THAT HAS A SINGLE CLEAR SPAN OF AT LEAST TWO TIMES THE BANKFULL CHANNEL WIDTH AND WILL RESTORE CRITICAL CONNECTIVITY TO AN ESTIMATED 70 MILES OF UPSTREAM HABITAT

THE MUSKEGON RIVER WATERSHED ASSEMBLY  MRWA  HAS A PLAN PRIORITIZING REMOVAL OF TWELVE DAMS WITHIN THE MUSKEGON RIVER WATERSHED, INCLUDING THE ALTONA DAM  THE ALTONA DAM IS ONE OF OVER ONE HUNDRED DAMS IN THE MUSKEGON RIVER WATERSHED KNOWN TO DISRUPT THE ECOLOGICAL RESILIENCY AND FUNCTION OF ONE OF MICHIGAN S MOST PRODUCTIVE WATERSHEDS  ALTONA, LIKE MANY OF THE DAMS IN THE WATERSHED, IS OVER 100 YEARS OLD, NO LONGER SERVING ITS INTENDED FUNCTION, AND FAILING  BEYOND THE PUBLIC SAFETY RISKS, THE ALTONA DAM REMOVAL IS AN OPPORTUNITY TO IMPROVE THE ECOLOGY OF THE RIVER BECAUSE THE DAM IS IMPOSING MAJOR IMPACTS ON THE WATERSHED INCLUDING FRAGMENTATION OF HABITAT FOR BROOK TROUT AND OTHER AQUATIC LIFE, WHILE CONTRIBUTING TO WARMER WATER TEMPERATURES, LOWER DISSOLVED OXYGEN, AND DISRUPTION OF HYDROLOGIC FLOW  IN 2008, THE MRWA AND PARTNERS COMPLETED A COMPREHENSIVE STUDY OF THE WATERSHED AND FOUND THAT THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON MUSKEGON RIVER FISHES, AND THEIR HABITAT, WOULD BE DRAMATIC BECAUSE OF WARMER WATER AND MORE ERRATIC RIVER DISCHARGE  THE STUDY DATA SUGGESTED HYDROLOGIC AND WATER QUALITY CHANGES THREATENED TO REDUCE USEABLE HABITAT FOR THE ICONIC BROOK TROUT  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REMOVE THE HIGH PRIORITY ALTONA DAM AND BEGIN THE SYSTEMATIC APPROACH OF HABITAT AND CONNECTIVITY RESTORATION AND TO VIBRANTLY IMPROVEMENT CONDITIONS FOR BROOK TROUT AND OTHER AQUATIC LIFE  THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED WATERSHED WIDE THROUGH PROMOTING FURTHER DAM REMOVAL, ADDRESSING ECOLOGICAL IMPAIRMENTS, AND SHOWCASING SUCCESS AND LESSONS LEARNED FROM ALTONA DAM  SEVERAL OTHER FISH SPECIES WILL BENEFIT FROM THE REMOVAL INCLUDING BROWN TROUT AND RAINBOW TROUT THE ALTONA DAM IS A VELOCITY AND VERTICAL BARRIER FOR AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE IN THE SYSTEM  FURTHERMORE, COOL  AND COLD WATER HABITAT WITHIN THE LITTLE MUSKEGON RIVER HEADWATERS PROVIDE THERMAL REFUGIA  REMOVING THE ALTONA DAM WILL PROVIDE AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE AND CONNECT VALUABLE THERMAL REFUGIA THAT WILL SERVE TO SUSTAIN BROOK TROUT AND OTHER COOL COLD WATER SPECIES IN THE FACE OF CHANGING CLIMATE REGIMES  THE ALTONA DAM IS THE LAST BARRIER ON THE MAIN BRANCH OF THE LITTLE MUSKEGON RIVER AND THIS PROJECT WILL RECONNECT 4 2 MILES OF INSTREAM HABITAT IN THE MAIN BRANCH WITH AN ADDITIONAL  10 MILES OF INSTREAM HABITAT RECONNECTED IN THE EAST AND WEST BRANCHES OF THE LITTLE MUSKEGON RIVER THE LITTLE MUSKEGON RIVER IS A VALUABLE NATURAL RESOURCE AND PRIZED RECREATIONAL AND FISHING DESTINATION FOR THE COMMUNITY  THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE IN STREAM HABITAT AND CONNECTIVITY AND WILL ENHANCE RECREATIONAL AND FISHING OPPORTUNITIES  KAYAK AND CANOE USE OF THE SYSTEM IS HIGHLY VALUABLE AND REMOVING THE DERELICT DAM OPENS UP CONTINUOUS RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITY IN THE SYSTEM AND REMOVES A HAZARDOUS OBSTACLE  A CANOE AND ANGLING ACCESS SITE IS PLANNED FOR THE SITE

INDIAN CREEK IS IN SOUTHERN INDIANA WITHIN THE KARST REGION OF THE STATE AND JOINS THE OHIO RIVER AT RIVER MILE 657  THE STREAM HAS AN OVERALL WATERSHED AREA OF 256 SQUARE MILES AND THE WATERSHED AREA ABOVE THE CONFLUENCE WITH LITTLE INDIAN CREEK NEAR THE TOWN OF CORYDON IS 193 SQUARE MILES  CULTIVATED AGRICULTURE AND ACCOUNTS FOR NEARLY 62  OF THE WATERSHED LAND USE AND FOREST ACCOUNTS FOR 35  OF WATERSHED LAND USE  THE STREAM IS NOTABLE AS AN INDIANA OUTSTANDING RIVER AS DESIGNATED BY THE INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES AND IT IS A PRIORITY WATERSHED FOR THE NATURE CONSERVANCY BECAUSE OF ECOLOGICAL SIGNIFICANCE  INDIAN CREEK IS KNOWN TO HAVE HAD IMPORTANT AQUATIC SPECIES INCLUDING EASTERN HELLBENDER  CRYPTOBRANCHUS ALLEGANIENSIS  AND SALAMANDER MUSSEL  SIMPSONAIAS AMBIGUA   THERE IS ONGOING RESEARCH TO ASSESS THE POSSIBLE REINTRODUCTION OF EACH SPECIES  INDIAN CREEK HAD FOUR LOW HEAD DAMS CONSTRUCTED IN THE MAINSTEM OF THE STREAM  THREE OF THESE LOW HEAD DAMS WERE NEAR THE TOWN OF CORYDON AND A FOURTH DAM APPROXIMATELY 6 STREAM MILES UPSTREAM OF CORYDON  IN 2019 TWO DAMS OWNED BY THE TOWN OF CORYDON WERE SUCCESSFULLY REMOVED  REPORT AVAILABLE  AND IN 2020 THE MOST UPSTREAM  RAIGANS DAM  WAS SUCCESSFULLY REMOVED  THESE DAMS COMPROMISED FISH PASSAGE, STREAM ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY, AND WERE A SIGNIFICANT SAFETY HAZARD FOR HUMANS  THE CITY OF CORYDON, NATIONAL FISH PASSAGE PROGRAM, INIDAND DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, LAKE AND RIVER ENHANCEMENT, THE NATURE CONSERVANCY, AND ECOSYSTEMS CONNECTIONS INSTITUTE, LLC WORKED IN PARTNERSHIP TO REMOVE THESE THREE DAMS THAT PROVIDED OVER 5 KM OF STREAM HABITAT AND RECONNECTED NEARLY 550 STREAM MILES  ONE LOW HEAD DAM REMAINS IN INDIAN CREEK NEAR THE TOWN OF CORYDON  GUPTA DAM  THAT IS PRIVATELY OWNED  PERMISSION HAS BEEN GIVEN BY THE OWNER TO REMOVE THE DAM  REMOVAL OF THIS DAM WILL RECONNECT THE ENTIRE BASIN AND RECONNECT 571 STREAM MILES

AWARD PURPOSE  PROVIDE COORDINATION SERVICES FOR THE KENAI PENINSULA FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP  KPFHP , COMPLETEANNUAL ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE STREAM WATCH PROGRAM AND INVASIVE SPECIES WORK COORDINATION OF KPFHP WILL INCLUDE HOSTING A SERIES OF STEERING COMMITTEE MEETINGS, COORDINATION OF A SCIENCESYMPOSIUM, UPDATING KPFHP WEBSITE, AND GENERALLY KEEPING THE STEERING COMMITTEE AND MEMBERSHIP AWARE OF FISHHABITAT TOPICS  THE STREAM WATCH PROGRAM WILL MANAGE 70  VOLUNTEERS WHO STEWARD AND RESTORE FISH AND WILDLIFERESTORATION PROJECTS  THE INVASIVE SPECIES PROJECT WILL USE THE WATERBODY PRIORITIZATION METHOD DEVELOPED BYKENAI WATERSHED FORUM TO COMPLETE SURVEYS  ADDITIONALLY, EDUCATION OUTREACH USING THE ALASKA INVASIVE SPECIESPARTNERSHIP INVASIVE SPECIES COMMUNICATION FRAMEWORK THE BENEFICARIES INCLUDE FRESHWATER SYSTEMS THROUGHOUT THE KENAI PENINSULA INCLUDING THE REMOVAL OF INVASIVESPECIES THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO HAVE SUBRICIPIENT ACTIVITIES BEYOND HAVING UNPAID VOLUNTEERS ASSISTANCE WITHTHE STREAMWATCH PROGRAM ACTIVITIES

THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE DEGRADED OXBOW WETLANDS IN THE BOONE RIVER WATERSHED IN NORTHCENTRAL IOWA  OXBOWS ARE IDENTIFIED IN THE RECOVERY PLAN FOR THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED TOPEKA SHINER  TS  AS CRITICAL HABITAT  HOWEVER, MANY OXBOWS HAVE FILLED IN WITH SEDIMENT AND ARE CEASING TO PROVIDE YEAR ROUND HABITAT FOR TS  RESEARCH SHOWS THAT RESTORATION OF OXBOWS HAS PROVEN TO RETURN MULTIPLE BENEFITS FOR WILDLIFE  INCLUDING TS , WATER QUALITY, AND FLOODWATER STORAGE  FISH SURVEYS OF RESTORED OXBOWS SHOW HEALTHY POPULATIONS OF TS  AND 56 OTHER FISH SPECIES  AND DISPLAY EVIDENCE OF REPRODUCTION  WHEN PAIRED WITH SUBSURFACE TILE OUTLETS, RESTORED OXBOWS CAN REMOVE AN AVERAGE 42  OF NITRATE FROM WATER THE BOONE RIVER WATERSHED  BRW  PROJECT HAS ALREADY RESTORED 37 OXBOWS, BUT THERE ARE NEARLY 400 MORE POTENTIAL RESTORATION SITES  THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND LAND STEWARDSHIP WAS RECENTLY AWARDED A REGIONAL CONSERVATION PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM  RCPP  THAT BRINGS FEDERAL FUNDING FOR UP TO 40 ACRES OF OXBOW RESTORATIONS IN THE DES MOINES LOBE, INCLUDING THE BRW  THIS PROJECT WOULD LEVERAGE FUNDING THROUGH THIS GRANT BY PAIRING IT WITH RCPP FUNDS TO RESTORE EVEN MORE OXBOWS  THIS FUNDING WOULD ALSO HELP US TARGET THE RCPP FUNDING TO THE BRW, WHICH IS DESIGNATED AS A CRITICAL HABITAT LOCATION FOR TS  TAKING NO ACTION WILL LEAVE SOME TS WITH DEGRADED OR INACCESSIBLE HABITAT  TS SUFFER FROM A LOSS OF HABITAT IN A HEAVILY ALTERED LANDSCAPE  STREAMS HAVE BEEN STRAIGHTENED, WETLANDS DRAINED, AND OXBOWS FILLED IN WITH EXCESS SEDIMENT  ERODED AND INCISED STREAMS ARE NOW DISCONNECTED FROM THEIR FLOODPLAINS, PREVENTING TS FROM ACCESSING CRITICAL HABITAT THIS PROJECT, IF PAIRED WITH RCPP FUNDING, WILL RESTORE UP TO 5 OXBOWS IN THE BRW  EACH OXBOW IS, ON AVERAGE, 0 5 TO 1 ACRE IN SIZE, FOR A TOTAL OF UP TO 5 ACRES OF OXBOW HABITAT POTENTIALLY RESTORED THROUGH THIS PROJECT  THE PROJECT MANAGER WILL PROVIDE LANDOWNER OUTREACH AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR OXBOW RESTORATIONS

A PARTNERSHIP FOCUSED ON RESTORING AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE  AOP  FOR BROOK TROUT AND OTHER COLDWATER SPECIES IN THE NB OCONTO RIVER NEAR WABENO, WI IDENTIFIED THREE REMNANT LOGGING DAMS AS BARRIERS TO FISH PASSAGE IN 2016 AND 2017  SINCE THAT TIME, TROUT UNLIMITED  TU HAS WORKED WITH THE FOREST COUNTY POTAWATOMI COMMUNITY  FCPC , WISCONSIN DNR, US FOREST SERVICE CHEQUAMEGON NICOLET NATIONAL FOREST, FOREST COUNTY, THE TOWN OF WABENO, PROFESSIONAL CONSULTANTS, AND OTHER PARTNERS TO REMOVE TWO OF THE THREE DAMS THIS IS THE THIRD AND FINAL OF THREE REMNANT LOGGING DAMS IN THIS STRETCH OF OF THE NB OCONTO RIVER THE DAM CREATES A 2 8 FT VERTICAL DROP IN WATER SURFACE AND CONSTRICTS THE STREAM CREATING VELOCITIES IN EXCESS OF 3 7 FT S  CONSULTANTS ANALYZING IMPACTS OF THE DAM ESTIMATE THAT FLOOD IMPACTS TO THE AREA WOULD BE INCREASED DUE TO THE DAM CONSTRICTING THE STREAM AND DEGRADING ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THAT WOULD HELP MITIGATE POTENTIAL FLOOD DAMAGE  REMOVING THE DAM WILL INVOLVE PULLING THE EXISTING STRUCTURE FROM THE STREAM BED AND REMOVING THE ABUTMENTS THAT ARE CONSTRICTING THE CHANNEL  A REFERENCE REACH, AND UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM CONDITIONS, WILL BE USED TO RESTORE THE CHANNEL GRADE WHERE THE DAM HAS IMPACTED THE STREAM AND TO MATCH STREAK BANK SLOPES TO EXISTING REFERENCE CONDITIONS RESTORING AOP WILL RESULT IN THE RECONNECTION OF AT LEAST 5 MILES OF CLASSIFIED TROUT STREAM HABITAT THIS PROJECT IS A KEY COMPONENT OF THE NB OCONTO RIVER RESTORATION COLLABORATION STARTED BY THE FCPC IS AN EXCELLENT EXAMPLE OF HOW TRIBAL, PUBLIC, AND PRIVATE RESOURCES CAN BE EFFECTIVELY LEVERAGED TO IMPROVE AQUATIC HABITAT AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES  FUNDING THIS PROJECT PROPOSAL WILL HELP TO CONTINUE THOSE EFFORTS

THE WILLHITE ROAD HUZZAH CREEK CROSSING IS AN EXISTING LOW WATER CROSSING STRUCTURE THAT HAS A VISIBLE CONCRETE SLAB APPROXIMATELY 7  DEEP, 127  LONG, AND 13  WIDE WITH GROUTED RIPRAP  THE EXISTING CROSSING IS AN AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE BARRIER CAUSING SUBSTANTIAL STREAM MORPHOLOGY AND AQUATIC HABITAT DEGRADATION AND IS A SAFETY CONCERN TO MOTORISTS  THE EXISTING CROSSING IS ESSENTIALLY ACTING AS A DAM AND IS A BARRIER TO MIGRATING AQUATIC SPECIES  ON THE UPSTREAM SIDE OF THE STRUCTURE, AGGRADATION, STREAMBANK EROSION, AND OVER WIDENING OF THE CHANNEL ARE CAUSING SHALLOW WATER, WHICH LEADS TO A RISE IN STREAM TEMPERATURES DURING WARMER MONTHS  ON THE DOWNSTREAM SIDE, THE STRUCTURE IS CAUSING DEGRADING, STREAMBANK EROSION, AND OVER WIDENING  THE PROPOSED ACTIONS INCLUDE USING HEAVY EQUIPMENT TO REMOVE THE EXISTING STRUCTURE  THERE WILL BE INSTALLATION OF ROCK ALONG STREAMBANKS UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE NEW CROSSING AND PLACING PLANTING RIPARIAN VEGETATION ALONG THE STREAMBANKS AND OLD CROSSING LOCATION  THE NEW LOW WATER CROSSING WILL RESTORE AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE AND STREAM MORPHOLOGY RECONNECTING APPROXIMATELY 12 STREAM MILES IN HUZZAH CREEK  IN ADDITION, THE PROPOSED ACTIVITIES WOULD MITIGATE SAFETY CONCERNS AND REDUCE MAINTENANCE COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH THE WILLHITE ROAD LOW WATER CROSSING

THE AMERICAN WATER LOW HEAD DAM IS LOCATED IN THE EAST FORK OF THE WHITE RIVER HUC  051202060502  AT 7373 EAST REDDINGTON ROAD, SEYMOUR, INDIANA, 47274 OR APPROXIMATELY 450 FEET DOWNSTREAM OF THE NORTH COUNTY ROAD 725 NORTH BRIDGE  COORDINATES  LAT  38 985897 LONG   85 898632  THE CONCRETE PORTION OF THE DAM IS APPROXIMATELY 260 FEET LONG AND EXTENDS FROM RIVER LEFT TO APPROXIMATELY THE CENTER OF THE RIVER WHERE IT JOINS A LARGE WING STRUCTURE ABOUT 0 25 ACRES MADE FROM RIPRAP AND CAPPED WITH CONCRETE THAT EXTENDS AND ADDITIONAL 170 FEET NORTHWEST TO RIVER RIGHT BANK  THIS DAM IS NO LONGER NEEDED BY THE INDIANA AMERICAN WATER COMPANY AND IS CONSIDERED A SAFETY LIABILITY AND A SIGNIFICANT FISH PASSAGE BARRIER IN THE WHITE RIVER  REMOVAL OF THIS DAM WILL RECONNECT 836 STREAM MILES

OTTER CREEK IS A 3RD ORDER STREAM IN WEST CENTRAL INDIANA AND HAS A WATERSHED AREA OF 126 MI2  326 KM2   IN VIGO, CLAY, AND PARKE COUNTIES, INDIANA  THE STREAM IS APPROXIMATELY 24 MILES LONG  38 6 KM  WITH HEADWATERS NEAR CARBON, INDIANA AND JOINS THE WABASH RIVER AT RM 406  HOGGATT 1975 AND SIMON ET AL  2014   LAND USE ACROSS THE WATERSHED IS 43  DECIDUOUS FOREST AND 33  CULTIVATED AGRICULTURE  THE MARKLE MILL DAM IS THE ONLY FISH BARRIER IN OTTER CREEK MAINSTEM LOCATED AT RM 6 1  THE DAM WAS ORIGINALLY BUILT AS A WOOD CRIB DAM IN ABOUT 1816, BUT IT WAS RECONSTRUCTED USING CONCRETE IN 1910  THE DAM IS 215 FEET LONG, 09 FEET TALL AND 03 FEET WIDE AT THE TOP  THE FOUNDATION OF THE DAM IS ESTIMATED TO BE 08 FEET WIDE  REMOVAL OF THE MARKLE MILL DAM WILL RECONNECT 184 STREAM MILES AND RECONNECT THE ENTIRE MAINSTEM  WHILE THIS DAM HAS SIGNIFICANT HISTORIC VALUE, IT IS ALSO A MAJOR FISH PASSAGE BARRIER IN OTTER CREEK, A DANGEROUS DAM TO RECREATIONAL USERS OF THE STREAM, AND THE STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY OF THE DAM IS ACUTELY COMPROMISED  OTTER CREEK HAS HAD A LONG SERIES OF FISH SURVEYS DATING BACK TO DAVID STAR JORDEN IN 1885 WHERE 63 SPECIES WERE DOCUMENTED BETWEEN 1885 1886  SIMON ET AL  2014   MORE RECENTLY, J O  WHITAKER SURVEYED 60 SITES ACROSS THE OTTER CREEK BASIN OVER A 12 YEAR PERIOD  1962 1974   ONE OF THE 60 SITES WAS BELOW THE MARKLE MILL DAM  THERE WERE 57 FISH SPECIES RECORDED AT THE MARKLE DAM  WHITAKER 1974   A FISH SURVEY BY THE INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES IN 2006 RECORDED 30 SPECIES OF FISH BELOW THE MARKLE MILL DAM  THERE WOULD BE SIGNIFICANT ECOLOGICAL LIFT THROUGH REMOVAL OF THE MARKLE MILL DAM AND THIS INITIATIVE COMES FULLY SUPPORTED BY THE VIGO COUNTY COMMISSIONERS

THE WARM SPRINGS FISH PASSAGE IMPROVEMENT PROJECT WILL CONSTRUCT IMPROVEMENTS TO THREE WATER DIVERSION STRUCTURES ASSOCIATED WITH BUTTE SILVER BOW COUNTY S SILVER LAKE INDUSTRIAL WATER SYSTEM IN THE WARM SPRINGS CREEK WATERSHED TO PROVIDE FISH PASSAGE FOR NATIVE TROUT  FISH TRAPPING FACILITIES WILL BE CONSTRUCTED AT MEYERS DAM ON WARM SPRINGS CREEK AND AT A DIVERSION STRUCTURE ON STORM LAKE CREEK TO ALLOW MONTANA FISH WILDLIFE AND PARKS TO SELECTIVELY PASS ADULT MIGRATORY BULL TROUT UPSTREAM TO SPAWN WHILE MAINTAINING BARRIERS TO UPSTREAM MIGRATION OF NON NATIVE SPECIES  A FISHWAY AND TRAPPING FACILITY WILL ALSO BE CONSTRUCTED AT A DIVERSION DAM ON TWIN LAKES CREEK TO PROVIDE SEASONAL UPSTREAM PASSAGE FOR MIGRATORY NATIVE WESTSLOPE CUTTHROAT TROUT IN THE SPRING AND SELECTIVE PASSAGE FOR MIGRATORY BULL TROUT IN THE FALL WHILE MAINTAINING A BARRIER TO UPSTREAM MIGRATION OF NON NATIVE SPECIES  OVER 25 MILES OF UPSTREAM HABITAT WILL BE RE OPENED

OUR PHASE IV PROPOSAL BUILDS ON THE SUCCESSES OF THE PHASE I, II, AND III TO ADDRESS THE SIGNIFICANT LOSS OF WETLANDS IN THE WESTERN LAKE ERIE BASIN OF OHIO, MICHIGAN, AND INDIANA  PRIOR TO 1850, THE WESTERN LAKE ERIE BASIN WAS AN EXPANSIVE WETLAND COMPLEX MORE THAN 300,000 ACRES IN SIZE KNOWN AS THE GREAT BLACK SWAMP  TODAY ONLY ABOUT 12,000 ACRES  4   REMAIN  LOSS OF WETLANDS ALONG LAKE ERIE S WESTERN SHORE IS ALSO SEVERE  MORE THAN 95  OF THE ORIGINAL WETLANDS ALONG THE U S  SHORELINE HAVE BEEN LOST SINCE THE 1860S  THE CONDITION OF MANY REMAINING WETLANDS HAS BEEN DEGRADED BY EXCESSIVE LOADINGS OF SEDIMENTS AND NUTRIENTS, CONTAMINANTS, SHORELINE MODIFICATION, INVASIVE SPECIES, AND OTHER STRESSORS MORE THAN 90  OF THE WESTERN LAKE ERIE BASIN IS PRIVATELY OWNED AND 71  IS IN ROW CROP AGRICULTURE  HIGH COMMODITY PRICES CONTINUE TO DRIVE UPLAND CONVERSION AND WETLAND DRAINAGE, EXACERBATE ALREADY HIGH RATES OF HABITAT LOSS AND SOIL EROSION, AND CONTRIBUTE TO SEVERE WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS  THIS HAS ALSO LED TO POPULATION REDUCTIONS IN MANY SPECIES OF FISH, WILDLIFE, AND PLANTS, AND SIGNIFICANT WATER QUALITY ISSUES IN LAKE ERIE  HIGH RATES OF NITROGEN AND PHOSPHOROUS ENTERING LAKE ERIE HAVE RESULTED IN WIDESPREAD ALGAL BLOOMS, LOW LEVELS OF OXYGEN THAT STRESS FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC ORGANISMS, BEACH CLOSINGS, DRINKING WATER RESTRICTIONS, AND HAVE NEGATIVELY IMPACTED THE REGIONAL ECONOMY THAT IS LARGELY DRIVEN BY LAKE BASED RECREATION  IN NOVEMBER 2016, THE STATE OF MICHIGAN DESIGNATED ITS PORTION OF THE LAKE ERIE WATERSHED AS IMPAIRED  IN MARCH 2018, THE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND IMPAIRED WATER QUALITY IN LAKE ERIE BY RESTORING OR ENHANCING AT LEAST 293 ACRES OF WETLANDS AND 165 ACRES OF NATIVE WARM SEASON GRASSES IN THE WESTERN LAKE ERIE BASIN  THESE ACTIVITIES WILL BE IMPLEMENTED THROUGH PRIVATE LAND PROGRAMS ADMINISTERED BY THE U S  FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE S PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE, OHIO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, OTTAWA SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT, DUCKS UNLIMITED, AND PHEASANT FOREVER OBJECTIVES 1  RESTORE AT LEAST 293 ACRES OF WETLANDS, PRIMARILY PALUSTRINE EMERGENT AND OTHER NATIONALLY DECREASING WETLAND TYPES, ON PRIVATELY OWNED LANDS IN THE WESTERN LAKE ERIE BASIN 2  RESTORE AT LEAST 165 ACRES OF NATIVE WARM SEASON GRASSES WITH WILDFLOWERS ON PRIVATELY OWNED LANDS IN THE WESTERN LAKE ERIE BASIN 3  IMPROVE WATER QUALITY IN LAKE ERIE BY RESTORING HABITATS THAT HAVE PROVEN TO REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF SEDIMENTS AND THE NATURE CONSERVANCY IS REQUESTING A GRANT FROM THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE HAWAII FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP TO SCALE UP RESTORATION OF KA LOKO O KIHOLO  KIHOLO FISHPOND  IN COLLABORATION WITH LOCAL NON PROFIT ORGANIZATION HUI ALOHA KIHOLO  KIHOLO FISHPOND IS A VITAL ESTUARINE ECOSYSTEM ON THE WEST COAST OF HAWAII ISLAND THAT PROVIDES HABITAT FOR NATIVE FISH, BIRDS AND INVERTEBRATES, AND SERVES AS A NURSERY FOR CORAL REEF AND ESTUARINE FISH SPECIES  HAWAIIAN FISHPONDS SUCH AS KIHOLO ARE HIGHLY REFINED TRADITIONAL AQUACULTURE SYSTEMS AS WELL AS ESTUARINE ECOSYSTEMS THAT PROVIDE HABITAT, PROTECT COASTLINES, AND PROVIDE A SUSTAINABLE SOURCE OF SEAFOOD FOR THE COMMUNITY  THE HABITAT AT KIHOLO HAS BEEN DEGRADED BY A COMBINATION OF TSUNAMI DAMAGE, SEDIMENTATION FROM ORGANIC DETRITUS, AND NON NATIVE SPECIES THAT REDUCE AVAILABLE SPACE FOR NATIVE AND ENDEMIC SPECIES  OVER THE 18 MONTH PROJECT PERIOD FROM JULY 2022 TO DECEMBER 2023, THE NATURE CONSERVANCY WILL CONDUCT RESTORATION ACTIVITIES TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND HARD BOTTOM HABITAT UPON WHICH MARINE AND ESTUARINE FISH, INVERTEBRATES, AND THREATENED GREEN SEA TURTLES DEPEND  OUR OBJECTIVES ARE TO REMOVE INVASIVE VEGETATION FROM ONE ACRE OF ESTUARINE HABITAT, RESTORE ONE ACRE WITH NATIVE PLANTS, REMOVE SEDIMENT FROM 0 25 ACRES OF THE FISHPOND, AND ENGAGE 300 VOLUNTEERS THROUGH A SERIES OF NINE COMMUNITY WORKDAYS  WE WILL CONTRACT A PROFESSIONAL FORESTRY SERVICE COMPANY TO REMOVE LOGS AND BRUSH PILES CREATED BY TAKING DOWN LARGE TREES, AND CONTINUE OUR LARGE SCALE EFFORT TO REMOVE SEDIMENT FROM THE POND, WHICH EXPOSES THE UNDERLYING ROCKY SUBSTRATE, CREATING HIGHER QUALITY FORAGING AND SHELTER FOR NATIVE FISH  THE IMPACT OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE DEMONSTRATED BY OUR LONG TERM DATASETS ON VEGETATION, SEDIMENT, WATER QUALITY AND FISH, WHICH HELP US UNDERSTAND AND SHARE HOW RESTORATION EFFORTS CAN LEAD TO MEASURABLE IMPROVEMENTS IN HABITAT  THE HAWAII FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP HAS PROVIDED INVALUABLE SUPPORT OVER THE PAST DECADE TO CATALYZE AND ADVANCE RESTORATION AT KIHOLO TO ADDRESS THESE CRITICAL THREATS TO FISH HABITAT  NOW WE AIM TO INCORPORATE LESSONS LEARNED TO EXPAND THE PACE AND SCALE OF THIS WORK

THE  SCOTT RIVER TAILINGS STREAMFLOW AND ECOLOGICAL BENEFIT PROJECT DATA ACQUISITION  PROJECT WILL ADVANCE THE USFWS FISH PASSAGE PROGRAM PRIORITY OF ENHANCING AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE BY INTEGRATING AND STRATEGICALLY LEVERAGING SUBSTANTIAL EXISTING COLLABORATION AND FUNDING TO PLAN TO REMEDIATE FLOW RELATED LIMITING FACTORS FOR COHO SALMON  ONCORHYNCHUS KISUTCH  IN A 1 8 MILE REACH IN THE SCOTT RIVER TAILINGS  THIS PROJECT WILL ADVANCE OUR PARTNERS  AND REGIONAL STAKEHOLDERS  STRATEGIC RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES BY PROVIDING THE SCIENTIFIC BASIS TO IDENTIFY EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR A STREAM THAT CURRENTLY SUPPORTS THE LARGEST WILD COHORT OF COHO SALMON IN CALIFORNIA

THE FIRST 250  OF MIDDLE CREEK  CONFLUENCE TO HORSE CREEK  HAS THREE OBSTACLES TO ADULT COHO SALMON FISH PASSAGE  THESE THREE OBSTACLES ARE  1  A 2 1 4 FEET HIGH BOULDER WEIR  REMNANT FROM A HISTORIC DIVERSION SYSTEM , 2  A FREQUENTLY MALFUNCTIONING POINT OF DIVERSION, AND 3  A CULVERT THAT IS BADLY DETERIORATED  THESE THREE OBSTACLES ARE PARTIAL BARRIERS, THEY IMPEDE FISH PASSAGE AT CERTAIN FLOWS  CONDITIONS ARE WORST IN THIS 250  SECTION OF MIDDLE CREEK WHEN THERE ARE LOW FLOWS IN NOVEMBER AND DECEMBER, WHEN COHO SALMON ADULTS ARE TRYING TO SPAWN IN MIDDLE CREEK THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE CULVERT PROBLEM BY REPLACING THE CULVERT WITH A CONCRETE SINGLE SPAN BRIDGE REPLACING THIS DETERIORATING CULVERT WITH A BRIDGE IS IMPORTANT TO THE LONG TERM PERSISTENCE OF COHO SALMON AND STEELHEAD  THE BRIDGE WILL EASE FISH PASSAGE, PARTICULARLY FOR ADULT COHO SALMON TRYING TO ACCESS SPAWNING GROUNDS IN MIDDLE CREEK  THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE PUBLIC BECAUSE IT WILL INCREASE THE NUMBER OF RETURNING ADULT COHO SALMON, A THREATENED SPECIES  THE PUBLIC HAS EXPRESSED CONCERN FOR BIODIVERSITY BY SUPPORTING THE NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT ADDITIONALLY, A RELIABLE BRIDGE WILL BENEFIT THE PUBLIC  IN THE DECEMBER 2020  ENGINEERING REPORT MIDDLE CREEK CROSSING OF BAR ROAD AND  MIDDLE CREEK FISH PASSAGE  E AND  S ENGINEERS AND  SURVEYORS, INC  REPORT,  THE BOTTOM OF THE EXISTING CULVERT IS BADLY DETERIORATED AND COULD FAIL DURING A HEAVY STORM EVENT CAUSING BAR ROAD TO BE IMPASSABLE  ADDITIONALLY, THE BOTTOM OF THE CULVERT WAS INSTALLED UP NEAR THE STREAM FLOWLINE WHICH IS NOT OPTIMUM FOR AQUATIC SPECIES

SINCE 2001, THE SALMON RIVER RESTORATION COUNCIL  SRRC  HAS BEEN WORKING WITH OUR PARTNERS TO IDENTIFY AND MANUALLY TREAT BARRIERS TO ANADROMOUS FISH PASSAGE ON KEY TRIBUTARIES IN THE SALMON RIVER WATERSHED  LOW FLOW BARRIERS INTO THESE ANADROMOUS STREAMS AND TEMPORARY DAMS BUILT FOR FIRE SUPPRESSION OR RECREATIONAL PURPOSES WILL BE MANUALLY RECONSTRUCTED TO ALLOW FOR ADULT AND JUVENILE FISH PASSAGE  THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL IMPROVE JUVENILE AND ADULT SALMONID FISH PASSAGE TO APPROXIMATELY 20 TRIBUTARIES IN THE SALMON RIVER WATERSHED THROUGH MANUAL MODIFICATION OF ANTHROPOGENIC BARRIERS  THIS WORK IS ANTICIPATED TO OPEN AT LEAST 36 MILES OF STREAM WE REQUEST FUNDING TO COVER TWO SEASONS OF FIELD WORK  2023 AND 2024   THIS WORK IS SEASONAL AND IS NOT EXPECTED NOR INTENDED TO REMAIN AFTER ANNUAL WINDER FLOODING, BUT IT IS COST EFFECTIVE AND PROVIDES IMMEDIATE RESULTS TO THE FISHERY

THE UPPER BEAR RIVER DRAINAGE IN UTAH AND WYOMING IS A FISHERIES CONSERVATION PRIORITY FOR NATIVE FISHES SUCH AS BONNEVILLE CUTTHROAT TROUT, BLUEHEAD SUCKERS, AND NORTHERN LEATHERSIDE CHUB  IN THE MAINSTEM BEAR RIVER AND BEAR LAKE THE CUTTHROAT TROUT MIGRATE TO TRIBUTARIES TO SPAWN  REMOVING FISH PASSAGE BARRIERS ALONG THESE MIGRATORY ROUTES WILL ALLOW THE FISH TO ACCESS THE HABITAT THEY NEED TO COMPLETE THEIR LIFE CYCLES  THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS FOUR WATER DIVERSIONS THAT ARE FISH PASSAGE BARRIERS ON THE MAINSTEM BEAR RIVER OR TRIBUTARIES TO RECONNECT 44 7 MILES OF RIVERINE HABITAT  ALSO, AN IMPASSABLE CULVERT WILL BE REBUILT OR REPLACED TO ALSO FACILITATE STREAM RECONNECTION ON ONE OF THESE TRIBUTARIES  THIS WORK WILL ALSO IMPROVE HABITAT FOR 6,800 FEET OF THE BEAR RIVER AND RESTORE INSTREAM FLOWS DURING THE IRRIGATION SEASON ON 1 6 MILES OF A TRIBUTARY  ALL THESE ACTIONS ARE INTENDED TO IMPROVE THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF CUTTHROAT TROUT, WHICH WILL BENEFIT THE LONG TERM CONSERVATION OF THE SPECIES AND PROVIDE ENHANCED ANGLING OPPORTUNITIES  THE REBUILDING OR REPLACEMENT OF IRRIGATION INFRASTRUCTURE WILL ALSO BENEFIT WATER RIGHTS HOLDERS

THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE HABITAT FOR NATIVE BROOK TROUT AND OTHER NATIVE SPECIES BY RESTORING NATURAL RIVER PROCESSES AND RECONNECTING APPROXIMATELY 17 MILES OF UPSTREAM, COLDWATER AQUATIC HABITAT ON BEAVERTAIL CREEK BY REPLACING TWO IMPAIRED ROAD STREAM CROSSINGS ON SOUTH PRENTISS BAY ROAD IN CHIPPEWA COUNTY  THE EXISTING CROSSINGS DISRUPT FISH PASSAGE AND CAUSE EROSION PROBLEMS, ESPECIALLY DURING PERIODS WHERE THE CREEK OVERTOPS THE ROAD  NEW CROSSING STRUCTURES WILL BE APPROPRIATELY SIZED AND WILL MEET OR EXCEED BANKFULL CHANNEL WIDTH, PROVIDING AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE TO UPSTREAM HABITAT DURING ALL LIFECYCLE MOVEMENTS  A THIRD BEAVERTAIL CREEK CROSSING WILL BE REPLACED AT THE BEAVERTAIL CREEK STATE FOREST ROAD WHICH WILL ADD VALUE TO THE PROJECT, BUT FUNDING FOR THIS CROSSING REPLACEMENT WILL BE PROVIDED BY OTHER SOURCES

TROUT UNLIMITED, IN ASSOCIATION WITH THE SOUTHEAST ALASKA FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP  SEAKFHP  SEEKS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE THROUGH THE NATIONAL FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP TO CONTINUE TO SUPPORT COORDINATION SERVICES OF THE PARTNERSHIP AND TO IMPLEMENT PRIORITY ACTIONS FROM THE PARTNERSHIPS REVISED STRATEGIC ACTION DOCUMENTS INCLUDING THE 2017 2021 SEAKFHP FISH HABITAT CONSERVATION ACTION PLAN AND BUSINESS PLAN THAT WERE FINALIZED IN DECEMBER OF 2017 AND IS CURRENTLY UNDER REVISION THE SEAKFHP PROVIDES A VARIETY OF COORDINATION AND FACILITATION SERVICES TO OUR PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS AS WELL AS OTHER NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS AND INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS THROUGHOUT SOUTHEAST ALASKA  EFFORTS TO DATE HAVE LED TO FOSTERING RELATIONSHIPS THAT PROVIDE A GREATER LEVEL OF INFORMATION SHARING AND IMPROVED COLLABORATION WITHIN THE REGION  IN ADDITION, SEAKFHP HAS MATURED SIGNIFICANTLY AS A FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP AND IS SUCCESSFULLY LEVERAGING OTHER FUNDING SOURCES TO ADDRESS PRIORITY FISH HABITAT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES IN THE REGION  ADDITIONALLY, IN MAY OF 2021 SEAKFHP HAS BEEN INVITED TO PARTICIPATE IN THE NFHP PROJECT FUNDING REQUEST PROCESS NOW BEING ADMINISTERED BY THE NFHP BOARD PER PASSAGE OF THE ACE ACT IN OCTOBER OF 2020  PARTNERSHIP COORDINATION IS KEY IN PROVIDING SERVICES TO PARTNER MEMBERS AND WITH CONTINUED SUPPORT THROUGH FY22 NFHP OPERATIONAL FUNDING THESE SERVICES WILL REMAIN STABLE TROUT UNLIMITED CONTINUES TO SERVE AS A PARTNER MEMBER OF THE SEAKFHP AND PROVIDES THE FISCAL SPONSORSHIP TO THE PARTNERSHIP  CONTINUING TO GROW THE PARTNERSHIP AND FOCUSING ON THE DELIVERY OF HIGH QUALITY PROJECTS FOR THE REGION AS WELL AS PROVIDING ON GOING COORDINATOR SUPPORT IS THE BASIS FOR THIS FUNDING REQUEST

WHILE IT IS WELL KNOWN LOW HEAD DAMS ARE EXTREMELY DANGEROUS AND RESULT IN A CASCADE OF NEGATIVE ECOLOGICAL EFFECTS, REMOVAL OF DAMS IN INDIANA CONTINUES A SLOW UPWARD TRAJECTORY RELATIVE TO OTHER PARTS OF THE UNITED STATES  DAMS ALTER CHEMICAL, PHYSICAL, AND BIOLOGICAL ATTRIBUTES OF STREAMS RELATIVE TO STREAMS WITHOUT DAMS OR STREAMS WHERE DAMS HAVE BEEN REMOVED  THERE IS A GROWING BODY OF SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE THAT QUANTIFIES AND SUPPORTS THE ECOLOGICAL LIFT AND SOCIAL BENEFITS OF REMOVING LOW HEAD DAMS FROM STREAMS  OUR RESEARCH IN THE EEL RIVER BASIN HAS SHOWN A 25  TO 35  INCREASE IN FISH INDICES AND STREAM HABITAT INDICES AFTER FOUR DAMS HAVE BEEN REMOVED BETWEEN 2012 AND 2019  REMOVAL OF THESE FOUR DAMS RECONNECTED NEARLY 1,200 STREAM MILES  THESE INCREASES ARE GENERALLY FROM THE LOSS OF TOLERANT FISH SPECIES  LENTIC SPECIES  FOUND IN THE POOLS ABOVE DAMS THAT ARE REPLACED BY INTOLERANT SPECIES ONCE A DAM IS REMOVED  WE HAVE DOCUMENTED SIMILAR RESULTS FROM THREE DAMS REMOVED FROM INDIAN CREEK NEAR CORYDON AND REMOVAL OF A DAM IN SUGAR CREEK IN CRAWFORDSVILLE  WHILE SCIENCE PROVIDES STRONG EVIDENCE FOR ECOLOGICAL LIFT FROM DAM REMOVALS AND EVIDENCE OF IMPROVED RECREATIONAL SAFETY IS CLEAR, IT IS A LACK OF FUNDING OR THE SOCIAL WILL THAT IS LAGGING  COMMUNITIES OFTEN HAVE A VOCAL MINORITY WITH PASSIONATE HISTORICAL CONNECTIONS TO LOW HEAD DAMS AND OR A PERCEIVED DECLINE IN SPORT FISHING IF THE DAM IS REMOVED  IN EXTREME INSTANCES THERE IS A LACK OF EMPATHY TOWARD INJURIES AND OR DEATHS THAT RESULT FROM LOW HEAD DAMS  THE CHARLES MILL DAM IS A RUN OF THE RIVER DAM 350 FEET LONG AND 10 FEET TALL IN THE MISSISSINEWA RIVER AT MARION, INDIANA AT RIVER MILE 36  THE DAM WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 1936 AND IS CURRENTLY OWNED BY THE CITY OF MARION  THERE IS A TAINTER GATE ON RIVER LEFT INSTALLED TO CONTROL WATER LEVELS IN THE POOL, BUT THIS GATE LONGER FUNCTIONS AND ADDS SIGNIFICANTLY TO THE DANGER AT THIS DAM  THERE HAVE BEEN DEATHS AND INJURIES AT THE CHARLES MILL DAM AND REMOVAL OF THE DAM WILL IMPROVE FISH PASSAGE, SAFETY FOR RECREATIONAL USERS, REDUCE LIABILITY, AND PROVIDE AN ECOLOGICAL LIFT TO THE MISSISSINEWA RIVER

THE NORTH BURNT FORK CREEK RECONNECT PROJECT ON LEE METCALF NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE WILL REMOVE A  MAJOR PASSAGE BARRIER THAT HAS PREVENTED FISH MOVEMENT BETWEEN NORTH BURNT FORK CREEK AND THE  BITTERROOT RIVER FOR OVER 40 YEARS. THE PROJECT WILL REMOVE A PAIR OF STANDPIPES OBSTRUCTING AQUATIC  ORGANISM PASSAGE AND REPLACE THEM WITH A PEDESTRIAN BRIDGE, RECONNECTING 2.5 MILES OF CREEK HABITAT TO  THE BITTERROOT RIVER, WHILE VISITOR MAINTAINING ACCESS THROUGHOUT THE REFUGE'S ADA-ACCESSIBLE TRAIL  SYSTEM. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO ESTABLISH NATIVE TREES AND SHRUBS ACROSS 1/2 MILE OF NORTH BURNT FORK CREEK,  CURRENTLY DOMINATED BY INVASIVE REED CANARY GRASS. THIS HIGHLY VISIBLE PROJECT IS AN OUTSTANDING PUBLIC  OUTREACH OPPORTUNITY THAT PARTNERS WILL REALIZE THROUGH SIGNAGE, VOLUNTEER PLANTING DAYS AND PROJECT  TOURS.  NORTH BURNT FORK CREEK IS DESIGNATED BULL TROUT CRITICAL HABITAT AND ALSO SUPPORTS POPULATIONS OF NATIVE  WESTSLOPE CUTTHROAT TROUT, AS WELL AS WILD POPULATIONS OF BROOK, BROWN AND RAINBOW TROUT. THIS PROJECT  FALLS WITHIN THE FWS'S 2015 BULL TROUT RECOVERY PLAN STRATEGY (SECTION 2.3.1) AIMING TO "CONSERVE AND  ENHANCE BITTERROOT RIVER MIGRATORY POPULATIONS." IT ALSO SUPPORTS LEE METCALF NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE'S  COMPREHENSIVE CONSERVATION PLAN (2012).  FWS FUNDS WILL BE USED PRIMARILY FOR CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING SUBCONTRACTING FOR HEAVY  EQUIPMENT OPERATION, CONSTRUCTION OVERSIGHT, BRIDGE FABRICATION, BRIDGE INSTALLATION AND PLANTING. A  MINOR PORTION OF FWS FUNDS WILL BE USED FOR PRE-CONSTRUCTION ENGINEERING AND PERMITTING. MATCH FUNDS  WILL SUPPORT ENGINEERING, PERMITTING AND PROJECT PLANNING COSTS, AS WELL AS CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES.

THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE CONNECTIVITY FOR NATIVE TROUT IN MONTANA BY CREATING FISH PASSAGE AT ONE DIVERSION AND ONE CULVERT  THE PROJECT LOCATIONS ARE IN LONG TERM, CLIMATE RESILIENT PRIORITY WATERSHEDS FORBULL TROUT  SALVELINUS CONFLUENTUS , WHICH ARE LISTED UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE RECOVERY OF THIS SPECIES BY RESTORING COLD, CLEAN, COMPLEX, AND CONNECTED HABITATS  SPECIFICALLY, THESE PROJECTS WILL ADDRESS CONNECTIVITY AND INSTREAM FLOW CONCERNS IDENTIFIED IN THE COLUMBIA HEADWATERS RECOVERY UNIT IMPLEMENTATION PLAN THE NORTH FORK BLACKFOOT RIVER, DOWNSTREAM OF THE EXISTING DIVERSION POINT, GENERALLY SHIFTS TO SUBSURFACE FLOW  GOES DRY  DURING PERIODS OF LOW BASE FLOWS, CREATING A FISH PASSAGE BARRIER  THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE FLOWS TO OVER A MILE OF RIVER BY UPGRADING IRRIGATION INFRASTRUCTURE TO IMPROVE EFFICIENCY AND LEASING THE SALVAGED WATER SO THAT IT REMAINS INSTREAM  THE EXISTING HEADGATE FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE CLOSED AND THE LANDOWNER S IRRIGATION SYSTEM WILL BE UPGRADED FROM FLOOD AND WHEEL LINE IRRIGATION TO A WATER EFFICIENT SPRINKLER IRRIGATION SYSTEM  THE POINT OF DIVERSION WILL ALSO BE MOVED DOWNSTREAM TO THE SPRING CREEK  THE WATER SALVAGED BY THESE INFRASTRUCTURE UPGRADES  APPROXIMATELY 7 CUBIC FEET PER SECOND  WILL BE LEASED FOR INSTREAM USE BY THE BIG BLACKFOOT CHAPTER OF TROUT UNLIMITED TO BENEFIT BULL TROUT THE POORMAN CREEK PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A DESIGN TO REPLACE AN UNDERSIZED CULVERT WITH A NEW STREAM CROSSING THAT WILL ALLOW FISH PASSAGE  BOTH PROJECTS WILL BENEFIT BULL TROUT AND WILL CREATE STABLE DIVERSIONS INTO THE FUTURE FOR THE LOCAL AGRICULTURE AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, ARMORING THE LOCAL AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITY AGAINST POTENTIAL LOSS OF CROPS DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND CONTRIBUTING TO A STABLE ECONOMY IN THE AREA

CANAAN VALLEY INSTITUTE (CVI) WILL IMPLEMENT A BARRIER/DAM REMOVAL PROJECT ON THE LITTLE RIVER IN THE CLINCH RIVER WATERSHED. THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE PROJECT PLANNING, RIVER/STREAM ASSESSMENT, DAM REMOVAL FEASIBILITY AND ASSESSMENT, PROJECT DESIGN, PERMITTING AND COMPLIANCE, MONITORING, DAM REMOVAL AND FOLLOW UP STREAM RESTORATION/ENHANCEMENT, AND OTHER SERVICE DEEMED NECESSARY TO EFFECTIVELY DELIVER THE DAM REMOVAL/STREAM RESTORATION PROJECT AND IMPROVE AQUATIC CONNECTIVITY. TASKS INCLUDE 1 FISH PASSAGE BARRIER REMOVAL (LITTLE RIVER DAM), 2 MILES OF STREAM RESTORATION AND/OR STREAMBANK STABILIZATION, 5 ACRES OF RIPARIAN BUFFER ESTABLISHMENT. CVI PROPOSES TO COMPLETE THIS PROJECT IN COLLABORATION WITH USFWS PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM (PFW) AND USFWS FISH AND AQUATIC CONSERVATION PROGRAM (FAC). PFW WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO COMPLETE THE SCOPE OF WORK, INCLUDING STREAM DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT. CVI WILL COORDINATE DIRECTLY WITH USFWS PFW TO OBTAIN ALL REQUIRED PERMITTING AND ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE DOCUMENTATION TO IMPLEMENT THE PROJECT. IF DEEMED FEASIBLE, THE DAM REMOVAL WILL BENEFIT A MULTITUDE OF FEDERALLY LISTED ENDANGERED/THREATENED SPECIES AND VIRGINIA SGCN. THE IMPLEMENTATION OF STREAM RESTORATION AND RIPARIAN BUFFER ACTIVITIES WILL BENEFIT NUMEROUS FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES AS WELL AS VIRGINIA SGCN, MIGRATORY BIRDS, AND RIPARIAN OBLIGATE SPECIES.

THIS PROJECT WILL ESTIMATE THE ABUNDANCE OF JUVENILE SOCKEYE SALMON REARING IN HEWITT LAKE IN THE FALL OF THE YEAR  THE ABUNDANCE OF JUVENILE SOCKEYE SALMON WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY USE OF UNDERWATER HYDROACOUSTIC POPULATION SURVEY AND MIDWATER TRAWL FISHING TECHNIQUES  THIS PROJECT WILL DOVETAIL AND LEVERAGE THE COOK INLET AQUACULTURE ASSOCIATION  CIAA  PROPOSED PROJECT  AKSSF  TO CONTINUE SUPPRESSION OF INVASIVE NORTHERN PIKE  ESOX LUCIUS  POPULATIONS IN HEWITT AND WHISKEY LAKES AND THE HEWITT WHISKEY CREEK OUTLET THAT CONNECTS THESE LAKES TO THE YENTNA RIVER  HEWITT AND WHISKEY LAKES SUPPORT POPULATIONS OF SOCKEYE SALMON  ONCORHYNCHUS NERKA , AS WELL AS CHINOOK  O  TSHAWYTSCHA , COHO  O  KISUTCH , CHUM  O  KETA  AND PINK  O  GORBUSCHA  SALMON  NORTHERN PIKE REMOVED WILL DECREASE PREDATION ON JUVENILE SOCKEYE SALMON INHABITING HEWITT LAKE THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE WORK FUNDED BY THE ALASKA SUSTAINABLE SALMON FUND AND CONDUCTED BY CIAA, ADFAND G AND THE USGS THAT INVESTIGATED NORTHERN PIKE SUPPRESSION METHODS IN THE HEWITT, WHISKEY AND CHELATNA LAKES  SMUKALL 2015B

THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME  ADFAND G  ANADROMOUS WATERS CATALOG  AWC  IS AN INVENTORY OF FRESHWATER HABITATS USED BY ANADROMOUS FISH SPECIES  THOSE THAT USE BOTH FRESHWATER AND MARINE WATERBODIES TO COMPLETE THEIR LIFE STAGES  AND PROVIDED PROTECTIONS UNDER STATE OF ALASKA LAW  ANY ACTIVITIES IN ANADROMOUS WATERBODIES REQUIRES PRIOR NOTIFICATION AND PERMIT APPROVAL FROM ADFAND G  THE MATANUSKA SUSITNA  MAT SU  FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP HAS IDENTIFIED THE PRIORITIZATION OF STREAMS FOR NOMINATION TO THE AWC AN IMPORTANT DATA GAP FOR THE PROTECTION AND CONSERVATION OF FISH HABITAT  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE THE EFFICIENCY AND ACCURACY OF STREAM SURVEYS IN ROADLESS AREAS OF THE MAT SU BASIN FOR NOMINATIONS TO THE AWC BY BUILDING A STATISTICAL MODEL OF POTENTIAL JUVENILE SALMON HABITAT ACROSS THE MAT SU BASIN THAT CAN BE USED TO PRIORITIZE AWC SURVEYS FOR THIS PROJECT, UAA WILL BUILD AN ENSEMBLE MODEL OF JUVENILE SALMON HABITAT FOR THE MAT SU BASIN  ENSEMBLE MODELS INCLUDE PREDICTIONS FROM SEVERAL MODELS TO INCREASE MODEL ACCURACY  DATA INPUTS TO THE MODEL WILL INCLUDE THE NEWLY DEVELOPED NHDPLUS FOR THE MAT SU AND JUVENILE SALMON OCCURRENCE LOCATIONS FROM THE ADFAND G ALASKA FRESHWATER FISH INVENTORY  AFFI   THE AFFI CONTAINS OVER 1,800 SURVEY POINTS IN THE MAT SU BASIN DOCUMENTING SALMON PRESENCE OR ABSENCE THAT WILL BE USED AS INPUTS TO THE MODELS  THE NHDPLUS IS A NEW HYDROGRAPHY PRODUCT THAT LINKS SURROUNDING CATCHMENTS TO STREAM REACHES AND CAN BE USED TO GENERATE IMPORTANT HABITAT VARIABLES FOR MODELING SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS  THE COMBINATION OF HIGH QUALITY HYDROGRAPHY DATA AND A HIGH DENSITY OF FISH SURVEY DATA MAKES THE MAT SU BASIN AN IDEAL REGION FOR DEVELOPING DISTRIBUTION MODELS FOR JUVENILE SALMON HABITAT THAT CAN BE USED TO PRIORITIZE WATERSHEDS FOR ANADROMOUS STREAM SURVEYS AFTER MODEL DEVELOPMENT, STREAM SURVEYS WILL BE USED TO ASSESS MODEL PERFORMANCE AND ADAPT THE MODEL TO INCLUDE ADDITIONAL DATA  FINAL MODEL PREDICTIONS WILL BE PROVIDED AS SEARCHABLE MAP PRODUCTS ACCESSIBLE ON ARCGIS ONLINE TO INCREASE THEIR AVAILABILITY AND USE FOR STREAM SURVEYS  THE FINAL REPORT WILL INCLUDE A PRIORITIZATION OF WATERSHEDS FOR STREAM SURVEYS  USING 12 DIGIT USGS HYDROLOGIC UNIT CODES  PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE 1  CREATING A DATABASE OF TOPOGRAPHIC AND CLIMATIC ATTRIBUTES FOR ALL STREAM REACHES IN THE NHDPLUS FOR THE MAT SU BASIN, 2  BUILDING A SUITE OF SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELS FOR JUVENILE SALMONIDS ACROSS THE MAT SU BASIN, 3  MAPPING PREDICTED PROBABILITIES OF SUITABLE HABITAT FOR JUVENILE SALMONIDS USING AN ENSEMBLE OF SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELS AND CREATE PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE MAP PRODUCTS ON ARCGIS ONLINE, 4  VALIDATING PREDICTED HABITATS IN SUMMER 2023 USING A ROAD BASED FIELD SURVEY, AND 5  DOCUMENTING ALL METHODS AND RESULTS IN A FINAL REPORT THAT THAT INCLUDES A PRIORITIZATION OF BASINS FOR STREAM SURVEYS TO INCREASE NOMINATIONS IN THE ANADROMOUS WATERS CATALOG ACROSS THE MAT SU BASIN PROJECT OUTREACH WILL INCLUDE DEVELOPING MAP PRODUCTS PUBLISHED TO ARCGIS ONLINE WHERE FIELD BIOLOGISTS CAN LOCATE AND PLAN STREAM SURVEYS TO INCREASE NOMINATIONS TO THE ANADROMOUS WATERS CATALOG  ALL DATA USED FOR MODELING AND FINAL MODEL OUTPUTS  SPATIAL DATASETS  WILL BE PUBLISHED TO THE ACCS DATA CATALOG  ACCSCATALOG UAA ALASKA EDU  ALL PROJECT RESULTS WILL BE PRESENTED AT THE MAT SU SCIENCE SYMPOSIUM

TYONEK TRIBAL CONSERVATION DISTRICT  TTCD  REPRESENTS A LARGE LAND BASE IN SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA ON WESTERN COOK INLET THAT CONTAINS A NETWORK OF BOTH FISH BEARING STREAMS AND ROADS, WHICH OFTEN INTERSECT  SINCE 2012, TTCD HAS WORKED CLOSELY WITH THE US FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE TO ADDRESS BARRIERS TO FISH PASSAGE, RESULTING IN 10 SUCCESSFUL CULVERT REPLACEMENTS AS OF 2020  THE BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE SEVERAL SPECIES OF ANADROMOUS FISH WITHIN TTCD  SALMON IS A PRIMARY SUBSISTENCE RESOURCE FOR TYONEK  THE DISTRICT CONTAINS OVER 30 CULVERTS ON KEY RIVER SYSTEMS WITH SEVERAL DEFINED AS IMPASSABLE, INCLUDING THE CULVERTS AT THE PROPOSED PROJECT SITES  THEREFORE, ADDRESSING FISH PASSAGE BARRIERS IS A PRIMARY CONCERN FOR TTCD AND THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF TYONEK  NVT   ADDRESSING FISH PASSAGE IS OUTLINED IN TTCD S WATERSHED ACTION PLAN AS A PRIMARY CONCERN, AS WELL AS NVT S LONG TERM ENVIRONMENTAL PLAN  WITH THIS PROJECT, TTCD PLANS TO COMPLETE THE DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF THE TYONEK CREEK CULVERT LISTED AT THE HEAD OF THEIR PRIORITY LIST  AK DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME  20601540   WITHIN THIS AGREEMENT, TTCD WILL FACILITATE THE COMPLETION OF ARCHITECTURAL AND ENGINEERING WORK, MANAGE THE RFP FOR CONSTRUCTION, AND WORK TOGETHER WITH USFWS TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND CONDUCT SITE VISITS

THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE SEVEN ACRES OF RIPARIAN AREA ADJACENT TO A HISTORIC AUWAI  FRESHWATER CHANNEL  THAT RUNS ALONG THE NORTHERN PORTION OF ALAKOKO FISHPOND ON THE ISLAND OF KAUAI  THE GOAL OF THE RESTORATION WORK IS TO RESTORE BOTH THE NATURAL WATERCOURSE AND THE CONTIGUOUS ANCIENT HAWAIIAN WATER SYSTEM THAT WAS EXPOSED AS A RESULT OF ONGOING INVASIVE TREE REMOVAL  RESTORATION OF THE CHANNEL AND RIPARIAN AREA ALONG THE AUWAI WILL IMPROVE HYDROLOGIC FUNCTION, RESTORE PHYSICAL HABITAT FOR NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES, IMPROVE WATER QUALITY, INCREASE FRESHWATER FLOW AND INCREASE CHANNEL CAPACITY  THE MAIN ACTIVITIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE REMOVAL OF INVASIVE VEGETATION  GRASS AND LOW LYING SHRUBS , REMOVAL OF ORGANIC DEBRIS AND SEDIMENTATION FROM THE CHANNEL, SITE PREPARATION AND PLANTING OF NATIVE AND TRADITIONAL HAWAIIAN PLANTS AND COORDINATING VOLUNTEER PARTICIPATION IN THE PROJECT  THE IMPROVED AQUATIC HABITATS WILL INCREASE PRODUCTION OF CULTURALLY AD RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT FISHERY SPECIES AND WILL BENEFIT NATIVE HAWAIIAN SUBSISTENCE USE AND RECREATIONAL USE OF THESE AQUATIC RESOURCES

THE HOONAH INDIAN ASSOCIATION IS A MEMBER OF THE HOONAH NATIVE FOREST PARTNERSHIP  THROUGH THE PARTNERSHIP WE HAVE TRAINED A LOCAL WORKFORCE TO IMPLEMENT STREAM RESTORATION   TO DATE OUR LOCAL CREWS HAVE COMPLETED RESTORATION ON THREE STREAMS WITH A 4TH PLANNED IN 2021 IN THE SPASSKI WATERSHED  OUR PROPOSAL WOULD RESTORE  180 METERS OF STREAM IN THE HUMPBACK CREEK WATERSHED THAT IS NOT FUNCTIONING PROPERLY AND HAS A DOWNWARD TREND INFUNCTION  PAST TIMBER HARVEST ALONG THE RIPARIAN AREA HAS REDUCED THE NUMBER OF TREES AVAILABLE FOR INSTREAM WOOD THAT IS IMPORTANT TO THE FUNCTION OF THE STREAM, THE CONDITION FOR FISH HABITATS AND THE RESILIENCE TO CHANGING CLIMATE  THE RESTORATION WILL ENHANCE CHANNEL COMPLEXITY INCREASING SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT FOR COHO, CHUM, AND PINK SALMON  THE PROJECT WILL ALSO DESIGN A NEW FISH PASSAGE STRUCTURE AT THE SITE  THE CURRENT STRUCTURE IS FAILING AND MAY BE DETRIMENTAL TO FISH HABITAT AND PASSAGE WHEN IT FAILS  WE ARE REQUESTING  69,721 DOLLARS TO SUPPORT THIS PROJECT

THIS PROJECT IN GUSTAVUS, ALASKA, WILL REPLACE A PERCHED CULVERT THAT CARRIES HARRY HALL CREEK UNDER GRANDPA S FARM ROAD  THE CULVERT HAS BECOME PERCHED DUE TO ISOSTATIC REBOUND, WHICH HAS CAUSED THE STREAM TO CUT DEEPER INTO THE LANDSCAPE  THE APPROXIMATELY FIVE MILE LONG HARRY HALL CREEK AND MOUNTAIN VIEW STREAM HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED BY THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME AS VALUABLE SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT FOR COHO SALMON  THE STREAM ALSO SUPPORTS POPULATIONS OF SPAWNING PINK SALMON, DOLLY VARDEN CHAR, AND CUTTHROAT TROUT  THE PERCHED CULVERT IS A BARRIER ESPECIALLY FOR REARING COHO SALMON FRY  THE EXISTING CULVERT CROSSING IS UNGUARDED AND IS A TRAFFIC HAZARD  PROJECT DELIVERABLES INCLUDE REPLACING THE EXISTING CULVERT WITH A TIMBER BRIDGE  A SMALL SECTION OF THE DOWNSTREAM REACH WILL BE REDIRECTED TO MORE NATURALLY AND EFFICIENTLY CONVEY FLOW IN A MANNER THAT ALLEVIATES CURRENT BANK EROSION  THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS WORK WILL ALLOW THE STREAM TO CUT DEEPER WITH ISOSTATIC REBOUND INTO THE FUTURE WITHOUT CREATING A NEW FISH PASSAGE BARRIER  IN ADDITION TO IMPROVING HABITAT ACCESS FOR SALMONID FISHES, THE PROJECT ELIMINATES THE TRAFFIC HAZARD ON A ROAD LEADING TO RESIDENTIAL SUBDIVISIONS AND SERVING A MAJOR TOURIST LODGE  THIS IS THE EIGHTH PROJECT IN A SERIES TO REMOVE CULVERT FISH PASSAGE BARRIERS AND INSTALL ROAD OR WALKING BRIDGES FOR ANADROMOUS FISH STREAMS IN GUSTAVUS

THE BRISTOL BAY HERITAGE LAND TRUST  BBHLT  PROPOSES TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR THE BRISTOL BAY RIVER, FLY FISHING AND  GUIDE ACADEMY  ACADEMY  A ONE WEEK RIVERSIDE TRAINING PROGRAM HELD EACH YEAR AT A FISHING LODGE IN BRISTOL BAY  THE ACADEMY IS ONE OF THE MOST SUCCESSFUL SALMON AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS IN ALASKA  BBHLT WITH PARTNERS TROUT UNLIMITED AND BRISTOL BAY NATIVE CORPORATION WILL RECRUIT YOUTH FROM THE BRISTOL BAY REGION, SECURE A FISHING LODGE LOCATION, RECRUIT VOLUNTEER INSTRUCTORS, AND MAKE TRAVEL ARRANGEMENTS FOR ALL PARTICIPANTS AND INSTRUCTORS  THE ACADEMY IS DESIGNED TO PREPARE THE NEXT GENERATION OF COMMUNITY LEADERS IN WITH THE KNOWLEDGE, VALUES AND SKILLS NECESSARY TO PURSUE OPPORTUNITIES IN THE BRISTOL BAY LODGE INDUSTRY AND UNIQUELY ENGAGE IN SALMON CONSERVATION ISSUES IN THEIR COMMUNITIES, VILLAGE CORPORATIONS AND ON ADJACENT PUBLIC LANDS

THE PARTNERSHIP STRATEGICCONSERVATION PLAN IDENTIFIED THE LEGAL FRAGMENTATION OF LAND AS A MAJOR THREAT TO THE FRAGMENTATION OFSALMON HABITAT  SOME 7 MILLION ACRES OF LAND IN SOUTHWEST ALASKA, MUCH OF IT ENCOMPASSING RICH SALMONHABITAT, IS PRIVATELY OWNED BY VILLAGE CORPORATIONS FORMED UNDER THE ALASKA NATIVE CLAIMS SETTLEMENT ACT ANCSA   WATERSHED PLANNING IDENTIFYING SALMON AND FRESHWATER FISH HABITAT AND DETERMINING HOW MUCHIS SUBJECT TO PRIVATE OWNERSHIP IS KEY TO CONSERVATION PLANNING FOR A WATERSHED  THIS PROJECT WILL HELP THEVILLAGE CORPORATIONS AND THE APPLICANT BBHLT IDENTIFY LOCATIONS FOR POSSIBLE FUTURE PROTECTION WITHCONSERVATION EASEMENTS  THE INITIAL FOCUS OF THE PROJECT WILL BE THE CHIGNIK REGION OF THE ALASKAPENINSULA, AND MAY EXTEND TO OTHER LOCATIONS WITHIN THE PARTNERSHIP SERVICE AREA THE PROJECT WILL REQUIRE ASSEMBLING DATA FROM A VARIETY OF SOURCES AND ENGAGING WITH LEADERS AND KNOWLEDGEABLE PERSONS PROVIDED BY LOCAL TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS AND VILLAGE CORPORATIONS TO REVIEW THE ASSESSMENT PROCESS AND DETERMINE DATA GAPS ESPECIALLY WITH RESPECT TO TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE  THE DELIVERABLES FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE A SERIES OF DIGITAL AND PRINTED POSTER MAPS AS WELL AS APPLICABLE GIS DATASETS FOR ALL LANDS WITHIN THE SUBREGION OCCUPIED BY NATIVE VILLAGE  THESE MAPS WILL CONTAIN HABITAT AND RESOURCE FEATURES, THE LOCATION OF TRADITIONAL SUBSISTENCE AND CULTURAL SITES AND PLACE NAMES  IN ADDITION, FOR PRIVATE LANDS WITHIN THE SUBREGION, THE MAPS WILL DESIGNATE THE CONSERVATION VALUE OF LANDS ON A SECTIONAL BASIS

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO RENOVATE AND RESTORE A DESERT FISH HABITAT THAT WILL SERVE AS REFUGE FOR POPULATIONS OF ROUND TAIL CHUB AND LONGFIN DACE, WHILE IMPROVING THE HABITAT FOR ADDITIONAL SPECIES SUCH AS THE CHIRICAHUA LEOPARD FROG, NARROW HEADED GARTER SNAKE AND MONARCH BUTTERFLY  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE POND RENOVATION, IMPROVED ROAD DRAINAGE, POND ACCESS WALKWAY, SUPPLY WATER SPRING BOX AND PIPELINE REPAIR REPLACEMENT  DELIVERABLES INCLUDE ESTABLISHMENT OF AN OUTDOOR CONSERVATION AND NATURE EDUCATIONAL SITE SPECIFICALLY BENEFITING YOUTH IN SUMMER CAMP PROGRAMS, YEAR ROUND EDUCATION PROGRAMS, AS WELL AS MOGOLLON RIM AREA SCHOOLS
