THIS RESEARCH WILL INCORPORATE AN UNDERSTANDING OF BOTH BIOTIC AND ABIOTIC FACTORS TO HELP INFORM INITIAL STOCKING DECISIONS AND IDENTIFY THE BEST AVAILABLE HABITAT FOR FUTURE POPULATION PERSISTENCE OF ARCTIC GRAYLING  FLUVIAL ARCTIC GRAYLING IN MICHIGAN, IN PARTICULAR, HAVE NOT BEEN SUCCESSFULLY STOCKED PREVIOUSLY, AND NEED MORE FOCUSED MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO INCREASE THE LIKELIHOOD OF REINTRODUCTION SUCCESS  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THIS WORK INCLUDE  HABITAT ASSESSMENTS  I E , WATER TEMPERATURE, SUBSTRATE, VELOCITY, AND WATER DEPTH , FISH COMMUNITY ASSEMBLAGE ASSESSEMNTS TO UNDERSTAND COMPETITION, PREY AVAILABILITY, AND PREDATOR THREATS, AND DEVELOPMENT OF A HABITAT SUITABILITY MODEL TO HELP UNDERSTAND BEST TRIBUTARIES AND LOCATIONS TO SUPPORT REINTRODUCTION EFFORTS  THIS WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED IN MULTIPLE TRIBUTARIES IN THE UPPER MANISTEE RIVER WATERSHED IN MICHIGAN  THE EXPECTED DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES WILL BE A THOROUGH REVIEW OF HABITAT AND FISH COMMUNITY ASSEMBLAGE DATA, A SERIES OF HABITAT SUITABILITY MODELS FOR ARCTIC GRAYLING, AND A BIOLOGICAL REPORT OVERVIEWING SPECIES ASSESSMENTS, HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS, AND HABITAT SUITABILITY TO HELP PARTNERS WITH MANAGEMENT OF ARCTIC GRAYLING REINTRODUCTIONS IN THE UPPER MANISTEE WATERSHED THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE MULTIPLE STAKEHOLDERS AND PARTNERS INVESTED IN MICHIGAN ARCTIC GRAYLING INITIATIVE INCLUDING THELITTLE RIVER BAND OF OTTAWA INDIANS, THE GRAND TRAVERSE BAND OF OTTAWA AND CHIPPEWA INDIANS, THE LITTLE TRAVERSE BAY BAND OF ODAWA INDIANS, THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURATION RESOURCES, TROUT UNLIMITED, AND MORE  WHILE THERE ARE MANY PARTNERS CONTRIBUTING TO THE RESEARCH AND DESIGN OF THIS PROJECT, THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES THAT WILL BE AWARDED DURING THIS AGREEMENT

THROUGH THIS PROJECT, HURON PINES WILL INVENTORY 40 ROAD STREAM CROSSING LOCATIONS ACROSS NORTHEAST MICHIGAN THAT HAVE RECENTLY BEEN RESTORED, TO UPDATE INVENTORY DATA AND EVALUATE PROJECT EFFECTIVENESS  AN ADDITIONAL 40 ROAD STREAM CROSSINGS WILL BE INVENTORIED IN THE BLACK RIVER WATERSHED OF ALCONA COUNTY TO DOCUMENT CURRENT CONDITIONS IN THIS WATERSHED WHICH WILL HELP PRIORITIZE FUTURE RESTORATION OPPORTUNITIES  THE THUNDER BAY RIVER WATERSHED AND THE BLACK RIVER WATERSHED OF CHEBOYGAN COUNTY WILL BE SURVEYED FOR HUNGERFORD S CRAWLING WATER BEETLES IN 25 LOCATIONS, AS THESE WATERSHEDS HAVE A HIGH PROBABILITY OF OCCURRENCE BASED ON HABITAT SUITABILITY MODELING  IN ADDITION, HURON PINES WILL BUILD ORGANIZATIONAL CAPACITY ON FRESHWATER MUSSEL IDENTIFICATION AND SURVEY PROTOCOLS, WITH THE GOAL OF EXPANDING FRESHWATER MUSSEL MONITORING IN NORTHERN MICHIGAN IN THE FUTURE

THE TROUT RIVER DAM IS DETERIORATING AND SERVES AS A FIRST BARRIER TO INVASIVE SEA LAMPREY MIGRATION  THE DAM ALSO PREVENTS NATIVE DESIRABLE FISH FROM ACCESSING 20 MILES OF UPSTREAM COLDWATER HABITAT  DUE TO THE COMPETING MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES  INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL VERSUS NATIVE DESIRABLE FISH PASSAGE , IT IS IMPORTANT TO FULLY ASSESS A RANGE OF POTENTIAL OPTIONS THROUGH A FEASIBILITY ANALYSIS  THROUGH PHASE 1 OF THIS PROJECT, A STEERING COMMITTEE WILL BE FORMED TO CONSIDER POTENTIAL OPTIONS  I E , DO NOTHING, FULL DAM REMOVAL AND RIVER RESTORATION, REPAIR EXISTING STRUCTURE, CONSTRUCT A NEW FIXED CREST STRUCTURE OR CONSTRUCT A NEW ADJUSTABLE CREST SEASONAL BARRIER STRUCTURE  AND TO SELECT A FINAL OPTION THAT WOULD BEST MEET THE MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES AT THE LOCATION OF THE TROUT RIVER DAM  PHASE 1 ALSO INCLUDES DEVELOPING A COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT PLAN FOR THE PROJECT TO SHARE PROJECT INFORMATION, INFORM THE PUBLIC AND TO GATHER COMMUNITY INPUT

THE FLINT RIVER RESTORATION IS A LONG-TERM PROJECT KEY TO THE REVITALIZATION OF THE RIVERFRONT IN DOWNTOWN FLINT, MICHIGAN. IN-RIVER COMPONENTS OF THE PROJECT WILL OPEN NEARLY 25 MILES OF STREAMS TO FISH PASSAGE, IMPROVE IN-CHANNEL HABITAT, AND SUPPORT SPAWNING RUNS OF LAKE STURGEON AND WALLEYE.THE FLINT RIVER HAS BEEN DEGRADED BY DAMMING, CHANNELIZATION, DREDGING, AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT. EXISTING ISSUES INCLUDE DEGRADED IN-STREAM HABITAT, BARRIERS TO FISH MOVEMENT, ELEVATED WATER TEMPERATURE, AND WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENT. THE PROJECT WILL REMOVE THE REMNANT FOUNDATION OF THE FABRI DAM AND THE CONCRETE WEIR OF THE HAMILTON DAM, WHICH IS THE FIRST FISH BARRIER ON THE RIVER UPSTREAM OF SAGINAW BAY. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO INSTALL A SERIES OF CONSTRUCTED RIFFLES ALONG THE 1.7-MILE-LONG PROJECT REACH TO RESTORE FISH HABITAT AND IMPROVE HYDRAULICS. RIVERBANKS WILL BE STABILIZED ALONG THE REACH USING BIOENGINEERING AND NATIVE PLANTINGS IN CONCERT WITH RIVERFRONT PARK IMPROVEMENTS.THE FLINT RIVER RESTORATION PROVIDES A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY FOR A PROJECT TO PROVIDE SUBSTANTIAL ECOLOGICAL LIFT WITH SOCIAL BENEFITS INCLUDED. THE PROJECT ENJOYS BROAD SUPPORT IN THE COMMUNITY AND AMONG STAKEHOLDERS, WITH A LONG LIST OF PROJECT PARTNERS. IT DIRECTLY ADDRESSES FISH PASSAGE PRIORITIES WITHIN US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) REGION 3, BOTH FOR MAJOR SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN (LAKE STURGEON) AND RECREATIONAL INTEREST (WALLEYE). IT SUPPORTS STURGEON REESTABLISHMENT EFFORTS, FISH PASSAGE PRIORITIES, AND WATERSHED RESTORATION GOALS PROMOTED BY SEVERAL FEDERAL AND MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES PROGRAMS. THE PROJECT ALSO MEETS THE PRIORITIES OF THE CITY OF FLINT AND GENESEE COUNTY IN PROVIDING OUTDOOR RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, AS WELL AS RE-VITALIZING THE DOWNTOWN CORRIDOR.SPECIFIC PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1) PROVIDE VOLITIONAL FISH PASSAGE UPSTREAM THROUGH THE PROJECT REACH BY REMOVING EXISTING BARRIERS; 2) NATURALIZE THE PROJECT REACH TO EXTENT PRACTICAL, WITH EMPHASIS ON GEOMORPHIC STABILITY, HABITAT DIVERSITY, AND HYDRAULIC DIVERSITY; 3) IMPROVE CONVEYANCE AND AVOID INCREMENTAL WATER SURFACE ELEVATION INCREASES THAT RESULT IN FLOOD RISK IMPACTS; 4) STABILIZE STREAM BANKS ALONG PROJECT REACH; 5) PROVIDE ANGLING ACCESS AND IMPROVE SAFE BOATING POTENTIAL THROUGH THE PROJECT REACH; AND 6) IMPLEMENT RIVERFRONT PARK IMPROVEMENTS ALONG DOWNTOWN RIVERBANKS.THE PROJECT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED IN PHASES. MAJOR STEPS IN HABITAT RESTORATION ARE AS FOLLOWS: 1) MODIFY SEA WALLS FOR CONSTRUCTION ACCESS; 2) REMOVE FABRI-DAM FOUNDATION; 3) INSTALL RIFFLES AT FORMER FABRI-DAM SITE; 4) BEGIN RIPARIAN AND RIVERSIDE PARK ENHANCEMENTS; 5) INSTALL TEMPORARY CONSTRUCTION CAUSEWAY DOWNSTREAM OF HAMILTON DAM; 6) NOTCH DAM AND DRAW DOWN BACKWATER; 7) REMOVE REMAINING CONCRETE WEIR; 8) RE-GRADE CAUSEWAY MATERIAL TO RIFFLE FINAL GRADE AND INSTALL HABITAT ENHANCEMENTS; 9) INSTALL RIFFLES AT UP- AND DOWNSTREAM LIMITS OF VIETNAM VETERANS PARK; 10) INSTALL BANK STABILIZATION; 11) COMPLETE RIPARIAN AND RIVERSIDE PARK ENHANCEMENTS.THE WORK PROPOSED IN THIS PROJECT WOULD ALLOW UPSTREAM ACCESS TO 5 MILES OF THE MAIN BRANCH OF THE RIVER AND PORTIONS OF GILKEY CREEK, KEARSLEY CREEK, AND RISKIN DRAIN, RESULTING IN 24.73 RECONNECTED STREAM MILES TO LAKE HURON FOR THE FIRST TIME IN 100 YEARS. THE PROJECT DIRECTLY ADDRESSES THE GOALS OF THE GREAT LAKES FISH AND WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACT OF 2016 AS WELL AS SPECIFIC GOALS OF VARIOUS MANAGEMENT PLANS. THE PROJECT MEETS THESE OBJECTIVES BY REMOVING BARRIERS AND PROVIDING PASSAGE UPSTREAM, CREATING HABITAT AND CONTRIBUTING TO THE RESTORATION OF THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES TO SELF-SUSTAINING LEVELS.IN ADDITION TO THE ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS OF THIS PROJECT, ITS IMPLEMENTATION WILL PROVIDE THE OPPORTUNITY TO RESIDENTS OF FLINT RECREATIONAL ACCESS AND PROMOTE THE DEVELOPMENT OF ADJACENT, ABANDONED INDUSTRIAL PROPERTIES TO PARKS AND OTHER USABLE SPACE.

THE WEST BRANCH TITTABAWASSEE RIVER DAM IS AN OBSOLETE CONCRETE STRUCTURE, WHICH THE PRIVATE LANDOWNER WISHES TO HAVE REMOVED AND WHICH BLOCKS UPSTREAM FISH PASSAGE AND DISRUPTS A SUITE OF RIVER PROCESSES INCLUDING HYDROLOGY, CHANNEL GEOMORPHOLOGY, AND TRANSPORT OF SEDIMENT, WOOD, AND OTHER MATERIALS THROUGH THE RIVER SYSTEM  THROUGH THIS PROJECT WE WILL FULLY REMOVE THE EXISTING DAM TO RECONNECT AQUATIC HABITAT  6 2 UPSTREAM MILES OF HIGH QUALITY COLDWATER STREAM THAT SUPPORTS TROUT AND MANY NATIVE SPECIES   A BOTTOMLESS BOX CULVERT, SIZED TO SPAN BANKFULL WIDTH OF THE RIVER, WILL BE INSTALLED ONCE THE DAM IS GONE TO PRESERVE THE LANDOWNERS  ACCESS ACROSS THE RIVER TO THE SOUTHERN PORTION OF THEIR PROPERTY  ALL PROJECT WORK IS EXPECTED TO BE COMPLETED IN SUMMER 2022

FUNDING FOR THIS AWARD WILL BE USED FOR THE REMOVAL OF THE HIGH HAZARD POTENTIAL BROOKLYN HYDROELECTRIC DAM. THIS INCLUDES DRAWDOWN OF THE IMPOUNDMENT, REMOVAL OF THE DAM STRUCTURE, RESTORATION OF 1,830 FEET OF RIVER UTILIZING NATURAL CHANNEL DESIGN THROUGH THE FORMER IMPOUNDMENT, AND PASSIVE RESTORATION OF APPROXIMATELY 11,000 FEET OF LACUSTRINE TO LOTIC HABITAT AND CONSTRUCTION OF NATURAL ROCK ARCH RAPIDS OVER NOONEY DAM, LOCATED AT THE OUTLET OF VINEYARD LAKE. THE GOAL OF THESE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WILL BE TO RESTORE STREAM FUNCTION TO OVER 2 MILES OF RIVER AND ALLOW FOR ACCESS OF 44 UPSTREAM MILES FOR FISH PASSAGE.

PROJECT PURPOSE: REPLACE THREE UNDERSIZED CULVERT FISH BARRIERS: ONE CULVERT ON WISEN CREEK AND TWO CULVERTS ON WISEN BRANCH CREEK.DELIVERABLES: THE OVERALL GOAL IS TO REPLACE THE THREE UNDERSIZED CULVERTS WITH FISH PASSABLE STRUCTURES TO INCREASE THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF ACCESSIBLE SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT FOR COHO, STEELHEAD, AND TROUT SPECIES. CONSTRUCTION WILL BE COMPLETED USING THE DESIGNS COMPLETED EARLY 2022. UPON COMPLETION OF THIS PROJECT, AQUATIC SPECIES WILL GAIN UNIMPEDED ACCESS TO 2.9 KILOMETERS OF QUALITY HABITAT UPSTREAM AS WELL AS IMPROVED ACCESS TO OVER TWO ACRES OF WETLAND AND BEAVER POND HABITAT.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: PROCURE CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTOR VIA FEDERAL PROCUREMENT STANDARDS; PREP SITE FOR CONSTRUCTION (STAKING, STAGING, ETC.); MOBILIZE TO SITE FOR CONSTRUCTION; COMPLETE CONSTRUCTION (REPLACE THREE CULVERT BARRIERS WITH ALUMINUM PLATE PIPE ARCH X2 AND ALUMINUM BOX CULVERT X1; SEED/MULCH DISTURBED AREAS; COMPLETE ALL INSPECTIONS; AND DEMOBILIZE); COMPLETE FINAL BUDGETING, INVOICING, AND REPORTING; PROJECT COMPLETEDELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: REPLACE THREE CULVERT BARRIER CULVERTS WITH APPROPRIATE ROAD STREAM CROSSING STRUCTURES THAT ALLOW FISH PASSAGE PER WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE FISH PASSAGE PROTOCOL (FISH PASSAGE INVENTORY, ASSESSMENT, AND PRIORITIZATION MANUAL, 2019)INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: WISEN CREEK SALMON, STEELHEAD, AND RESIDENT FISH; CLALLAM COUNTY ROADS DEPT; FISHERY CO-MANAGERS = QUILEUTE TRIBE AND WA DEPT FISH AND WILDLIFE.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: THERE WILL BE NO SUBRECIPIENTS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT.

THIS PROJECT EXPLORES OPPORTUNITIES TO PROVIDE AQUATIC SPECIES VOLITIONAL ACCESS TO APPROXIMATELY 61 MILES OF UPSTREAM MAINSTEM DESCHUTES RIVER HABITAT ABOVE MIRROR POND IN BEND, OREGON, WHILE MEETING COMMUNITY GOALS  THE PROJECT INVOLVES A FEASIBILITY STUDY WITH THE GOAL OF DEVELOPING A PREFERRED ALTERNATIVE FOR FISH PASSAGE WITH PLANS FOR FUTURE PHASES TO INVOLVE DESIGN OF THE PREFERRED ALTERNATIVE

THE FIELDS DIVERSION IS AN IRRIGATION DIVERSION STRUCTURE LOCATED ON THE WEST MANCOS RIVER, IN SOUTHWEST COLORADO. THE WEST MANCOS RIVER PROVIDES IDEAL HABITAT FOR A VARIETY OF AQUATIC ORGANISMS, INCLUDING SEVERAL SPECIES OF WARM WATER FISH INCLUDING THE BLUEHEAD SUCKER (CATOSTOMUS DISCOBLUS), FLANNELMOUTH SUCKER (CATOSTOMUS LATIPINNUS), ROUNDTAIL CHUB (GILA ROBUSTA), AND MOTTLED SCULPIN (COTTUS BAIRDII). THESE WARM WATER FISH ARE HIGHLY VULNERABLE TO LOW SUMMER STREAM FLOWS, FREQUENCY OF DROUGHT AND HABITAT FRAGMENTATION AND RELY ON HABITAT THAT IS CONNECTED BY FLOW AND TOLERABLE WATER TEMPERATURES. CLIMATE CHANGE HAS THE POTENTIAL TO IMPACT WARM WATER FISH HABITAT CONNECTIVITY AS DOES FRAGMENTATION CAUSED BY INSTREAM WATER DIVERSIONS, SUCH AS THE FIELD DIVERSION. THE FIELD DIVERSION IS A SIGNIFICANT BARRIER TO THESE WARM WATER FISH, AND THE ADDITION OF STEP AND RAMP STRUCTURES BELOW THIS BARRIER, IN COORDINATION WITH THE WEBBER DIVERSION FISH PASSAGE PROJECT, WOULD OPEN 15.74 ADDITIONAL MILES OF RIVER HABITAT FOR WARM WATER FISH AND HELP TO STABILIZE THE DIVERSION STRUCTURE AND IMPROVE THE IRRIGATION INFRASTRUCTURE. AS CLIMATE CHANGE CONTINUES TO IMPACT SOUTHWEST COLORADO, IT IS IMPORTANT TO ENSURE THAT THE 'THREE SPECIES' HAVE ACCESS TO TOLERABLE HABITATS WHILE CONTINUING TO SUPPORT THE LIVELIHOOD OF THE AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS WHO ARE ALSO AFFECTED BY DROUGHT. PARTNERING WITH LANDOWNERS TO ELIMINATE BARRIERS TO FISH PASSAGE FOR WARM WATER SPECIES HAS BECOME AN IMPORTANT PART OF THE MANCOS WATERSHED STREAM MANAGEMENT PLANNING EFFORT. THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO:1. TO REMOVE A SIGNIFICANT FISH PASSAGE BARRIER TO THE 'THREE SPECIES' OF WARM WATER FISH. THESE FISH ARE HIGHLY VULNERABLE TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND SHIFTING WATER TEMPERATURES, AND REMOVAL OF THIS BARRIER WOULD OPEN VALUABLE MILES OF STREAM HABITAT FOR WARM WATER FISH IN THE WEST MANCOS RIVER AND MANCOS RIVER.2. PROVIDE STABILIZATION TO THE FIELD DIVERSION, TO ENSURE WATER MAY BE EFFICIENTLY DIVERTED FOR AGRICULTURAL USE, WHILE PROVIDING FISH ACCESSIBLE PASSAGE.3. ASSESSING THE EFFICACY OF THE FISH PASSAGE CREATED BY USING PIT-TAGGING AND EDNA ANALYSIS AS PARTS OF THE POST-MONITORING STRATEGY.4. ANNUAL DIVERSION AND STRUCTURE INSPECTIONS BY MCD TECHNICIAN TO DETERMINE CONTINUED FUNCTIONALITY AND O&M RECOMMENDATIONS.5. OUTREACH AND REPORTING ON THE SUCCESSES OF COOPERATIVE PROJECTS FOR OVERALL STREAM RESTORATION AND WATERSHED HEALTH.

THE LACK OF INFORMATION ON LAMPREYS GLOBALLY HINDERS ONGOING MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION EFFORTS. PACIFIC LAMPREY ENTOSPHENUS TRIDENTATUS IS A SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN IN NORTH AMERICA AND IS OF INTEREST IN ALASKA BECAUSE THIS REGION MARKS THE NORTHERN EXTENT OF ITS RANGE. THE SUSITNA RIVER DRAINAGE, A 504- KM GLACIAL RIVER THAT DISCHARGES INTO COOK INLET AND THE GULF OF ALASKA, IS THE NORTHERNMOST RIVER SYSTEM THAT SUPPORTS A SPAWNING AND REARING POPULATION OF PACIFIC LAMPREY (MECKLENBURG ET AL. 2002). HOWEVER, THE STATUS AND DISTRIBUTION OF PACIFIC LAMPREY IN ALASKA HAS BEEN POORLY DOCUMENTED. TO ADDRESS THIS DATA DEFICIENCY, THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT, WHICH WILL TAKE PLACE IN CLEARWATER TRIBUTARIES AND EXPAND ON PREVIOUS EFFORTS (COMPLETED: 2019; PROPOSAL PENDING: 2022) TO SAMPLE IN THE LOWER SUSITNA RIVER, INCLUDE: (1) ASSESSMENT OF THE DISTRIBUTION OF LARVAL AND ADULT PACIFIC LAMPREY; (2) EXAMINATION OF THE REARING (LARVAL) AND SPAWNING (ADULT) HABITAT USE OF PACIFIC LAMPREY; (3) DETERMINATION OF THE SIZE AND AGE STRUCTURE OF LARVAL AND ADULT PACIFIC LAMPREY; AND (4) USE OF EDNA FROM COLLECTED WATER SAMPLES TO DETECT THE PRESENCE OF PACIFIC LAMPREY.

THIS PROJECT WILL CORRECT TWO FISH PASSAGE BARRIERS ON TRIBUTARY STREAMS WITHIN THE SOL DUC WATERSHED ON WASHINGTON STATE S OLYMPIC COAST  THE TWO TRIBUTARIES, ANTON CREEK AND CEDAR CREEK, CROSS AT MILEPOSTS 1 74 AND 1 78 OF THE BEAR CREEK ROAD WHICH IS MANAGED BY CLALLAM COUNTY  THERE ARE NEARLY 5 MILES OF FIELD VERIFIED HABITAT FOR SALMON AND TROUT SPECIES UPSTREAM OF THESE CULVERT BARRIERS, AND THE SITES HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS HIGH PRIORITIES FOR CORRECTION ACTIVITIES  PRELIMINARY DESIGNS HAVE BEEN COMPLETED, AND FUNDING FOR FINAL DESIGNS IS SECURED DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT THE CONSTRUCTION AND CORRECTION OF TWO BARRIERS INTENDED BENEFICIARIES THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT AMONG SEVERAL STAKEHOLDERS, INCLUDING WILD SALMON CENTER, TROUT UNLIMITED, COAST SALMON PARTNERSHIP, CLALLAM COUNTY, WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THE QUILEUTE TRIBE  THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE AMERICAN PUBLIC AS WELL AS AQUATIC ORGANISMS AND OTHER NATURAL RESOURCES

THE TWIN UNDERSIZED PIPES AT SPARR ROAD OVER BLACK RIVER IN OTSEGO COUNTY, MICHIGAN WILL BE REPLACED WITH A BOTTOMLESS BOX CULVERT SIZED TO EXCEED BANKFULL WIDTH TO RESTORE UPSTREAM FISH PASSAGE AND A SUITE OF NATURAL RIVER PROCESSES. A SECOND UNDERSIZED AND PERCHED CULVERT AT NEARBY JOHNSONS CROSSING OVER A TRIBUTARY OF THE BLACK RIVER WILL ALSO BE REPLACED AS PART OF THIS PROJECT. APPROXIMATELY 9 UPSTREAM MILES OF AQUATIC HABITAT WILL BE RECONNECTED THROUGH THIS PROJECT. THE UPPER BLACK RIVER IS A WORLD-CLASS BROOK TROUT FISHERY AND IS A PRIORITY WATERSHED FOR USFWS, MICHIGAN DNR, AND MANY OTHER STAKEHOLDERS. PROJECT WORK IS ANTICIPATED FOR FALL 2022 CONSTRUCTION IF SUFFICIENT FUNDING IS SECURED IN TIME TO HIRE A CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTOR FOR IMPLEMENTATION.

THE RESTORATION PROJECT WILL CORRECT TWO FISH PASSAGE BARRIER CULVERTS ON CAMP CREEK AT SEPARATE ROAD CROSSINGS ON SCHAFER BOOM ROAD, SOUTHEAST OF MONTESANO, WASHINGTON. SITE ONE (WDFW SITE ID 127S0362) IS LOCATED AT ROAD MILE 0.16 ON SCHAFER BOOM ROAD AND STREAM MILE 0.42 (LAT/LONG 46.9801/-123.56473). PRIOR TO THE PLANNED RESTORATION, THE CROSSING WAS RATED AS BEING 33 PERCENT PASSABLE FOR SALMONIDS DUE TO RIP RAP AT THE CULVERT OUTLET THAT CREATED A LARGE SCOUR POOL. ADDITIONALLY, THE STREAM HAS A BANKFULL WIDTH OF 20 FEET BUT THE BARRIER CULVERT IS ONLY 3 FEET IN DIAMETER, IS NOT COUNTERSUNK, AND HAS A SLOPE OF 2.2 PERCENT, CREATING FLOWS THROUGH THE PIPE THAT ARE TOO FAST FOR FISH TO SWIM THROUGH TO GET UPSTREAM. A CORRECTION TO THIS BARRIER CULVERT WAS DESIGNED AND PERMITTED UNDER A GRANT FROM THE WASHINGTON STATE SALMON RECOVERY FUNDING BOARD (GRANT 16-1327). FUNDS FROM THIS AGREEMENT WILL BE USED FOR CONSTRUCTION TO REMOVE THE CURRENT BARRIER CULVERT AND RIP RAP AND REPLACE IT WITH A STRUCTURE THAT ALLOWS ALL LIFE FORMS AND STAGES OF AQUATIC LIFE ACCESS TO CRITICAL UPSTREAM HABITAT. SITE TWO (WDFW SITE ID 127S0361) IS LOCATED AT ROAD MILE 0.10 ON SCHAFER BOOM ROAD AND STREAM MILE 0.55 (LAT/LONG 46.98121/-123.56489). HIGH WATER VELOCITIES FROM THE UNDERSIZED CULVERT (3 FEET WIDE) CREATE A 67 PERCENT PASSABLE BARRIER, AND FUNDING FROM THIS AGREEMENT WILL BE USED TO DESIGN AND PERMIT A FISH BARRIER CORRECTION AT SITE TWO FOR WHICH CONSTRUCTION FUNDS WILL BE SOUGHT IN FUTURE GRANTS. THE OVERALL GOAL IS TO IMPROVE FISH PASSAGE TO 10.21 MILES OF HIGH QUALITY UPSTREAM HABITAT FOR FIVE SPECIES OF SALMONIDS: CHINOOK, COHO AND CHUM SALMON, STEELHEAD AND CUTTHROAT TROUT.

THE HELPER RIVER REVITALIZATION PROJECT IS AN ENVIRONMENTAL INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECT ON THE PRICE RIVER WITH ITS MAIN ASPECTS TO IMPROVE FISH PASSAGE AND RECREATION ACCESS ALONG THE PRICE RIVER. IT PRIORITIZES CONSTRUCTION OF GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE FOR 2.5 MILES OF WATERWAY AND HAS BEEN ADOPTED INTO THE PRICE RIVER WATERSHED PLAN. THE PROJECT HAS AND WILL CONTINUE TO RESTORE STREAM AND RIPARIAN HEALTH FUNCTIONS, IMPROVE WATER QUALITY, ENHANCE PUBLIC ACCESS AND SAFETY, AND BUILD COMMUNITY STEWARDSHIP OF THE RIVER. THERE WERE SIX MAJOR FISH PASSAGE BARRIERS WITHIN THE PROJECT REACH BEFORE THE HELPER RIVER REVITALIZATION PROJECT BEGAN. FIVE OF THE SIX BARRIERS HAVE BEEN REMOVED WITH THE LAST ONE THE GIGLIOTTI DIVERSION. THIS PROJECT WILL REMOVE THIS LAST BARRIER AND CREATE A CORRIDOR FOR NATIVE AND RECREATIONAL SPECIES. FUNDING THROUGH THE USFWS NATIONAL FISH PASSAGE PROGRAM WILL BE USED TO REMOVE PART OR ALL OF THE GIGLIOTTI DIVERSION, CREATE FISH PASSAGE FOR ALL SPECIES AND RESTORE THE CHANNEL AND BANKS TO A MORE NATURAL FORM THAT IS FRIENDLY TO FISH MOVEMENT, THE LOCAL RIPARIAN ECOLOGY AND FLOODPLAIN FUNCTION, AND USE BY LOCAL RECREATION.

REMOVAL AND RESTORATION OF THE BALD MOUNTAIN POND DAM WITH FOLLOW UP NATIVE VEGETATION PLANTINGS WILL RESTORE CONNECTIVITY FOR NATIVE FISH SPECIES AND REINSTATE NATURAL FLOW AND SEDIMENT REGIMES TO TROUT CREEK. THIS WILL ENHANCE ONE OF THE LARGEST TRIBUTARIES TO PAINT CREEK, ONE OF THE FEW REMAINING COLDWATER TROUT STREAMS IN SOUTHEAST MICHIGAN AND A POPULAR FISHING DESTINATION. UPSTREAM ROAD STREAM CROSSING SURVEYS WILL EXTEND THE PROJECT SCOPE TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL PHASE TWO EFFORTS TO CONTINUE TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE THIS VALUABLE TRIBUTARY. INCORPORATION OF NATIVE VEGETATION MATERIAL WILL STABILIZE STREAM BANKS FOLLOWING DAM REMOVAL AND BROADEN STREAM CANOPY COVER AND RIPARIAN HABITAT. BENEFITS OF THIS EFFORT INCLUDE INCREASED FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT, OPEN CONNECTIVITY FOR NATIVE SPECIES TO HEADWATER STREAMS AND OPPORTUNITY FOR VOLUNTEERS TO PARTICIPATE IN ON-THE-GROUND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES.

FY 22 IIJA NFPP PROJECT ABSTRACT - SALMON SUPERHWYFISH PASSAGE BARRIERS IDENTIFIED IN SUBBASIN WIDE CULVERT ASSESSMENTS IN THE TILLAMOOK, NESTUCCA, AND SAND LAKE WATERSHEDS BLOCK ACCESS TO UPSTREAM SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT FOR ESA LISTED COHO SALMON, FALL CHINOOK, WINTER STEELHEAD, ANADROMOUS AND RESIDENT COASTAL CUTTHROAT TROUT, CHUM SALMON, AND TRIBALLY SIGNIFICANT SPECIES OF CONCERN PACIFIC LAMPREY.ROAD-STREAM CROSSING CULVERTS IDENTIFIED BY SALMON SUPERHWY AS FISH PASSAGE BARRIERS ARE OFTEN UNDERSIZED AND PRONE TO BLOCKING UP WITH SEDIMENT AND DEBRIS. AS A RESULT THEY REQUIRE COSTLY MAINTENANCE AND CONTRIBUTE TO CHRONIC FLOODING. WHEN CULVERTS FAIL, THE ROAD IS ALSO FREQUENTLY DAMAGED WHICH CAN CAUSE PUBLIC SAFETY ISSUES AS WELL AS TRANSPORTATION DELAY AS ROADS CAN BE CLOSED FOR MANY DAYS. SEVERAL OF THE PRIORITY PROJECTS ARE ON CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE FOR TSUNAMI EVACUATION OR MAY BE THE ONLY ACCESS / EGRESS FOR LOCAL COMMUNITIES.THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN REMOVAL OF THREE IN STREAM BARRIERS AND REPLACEMENT WITH APPROPRIATELY SIZED STREAM SPANNING STRUCTURES THAT MEET FEDERAL AND STATE FISH PASSAGE STANDARDS AND ALLOW FULL STREAM PROCESSES INCLUDING TRANSPORT OF SEDIMENT, WOOD, AND NUTRIENTS, RESTORING ACCESS TO OVER 4 MILES OF SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE ECOLOGICAL, ECONOMIC, AND PUBLIC SAFETY BENEFITS BY ELIMINATING ROAD WASHOUT HAZARDS (UNDERSIZED AND FAILING CULVERTS) AND REPLACING THEM WITH STREAM SPANNING STRUCTURES DESIGNED FOR FULL VOLITIONAL FISH PASSAGE FOR ALL SPECIES AND LIFE STAGES, RESULTING IN SAFE, CLIMATE RESILIENT TRANSPORTATION INFRASTRUCTURE.

PROJECT TITLE: SALMON SUPERHWY - TILLAMOOK BASIN FISH PASSAGE RESTORATION PROJECT - FY22THE FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO WORKS IN PARTNERSHIP TO PROVIDE FISH (AND OTHER AQUATIC ORGANISMS) PASSAGE AND RESTORE AQUATIC CONNECTIVITY FOR THE BENEFIT OF FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION TO ADDRESS THREE FISH PASSAGE BARRIERS IN THE TILLAMOOK BAY WATERSHED AND REPLACE THEM WITH AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE STRUCTURES THAT WILL RESTORE NATURAL STREAM PROCESSES AND ACCESS FOR FISH TO SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT.TROUT UNLIMITED WILL WORK WITH ENGINEERING SERVICES PROVIDERS TO DESIGN AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE THAT FULLY ADDRESSES THE BARRIERS, WORK WITH PARTNERS TO SECURE FUNDING AND PERMITS, AND OVERSEE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE BARRIER REMOVAL PROJECTS.THE PROJECTS WILL RESTORE PASSAGE TO 3.2 MILES OF SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT BENEFITTING CHINOOK, CHUM, AND ESA LISTED OC COHO SALMON, STEELHEAD, CUTTHROAT TROUT, AND LAMPREY, WHILE IMPROVING HUMAN SAFETY BY REMOVING THE RISK OF CATASTROPHIC BARRIER FAILURE.

THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FEASIBILITY AND CONCEPT DESIGN DEVELOPMENT AS AN INITIAL PROJECT PHASE TO HELP ADVANCE THE REMOVAL OF THE IMPEDIMENT TO FISH PASSAGE POSED BY KELLOGG DAM AT THE CONFLUENCE OF KELLOGG CREEK AND THE WILLAMETTE RIVER IN MILWAUKIE, OR, AND RESTORE STREAM AND FLOODPLAIN HABITAT WITHIN THE 14 ACRE IMPOUNDMENT ABOVE THE DAM. USFWS FUNDS WILL SPECIFICALLY BE USED FOR PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND COORDINATION WITH AND OVERSIGHT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSULTANT WORK PAID FOR BY OTHER SOURCES.KELLOGG DAM WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 1858, BEFORE EITHER STATEHOOD OR THE CIVIL WAR, FOR A FLOUR MILL. THE MILL STOPPED OPERATION IN THE 1890S, BUT THE DAM WAS LEFT IN PLACE AND HAS SERVED NO PURPOSE SINCE. KELLOGG DAM, LOCATED WHERE KELLOGG CREEK MEETS THE WILLAMETTE RIVER, BLOCKS FISH PASSAGE TO THE ENTIRE IN THE KELLOGG AND MT. SCOTT WATERSHEDS. REMOVING THE DAM WILL BENEFIT THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SALMONIDS AND OTHER PRIORITY SPECIES: WINTER STEELHEAD, CHINOOK AND COHO SALMON, PACIFIC LAMPREY, AND CUTTHROAT TROUT. ESA-LISTED SALMON AND STEELHEAD FROM THE CLACKAMAS AND UPPER WILLAMETTE BASIN USE THE LOWER WILLAMETTE RIVER FLOODPLAIN FOR MIGRATION AND OFF-CHANNEL REARING FOR JUVENILES. KELLOGG DAM IS THE #1 STATEWIDE FISH PASSAGE PRIORITY FOR ODOT-OWNED INFRASTRUCTURE IN THE STATE OF OREGON AS RANKED BY THE OREGON FISH & WILDLIFE COMMISSION.

THE STEWART DITCH DIVERSION MODIFICATION PROJECT IS INTENDED TO ADDRESS MULTIPLE DEFICIENCIES ON THE NORTH FORK OF THE GUNNISON RIVER CAUSED BY THE STEWART DITCH DIVERSION STRUCTURE. THE STEWART DITCH DIVERSION CONSISTS OF A 1,200-FOOT-LONG PUSH-UP ROCK DAM. THE DAM DIVERTS WATER INTO THE STEWART DITCH, WHICH SERVES APPROXIMATELY 236 AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS NEAR THE TOWN OF PAONIA, COLORADO. RECENT REPAIRS TO THE DAM HAVE INCLUDED CONSTRUCTION OF A BOULDER WALL WHICH ELEVATED THE RIVERBED SUBSTANTIALLY AND CREATED A POOL IN FRONT OF THE DIVERSION INTAKE. HISTORIC MAINTENANCE OF THE DAM HAS CAUSED SERIOUS IMPACT TO THE RIVER INCLUDING OVER WIDENING AND EROSION. THE STEWART DITCH AND RESERVOIR COMPANY (SDRC) HOLDS SENIOR WATER RIGHTS ON THE NORTH FORK AND DIVERTS APPROXIMATELY 70% OF THE RIVER FLOW DURING LATE SUMMER AND FALL MONTHS. THE ORIENTATION AND SIZE OF THE DIVERSION STRUCTURE ALONG WITH THE AMOUNT OF WATER DIVERTED RESULTS IN A CONSIDERABLE IMPACT ON THE FISH POPULATIONS IN THE NORTH FORK. AT ALL BUT HIGH FLOWS, THE DIVERSION STRUCTURE IS A BARRIER TO FISH. FISH THAT END UP BELOW THE DIVERSION FROM HIGH SPRING FLOWS ARE UNABLE TO MOVE UPSTREAM ABOVE THE DIVERSION TO FIND REFUGE IN DEEPER AND COOLER WATER AND LIKELY PERISH. MANY FISH ARE ALSO LOST TO ENTRAINMENT IN THE DITCH. MODIFICATION TO THE STEWART DITCH DIVERSION WAS IDENTIFIED AS A PRIORITY IN TWO RECENT WATERSHED PLANNING ASSESSMENTS.THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO IMPROVE FISH PASSAGE AND PASSAGE FOR RECREATIONAL BOATERS, REDUCE FISH LOST TO ENTRAINMENT IN THE DITCH, AND STABILIZE THE STREAM CHANNEL, THUS IMPROVING RIPARIAN FUNCTION IN THIS SECTION OF RIVER. PROJECT PROPONENTS WILL ALSO COMMUNICATE LESSONS LEARNED AND PROJECT BENEFITS AND USE THE PROJECT AS AN EXAMPLE OF HOW WATER DEMANDS CAN BE MET WHILE IMPACTS TO THE ENVIRONMENT AND OTHER USERS.PROJECT PROPONENTS WILL MEET THESE GOALS BY REMOVING THE EXISTING PUSH-UP ROCK DAM AND REPLACING IT WITH A MODERN, ENGINEERED DIVERSION STRUCTURE. THE NEW STRUCTURE WILL MEET SDRC REQUIREMENTS WHILE IMPROVING FISH PASSAGE, BOAT PASSAGE, AND CHANNEL STABILITY AND REDUCING FISH ENTRAINMENT INTO THE DITCH. STAKEHOLDERS HAVE HIRED ENGINEERS WHO HAVE SURVEYED THE SITE, CREATED CONCEPTUAL DESIGNS, AND PRODUCED HYDRAULIC 2D MODELS. INITIAL SITE SURVEYS AND HYDRAULIC MODELING HAVE REVEALED THAT THE ELEVATION OF THE DIVERSION DAM CAN BE REDUCED BY AS MUCH AS THREE FEET WHILE STILL ALLOW FOR ADEQUATE HEAD TO DIVERT WATER INTO THE DITCH.THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN TROUT UNLIMITED (TU), SDRC, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS. WESTERN SLOPE CONSERVATION CENTER (WSCC), A LOCAL NON-PROFIT, IS ASSISTING WITH STAKEHOLDER SUPPORT, OUTREACH AND FUNDING. NEIGHBORING LANDOWNERS AND DELTA COUNTY COMMISSIONERS HAVE EXPRESSED SUPPORT FOR THE PROJECT. TO DATE, THE PROJECT HAS SECURED FUNDING FROM LOCAL CHAPTER OF TU, WSCC, AND THE COLORADO WATER CONSERVATION BOARD (CWCB). THESE FUNDS HAVE BEEN USED TO COMPLETE AN EXTENSIVE SURVEY OF THE RIVER AROUND THE DIVERSION AREA, CREATED DESIGN ALTERNATIVES, PRODUCE HYDRAULIC MODELS FOR ALTERNATIVES, AND THE REFINE PREFERRED DESIGN ALTERNATIVE.UPON COMPLETION OF THE PROJECT, TU AND PARTNERS WILL DISSEMINATE THE RESULTS OF THE EFFORT TO VARIOUS FUNDING AGENCIES, WATER USERS AND OTHER PARTIES. ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL INFORM TU'S ONGOING DIVERSION MODIFICATIONS ASSESSMENT AND WILL INFORM FUTURE RESTORATION PROJECTS.

THE ALBRIGHT POWER STATION DAM REMOVAL PROJECT ON THE CHEAT RIVER WILL IMPROVE WATERSHED CONNECTIVITY, WATER QUALITY, SENSITIVE SPECIES POPULATION HEALTH, AND FLOOD AND CLIMATE RESILIENCY FOR THE CHEAT RIVER AND ITS COMMUNITIES THROUGH THE REMOVAL OF AN OBSOLETE LOWHEAD DAM. THE PROJECT WILL RECONNECT 75 MILES OF MAINSTEM HABITAT AND HUNDREDS OF MILES OF TRIBUTARY RIVERS AND STREAMS FOR SENSITIVE SPECIES, SUCH AS EASTERN HELLBENDER, FRESHWATER MUSSELS, WALLEYE, AND BROOK TROUT. CURRENTLY, THE ALBRIGHT POWER STATION DAM BLOCKS NATIVE WALLEYE FROM RECOLONIZING THE CHEAT RIVER AFTER DECADES-LONG POLLUTION CLEANUP EFFORTS HAVE RESULTED IN THE RESTORATION OF THEIR POPULATION IN CHEAT LAKE. THE DAM ALSO BLOCKS MAINSTEM CONNECTION BETWEEN LOCAL BROOK TROUT STREAMS UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE DAM. EASTERN HELLBENDER HAVE BEEN DETECTED UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE DAM, ISOLATING POPULATIONS FROM ONE ANOTHER. FRIENDS OF THE CHEAT IS PURSUING REINTRODUCTION EFFORTS FOR NATIVE FRESHWATER MUSSELS IN THE CHEAT RIVER, OF WHICH THE DAM WOULD IMPEDE THEIR SUCCESS. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT WILL OPEN 6 MILES OF RIVER TO FLATWATER PADDLING OPPORTUNITIES, PREVIOUSLY INACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC, AND WILL ESTABLISH A NEW PUBLIC RIVER ACCESS POINT. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE LOCAL COMMUNITIES IN PRESTON AND TUCKER COUNTIES, OF WHICH THE CHEAT RIVER FLOWS THROUGH. NEW OPPORTUNITIES FOR THESE COMMUNITIES INCLUDE INCREASED FISHING OPPORTUNITIES, ONE DAY OR MULTI-DAY PADDLING TRIPS, AND NEW OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES TO OFFER RECREATION-BASED TOURISM SERVICES (FOOD, LODGING, FISHING & BOATING SUPPLIES, ETC.) ADDITIONALLY, REMOVING THE ALBRIGHT POWER STATION DAM WILL REDUCE THE RISK OF INFRASTRUCTURE FAILURE IN ALBRIGHT, WV, AS THE STRUCTURE IS OVER 70 YEARS OLD AND NO LONGER SERVES A PURPOSE. SPECIFICALLY, THE GOALS OF THE PROJECT ARE TO COMPLETE DESIGN AND PERMITTING FOR THE REMOVAL OF THE ALBRIGHT POWER STATION DAM AND REMOVE THE DAM AND RESTORE THE ADJACENT RIVER REACH. THE DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES CAN BE DESCRIBED AS THE FOLLOWING: 1 AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE BARRIER RECTIFIED, 75 MILES OF RIVER RECONNECTED, 1.25 MILES OF IN-STREAM HABITAT RESTORED, AND 7 MILES OF RIVER OPENED FOR PUBLIC ACCESS. FUNDS FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED TO CONTRACT THE FOLLOWING SERVICES: ENGINEERING AND CONSULTING SERVICES THAT RESULT IN 100% PLANS FOR REMOVAL AND RESTORATION, LEGAL SERVICES ASSOCIATED WITH ACQUIRING THE DAM AND ADJACENT PROPERTY FOR REMOVAL AND STREAM BANK RESTORATION, AND DEMOLITION/CONSTRUCTION SERVICES ASSOCIATED WITH REMOVING THE DAM AND RESTORING THE RIVER REACH. FUNDS WILL ALSO BE USED TO ALLOW FRIENDS OF THE CHEAT STAFF TO MANAGE THE PROJECT, PROVIDE CRITICAL ENGINEERING AND CONSTRUCTION OVERSIGHT, LEAD STAKEHOLDER MEETINGS AND PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT, COLLABORATE WITH AGENCY PARTNERS, ADVANCE AND SECURE PERMITTING REQUESTS, AND CONDUCT CRITICAL MONITORING ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH SPECIES OCCUPANCY AND WATER QUALITY, SUPPORTING FOUR FULL TIME PERMANENT POSITIONS WITHIN THE ORGANIZATION OVER 18 MONTHS, AND WILL ALSO COVER A PORTION OF FRIENDS OF THE CHEAT ADMINISTRATION ALLOCATIONS ASSOCIATED WITH MANAGING THE PROJECT AT A 10 PERCENT DE MINIMIS MODIFIED TOTAL DIRECT COST RATE.

THIS PROPOSAL IS TO DESIGN A REPLACEMENT OF A OLD, CONCRETE LOW ROAD CROSSING THAT IS A FISH PASSAGE BARRIER WITH A SAFER, FISH-FRIENDLY LOW WATER CROSSING BRIDGE ON A COUNTY ROAD. THIS STRUCTURE WILL SPAN LYONS CREEK AND OPEN UP 10 MILES OF UPSTREAM HABITAT. THE DESIGN WILL INCLUDE FIELDWORK, GEOTECHNICAL INVESTIGATIONS, PERMITTING AND DESIGN. DELIVERABLES ARE STAMPED, FINAL DESIGN DRAWINGS, SPECIFICATIONS AND COST ESTIMATES TO CONSTRUCT THE PROJECT PER COUNTY ROAD STANDARDS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE TOPEKA SHINER AND OTHER PLAINS FISHES, DICKINSON COUNTY AND THE PUBLIC. THE DESIGN PROCESS WILL BE MANAGED BY THE COUNTY AND SUB-CONTRACTED TO A DESIGN FIRM FOR THE WORK.

THIS AGREEMENT WILL PROVIDE EMPLOYMENT OF TRIBAL MEMBERS THROUGH THE TRIBAL EMPLOYMENT RIGHTS ORDINANCE (TERO) PROGRAM, WHEN NECESSARY, TO SUPPORT HATCHERY OPERATIONS AT QUINAULT NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY. THE QUINAULT NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY PRODUCES OVER 3.5 MILLION JUVENILE SALMON AND STEELHEAD ANNUALLY FOR FRESHWATER RELEASE OR TRANSFER TO QUINAULT INDIAN NATION OWNED FACILITIES. WITH FIVE DIFFERENT REARING STOCKS REQUIRING HUSBANDRY ON A DAY TO DAY BASIS, FISH MARKING REQUIREMENTS, AND APPROXIMATELY 20 TO 40 THOUSAND RETURNING ADULT SALMON NEEDING PROCESSED THROUGH THE FALL AND WINTER MONTHS, THE HANDS-ON WORKLOAD IS SUBSTANTIAL, AND COULD NOT BE ACHIEVED WITHOUT CONTINUED QUINAULT INDIAN NATION TERO WORKERS, AND THEIR SPECIFIC SKILL SETS.

THE GRAND TRAVERSE BAND OF OTTAWA AND CHIPPEWA INDIANS - NATURAL RESOURCES DEPARTMENT WILL ASSESS THE POPULATION OF SEA LAMPREY INHABITING LAKE MICHIGAN BY MONITORING ITS TRIBUTARIES DURING THE SPAWNING SEASON. THE DEPARTMENT WILL SUPPLY TWO WORKERS OVER A 9-WEEK PERIOD TO ASSIST THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WITH MONITORING THE MIGRATION OF ADULT SEA LAMPREYS IN THE BOARDMAN RIVER. CONTINUED MONITORING OF SEA LAMPREY ABUNDANCE IN THIS TRIBUTARY IS CRITICAL TO ASSESSMENT OF SUCCESS OF SEA LAMPREY CONTROL IN LAKE MICHIGAN. THE INFORMATION COLLECTED DURING THE MONITORING PERIOD IS USED TO ESTIMATE THE ADULT SEA LAMPREY POPULATION IN NORTHERN LAKE MICHIGAN AND ULTIMATELY THE LAKE MICHIGAN ESTIMATE, WHICH IS USED TO MAKE DECISIONS ON BUDGET AND TREATMENT ALLOCATIONACROSS THE GREAT LAKES.

THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) IS A NEW COLLABORATION BETWEEN DR. KENTARO INOUE AT THE SHEDD AQUARIUM IN CHICAGO AND DR. DAVID ZANATTA AT CENTRAL MICHIGAN UNIVERSITY (BIOLOGY/INSTITUTE FOR GREAT LAKES RESEARCH). TOGETHER, DR. INOUE AND DR. ZANATTA WILL MENTOR A CMU BIOLOGY MS STUDENT TO INVESTIGATE THE POPULATION GENOMICS OF THE SLIPPERSHELL MUSSEL. THE SLIPPERSHELL IS AN IMPERILLED FRESHWATER MUSSEL (ENDANGERED IN MICHIGAN) TYPICALLY FOUND IN SMALL HEADWATER STREAMS IN THE MIDWEST. HEADWATER STREAMS ARE PARTICULARLY THREATENED BY HUMAN IMPACTS (RUN OFF FROM INTENSIVE AGRICULTURE) AND CLIMATE CHANGE (INCREASED FREQUENCY AND SEVERITY OF DROUGHT AND INCREASING SURFACE WATER TEMPERATURES). WE WILL BE USING THE GENOMIC DATA COLLECTED FROM SLIPPERSHELL POPULATIONS TO MODEL HOW GENETIC DIVERSITY IS LIKELY TO CHANGE WITH THE COMBINED THREATS OF HUMAN IMPACTS AND CLIMATE CHANGE TO THEIR HABITAT. THE PROJECT FUNDING WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT AN MS STUDENT, TRAVEL FOR FIELD WORK, LODGING FOR THE STUDENT WHILE ON A VISITING RESEARCH FELLOWSHIP AT THE SHEDD AQUARIUM, LABORATORY SUPPLIES, AND A COURSE RELEASE FOR DR. ZANATTA TO PROVIDE TIME TO WORK ON THE PROJECT. CMU WILL PROVIDE A SUB-AWARD TO THE SHEDD AQUARIUM FOR EXPENSES DR. INOUE INCURS ON THE PROJECT.

THE SENECA NATION CONSERVATION-FISH AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT WILL ASSESS THE POPULATION OF SEA LAMPREY INHABITING LAKE ERIE BY MONITORING ITS TRIBUTARIES DURING THE SPAWNING SEASON. THE DEPARTMENT WILL SUPPLY TWO WORKERS OVER A 9-WEEK PERIOD TO ASSIST THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WITH MONITORING THE MIGRATION OF ADULT SEA LAMPREYS IN THE CATTARAUGUS CREEK. CONTINUED MONITORING OF SEA LAMPREY ABUNDANCE IN THIS TRIBUTARY IS CRITICAL TO ASSESSMENT OF SUCCESS OF SEA LAMPREY CONTROL IN LAKE ERIE. THE INFORMATION COLLECTED DURING THE MONITORING PERIODIS USED TO ESTIMATE THE ADULT SEA LAMPREY POPULATION IN EASTERN LAKE ERIE AND ULTIMATELY THELAKE ERIE ESTIMATE, WHICH IS USED TO MAKE DECISIONS ON BUDGET AND TREATMENT ALLOCATIONACROSS THE GREAT LAKES.

LAKE SUPERIOR STATE UNIVERSITY WILL SUPPLY TWO STUDENTS OVER A 12-WEEK PERIOD TO ASSIST THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WITH MONITORING THE MIGRATION OF ADULT SEA LAMPREYS IN THE ST. MARYS RIVER. THE LAKE SUPERIOR STATE UNIVERSITY CENTER FOR FRESHWATER RESEARCH AND EDUCATION (FORMERLY AQUATIC RESEARCH LAB) IS LOCATED DIRECTLY ON THE ST. MARYS RIVER AND ALLOWS THE STUDENTS TO MONITOR TRAPS CONTINUOUSLY. THE INFORMATION COLLECTED DURING THE MONITORING PERIOD IS USED TO ESTIMATE THE ADULT SEA LAMPREY POPULATION IN THE ST. MARYS RIVER AND ULTIMATELY THE LAKE HURON ESTIMATE, WHICH IS USED TO MAKE DECISIONS ON BUDGET AND TREATMENT ALLOCATION ACROSS THE GREAT LAKES.

SEA LAMPREY POPULATIONS ARE MONITORED BY GENERATING AN ADULT SEA LAMPREY ABUNDANCE INDEX FOR EACH LAKE. THE INDEX IS CALCULATED BY ASSESSMENT CREWS WHO CAPTURE MIGRATING ADULT SEA LAMPREY IN INDEX STREAMS WITH TRAPS DURING THE SPRING AND EARLY SUMMER. A MARK-RECAPTURE STUDY IS CONDUCTED ON EACH INDEX STREAM TO GENERATE A POPULATION ESTIMATE. INDIVIDUAL INDEX STREAM POPULATION ESTIMATES ARE THEN SUMMED TO CREATE THE LAKE-WIDE ADULT SEA LAMPREY ABUNDANCE INDEX. WHOLE-LAKE ADULT SEA LAMPREY ABUNDANCE ESTIMATES CAN BE CALCULATED BY MULTIPLYING THE LAKE-WIDE INDEX BY A LAKE-SPECIFIC CONVERSION FACTOR.

THE GREAT LAKES SECTION WILL MONITOR TRIBUTARIES TO LAKE SUPERIOR AND WORK WITH THE KEWEENAW BAY INDIAN COMMUNITYTO IMPLEMENT SUPPLEMENTAL CONTROL FROM SEPTEMBER TO DECEMBER IN COOPERATION WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFESERVICE- SEA LAMPREY CONTROL PROGRAM (USFWS). SUPPLEMENTAL CONTROLS ARE METHODS THAT SUPPLEMENT THE TWO PRIMARYSEA LAMPREY CONTROL TOOLS - LAMPRICIDES AND SEA LAMPREY BARRIERS. THIS CONTROL STRATEGY IS BASED ON THEINTEGRATION AND SYNERGY OF MULTIPLE METHODS TO REDIRECT OR REMOVE UPSTREAM MIGRATING ADULTS, DOWNSTREAM MIGRATINGJUVENILES, OR LARVAL SEA LAMPREYS. SUPPLEMENTAL CONTROLS ARE NOT EXPECTED TO BE AN ALTERNATIVE TO EFFECTIVELAMPRICIDE APPLICATIONS OR BARRIERS, BUT INSTEAD WOULD BE USED TO ENHANCE CONTROL WHERE LAMPRICIDES OR BARRIERSARE LESS EFFECTIVE DUE TO PHYSICAL, BIOLOGICAL, CHEMICAL, OR SOCIAL CHALLENGES.

IN 2004, CONGRESS PASSED THE SNAKE RIVER WATER RIGHTS ACT OF 2004, PUBLIC LAW 108-447, IN WHICH THE UNITED STATES  AND THE NEZ PERCE TRIBE ENTERED INTO AN AGREEMENT FOR JOINT MANAGEMENT OF HATCHERY PROGRAMS AT THE DWORSHAK  NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY (NFH). AS A RESULT, THE NEZ PERCE TRIBE (TRIBE) AND U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  (SERVICE) BECAME "JOINT MANAGERS" IN THE OPERATION AND MANAGEMENT OF THE DWORSHAK NFH.  IMPLEMENTATION OF JOINT MANAGEMENT WAS LAID OUT THROUGH SEVERAL MEMORANDUMS OF AGREEMENT (MOAS) BETWEEN THE  SERVICE AND THE TRIBE. THE MOAS IDENTIFIED A HIRING AND TRANSITION PLAN FOR SERVICE AND TRIBAL EMPLOYEES TO  ACHIEVE A GOAL OF 50:50 (TRIBE:SERVICE) BY 2020, WHICH HAS BEEN ACHIEVED.  THIS CONTRACT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR THE NEZ PERCE TRIBE EMPLOYEES AT DWORSHAK NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY THAT ARE  RESPONSIBLE FOR OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE.
ALL SALMON AND STEELHEAD REARED AT THE MAKAH NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY (NFH) WILL BE MARKED WITH A FIN CLIP, TAGGED WITH A CODED-WIRE TAG, OR BOTH PRIOR TO RELEASE FROM THE HATCHERY.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) REQUESTS INTERESTED ENTITIES TO SUBMIT RESEARCH, RESTORATION, AND REGIONAL PROJECT PROPOSALS FOR THE RESTORATION OF THE GREAT LAKES BASIN FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES, AS AUTHORIZED UNDER THE GREAT LAKES FISH AND
WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACT (16 USC 941C). THE PURPOSE OF THE GREAT LAKES FISH AND WILDLIFE RESTORATION ACT (GLFWRA) IS TO PROVIDE ASSISTANCE TO STATES, INDIAN TRIBES, AND OTHER INTERESTED ENTITIES TO ENCOURAGE COOPERATIVE CONSERVATION, RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT OF THE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND THEIR HABITATS IN THE GREAT LAKES BASIN. SUPPORTED IN PART BY THE GREAT LAKES RESTORATION INITIATIVE, WE EXPECT
APPROXIMATELY $1.2 MILLION TO SUPPORT PROJECTS THIS FISCAL YEAR. AVAILABLE FUNDING AND PROJECT AWARDS ARE SUBJECT TO FINAL CONGRESSIONAL APPROPRIATIONS FOR FISCAL YEAR 2018.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED FOR:  PROTECTING A WORKING LANDSCAPE, UNFRAGMENTED BY DEVELOPMENT, WHICH RETAINS ECOSYSTEM AND WATERSHED FUNCTION WITHIN THE HISTORICAL RANGE OF RESOURCES AND VARIABILITY.  SPECIFICALLY, THESE FUNDS WILL PROVIDE LABOR AND SUPPORT TO CONDUCT HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS, MONITORING, AND DATA PROCESSING.  THE GOAL OF THIS AWARD IS TO ENHANCE A SEMI-DESERT GRASSLAND LANDSCAPE THAT INCLUDES BUENOS AIRES NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, HABITAT ENHANCEMENTS ARE EXPECTED TO BENEFIT ALL OF THE NATIVE WILDLIFE SPECIES SUPPORTED BY ARIZONA'S ALTAR VALLEY.  ADDITIONAL GOALS ARE TO MONITOR THE RESPONSE OF RESTORATION EFFORTS, MANAGE MONITORING DATA, AND CONDUCT DATA ANALYSIS. VEGETATION AND WILDLIFE RESPONSE WILL BE MONITORED USING STANDARD APPROACHES TO FACILITATE AN ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT APPROACH FOR THIS PROJECT AND TO BETTER GUIDE SIMILAR PROJECTS ON OTHER PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS, THEREFORE HAVING A GREATER POSITIVE IMPACT ACROSS THE LARGER LANDSCAPE.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO:  TO COLLECT INFORMATION AT A HIBERNACULUM LOCATED ON THE OZARK PLATEAU NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (OPNWR) DURING FALL EMERGENCE OF 2019.  THESE DATA WILL BE USED, ALONG WITH THE DATA FROM PREVIOUS SIMILAR SURVEYS, TO DOCUMENT THE POPULATION CHANGES AND DEMOGRAPHY OF THE FEDERALLY-LISTED THREATENED NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT (MYOTIS SEPTENTRIONALIS, MYSE) AND THE TRI-COLORED BAT (PERIMYOTIS SUBFLAVUS, PESU), A SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN THAT IS UNDER CONSIDERATION FOR FEDERAL LISTING, AS THE FUNGUS THAT CAUSES WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME BECOMES MORE PREVALENT AND AS FUNGAL LOADS INCREASE WITHIN THE HIBERNACULUM.  THE HIBERNACULUM SITE FOR THIS STUDY IS LOCATED AT DUNCAN FIELD CAVE, A LARGE MULTI-ENTRANCE CAVE SYSTEM WITH OVER NINE MILES OF PASSAGE ON THE OPNWR IN ADAIR COUNTY, OKLAHOMA.

THIS PROJECT WILL EXEMPLIFY THE ''WORKING LANDS'' CONSERVATION ETHIC BY ILLUSTRATING HOW RANCHLANDS MAY INCREASE THEIR PRODUCTIVITY WHILE IMPROVING HABITAT CONDITIONS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE. CURRENT LAND USE CONSISTS OF MANAGED PASTURE LIVESTOCK GRAZING ON A TIDAL FLOODPLAIN IN THE COQUILLE ESTUARY.  WATER MOVEMENT THROUGH THE PASTURE IS CONTROLLED BY MULTIPLE TIDE GATES THAT IMPEDE FISH MOVEMENT AND ALTER ESTUARINE FUNCTION.  THE OVERALL RESTORATION GOALS FOR THE PROJECT AREA INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: 1) REESTABLISHMENT OF HYDROLOGIC FUNCTION TO THE GREATEST DEGREE POSSIBLE WHILE ACCOMMODATING EXISTING GRAZING USE ON THE PROPERTY; 2) INCREASING ACCESSIBILITY FOR NATIVE MIGRATORY FISH INTO THE TIDAL MARSH; 3) INCREASING AQUATIC HABITAT AVAILABILITY AND QUALITY THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF A TIDAL CHANNEL NETWORK; AND 4) IMPROVING WATER MANAGEMENT FOR AGRICULTURAL USE ON ADJACENT PASTURES.  THIS AR WILL CONTRIBUTE PARTNERS FUNDS TOWARDS CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES BEGINNING IN 2019.
COMPLETE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE TRIANGLE WETLANDS PROJECT, WHICH INCLUDE EARTHEN DAM BUILDING, PURCHASE OF MATERIALS, AND HEAVY-EQUIPMENT OPERATION.

THE CANADIAN WILDLIFE SERVICE AND THE SERVICE ARE COLLABORATING ON A PROJECT EVALUATING THE NEST SUCCESS FOR WHOOPING CRANES IN WOOD BUFFALO NATIONAL PARK AND IDENTIFYING THE FACTORS LIMITING NEST SUCCESS (PREDATORS AND WEATHER).  THE PROJECT WILL SHOW HOW THE POTENTIAL WORK AND RELATED COSTS REQUIRED TO INCREASE RECRUITMENT COULD SUBSEQUENTLY AID POPULATION GROWTH AND PERSISTENCE.  RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL INFORM DECISIONS ON WHETHER TO CONSIDER AND POTENTIALLY DESIGN STRATEGIES TO MITIGATE THE THREATS ON WHOOPING CRANE NESTS AND TO SUBSEQUENTLY INCREASE RECRUITMENT AND SPEED THIS SPECIES TO RECOVERY (PREDATOR CONTROL).

THIS PROJECT IS A CONTINUATION OF LONG-TERM MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT EFFORTS OF BLUE CREEK ANADROMOUS SALMONID RUNS.  BLUE CREEK IS THE ONLY REMAINING DRAINAGE IN THE LOWER KLAMATH SUB-BASIN WHICH SUPPORTS SIZABLE RUNS OF CHINOOK SALMON (ONCORHYNCHUS TSHAWYTSCHA) AND COHO SALMON (O. KISUTCH), AND THE ONGOING MONITORING OF THE STATUS OF THESE FISH RUNS IS ESSENTIAL IN ORDER TO ACCURATELY ASSESS THE STATUS OF WILD SALMONID RUNS THROUGHOUT THE KLAMATH RIVER BASIN.  THIS PROJECT WAS INITIATED BY USFWS IN FY 1989, IS DESIGNED TO COLLECT ADULT ESCAPEMENT DATA FOR THE BLUE CREEK BASIN.  THIS DATA ALLOWS FOR AN ASSESSMENT OF ANADROMOUS SALMONID POPULATION TRENDS WITHIN THE BASIN AS WELL AS CONTINUED ASSESSMENT AND REFINEMENT OF ANADROMOUS SALMONID DISTRIBUTION, IMMIGRATION TIMING, AND HABITAT USAGE THROUGHOUT THE BLUE CREEK DRAINAGE.  THIS TREND DATA IS AN INTEGRAL COMPONENT OF THE MEGA-TABLE AND ALLOWS FOR A MORE ACCURATE ASSESSMENT OF WILD SALMONID POPULATION NUMBERS THROUGHOUT THE KLAMATH BASIN, WHICH IN TURN ALLOWS FOR MORE ACCURATE PREDICTIONS OF FUTURE CHINOOK RUN SIZES AND CORRESPONDING ALLOWABLE HARVEST NUMBERS.  INFORMATION COLLECTED THROUGH THIS PROJECT ALSO ALLOWS FOR MORE MEANINGFUL AND INFORMED INPUT INTO LAND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES WITHIN THE BASIN AS WELL AS ON-GOING WATERSHED RESTORATION ACTIVITIES.
